question_text:
A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal examination. Her last pregnancy was two years ago and she gave birth to a healthy Rhesus (RhD) positive girl. Four years ago, she had a complex femoral fracture that required several blood transfusions. She has no history of sexually transmitted diseases. She has been monogamous with her husband for 5 years. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. Examination shows that the uterus is at the level of the umbilicus. Abdominal ultrasound shows normal fetal heart rate, movement, and anatomy. Laboratory studies show:

Blood group
A, Rh-negative

Hemoglobin
12.5 g/dL

Leukocyte count
11,000/mm^3

Platelet count
345,000/mm^3

Serum

 Anti-D antibody screen

negative

 Rubella IgM
negative

 Rubella IgG
negative

 Varicella IgM
negative

 Varicella IgG
positive

 STI panel
negative

Urine

Protein
trace

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal examination. Her last pregnancy was two years ago and she gave birth to a healthy Rhesus (RhD) positive girl. Four years ago, she had a complex femoral fracture that required several blood transfusions. She has no history of sexually transmitted diseases. She has been monogamous with her husband for 5 years. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. Examination shows that the uterus is at the level of the umbilicus. Abdominal ultrasound shows normal fetal heart rate, movement, and anatomy. Laboratory studies show: Blood group A, Rh-negative Hemoglobin 12.5 g/dL Leukocyte count 11,000/mm3 Platelet count 345,000/mm3 Serum Anti-D antibody screen negative Rubella IgM negative Rubella IgG negative Varicella IgM negative Varicella IgG positive STI panel negative Urine Protein trace Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This Rh-negative patient is potentially carrying an Rh-positive fetus and is at risk of becoming sensitized to the Rh(D) antigen. She should undergo further screening and, if indicated, prophylaxis with anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) to prevent Rh(D) sensitization and hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) in a future pregnancy with an Rh-positive fetus.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate timing for anti-D antibody screening and administration of anti-D immunoglobulin in Rh-negative pregnant women.

answers.content: Perform a direct Coombs test at this visit. No anti-D immunoglobulin is necessary unless the patient undergoes cesarean delivery.
answers.explanation_why: A direct Coombs test is performed on the newborn to diagnose HDFN but is not used to screen for anti-D antibodies in the mother. Instead, an indirect Coombs test is performed for maternal anti-D antibody screening. RhoGAM is recommended for prophylaxis against sensitization in any situation where the Rh-negative mother is exposed to Rh(D)-positive fetal red blood cells. These situations include but are not limited to, C-sections.

answers.content: Administer anti-D immunoglobulin now and repeat anti-D antibody screening shortly before delivery.
answers.explanation_why: The first dose of RhoGAM is ideally administered at the beginning of the third trimester (because the risk of exposure to fetal Rh(D) antigens is highest during the third trimester) and anti-D antibody screening should be repeated before administering RhoGAM (since this medication only works in unsensitized mothers). If RhoGAM, which has a half-life of 6 weeks, is administered at this visit (20 weeks' gestation), a false-positive result for maternal sensitization will occur when the anti-D antibody screening is performed at 24–28 weeks' gestation.

answers.content: Repeat anti-D antibody screening at 28 weeks' gestation. Administer anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks' gestation and after delivery if the newborn is Rh(D) positive.
answers.explanation_why:
Since RhoGAM only works in unsensitized mothers, titers of anti-D antibodies should be checked (e.g., with an indirect Coombs test) prior to administration of the medication. In the United States, guidelines recommend that all Rh-negative mothers who may potentially be carrying an Rh-positive fetus undergo anti-D antibody screening at the first prenatal visit. If the first anti-D screen shows that the mother is unsensitized, she should undergo repeat screening between 24 and 28 weeks' gestation. If the anti-D screen remains negative, RhoGAM should be administered at 28 weeks' gestation (typically a single standard dose without confirmation of the fetal blood type) and, if the newborn is Rh-positive, again within 72 hours following delivery after fetomaternal hemorrhage tests to determine the dosage.

Other indications for the administration of RhoGAM include situations in which Rh-negative mothers are exposed to fetal red blood cells, e.g., invasive prenatal diagnostic or therapeutic procedures, abdominal trauma, external cephalic version, ectopic pregnancy, and bleeding during pregnancy.

answers.content: Repeat anti-D antibody screening at 28 weeks' gestation and administer anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks' gestation. No further anti-D immunoglobulin is necessary.
answers.explanation_why: Although this Rh-negative mother should receive an anti-D antibody screen and RhoGAM at 28 weeks' gestation, additional administration of RhoGAM may be necessary after delivery if the newborn is Rh-positive.

answers.content: No further anti-D antibody screening is necessary. Administer anti-D immunoglobulin shortly after delivery
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient's first anti-D antibody test was negative, titers should be checked again prior to administration of RhoGAM, as the therapy will not work in sensitized mothers. Guidelines recommend repeat anti-D antibody screening and RhoGAM administration at the end of the second trimester.

question_text:
A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after having a seizure. It lasted approximately 1 minute, and involved blinking and lip-smacking movements as well as left-sided jerking of the hand and foot. His mother says she measured a temperature of 38.2°C (100.7°F) at that time. He has had increasing difficulty feeding since yesterday. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation and weighed 3189 g (7 lb 1 oz); he currently weighs 2980 g (6 lb 9 oz). The mother's prenatal course was significant for gonorrhea infection diagnosed early in pregnancy and treated with ceftriaxone and azithromycin combination therapy. The boy appears irritable and lethargic. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F). Examination shows clusters of vesicular lesions with an erythematous base on the patient's face and trunk. There is profuse lacrimation. Laboratory studies show:

Leukocyte count
16,200/mm^3

Segmented neutrophils
25%

Bands
5%

Lymphocytes
65%

Monocytes
3%

Eosinophils
2%

Serum

Glucose
80 mg/dL

A lumbar puncture is performed. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 117/μL, a protein concentration of 52 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 58 mg/dL. Results of blood cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after having a seizure. It lasted approximately 1 minute, and involved blinking and lip-smacking movements as well as left-sided jerking of the hand and foot. His mother says she measured a temperature of 38.2°C (100.7°F) at that time. He has had increasing difficulty feeding since yesterday. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation and weighed 3189 g (7 lb 1 oz); he currently weighs 2980 g (6 lb 9 oz). The mother's prenatal course was significant for gonorrhea infection diagnosed early in pregnancy and treated with ceftriaxone and azithromycin combination therapy. The boy appears irritable and lethargic. His temperature is 36.0°C (96.8°F). Examination shows clusters of vesicular lesions with an erythematous base on the patient's face and trunk. There is profuse lacrimation. Laboratory studies show: Leukocyte count 16,200/mm3 Segmented neutrophils 25% Bands 5% Lymphocytes 65% Monocytes 3% Eosinophils 2% Serum Glucose 80 mg/dL A lumbar puncture is performed. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 117/μL, a protein concentration of 52 mg/dL, and a glucose concentration of 58 mg/dL. Results of blood cultures are pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: A seizure accompanied by fever is strongly concerning for neonatal meningitis and/or encephalitis. A high CSF protein and normal CSF glucose (∼ ⅔ of blood glucose) suggest a viral CNS infection. His diffuse vesicular rash suggests neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal herpes simplex virus infection, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Ganciclovir is indicated for congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which may manifest with seizures. However, this condition also classically manifests with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, microcephaly, and, at later stages of development, sensorineural hearing loss. Furthermore, congenital cytomegalovirus infection does not manifest with a vesicular rash.

images.title: Congenital CMV infection TORCH fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Ampicillin is a first-line treatment for group B Streptococcus (GBS), which is the most common cause of neonatal meningitis. While this patient likely has a CNS infection, his laboratory analysis suggests a nonbacterial cause (normal CSF glucose, ↑ lymphocyte count). Bacterial meningitis typically manifests on CSF analysis with low glucose, high protein, and high neutrophil count. Moreover, this patient's vesicular rash is not commonly associated with GBS.

Ceftriaxone is indicated in the treatment of neonatal gonococcal infection (Neisseria gonorrhoeae). Although perinatal gonococcal infection in this patient is possible given his mother's history, she had already been treated at the time of his birth, making transmission unlikely. Moreover, neonatal gonococcal infection is associated with prematurity and purulent conjunctivitis, not CNS infection or vesicular rash.

Acyclovir therapy should be initiated as soon as neonatal HSV is suspected, as the condition is rapidly progressive and can have severe sequelae (such as disseminated disease or this patient's likely meningoencephalitis). Neonatal HSV infection should be suspected in infants up to 6 weeks of age that present with vesicular skin lesions, especially if features of meningitis/encephalitis and/or sepsis (e.g., seizures, lethargy, and persistent fever) are present.

The prognosis of neonatal HSV depends on the extent of organ involvement. In infants with CNS involvement, only 30% will go on to have normal neurologic development.

Vancomycin is a first-line treatment for neonatal meningitis caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci (e.g., S. epidermidis), which can cause meningitis in neonates with very low birth weight (< 1500 g) or those who underwent CNS surgery (e.g., placement of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt). While this patient likely has a CNS infection, his laboratory analysis suggests a nonbacterial cause (normal CSF glucose, ↑ lymphocyte count). Bacterial meningitis typically manifests on CSF analysis with low glucose, high protein, and high neutrophil count. Moreover, this patient's vesicular rash is not associated with staphylococcal meningitis, his birth weight is normal, and he has no history of CNS surgery.

The combination of gentamicin and ampicillin works synergistically to increase the bactericidal effect of treatment and is used to treat neonatal Listeria monocytogenes infection, which is the third most common cause of neonatal meningitis. While this patient likely has a CNS infection, his laboratory analysis suggests a nonbacterial cause (normal CSF glucose, ↑ lymphocyte count). Bacterial meningitis typically manifests on CSF analysis with low glucose, high protein, and high neutrophil count. Moreover, this patient's vesicular rash is not commonly associated with listeriosis.

question_text: A 21-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 39 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has some mild edema and tiredness but generally feels well. Her nephew visited for 1 week and left 3 days ago because he became ill and was diagnosed with chickenpox. She has no history of chickenpox and is not vaccinated against the varicella zoster virus. Current medications include folic acid supplements and a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 116/64 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with 39 weeks' gestation. IgG antibody titers for the varicella zoster virus are negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 21-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 39 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has some mild edema and tiredness but generally feels well. Her nephew visited for 1 week and left 3 days ago because he became ill and was diagnosed with chickenpox. She has no history of chickenpox and is not vaccinated against the varicella zoster virus. Current medications include folic acid supplements and a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 116/64 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with 39 weeks' gestation. IgG antibody titers for the varicella zoster virus are negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Transmission of the varicella zoster virus (VZV) late in pregnancy may result in neonatal varicella infection. The patient is also at risk for severe varicella infection herself and requires treatment to prevent complications.
learning_objective: Recognize the risk of varicella infection in a pregnant woman without immunity, and choose the most appropriate prophylactic treatment.

answers.explanation_why: The varicella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine, which is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of the fetus becoming infected. Seronegative women of child-bearing age should receive a varicella vaccine before becoming pregnant.

Acyclovir may be recommended for pregnant women with an active varicella infection in the second or third trimester. This medication is also administered to newborns with severe neonatal varicella infection. Although this patient has been exposed to VZV and is at high risk of developing chickenpox, she does not have an active infection at this time. Acyclovir plays no role in the prevention of chickenpox.

Prescription of acyclovir for pregnant women must be done with caution as there are no well-controlled studies about its use during pregnancy (category B).

Serial ultrasounds are indicated for a pregnant woman who has chickenpox in the first or second trimester since the fetus is at risk of developing congenital varicella syndrome, which can lead to CNS, ocular, and limb defects. However, the patient here is at 39 weeks' gestation and is only at risk of developing chickenpox; therefore, no serial ultrasounds are indicated.

This woman is at high risk of developing chickenpox and its complications (e.g., pneumonia, encephalitis), and her fetus is at increased risk of developing neonatal varicella infection. Counseling about the risks of varicella infection in the mother and fetus is necessary. Moreover, this patient requires additional treatment to prevent varicella infection or decrease its severity.

Ganciclovir is an antiviral medication effective against cytomegalovirus infections. This medication is not routinely used in varicella infections and plays no role in the prevention of chickenpox. In addition, the use of ganciclovir during pregnancy can pose risks to the fetus (category C), as animal studies have shown teratogenic effects.

This pregnant woman is at an increased risk of developing varicella and its complications (e.g., encephalitis, pneumonia) because she does not have immunity against VZV. Passive immunization with varicella zoster immune globulin (VZIG) should be recommended in order to prevent infection or lessen its severity. VZIG is ideally given within 72–96 hours of exposure but can also be given as late as 10 days after exposure. Administration of VZIG can prevent fetal VZV infection. Neonatal varicella can manifest as a pox-like rash with potential visceral involvement in the form of pneumonia, encephalitis, or bacterial superinfection of the rash.

question_text: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 39 weeks' gestation, is admitted to the hospital in labor. She currently has contractions occurring every 3–5 minutes. For the past 3 days, she has had burning pain in the vulvar area associated with intense itching. Her pregnancy has been uneventful. She has a history of genital herpes at the age of 16, which was treated with acyclovir. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Genital examination shows grouped vesicles on an erythematous base over the vulvar region. Pelvic examination shows rupture of membranes and that the cervix is 3 cm dilated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 24-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 39 weeks' gestation, is admitted to the hospital in labor. She currently has contractions occurring every 3–5 minutes. For the past 3 days, she has had burning pain in the vulvar area associated with intense itching. Her pregnancy has been uneventful. She has a history of genital herpes at the age of 16, which was treated with acyclovir. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Genital examination shows grouped vesicles on an erythematous base over the vulvar region. Pelvic examination shows rupture of membranes and that the cervix is 3 cm dilated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The grouped vesicles in the vulvar region on an erythematous base indicate active genital herpes. The patient is in labor, as she is having contractions and her cervix is dilated 3 cm. What will prevent the newborn from acquiring a herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection?
learning_objective: Recognize active genital herpes in labor, and choose the appropriate delivery method and antiviral therapy.

answers.content: Tocolytic therapy until lesions are crusted
answers.explanation_why: Suppressing labor via tocolytics would not be a practical solution to preventing vertical transmission. Herpetic lesions take 10–12 days to crust and tocolytic agents are generally not recommended for more than 48 hours (although some may be effective for several more days). Additionally, the virus may still be present in maternal secretions even after initial crusting.

Topical acyclovir is less effective than oral acyclovir at reducing the symptoms of genital herpes. Although oral acyclovir therapy reduces the severity of symptoms and the duration of viral shedding, it does not prevent transmission to the newborn in patients with active genital herpes, which is why cesarean delivery is indeed recommended to prevent neonatal herpes.

answers.content: Oral acyclovir therapy and vaginal delivery
answers.explanation_why: Although acyclovir therapy reduces the severity of symptoms and the duration of viral shedding, it does not prevent transmission to the newborn in patients with active genital herpes. Additionally, vaginal delivery would expose the newborn to HSV in maternal secretions and increase the risk of neonatal HSV infection.

Topical acyclovir is less effective than oral acyclovir at reducing the symptoms of genital herpes. Although oral acyclovir therapy reduces the severity of symptoms and the duration of viral shedding, it does not prevent transmission to the newborn in patients with active genital herpes. Additionally, vaginal delivery would expose the newborn to HSV in maternal secretions and increase the risk of neonatal HSV infection.

answers.content: Oral acyclovir therapy and cesarean delivery
answers.explanation_why:
The risk for vertical transmission to the neonate from an infected mother is high (up to 50%) among women who exhibit active genital herpes near the time of delivery. Cesarean delivery is indicated in women with recurrent and active genital herpes at the onset of labor to reduce the risk of transmission and thereby prevent neonatal HSV, which could result in severe complications like disseminated disease or meningoencephalitis. Although oral acyclovir does not prevent vertical transmission, it will help reduce the severity and duration of symptoms. In severe infection, IV acyclovir should be considered. If HSV lesions are not genital, delivery can proceed as normal. After birth, breastfeeding can also continue as usual unless lesions are on the breast.

Oral acyclovir can be used as suppressive therapy for genital herpes after 36 weeks' gestation until delivery in women with a prior history of genital herpes.

Active genital herpes during vaginal delivery increases the risk of vertical transmission, as it exposes the newborn to HSV in the maternal secretions, which can result in neonatal HSV and life-threatening complications.

question_text: A 16-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department because of fever and poor feeding for 2 days. He became very fussy the previous evening and cried for most of the night. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation and weighed 2430 g (5 lb 3 oz). The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother does not recall any sick contacts at home. He currently weighs 2776 g (6 lb 2 oz). He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 180/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. He becomes more agitated when picked up. There is full range of motion of his neck and extremities. The anterior fontanelle feels soft and flat. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Blood cultures are drawn and fluid resuscitation is initiated. A urinalysis obtained by catheterization shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 16-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department because of fever and poor feeding for 2 days. He became very fussy the previous evening and cried for most of the night. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation and weighed 2430 g (5 lb 3 oz). The pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother does not recall any sick contacts at home. He currently weighs 2776 g (6 lb 2 oz). He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 180/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. He becomes more agitated when picked up. There is full range of motion of his neck and extremities. The anterior fontanelle feels soft and flat. Neurologic examination shows no abnormalities. Blood cultures are drawn and fluid resuscitation is initiated. A urinalysis obtained by catheterization shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: In neonates with fever, poor feeding, jaundice, and irritability or lethargy, meningitis should always be ruled out!
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal fever with signs of sepsis, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: An MRI scan of the head is used to diagnose various central nervous system conditions including infections. However, since MRI scans require that patients not move for an extended period of time, children are typically sedated during the procedure. It is therefore not the preferred imaging modality in acutely ill pediatric patients.

Although studies have suggested that bacterial and viral meningitis can be distinguished based on serum procalcitonin levels, there is no conclusive evidence for this hypothesis. Currently, serum procalcitonin is not routinely measured in the diagnosis of meningitis, which is suspected in this patient.

The onset of fever, irritability, jaundice, and poor feeding in a neonate are highly suggestive of a severe disease. Reassurance would result in lack or delay of adequate treatment, leading to further complications.

Urine culture is performed to diagnose urinary tract infections (UTIs). In neonates, a UTI may also manifest with unspecific symptoms such as fever, irritability, and poor feeding. If urosepsis develops, it can also lead to meningitis. Urine cultures would only be indicated in case of abnormal urinalysis, which has a high sensitivity for UTI. The first priority in this acutely ill child is to assess him for meningitis and to initiate empiric treatment.

In patients with suspected meningitis and signs of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., seizure, papilledema) a CT scan is typically performed prior to a lumbar puncture, as performing a lumbar puncture in a patient with elevated ICP can lead to brain herniation and death. However, this patient does not present with features suggestive of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., coma, papilledema, focal neurologic deficit) that would prompt a CT scan. In addition, a CT scan would not be the imaging method of choice in a neonate.

A lumbar puncture should be performed in all clinically stable neonates with suspected meningitis or signs of sepsis and no signs of increased intracranial pressure. In neonates, meningitis often manifests with nonspecific symptoms and without the classic triad of meningitis. CSF analysis can confirm the diagnosis and guide antibiotic treatment. Until the results of the CSF analysis are available, patients should be treated with empiric antibiotic therapy (e.g., ampicillin plus gentamicin and/or cefotaxime in patients < 1 month).

In patients with signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., seizures), imaging should be obtained before performing a lumbar puncture. In neonates and infants, a cranial ultrasound is usually the preferred method of neuroimaging. In older children, a CT scan should be performed. Although a bulging fontanelle can be a sign of increased intracranial pressure, it is not an indication for imaging on its own.

answers.explanation_why: An x-ray of the chest is a first-line diagnostic method upon suspicion of lower respiratory tract infections (e.g., pneumonia). However, this patient does not have any clinical features (e.g., signs of respiratory distress) that suggest this diagnosis.

question_text: A 2-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician for the evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 2 days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman in a birthing center. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the second half of the pregnancy. The newborn weighed 3700 g (8 lb 2.5 oz) at birth, and no congenital anomalies were noted. She currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). Examination of the newborn shows pink skin. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is mucopurulent discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Polymerase chain reaction assay of conjunctival scraping confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 2-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician for the evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 2 days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman in a birthing center. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the second half of the pregnancy. The newborn weighed 3700 g (8 lb 2.5 oz) at birth, and no congenital anomalies were noted. She currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). Examination of the newborn shows pink skin. The lungs are clear to auscultation. There is mucopurulent discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Polymerase chain reaction assay of conjunctival scraping confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Chlamydial conjunctivitis (CC) typically occurs in newborns 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with watery or mucopurulent discharge.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for neonatal chlamydial conjunctivitis.

answers.explanation_why: Topical erythromycin is insufficient for the treatment of CC because of the high rates of concomitant upper respiratory tract colonization by Chlamydia trachomatis, which topical erythromycin cannot treat. Topical therapy with an erythromycin ointment administered shortly after delivery is recommended for prophylaxis of gonococcal conjunctivitis, which usually manifests at age 2–5 days with copious mucopurulent drainage.

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated after flushing eyes with saline in cases of non-herpes viral conjunctivitis or chemical conjunctivitis, which generally resolves on its own. Chemical conjunctivitis occurs after topical silver nitrate administration and typically manifests within a day of birth and resolves after 4–5 days. Nonherpetic viral conjunctivitis is commonly unilateral with mucopurulent discharge.

Acyclovir is used to treat herpes infections. Herpetic neonatal conjunctivitis manifests with unilateral or bilateral lid edema, moderate conjunctival injection, and nonpurulent, serosanguinous discharge within 1–2 weeks after birth. Other signs include vesicles on the skin surrounding the eye and corneal epithelial involvement with dendritic or geographic ulcers. In this neonate, who has clinical features of CC, intravenous acyclovir would not be helpful.

Ceftriaxone is effective against neisserial conjunctivitis, not against chlamydial infections. Neisserial conjunctivitis typically manifests 2–7 days after birth with profuse bilateral purulent drainage and prominent eyelid swelling. This patient's mucopurulent discharge and mild swelling that developed almost 2 weeks after birth are more consistent with CC.

Oral erythromycin is the treatment of choice for neonates with CC as it provides systemic Chlamydia trachomatis coverage, given the high rates of concomitant upper respiratory tract colonization in patients with CC. These benefits are generally considered to outweigh the increased risk of developing infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) associated with the medication, which is more common in newborns < 2 weeks old. Infants should still be closely monitored for any signs of IHPS, such as nonbilious vomiting and irritability when feeding. See “Overview of neonatal conjunctivitis” table.

The CDC recommends chlamydia screening for all pregnant women < 25 years of age (and those over 25 years of age if at increased risk) and retesting during the third trimester because neither oral nor topical antibiotic therapy is effective for the prevention of CC.

A silver nitrate solution was formerly instilled into the eyes of neonates as a prophylaxis against gonococcal conjunctivitis (Crede prophylaxis). However, silver nitrate was later found to be toxic to the conjunctiva and thus cause chemical conjunctivitis. Today, silver nitrate is no longer used prophylactically or therapeutically in the US and topical antibiotics are used instead.

question_text: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to the physician because of a red, irritated eye with yellow discharge. She was born via vaginal delivery at 39 weeks' gestation to a 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother had an unmedicated delivery at home; the patient did not receive any routine postpartum medications. The mother had not seen her gynecologist since her first prenatal visit. The newborn's temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 73/53 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. There is no corneal ulceration or evidence of keratitis. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
content_preview: Two days after delivery, a newborn is brought to the physician because of a red, irritated eye with yellow discharge. She was born via vaginal delivery at 39 weeks' gestation to a 28-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother had an unmedicated delivery at home; the patient did not receive any routine postpartum medications. The mother had not seen her gynecologist since her first prenatal visit. The newborn's temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 73/53 mm Hg. Ophthalmic examination shows eyelid edema, conjunctival injection, and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge from the right eye. There is no corneal ulceration or evidence of keratitis. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
hint: This patient presents with conjunctival injection and copious yellow mucopurulent discharge 2 days after birth, all of which are consistent with neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis (NGC). NGC is typically caused by ophthalmic colonization of the newborn's conjunctiva during delivery from mothers with Neisseria gonorrhea infection.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal gonococcal conjunctivitis, and choose the appropriate prophylactic medication to prevent it.

answers.content: Oral erythromycin administered to the infant
answers.explanation_why: Oral erythromycin is the first-line treatment for chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis, which typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is consistent with NGC, for which oral erythromycin is not indicated as either prophylaxis or treatment.

answers.content: IV ceftriaxone administered to the infant
answers.explanation_why: Intravenous or intramuscular ceftriaxone is the treatment of choice in infants with NGC. However, ceftriaxone is not used for NGC prophylaxis.

answers.content: Topical erythromycin administered to the infant
answers.explanation_why: Topical erythromycin ointment should be applied within 1 hour of birth to prevent NGC. In most states in the US, prophylaxis against NGC is required by law. If left untreated, NGC may result in corneal scarring and blindness. After confirming NGC (using culture and Gram stain or PCR), systemic treatment with either an IV or IM third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone) is indicated. In addition, the eyes should be flushed with saline until the discharge clears.

images.title: Infant with gonococcal ophthalmic disease
images.description: The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

answers.content: Oral doxycycline administered to the mother
answers.explanation_why: Oral doxycycline may be administered to treat mothers of newborns who have newborn conjunctivitis due to an infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. However, administration of oral doxycycline (as a prophylactic measure) in pregnant women is contraindicated because it may lead to bone damage and deposits in teeth (yellowing of the primary teeth) in the offspring.

answers.content: Oral amoxicillin administered to the mother
answers.explanation_why: Oral amoxicillin can be used to treat infection with Chlamydia trachomatis in pregnant women and, therefore, help prevent chlamydial neonatal conjunctivitis (CNC). However, CNC typically occurs 5–14 days after delivery and manifests with mild eyelid swelling and watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge. This patient's presentation is more consistent with NGC. Amoxicillin is not the first-line treatment for infection with Neisseria gonorrhea and, therefore, would have not prevented this newborn's NGC.

question_text:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 35 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital 4 hours after spontaneous rupture of membranes. She has had mild abdominal discomfort and nausea for a day. Her pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes, which is controlled with a strict diet. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of placental abruption. Current medications include iron and vitamin supplements. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 122/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows severe, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. Speculum examination confirms rupture of membranes with drainage of malodorous, blood-tinged fluid. Ultrasonography shows the fetus in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 175/min and reactive with no decelerations. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
11.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
13,100/mm^3

Serum

 Na^+

136 mEq/L

 Cl^-

101 mEq/L

 K^+

3.9 mEq/L

 Glucose
98 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL

Urine

 Protein
Negative

 Glucose
1+

 Blood
Negative

 WBC
3–4/hpf

 RBC
Negative

 Nitrites
Negative

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 35 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital 4 hours after spontaneous rupture of membranes. She has had mild abdominal discomfort and nausea for a day. Her pregnancy has been complicated by gestational diabetes, which is controlled with a strict diet. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of placental abruption. Current medications include iron and vitamin supplements. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Her temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 122/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows severe, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. Speculum examination confirms rupture of membranes with drainage of malodorous, blood-tinged fluid. Ultrasonography shows the fetus in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 175/min and reactive with no decelerations. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 13,100/mm3 Serum Na+ 136 mEq/L Cl- 101 mEq/L K+ 3.9 mEq/L Glucose 98 mg/dL Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL Urine Protein Negative Glucose 1+ Blood Negative WBC 3–4/hpf RBC Negative Nitrites Negative Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Common risk factors for this condition include prolonged labor and preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM).
learning_objective: Recognize chorioamnionitis in the context of pregnancy.

answers.explanation_why: Influenza typically manifests with the sudden onset of high fever, headache, muscle/joint aches, nonproductive cough, and severe malaise. Inflammatory markers are usually normal. Influenza does not account for PPROM, leukocytosis, or fetal tachycardia seen here.

The combination of maternal fever, tachycardia, uterine tenderness, malodorous and purulent amniotic fluid, vaginal discharge, and fetal tachycardia indicates chorioamnionitis. A major risk factor for chorioamnionitis is PPROM, which is observed in this patient. Chorioamnionitis is a clinical diagnosis. Maternal blood tests frequently reveal leukocytosis. Treatment depends on whether the birth is vaginal (requiring IV ampicillin plus gentamicin) or cesarean (requiring IV ampicillin and gentamicin, plus clindamycin).

This patient presents with fever, nausea, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants, and leukocytosis, which may mimic the presentation of acute appendicitis. However, appendicitis does not account for a constellation of PPROM, purulent vaginal discharge, and fetal tachycardia seen here.

The combination of PPROM with maternal fever, leukocytosis, drainage of malodorous, blood-tinged fluid, and fetal tachycardia is highly suggestive of an infection. These features are not associated with normal labor.

Pregnant women have an increased risk of UTI and therefore also pyelonephritis, which could explain this patient's abdominal pain, fever, and leukocytosis. However, urinalysis in pyelonephritis would typically reveal pyuria (positive esterase on dipstick test), leukocyturia, WBC casts, positive nitrites, and microhematuria. Pyelonephritis, moreover, is not associated with PPROM.

Although uterine rupture causes abdominal pain and fetal tachycardia and is more likely in patients who have had a c-section in the past, the condition generally occurs during labor and results in hemodynamic instability, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, this patient has fever and leukocytosis, which are consistent with another diagnosis.

question_text:
A 2500-g (5-lb 8-oz) female newborn is delivered at term to a 23-year-old woman gravida 2, para 2. There is copious yellow amniotic fluid. The Apgar score is 4 at both 1 and 5 minutes. The mother did not receive any prenatal care. Her first pregnancy 2 years ago was uneventful and she spontaneously delivered a healthy girl at 40 weeks' gestation. The newborn's pulse is 85/min and respirations are 20/min. She has a swollen face and abdomen, pallor, reduced muscle tone, and grimacing on stimulation. The baby is taken to the neonatal intensive care unit for further care. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
7 g/dL

Hematocrit
21%

Leukocyte count
13,000/mm^3

Platelet count
200,000/mm^3

Serum

 Total bilirubin
8 mg/dL

A direct antiglobulin test shows immediate agglutination of red blood cells. Which of the following are the most likely blood types of the neonate and her mother?

Neonate
Mother

Group
Rhesus
Group
Rhesus

B

content_preview: A 2500-g (5-lb 8-oz) female newborn is delivered at term to a 23-year-old woman gravida 2, para 2. There is copious yellow amniotic fluid. The Apgar score is 4 at both 1 and 5 minutes. The mother did not receive any prenatal care. Her first pregnancy 2 years ago was uneventful and she spontaneously delivered a healthy girl at 40 weeks' gestation. The newborn's pulse is 85/min and respirations are 20/min. She has a swollen face and abdomen, pallor, reduced muscle tone, and grimacing on stimulation. The baby is taken to the neonatal intensive care unit for further care. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 7 g/dL Hematocrit 21% Leukocyte count 13,000/mm3 Platelet count 200,000/mm3 Serum Total bilirubin 8 mg/dL A direct antiglobulin test shows immediate agglutination of red blood cells. Which of the following are the most likely blood types of the neonate and her mother? Neonate Mother Group Rhesus Group Rhesus A B Negative A Negative B O Negative A Positive C AB Positive A Negative D AB Negative B Negative E B Negative O Positive
hint: This neonate presents with hydrops fetalis (swollen face and abdomen), anemia, elevated bilirubin, and a positive direct Coombs test, suggesting hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN).
learning_objective: Recognize hemolytic disease of the newborn due to Rh incompatibility, and recall its risk factors.

answers.explanation_why: This combination of maternal and fetal blood groups only very rarely causes ABO incompatibility because, in patients with blood group A, anti-B antibodies are predominantly of the IgM isotype and do not cross the placenta. Moreover, HDFN due to ABO incompatibility usually has a mild disease course; this neonate's severe distress and the presence of hydrops fetalis suggest a different cause of HDFN.

This combination of maternal and fetal blood types would not be associated with HDFN. Neither Rhesus incompatibility nor ABO incompatibility can occur with this constellation because the child's RBCs do not carry surface antigens, which makes a reaction due to maternal alloimmunization unlikely.

This combination is associated with Rhesus incompatibility, which may result in severe HDFN with hydrops fetalis because Rh antigen system expression on RBCs begins very early (during the embryonic period). In an Rh-negative mother and Rh-positive fetus, maternal exposure to fetal blood (most often during birth) leads to the production of maternal IgM antibodies against the Rh antigen. Over time, seroconversion to anti-Rh IgG antibodies occurs; these antibodies are able to cross the placenta in following pregnancies. In a subsequent pregnancy with another Rh-positive child, maternal anti-Rh IgG antibodies bind to the Rh antigen of fetal RBCs, marking them for destruction and resulting in HDFN. The first child of this patient's mother must have been Rh-positive.

Since Rh incompatibility may be fatal, anti-D immunoglobulin prophylaxis is administered to Rh-negative pregnant women during the 28^th week of gestation of their first pregnancy. However, the mother of this patient did not receive any prenatal care and she most likely did not receive anti-D immunoglobulin prophylaxis in her first pregnancy.

This combination of maternal and fetal blood groups only very rarely causes ABO incompatibility because, in patients with blood group B, anti-A antibodies are predominantly of the IgM isotype and do not cross the placenta. Moreover, HDFN due to ABO incompatibility usually has a mild disease course; this neonate's severe distress and the presence of hydrops fetalis suggest a different cause of HDFN.

ABO incompatibility most commonly occurs in neonates with blood groups A or B born to mothers with blood group O because these mothers have anti-B and anti-A antibodies of both the IgG isotype, which can cross the placenta, and IgM isotype. ABO incompatibility may lead to HDFN but usually has a significantly milder disease course than Rh incompatibility because fetal RBCs do not fully express antigens A and B. This neonate's severe distress and hydrops fetalis would be very unlikely with ABO incompatibility.

question_text: A 1550-g (3.3-lb) male newborn is delivered to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, at 33 weeks' gestation. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The pregnancy was complicated by iron deficiency anemia. The mother has no other history of serious illness and she received all routine immunizations. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. She does not drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by placenta previa. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding immunization for this newborn?
content_preview: A 1550-g (3.3-lb) male newborn is delivered to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, at 33 weeks' gestation. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The pregnancy was complicated by iron deficiency anemia. The mother has no other history of serious illness and she received all routine immunizations. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. She does not drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by placenta previa. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding immunization for this newborn?
hint: Preterm infants are to receive all recommended vaccinations as per their chronological age (the time elapsed after birth) unless contraindicated. Gestational age does not play a role in determining the timing of the regimen.
learning_objective: Choose the appropriate timing for DTaP vaccination in preterm infants.

answers.content: Diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine at 2 months of chronological age
answers.explanation_why:
The diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine is given to children < 7 years of age as a 5-dose regimen at 2, 4, 6, 15–18 months, and 4–6 years of age, respectively. This preterm infant has no indications that would delay the DTaP vaccine, such as uncontrolled seizures or nervous system disease, and can receive the vaccine at 2 months of chronological age.

Note that the Hepatitis B vaccine would be given before the DTaP vaccine but not immediately after birth, which is the standard immunization schedule for term newborns > 2000 g of birth weight. Infants with low birth weight have weak production of protective anti-HBs antibodies, so newborns < 2000 g should receive their first dose of Hepatitis B vaccine at 1 month of age (regardless of weight at that time) or upon discharge from the hospital, whichever comes sooner. All other vaccines are administered according to the standard immunization schedule, taking the infant's chronological age into account, irrespective of prematurity.

This is a good option to consider, but it is incorrect because of one detail - the patient's weight! According to the CDC, the hepatitis B vaccine is typically given as a 3-dose regimen, with the first dose administered at birth, the second dose at 1–2 months, and the third dose at 6–18 months of age in children whose mothers are HbsAg-negative, such as this newborn's fully-immunized mother. However, infants with low birth weight have weak production of protective anti-HBs antibodies, so newborns < 2000 g should receive their first dose at 1 month of age (regardless of weight at that time) or upon discharge from the hospital, whichever comes sooner. This newborn currently weighs 1550-g (3.3-lb), so hepatitis B vaccine administration would not be recommended at this time.

answers.content: Haemophilus influenza type b vaccine at 3 months of chronological age
answers.explanation_why: Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is a polysaccharide-protein conjugate vaccine used in infants to prevent meningitis, pneumonia, and epiglottitis caused by Hib. It is usually given as a 3-dose regimen, with the first dose at 2 months, the second dose at 4 months, and the last dose at 6 months. A booster dose should be given at 12–15 months. This preterm infant should not wait 3 months (≈ 5 weeks prematurity + 2 months) to get the first dose of the Hib vaccine.

answers.content: Inactivated poliovirus vaccine at 3 months of chronological age
answers.explanation_why: The inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV) is usually given as a 3-dose regimen, with the first dose at 2 months, the second dose at 4 months, and the last dose at 6–18 months. A booster dose should be given at 4–6 years of age. This preterm infant should not wait until 3 months (≈ 5 weeks prematurity + 2 months) to get the first dose of IPV.

answers.content: Rotavirus vaccine at 3 months of chronological age
answers.explanation_why: The rotavirus vaccine is given as a 2-dose or 3-dose regimen, depending upon the vaccine used. The first dose is given at 2 months, the second dose at 4 months, and the last dose at 6 months (if needed). This preterm infant should not wait until 3 months (≈ 5 weeks prematurity + 2 months) to get the first dose of the rotavirus vaccine.

answers.content: Measles, mumps, rubella vaccine at 2 months of chronological age
answers.explanation_why: The measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine is usually administered as a 2-dose regimen, with the first dose at 12–15 months of age and the second dose at 4–6 years of age. This preterm infant needs to be at least 12 months of age to receive the MMR vaccine.

question_text:
A 3100-g (6-lb 10-oz) male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of fever and irritability. The newborn was delivered at home 15 hours ago. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation. The mother's last prenatal visit was at the beginning of the first trimester. She received all standard immunizations upon emigrating from Mexico 2 years ago. Seven weeks ago, she experienced an episode of painful, itching genital vesicles, which resolved spontaneously within a week. Four hours before going into labor, she noticed a gush of pale yellow fluid from her vagina. The newborn appears ill and lethargic. His temperature is 39.9°C (103.8°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/45 mm Hg. His skin is mildly icteric. Expiratory grunting is heard on auscultation. Skin turgor and muscle tone are decreased. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
15 g/dL

Leukocyte count
33,800/mm^3

Platelet count
100,000/mm^3

Serum glucose
55 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 3100-g (6-lb 10-oz) male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of fever and irritability. The newborn was delivered at home 15 hours ago. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation. The mother's last prenatal visit was at the beginning of the first trimester. She received all standard immunizations upon emigrating from Mexico 2 years ago. Seven weeks ago, she experienced an episode of painful, itching genital vesicles, which resolved spontaneously within a week. Four hours before going into labor, she noticed a gush of pale yellow fluid from her vagina. The newborn appears ill and lethargic. His temperature is 39.9°C (103.8°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/45 mm Hg. His skin is mildly icteric. Expiratory grunting is heard on auscultation. Skin turgor and muscle tone are decreased. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 15 g/dL Leukocyte count 33,800/mm3 Platelet count 100,000/mm3 Serum glucose 55 mg/dL Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: This newborn's ill appearance, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and elevated leukocyte count 15 hours after birth raise concern for early-onset neonatal sepsis.
learning_objective: Recognize early-onset neonatal sepsis, and recall the most common pathogen.

answers.explanation_why: Staphylococcus aureus is a common cause of late-onset neonatal sepsis, which occurs between 3 and 28 days of life, not 15 hours after birth. S. aureus commonly manifests with skin, soft tissue, or bone infections in newborns that progress to sepsis. This neonate has no skin lesions to suggest an infection with S. aureus.

Clostridium botulinum causes botulism, which manifests with hypotonia in newborns, as seen in this patient. However, infantile botulism also presents with ptosis, poor suck, poor head control, and flaccid paralysis, none of which are present in this case. Moreover, infantile botulism does not present with fever and signs of sepsis. Additionally, this infant has no risk factors for botulism (e.g., exposure to dust or honey).

images.title: Infant botulism
images.description: This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

answers.explanation_why: Listeria monocytogenes can occasionally cause neonatal sepsis (especially during outbreaks of listeriosis), but it is not the most common pathogen. Although early-onset meningitis manifests with nonspecific symptoms (e.g., fever, irritability, tachycardia), L. monocytogenes commonly causes meningitis at age 2–4 weeks rather than within hours of birth.

Neisseria meningitidis causes meningitis and can rapidly progress to sepsis. Although Neisserial meningitis can manifest with nonspecific symptoms like fever, irritability, and tachycardia as seen in this patient, it is exceedingly rare in the first week of life.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes genital herpes and can be transferred to a newborn during childbirth. Neonatal HSV infection manifests with thrombocytopenia and disseminated sepsis-like illness. However, HSV infection also typically manifests with vesicular skin lesions, which this patient does not have. The patient's mother had a painful vesicular genital rash, likely due to genital herpes, but it resolved 6 weeks before the onset of labor, greatly reducing the risk of transmission. Although HSV may be vertically transmitted in the absence of an active maternal genital rash, a different organism is the more likely cause of this newborn's illness.

Streptococcus agalactiae, i.e., group B Streptococcus (GBS), is the most common pathogen in early-onset neonatal sepsis (< 72 hours after delivery). Common causes of this condition include chorioamnionitis and bacterial colonization of the maternal genital tract with intrapartum pathogen transfer to the infant. A common risk factor is premature rupture of membranes (PROM), as evidenced by the gush of pale yellow fluid prior to the onset of labor in this patient's mother.

Routine screening for maternal GBS colonization is performed by rectal or vaginal swab cultures from 36 0/7 to 37 6/7 weeks' gestation. Treatment with intrapartum penicillin G or ampicillin is indicated in birthing parents with positive screening, GBS bacteriuria, history of GBS infection, or risk factors (e.g., PROM, fever, preterm labor). Treatment of GBS neonatal sepsis includes parenteral ampicillin and gentamicin.

question_text:
A 10-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery and weighed 3100 g (6 lb 13 oz) at birth. The mother did not receive prenatal care. The newborn's 4-year-old brother has sickle cell disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice. The abdomen is nondistended and there is no hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
11 g/dL

Reticulocytes
9%

Leukocytes
9100/mm^3

Platelets
244,000/mm^3

Fetal blood group
B, Rh-negative

Serum

 Bilirubin, total

11.3 mg/dL

 Direct

0.3 mg/dL

The mother's blood group is O, Rh-negative and maternal serum studies show positive anti-Rh antibody titers. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this newborn's condition?
content_preview: A 10-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery and weighed 3100 g (6 lb 13 oz) at birth. The mother did not receive prenatal care. The newborn's 4-year-old brother has sickle cell disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice. The abdomen is nondistended and there is no hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 11 g/dL Reticulocytes 9% Leukocytes 9100/mm3 Platelets 244,000/mm3 Fetal blood group B, Rh-negative Serum Bilirubin, total 11.3 mg/dL Direct 0.3 mg/dL The mother's blood group is O, Rh-negative and maternal serum studies show positive anti-Rh antibody titers. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this newborn's condition?
hint: This newborn's indirect hyperbilirubinemia and reticulocytosis are highly suggestive of a hemolytic process.
learning_objective: Recognize ABO incompatibility as a cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn.

answers.explanation_why: Hemolytic anemia and neonatal jaundice can occur with certain congenital viral infections such as congenital CMV infection and congenital rubella syndrome. The lack of routine prenatal care puts this neonate at risk for congenital viral infections but this neonate has no other evidence of these infections (e.g., low birth weight, rash, hepatosplenomegaly). Patients with congenital parvovirus B19 infection can develop anemia as a result of red cell aplasia but these patients present with reticulocytopenia and no evidence of hemolysis. While a congenital viral infection cannot be ruled out definitively, the overall presentation and laboratory findings make another diagnosis more likely.

A deficiency of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) in red blood cells can cause hemolytic anemia and jaundice in affected neonates. However, symptoms usually do not occur till day 2–3 after birth. The lack of a family history of G6PD deficiency and the timing of jaundice make another diagnosis more likely.

RBC sickling, which can be seen in individuals with sickle cell disease (SCD), would result in hemolytic anemia. However, hemolytic anemia due to SCD generally does not develop until patients have reached 6 months of age when hemoglobin F (HbF) production decreases and hemoglobin S (HbS) production begins.

The presence of anti-D antibodies is characteristic of Rh incompatibility, which manifests with hemolytic anemia and jaundice in neonates. Rh incompatibility occurs in Rh-negative mothers who have developed anti-Rh antibodies from exposure to Rh-positive blood (e.g., during a prior pregnancy). Although the mother has developed anti-D antibodies due to previous exposure to Rh-positive RBCs (as is evident from her positive anti-Rh antibody titer), her son is Rh-negative and is therefore not at risk for Rh incompatibility.

Biliary atresia may manifest with jaundice within the first few days to weeks of life. Additional features include acholic stools and dark urine, which are not seen here. More importantly, due to the backup and reabsorption of conjugated bilirubin, direct rather than indirect hyperbilirubinemia would be expected.

ABO incompatibility is a relatively common cause of hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDFN) affecting approx. 20% of all pregnancies and can occur even during the first pregnancy. ABO incompatibility most commonly occurs in neonates with blood groups A or B born to mothers with blood group O. Mothers with blood group O often have anti-B and anti-A antibodies even if no prior sensitization has occurred. While most of these antibodies are of the IgM isotype, which cannot pass the placenta, some are IgG antibodies, which can enter into fetal circulation during pregnancy. Since fetal RBCs do not fully express antigens A and B, these IgG antibodies only cause mild hemolysis and the direct Coombs test is usually negative or only weakly positive. Evidence of hemolysis is apparent within the first 24 hours after birth. Patients with HDFN due to ABO incompatibility do not develop hydrops fetalis or kernicterus.

See “ABO vs. Rh incompatibility” table.

question_text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 36 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of worsening pelvic pain for 2 hours. Three days ago, she had a burning sensation with urination that resolved spontaneously. She has nausea and has vomited fluid twice on her way to the hospital. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.7°C (103.5°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 33/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness. No contractions are felt. Speculum examination shows pooling of nonbloody, malodorous fluid in the vaginal vault. The cervix is not effaced or dilated. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 14 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm^3, and a platelet count of 250,000/mm^3. Fetal heart rate is 148/min and reactive with no decelerations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 36 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of worsening pelvic pain for 2 hours. Three days ago, she had a burning sensation with urination that resolved spontaneously. She has nausea and has vomited fluid twice on her way to the hospital. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.7°C (103.5°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 33/min, and blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness. No contractions are felt. Speculum examination shows pooling of nonbloody, malodorous fluid in the vaginal vault. The cervix is not effaced or dilated. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 14 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3, and a platelet count of 250,000/mm3. Fetal heart rate is 148/min and reactive with no decelerations. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient, who is at 36 weeks' gestation, recently had a urinary tract infection and now has diffuse abdominal tenderness, nausea, vomiting, fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, and leukocytosis. These features, together with malodorous amniotic fluid, indicate a diagnosis of chorioamnionitis with preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM). There are no signs of severe fetal distress (e.g., fetal tachycardia).
learning_objective: Recognize chorioamnionitis with preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM), and choose the most appropriate management in labor induction.

answers.content: Administer intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin and perform cesarean delivery
answers.explanation_why: Antibiotic therapy and prompt delivery are critical components of the management of chorioamnionitis. A regimen of intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin is the appropriate antibiotic therapy for patients with this condition. However, cesarean delivery should only be performed in patients with chorioamnionitis who have standard obstetric indications (e.g., failure to progress during labor, nonreassuring fetal status), none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, if cesarean delivery is performed, patients should also receive antibiotic coverage of anaerobic bacteria with either clindamycin or metronidazole.

Prompt delivery is a critical component of the management of chorioamnionitis. However, expectant management is inappropriate for this patient, who does not have uterine contractions or cervical changes and thus should receive induction of labor. Moreover, prompt delivery alone is insufficient to treat chorioamnionitis.

answers.content: Administer oral azithromycin and induce labor
answers.explanation_why: Prompt delivery and antibiotic therapy are critical components of the management of chorioamnionitis. Induction of labor is appropriate for this patient, who does not have uterine contractions or cervical changes. However, azithromycin is not routinely used as part of the antibiotic regimen to treat chorioamnionitis.

answers.content: Administer intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin and induce labor
answers.explanation_why: Antibiotic therapy and prompt delivery are critical components of the management of chorioamnionitis. A regimen of intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin is the appropriate antibiotic therapy for patients with this condition. This patient, who does not have uterine contractions or cervical changes, should receive induction of labor. Augmentation of labor is appropriate for patients with prolonged labor or inadequate uterine contractions.

Cesarean delivery should only be performed in patients with chorioamnionitis who have standard obstetric indications (e.g., failure to progress during labor, nonreassuring fetal status), none of which are present in this patient. Moreover, prompt delivery alone is insufficient to treat chorioamnionitis.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her current pregnancy has been complicated by iron deficiency anemia treated with iron tablets. She has received routine prenatal care, but she has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by an infection with GBS that resulted in sepsis in the newborn. The patient has no history of serious illness. Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nontender and contractions are felt every 4 minutes. There is clear amniotic fluid pooling in the vagina. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 37 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her current pregnancy has been complicated by iron deficiency anemia treated with iron tablets. She has received routine prenatal care, but she has not been tested for group B streptococcal (GBS) colonization. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by an infection with GBS that resulted in sepsis in the newborn. The patient has no history of serious illness. Current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is nontender and contractions are felt every 4 minutes. There is clear amniotic fluid pooling in the vagina. The fetus is in a cephalic presentation. The fetal heart rate is 140/min. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's first child had sepsis due to a GBS infection. It is essential to prevent the infection from recurring in her second child.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for preventing neonatal GBS infection in labor.

answers.content: Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture and intravenous penicillin administration
answers.explanation_why: Culture of GBS is usually indicated at 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation for diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Indications for prophylaxis include maternal GBS colonization, GBS bacteriuria occurring during pregnancy, or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient). Because this patient already has an indication for prophylaxis, GBS screening cultures are not required.
This patient is most likely colonized by GBS and should receive a different intervention to avoid intrapartum transmission and a subsequent negative outcome in her unborn child.

answers.content: Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for GBS culture
answers.explanation_why: Culture of GBS is indicated at 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation for diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization. However, patients with GBS bacteriuria during pregnancy or a history of a previous newborn with GBS infection (as in this patient) require prophylaxis. Therefore, she does not require further testing, as it would not influence the treatment.

Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection. Maternal GBS colonization is a major risk factor for early-onset neonatal infection and sepsis. Routine screening for GBS colonization of all pregnant women via culture of vaginal and rectal swabs is indicated between 36 0/7–37 6/7 weeks' gestation. Women with GBS bacteriuria occurring anytime during pregnancy or history of a previous newborn with GBS infection, as in this patient, should receive routine prophylactic antibiotics and do not have to undergo prior screening for GBS colonization.

Other maternal risk factors for GBS infection that serve as indications for antibiotic prophylaxis in patients with unknown antepartum culture status include fever, preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, or positive intrapartum nucleic acid amplification testing for GBS.

answers.content: Obtain vaginal-rectal swab for nucleic acid amplification testing and intravenous penicillin administration
answers.explanation_why: Nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) can be used for rapid intrapartum diagnosis of maternal GBS colonization in women with an unknown culture status. However, NAAT is not routinely used because of its low sensitivity compared to standard GBS culture. Moreover, the management of cases with a possible maternal GBS colonization and an unknown antepartum culture status should be based on maternal risk factors rather than NAAT results. Intrapartum administration of intravenous penicillin G is used for the prophylaxis of neonatal GBS infection.

Colonization or active infections (e.g., chorioamnionitis) do not routinely justify a cesarean delivery. However, if an infection presents along with fetal distress or there is any other standard obstetric indication (e.g., insufficient maternal contractions), the patient would require a cesarean delivery.

question_text: A 2-week old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after the initial newborn examination showed asymmetry of the legs. She was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Pregnancy was complicated by a breech presentation for which she underwent an emergency lower segment transverse cesarean section. The newborn's head circumference is 35 cm (13.7 in). She is at the 60th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The spine is normal. Abduction of the right hip after cupping the pelvis and flexing the right hip and knee causes a palpable clunk. The feet have no deformities. Ultrasonography of the hip determines the angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium is 50°. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 2-week old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after the initial newborn examination showed asymmetry of the legs. She was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Pregnancy was complicated by a breech presentation for which she underwent an emergency lower segment transverse cesarean section. The newborn's head circumference is 35 cm (13.7 in). She is at the 60th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The spine is normal. Abduction of the right hip after cupping the pelvis and flexing the right hip and knee causes a palpable clunk. The feet have no deformities. Ultrasonography of the hip determines the angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium is 50°. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This newborn has a positive Ortolani sign (the clunk heard and felt on abducting her flexed hip), which suggests developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The sex of the child (female) and a breech presentation are risk factors for DDH. An alpha angle (angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium) of less than 60° on ultrasound also indicates DDH.
learning_objective: Recognize developmental dysplasia of the hip, and choose the most appropriate initial management for a newborn.

answers.content: Reassure the mother and schedule follow-up appointment in 4 weeks
answers.explanation_why: In most infants, mild hip instability (e.g., the femoral head is subluxable) resolves spontaneously within the first 6–8 weeks of life, as growth of the femoral head and acetabulum reduces hip laxity. If mild hip instability is detected at neonatal screening, close observation, and repeat examination after 2–6 weeks are appropriate. However, in infants with clinical evidence of hip instability (e.g., the femoral head is dislocatable) and abnormal ultrasound findings, DDH is unlikely to resolve without treatment. These infants are at high risk of developing a functional disability and accelerated osteoarthritis in the course of their lives. Expectant management would therefore not be appropriate.

answers.content: Immobilize the hips with a spica cast
answers.explanation_why: In the case of DDH, a hip spica cast is indicated only after an open or closed reduction of the femoral head or following a pelvic or femoral osteotomy. Since none of these procedures were performed in this infant, a hip spica cast would not be appropriate.

answers.content: Obtain an x-ray of the right hip
answers.explanation_why: An x-ray of the hip is not useful for assessing the hip joint at birth because the head of the femur is unossified for the first 4 months and cartilaginous structures do not appear on an x-ray. A hip x-ray would be appropriate (instead of an ultrasound) if the child were older than 4 months.

answers.content: Perform closed reduction of the right hip
answers.explanation_why: The clunk heard during the Ortolani maneuver (abduction of a flexed hip) indicates reduction of the dislocated hip. Therefore, further maneuvers to reduce the hip are not needed. In infants with DDH older than 6 months, contractures develop around the hip joint and make hip abduction difficult. Closed reduction of the hip joint under general anesthesia would be indicated in such a scenario.

A harness that keeps the hips abducted to 50° and flexed to 90–100° to achieve concentric reduction of the femoral head is the treatment of choice for DDH in infants who are less than 6 months old. The harness should be worn for at least 23 hours/day for 6–8 weeks. The type of abduction harness (rigid vs. nonrigid harness) used varies by region and institutional protocols.

Nonrigid harnesses (e.g., the Pavlik harness) are the most commonly used orthotic among patients with DDH, although recent evidence suggests rigid harnesses (e.g., von Rosen harness) are associated with better outcomes.

answers.content: Perform open reduction of the right hip
answers.explanation_why: Open reduction of the dislocated femoral head is the treatment of choice for DDH in patients 12–18 months of age. In individuals > 18 months of age, pelvic and/or femoral osteotomy may also be performed. This patient is 2 weeks old and therefore requires a different step in management.
