question_text: A 3175-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at 37 weeks to a 26-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The pregnancy had been uncomplicated. The mother had no prenatal care. She immigrated to the US from Brazil 2 years ago. Immunization records are not available. One day after delivery, the newborn's temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 182/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 82/60 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a continuous heart murmur. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There are several discolored areas on the skin that are nonblanchable upon pressure application. Slit lamp examination shows cloudy lenses in both eyes. The newborn does not pass her auditory screening tests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3175-g (7-lb) female newborn is delivered at 37 weeks to a 26-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The pregnancy had been uncomplicated. The mother had no prenatal care. She immigrated to the US from Brazil 2 years ago. Immunization records are not available. One day after delivery, the newborn's temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 182/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 82/60 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a continuous heart murmur. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There are several discolored areas on the skin that are nonblanchable upon pressure application. Slit lamp examination shows cloudy lenses in both eyes. The newborn does not pass her auditory screening tests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The mother of this newborn most likely did not receive the appropriate vaccinations, which put her and her child at risk of having contracted an infectious disease during the pregnancy. The newborn now presents with cataracts, auditory defects, and a murmur suggestive of patent ductus arteriosus, which is a triad of symptoms characteristic of a particular congenital infection (sometimes referred to as Gregg triad).
learning_objective: Recognize congenital rubella infection.

answers.explanation_why: Findings of congenital varicella infections vary greatly, depending on what stage of pregnancy the maternal infection occurred. Classically, congenital varicella infection manifests with chorioretinitis, cataracts, hypertrophic scar tissue, limb malformations (e.g., hypoplasia), and CNS defects. While this patient's cataracts can be explained by a congenital varicella infection, it would not account for the newborn's heart murmur. This newborn is not described as having any limb abnormalities or hypertrophic scar tissue, which are usually seen in this condition.

images.title: Congenital varicella syndrome TORCH fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Congenital parvovirus B19 infections may cause fetal hydrops and aplastic anemia, which can result in miscarriage. This newborn may have anemia, but she does not display signs of hydrops such as edema of the subcutaneous tissue or scalp, ascites, or pleural effusions. Also, a congenital parvovirus B19 infection does not explain this patient's cataracts, auditory defect, or continuous heart murmur.

While congenital syphilis may cause sensorineural hearing loss, this is typically a late finding that does not occur until children have reached 8–10 years of age. Findings of early congenital syphilis (onset prior to 2 years of age) include rhinorrhea with white or bloody nasal discharge, a maculopapular rash on palms and soles, skeletal abnormalities (e.g., metaphyseal dystrophy, periostitis), and nontender generalized lymphadenopathy.

The classic triad of congenital rubella infection is bilateral cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss (secondary to a cochlear dysfunction), and a heart defect – typically patent ductus arteriosus or pulmonary artery stenosis. Other, less specific findings include petechiae and purpura (“blueberry muffin rash”). Congenital rubella syndrome usually only results if the infection occurs during organogenesis, i.e., during the first 1–8 weeks of gestation. If the transmission occurs after 16 weeks' gestation, the risk of developing congenital rubella syndrome is extremely low.

There are different laboratory studies available to confirm the diagnosis of congenital rubella infection: PCR for rubella RNA, viral culture (both tests may be performed from nasal, throat, or blood specimens from the newborn), or serology (rubella-specific IgM or IgG antibodies in abnormally high or persistent concentrations).

images.title: Congenital rubella infection TORCH fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Newborns with congenital toxoplasmosis typically present with chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus. Cataracts and a heart murmur are not typical features of intrauterine infection with toxoplasmosis.

Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections typically manifest with sensorineural hearing loss, chorioretinitis, periventricular calcifications, and microcephaly. A congenital CMV infection may explain this patient's auditory defect, but it does not account for the newborn's bilateral cataracts or the heart murmur.

images.title: Congenital CMV infection TORCH fact sheet

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of arm pain following a fall that took place 5 hours ago. According to his mother, the boy was running in the yard when he fell and injured his right arm. The boy is crying and clutching his arm. During the past year, he has been brought in 4 other times for extremity pain following falls, all of which have been diagnosed as long bone fractures. He is at the 10^th percentile for height and 25^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 97/68 mm Hg. His right forearm is diffusely erythematous. The patient withdraws and yells when his forearm is touched. His left arm has two small ecchymotic regions overlying the elbow and wrist. A photograph of his eyes is shown. An x-ray of the right forearm shows a transverse mid-ulnar fracture with diffusely decreased bone density. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of arm pain following a fall that took place 5 hours ago. According to his mother, the boy was running in the yard when he fell and injured his right arm. The boy is crying and clutching his arm. During the past year, he has been brought in 4 other times for extremity pain following falls, all of which have been diagnosed as long bone fractures. He is at the 10th percentile for height and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 97/68 mm Hg. His right forearm is diffusely erythematous. The patient withdraws and yells when his forearm is touched. His left arm has two small ecchymotic regions overlying the elbow and wrist. A photograph of his eyes is shown. An x-ray of the right forearm shows a transverse mid-ulnar fracture with diffusely decreased bone density. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with short stature, recurrent bone fractures, blue sclera, and osteopenia, all of which are consistent with the diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta.
learning_objective: Recognize osteogenesis imperfecta, and recall its genetic basis.

answers.explanation_why: Type 5 collagen is a regulator of type 1 collagen fibrillogenesis. Type 5 collagen defects usually manifest as classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is characterized by chronic joint and bone issues. Rather than frequent bone fractures, the major symptoms are joint instability, early onset of osteoarthritis, hyperflexible joints, and scoliosis.

Non-accidental injury, i.e., child abuse, must always be considered in the differential diagnosis of children with growth retardation and concomitant fractures, especially those with multiple or recurrent fractures such as this boy. However, the presence of osteopenia suggests a metabolic disease as the cause. Additionally, the finding of blue sclerae is unique to patients with osteogenesis imperfecta, who have sclerae that are thinner than usual and allow the underlying choroidal veins to shine through.

Type 2 collagen defects predominantly affect tissues such as cartilage and vitreous humor. Various conditions are associated with type 2 collagen defects (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia, or osteoarthritis) and these differ substantially in presentation and age of onset. While some conditions could explain the growth retardation observed in this patient (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia), blue sclerae and recurrent bone fractures in an otherwise healthy child would not be consistent with any type 2 collagen defect.

The vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (type 4) arises from an autosomal mutation in type 3 collagen. This condition manifests predominantly in the cardiovascular system and often goes undiagnosed until it becomes apparent through some sort of vascular damage/injury (e.g., aortic dissection, ruptures arterial aneurysm, subarachnoid hemorrhage). The child presents with easy bruising, as evidenced by the ecchymosis, which is also a feature of Ehlers-Danlos type 4. However, the child's history of frequent fractures after minor trauma, the blue sclerae, and growth retardation are not consistent with this condition.

Vitamin D deficiency can cause rickets in children, which manifests with growth retardation, bone deformities, and osteopenia. However, blue sclerae and recurrent bone fractures are not seen in rickets. Patients at risk for developing vitamin D deficiency include premature infants, dark-skinned children on vegetarian and unusual diets, children living at higher latitudes, and children with malabsorption conditions. This patient has none of these risk factors.

images.title: Rickets secondary to vitamin D deficiency fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Mutations to the genes encoding type 4 collagen can manifest as Alport syndrome. This disorder usually affects boys, who present with intermittent gross hematuria, hearing loss, and ocular disturbances, none of which are seen here. Recurrent bone fractures, growth retardation, and blue sclerae are not features of Alport syndrome.

A mutation in type 1 collagen causes osteogenesis imperfecta type 1, the mildest and most common form of osteogenesis imperfecta. In fact, some patients with osteogenesis imperfecta type 1 appear normal and without obvious deformities to the casual observer despite requiring special accommodations for their bone fragility.

The prognosis depends heavily on the type of osteogenesis imperfecta. People with type 1 often have a normal life expectancy, no long-bone deformities, and few childhood fractures. Type 2 osteogenesis imperfecta is the most severe form, with most affected children dying in utero or within the first year of life due to respiratory failure secondary to underdeveloped lungs or intracerebral hemorrhage.

question_text: A 4-hour-old male newborn has perioral discoloration for the past several minutes. Oxygen by nasal cannula does not improve the cyanosis. He was delivered by cesarean delivery at 37 weeks' gestation to a 38-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus that was well-controlled during the pregnancy. She has not received any immunizations since her childhood. The newborn's temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a 2/6 holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Echocardiography shows pulmonary arteries arising from the posterior left ventricle, and the aorta rising anteriorly from the right ventricle. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-hour-old male newborn has perioral discoloration for the past several minutes. Oxygen by nasal cannula does not improve the cyanosis. He was delivered by cesarean delivery at 37 weeks' gestation to a 38-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus that was well-controlled during the pregnancy. She has not received any immunizations since her childhood. The newborn's temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a 2/6 holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Echocardiography shows pulmonary arteries arising from the posterior left ventricle, and the aorta rising anteriorly from the right ventricle. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Echocardiography findings are consistent with the diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries (TGA): In TGA, the systemic circulation is disconnected from pulmonary circulation and venous blood that is received by the right ventricle is pumped to the rest of the body without being oxygenated. TGA is more commonly associated with infants born to diabetic mothers.
learning_objective: Recognize transposition of the great arteries, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Without treatment, transposition of the great vessels is fatal. If the disease is allowed to follow its natural course, the mortality rate within the first year alone is about 90%.

TGA results in rapidly worsening hypoxemia and cyanosis shortly after birth, and relies on a patent ductus arteriosus. The ductus arteriosus is kept patent in fetal circulation by the effect of low partial pressure of oxygen in fetal circulation, as well as by endogenously produced prostaglandin E. After birth, the ductus arteriosus begins to close in response to an increase in the partial pressure of oxygen. Intravenously administered prostaglandin E1 keeps the ductus arteriosus open and allows mixing of blood between the pulmonary and systemic circulation. This effect is crucial for initial survival of infants with TGA because it is the only way to maintain oxygenation of the arterial blood until surgical repair can be performed.

images.title: Intracardiac shunt in the transposition of the great vessels
images.description: In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

answers.explanation_why: The ductus arteriosus is kept patent in fetal circulation by the low partial pressure of oxygen in fetal circulation, as well as by endogenously produced prostaglandin E. Indomethacin, a nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitor, closes the ductus arteriosus by decreasing prostaglandin synthesis. Because a patent ductus arteriosus is vital for this newborn's survival, administering indomethacin would be a grave mistake.

An arterial switch operation is required in all neonates with transposition of the great arteries. This procedure is usually delayed for 2–3 days until the high pulmonary vascular resistance of fetal circulation decreases. A different therapeutic measure is required immediately to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus while preparations for surgery are made.
A CT angiography is not indicated in this newborn with transposition of the great vessels because it would not alter the clinical management and echocardiography has already confirmed the diagnosis.

question_text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his parents because of poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting over the past week. The vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but he often spits up or refuses to eat. He has not had a cough, fever, or bloody stools. The patient was born at term by cesarean delivery and had his first bowel movement 2 days after delivery. He has since had one bowel movement daily. He is at the 50^th percentile for length, 10^th percentile for weight, and 40^th percentile for head circumference. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows that the patient has small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The abdomen is distended. When the finger is removed following a rectal exam, there is an explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his parents because of poor feeding, irritability, and frequent vomiting over the past week. The vomitus is greenish in color and smells strange. His parents have tried to feed him every 4 hours, but he often spits up or refuses to eat. He has not had a cough, fever, or bloody stools. The patient was born at term by cesarean delivery and had his first bowel movement 2 days after delivery. He has since had one bowel movement daily. He is at the 50th percentile for length, 10th percentile for weight, and 40th percentile for head circumference. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 40/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows that the patient has small, low-set ears, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a large space between the first and second toes bilaterally. The abdomen is distended. When the finger is removed following a rectal exam, there is an explosive release of stool from the patient's rectum. An x-ray of the abdomen shows a section of dilated colon followed by a segment of colon without stool or air. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: This newborn has features of Down syndrome and was noted at birth to have late passage of meconium, which raises concern for Hirschsprung disease (HD). The current symptoms of poor feeding and bilious vomiting, physical findings of abdominal distention and explosive stool release upon rectal examination, and the presence of a dilated colonic segment proximal to an empty segment on x-ray further support this diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize Hirschsprung disease, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: In adults, a CT scan of the abdomen is a common diagnostic test for patients with acute abdominal pain or severe abdominal distention. However, in children in general and even more so in newborns such as this boy at 3 weeks of age, CT scans should be avoided whenever possible because of the exposure to ionizing radiation and the significant risk of long-term complications (e.g., radiation-related cancers). Alternative imaging techniques such as ultrasonography and/or MRI are almost always preferred. Abdominal CT scans are not indicated for the diagnostic workup of HD.

Transabdominal ultrasonography can be used to assess other potential causes of abdominal distention or congenital malformations of the abdominal cavity (e.g., duodenal atresia). While findings on abdominal ultrasonography may support the diagnosis (e.g., dilated colonic segments), given its poor positive predictive value, ultrasound does not play an important role in the diagnosis of HD. It would not be an appropriate confirmatory test for this patient.

A barium enema may be used to determine the length of the aganglionic segment prior to surgery in infants with suspected HD. Barium enema is also useful for excluding HD in patients with a low clinical suspicion of the disease. However, it has a low sensitivity and specificity for HD and is, therefore, not an appropriate confirmatory test.

Anorectal manometry is a useful screening test in children > 1 month of age with suspected HD. However, because the developing anorectal sphincter does not reach a stable resting pressure until approx. 1 month of age, anorectal manometry is not the best diagnostic test for this 3-week-old patient. In addition, accurate evaluation in anorectal manometry requires precise placement of sensors, which is challenging with a newborn patient.

Quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis is the gold standard test for diagnosing cystic fibrosis (CF). Approx.10% of children with CF have meconium ileus, which manifests with delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distention, and possibly bilious vomiting. While the clinical presentation is similar to that seen in this patient, the findings of explosive stool release upon rectal examination and the association with Down syndrome are more suggestive of HD.

Rectal biopsy is the gold standard confirmatory test for suspected HD. It can be performed either as a full-thickness biopsy, carried out under general anesthesia, or as a rectal suction biopsy, directly at the bedside, sparing the patient the need to undergo general anesthesia. If the biopsy shows an absence of ganglion cells in an adequate tissue sample, HD is confirmed. A normal biopsy result taken from a correct site (i.e., 2 cm proximal to the dentate line) virtually rules out HD.

If HD is confirmed, the aganglionic segment of the colon is resected and anastomosed, either in a one-stage operation or, less commonly, as a two-stage surgery in which a diverting colostomy is performed to decompress the dilated bowel, followed by definitive anastomosis of the bowel loops.

images.title: Hirschsprung disease
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newbornA massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.Yellow overlay: gastric bubble

question_text: A 3900-g (8-lb 10-oz) newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Immediately after delivery, he spontaneously cries, grimaces, and moves all four extremities. Over the next five minutes, he becomes cyanotic and tachypneic. Bag-mask ventilation with 100% oxygen is begun, but ten minutes after delivery the baby continues to appear cyanotic. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen bag-mask ventilation shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. Breath sounds are normal on the right and absent on the left. Heart sounds are best heard in the right midclavicular line. The abdomen appears concave. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 3900-g (8-lb 10-oz) newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Immediately after delivery, he spontaneously cries, grimaces, and moves all four extremities. Over the next five minutes, he becomes cyanotic and tachypneic. Bag-mask ventilation with 100% oxygen is begun, but ten minutes after delivery the baby continues to appear cyanotic. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 100% oxygen bag-mask ventilation shows an oxygen saturation of 83%. Breath sounds are normal on the right and absent on the left. Heart sounds are best heard in the right midclavicular line. The abdomen appears concave. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?
hint: This newborn exhibits respiratory distress (cyanosis, tachypnea), absent breath sounds on the left, heart sounds shifted further to the right, and a scaphoid abdomen. These features, together with the chest x-ray demonstrating a mediastinal shift to the right, bowel loops within the thoracic cavity, and a poorly aerated lung in the left hemithorax, confirm the diagnosis of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
learning_objective: Recognize congenital diaphragmatic hernia, and choose the most appropriate initial step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Extracorporeal life support (ECLS) is indicated in infants with CDH and respiratory failure who do not improve with mechanical ventilation, as well as those with persistent hypoxia and/or acidosis on conventional medical therapy. This patient's respiratory decompensation requires immediate treatment, which means that ECLS is not the most appropriate next step.

Endotracheal surfactant is indicated in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). Neonates with NRDS may present with tachypnea and cyanosis, however, this patient's chest x-ray indicates CDH. While surfactant administration is also recommended in the management of CDH in infants born at < 34 weeks of gestation if the x-ray findings suggest concomitant NRDS, this patient was born at term and there is no evidence of NRDS on x-ray.

images.title: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome
images.description: X-ray chest (frontal view) of a premature infantThe lungs are opacified and have a granular appearance. Air bronchograms (green overlay) extend to the lung periphery. An endotracheal tube (red outlines) is well-positioned above the carina.In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), surfactant deficiency results in alveolar collapse and noncompliant lungs. Air bronchograms are visible when aerated bronchi and bronchioles are surrounded by acinar atelectasis.

answers.explanation_why: This neonate has cyanosis, hypoxia, and tachypnea, which can be findings of congenital heart disease. Echocardiography can be used to confirm the presence of a cardiac malformation (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot or transposition of the great vessels). However, this newborn's x-ray does not reveal any signs of heart disease (e.g., increased heart size or an abnormal configuration of the aortic arch), but rather findings indicating CDH.

Surgical repair is indicated in all cases of CDH since spontaneous closure is unlikely and surgery may prevent further complications of the lung (e.g., pulmonary hypoplasia and persistent pulmonary hypertension) and intestine (e.g., bowel obstruction, strangulation, or perforation). The most common procedure is the reduction of the hernial contents followed by closure (primary or using a biomaterial patch) of the diaphragmatic defect. However, surgery should be deferred until the newborn has been stabilized (most frequently at 24–48 hours); therefore, it is not the most appropriate next step in a patient with acute respiratory decompensation.

The patient has some of the characteristic features of tension pneumothorax, including respiratory distress, absent breath sounds over the affected side of the lung, and shifting of heart sounds to the contralateral side, suggesting mediastinal deviation. However, in addition to the mediastinal shift to the right, this patient's chest x-ray shows findings of CDH. While chest tube placement is the preferred and often life-saving treatment for pneumothorax, it is contraindicated in patients with a diaphragmatic hernia as there is a high risk of injury to the herniated bowel.

images.title: Tension pneumothorax
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)A large right tension pneumothorax is accompanied by lung collapse. When compared to the left hemithorax, no lung markings are seen in the right hemithorax beyond the margin of the collapsed right lung (green overlay). Signs of tension seen here include contralateral shift of mediastinal structures and depression of the right hemidiaphragm (indicated by red lines and arrow). Another sign that may be seen in tension pneumothorax is ipsilateral intercostal space widening.An unrelated finding on this radiograph is slight curvature of the upper to midthoracic spine, convex to the left.Black line and arrows: shift of mediastinal pleura; white line and arrows: shift of cardiomediastinal silhouette

answers.explanation_why:
In patients with CDH, the compression of the lung from protruded abdominal contents may interfere with fetal lung maturation and lead to pulmonary hypoplasia, persistent pulmonary hypertension, and poor surfactant production, resulting in severe respiratory distress in the newborn. Intubation and mechanical ventilation are the priority in all patients with CDH and should be performed before any further intervention because they help to decrease air swallowing and correct hypoxia. Bag-mask ventilation is contraindicated as air is pumped into the stomach and the bowel, resulting in gastric and/or intestinal distention and further compression of the lung. As in this patient, the majority (approximately 85%) of CDH cases are left-sided.

Following intubation, a nasogastric tube should be placed for gastric decompression to decompress the stomach/bowel and reduce lung compression.

images.title: Left-sided congenital diaphragmatic hernia
images.description: Chest x-ray, PA view, in a newborn.Mediastinal shift to the right (solid line: mediastinal border in this patient; dashed line: approximate physiologic position), bowel loops within the left thoracic cavity (green marking), and a poorly aerated lung in the left hemithorax.

question_text: A 12-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department because of a high-grade fever for 3 days. He has been lethargic and not feeding well during this period. He cries incessantly while passing urine. There is no family history of serious illness. He was delivered at 37 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was complicated by mild oligohydramnios. His immunizations are up to date. He is at the 35^th percentile for length and 40^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 165/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 55/30 mm Hg. Examination shows open anterior and posterior fontanelles. There is a midline lower abdominal mass extending 2–3 cm above the symphysis. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The child is diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy is begun. This patient will most likely benefit the most from which of the following interventions?
content_preview: A 12-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department because of a high-grade fever for 3 days. He has been lethargic and not feeding well during this period. He cries incessantly while passing urine. There is no family history of serious illness. He was delivered at 37 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was complicated by mild oligohydramnios. His immunizations are up to date. He is at the 35th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. His temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 165/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 55/30 mm Hg. Examination shows open anterior and posterior fontanelles. There is a midline lower abdominal mass extending 2–3 cm above the symphysis. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The child is diagnosed with a urinary tract infection and broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy is begun. This patient will most likely benefit the most from which of the following interventions?
hint: This patient's midline lower abdominal mass that extends 2–3 cm above the symphysis is most likely the distended bladder.
learning_objective: Recognize lower urinary tract obstruction due to posterior urethral valves in a newborn, and choose the most appropriate intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Meatotomy is the preferred treatment option for meatal stenosis. Congenital meatal stenosis, which is caused by failed regression of the distal urethral membrane, may manifest in neonates with signs of urinary obstruction, such as this patient's palpable bladder on physical examination and his history of oligohydramnios. However, meatal stenosis is most frequently acquired (e.g., secondary to circumcision) rather than congenital, making this diagnosis less likely.

Diverticulum excision with urethral reconstruction is used in the treatment of urethral diverticula. Even though urethral diverticula may rarely manifest with urinary retention, it more frequently manifests with dribbling, dysuria, and dyspareunia in adult women or as a complication of urethral surgery (e.g., correction of hypospadias).

Subureteric transurethral injection of dextranomer is indicated in the treatment of patients with severe vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). While VUR typically manifests with febrile urinary tract infection, which is seen in this patient, VUR does not usually cause bladder outflow obstruction (as indicated by the history of oligohydramnios and palpable bladder in this patient).

Surgical reimplantation of the ureters is indicated in patients with severe vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). Neonates with VUR typically present with febrile urinary tract infections, as seen in this patient. However, since VUR does not cause bladder outflow obstruction, the history of oligohydramnios and the finding of a palpable bladder on physical examination are not consistent with this diagnosis.

Vesicostomy is the second-line treatment in patients with posterior urethral valves. It is indicated if the preferred treatment is not possible, e.g., due to technical issues or in early preterm infants. While this neonate likely does have posterior urethral valves, he was born at term and should receive the first-line treatment.

This patient presents with urosepsis, a palpable bladder, and a history of oligohydramnios, all of which are features of lower urinary tract obstruction (UTO) due to posterior urethral valves (PUV). A PUV is present in about 1/4,000 live births, making it the most common cause of UTO in newborn boys. The treatment of choice is cystoscopy with primary valve ablation.

The presence of PUV can be detected via prenatal ultrasound, which usually shows a distended bladder, bilateral hydroureters, hydronephrosis with marked vesicoureteral reflux, and megaureter, as well as oligohydramnios. In severe cases, the deficiency of amniotic fluid may lead to the development of the Potter sequence: pulmonary hypoplasia, craniofacial abnormalities, and limb anomalies.

question_text: A 34-year-old primigravid woman at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a follow-up examination for a mass she found in her left breast 2 weeks ago. Menarche occurred at the age of 11 years, and menses occurred at 30- to 40-day intervals until pregnancy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm, firm, nontender, nonmobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. Ultrasound and ultrasound-guided core biopsy confirm an infiltrating lobular carcinoma. The pathological specimen is positive for estrogen and ERBB2 receptors and negative for progesterone receptors. Staging shows no distant metastatic disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 34-year-old primigravid woman at 20 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a follow-up examination for a mass she found in her left breast 2 weeks ago. Menarche occurred at the age of 11 years, and menses occurred at 30- to 40-day intervals until pregnancy. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm, firm, nontender, nonmobile mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. There is no palpable axillary lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. Ultrasound and ultrasound-guided core biopsy confirm an infiltrating lobular carcinoma. The pathological specimen is positive for estrogen and ERBB2 receptors and negative for progesterone receptors. Staging shows no distant metastatic disease. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Early-stage infiltrating lobular carcinoma is usually treated with breast-conserving surgery and adjuvant systemic therapy. For gestational breast cancer, it is important to offer a treatment regimen with a low risk of fetal damage.
learning_objective: Recognize gestational breast cancer, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical resection is associated with minimal risk to the fetus regardless of gestational age, but radiotherapy is contraindicated during pregnancy because of the risk of fetal damage.

Surgical resection (i.e., breast-conserving surgery or mastectomy with or without axillary node dissection) poses little risk to the fetus at any gestational age. Because her tumor is 3 cm, this patient is considered high risk and should therefore undergo adjuvant chemotherapy. Certain chemotherapeutic agents (e.g., doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, fluorouracil) have a low risk profile and can be used in the second or third trimester of pregnancy. Chemotherapy should be discontinued 3–4 weeks before delivery to reduce the risk of complications (e.g., transient neonatal myelosuppression, bleeding, sepsis) during childbirth and in the postpartum period.

A 3–6 month delay in chemotherapy is associated with less favorable outcomes in nonpregnant individuals. Therefore, physicians should counsel patients through open communication and shared decision-making, according to their individual treatment needs. Patients have the right to refuse chemotherapy and/or delay treatment until after delivery.

Trastuzumab can be considered in nonpregnant patients who have an ERBB2-positive tumor. However, because of the fetal complications associated with trastuzumab (e.g., pulmonary hypoplasia, fetal death), this medication should not be used in pregnant individuals.

The combination of hormonal therapy and trastuzumab is a recommended adjuvant treatment after surgical resection for estrogen-receptor-positive, ERBB2-positive breast cancer. However, both treatment options are contraindicated during pregnancy because of the risk of fetal damage.

Termination of pregnancy is not recommended in this patient because there is treatment available that is associated with only minimal risk of fetal damage. Furthermore, pregnancy termination is not associated with better breast cancer survival.

question_text: A 5-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of shortness of breath and noisy breathing for the past 2 weeks. She reports that the episodes are worse when he is agitated and better when he sleeps in supine position. During this period he has had frequent regurgitation of his feeds. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. The neonatal period was complicated by transient tachypnea. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 94/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows subcostal retractions. Stridor and diffuse wheezing are heard in the thorax. Anteroposterior and lateral x-rays of the chest show anterior tracheal bowing and narrowing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 5-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of shortness of breath and noisy breathing for the past 2 weeks. She reports that the episodes are worse when he is agitated and better when he sleeps in supine position. During this period he has had frequent regurgitation of his feeds. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. The neonatal period was complicated by transient tachypnea. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 94/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows subcostal retractions. Stridor and diffuse wheezing are heard in the thorax. Anteroposterior and lateral x-rays of the chest show anterior tracheal bowing and narrowing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's underlying condition is a rare but important cause of respiratory symptoms in infants. The presence of stridor (suggesting upper airway obstruction) and regurgitation of feeds (due to esophageal compression) are important clues.
learning_objective: Recognize a vascular ring causing respiratory symptoms in an infant, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Racemic epinephrine is used to treat upper airway obstruction caused by severe croup, which is a common cause of respiratory symptoms in young children (although uncommon in children < 3 months of age). Croup manifests with hoarseness and a barking cough; fever and rhinorrhea may also be seen. This patient has stridor but no fever or rhinorrhea. Moreover, in croup, x-ray shows a steeple sign, not tracheal bowing.

images.title: Steeple sign
images.description: X-ray neck of a young child (AP view)The upper tracheal air column, which normally appears with a square-shouldered configuration, has assumed a conical shape (green overlay) reminiscent of a church steeple (steeple sign; cf. illustration).The steeple sign indicates subglottic airway narrowing and is most commonly seen in croup. However, it may also appear in other conditions (e.g., bacterial tracheitis, tumors). An accompanying lateral radiograph might additionally show inspiratory overdistention of the hypopharynx.

answers.explanation_why: Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) causes respiratory distress, drooling, choking, and an inability to feed in newborns; it is unlikely to present in a 5-week-old infant. In addition, the majority of patients with TEF have a history of polyhydramnios due to the inability of the fetus to swallow amniotic fluid. Furthermore, TEF does not explain this patient's stridor or x-ray findings.

images.title: Gross classification of esophageal atresia
images.description: Gross type A: esophageal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type B: esophageal atresia with an upper tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type C: esophageal atresia with a lower tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type D: esophageal atresia with upper and lower tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type E: tracheoesophageal fistula without atresia

answers.explanation_why: Nebulized albuterol is used to treat acute asthma, which typically manifests with sudden shortness of breath, wheezing, and a dry cough that usually worsens at night. This patient presents with shortness of breath and wheezing, but his symptoms improve at night. In addition, chest x-ray findings in acute asthma exacerbation are expected to show hyperinflation of the lungs, not tracheal changes.

answers.content: Surgical division of a vascular ring
answers.explanation_why: A vascular ring is a rare cause of respiratory symptoms in infants that is treated with surgical division. Vascular rings typically manifest with shortness of breath, wheezing, stridor due to tracheal compression, as well as difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and/or unintended weight loss resulting from esophageal compression. The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of tracheal and esophageal compression by the vascular ring. X-ray typically shows tracheal bowing and narrowing, indicating tracheal compression.

images.title: Double aortic arch
images.description: Ventral view of mediastinal structuresThere is constriction of the trachea and esophagus as a result of the additional aortic arch (vascular ring anomaly).

answers.explanation_why: Ceftriaxone is indicated for bacterial airway infection (e.g., epiglottitis), which can manifest with respiratory distress and inspiratory stridor. However, it usually also manifests in older children with sore throat, dysphagia, drooling, and acute onset of high fever, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, x-ray of the epiglottitis often shows a characteristic thumbprint sign (enlarged epiglottis), not the tracheal changes seen here.

images.title: Thumb and vallecula signs (epiglottitis)
images.description: X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view)The epiglottis is swollen and rounded in appearance (thumb sign; highlighted by green overlay and black arrow) as a result of inflammation and edema. The normal air space between the tongue base and epiglottis has been almost entirely obliterated and is seen only as a shallow V-shaped space (vallecula sign; highlighted by red line).The thumb and vallecula signs are useful in the radiographic evaluation of epiglottitis.

answers.explanation_why: Supraglottoplasty is performed in severe cases of laryngomalacia. This condition typically manifests with low-pitched inspiratory stridor that worsens in the supine position and during sleeping or feeding. Other symptoms of laryngomalacia include reflux, swallowing dysfunction, and, in severe cases, failure to thrive. This patient presents with stridor that improves in the supine position and during sleeping. In addition, chest x-ray findings suggest involvement of the trachea rather than the larynx.

question_text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her first pregnancy and delivery were complicated by iron deficiency anemia and pregnancy-induced hypertension. She has had no routine prenatal care during this pregnancy but was diagnosed with oligohydramnios 4 weeks ago. The remainder of her medical history is not immediately available. A 2400-g (5.4-lb) female newborn is delivered vaginally. Examination of the newborn shows a short, mildly webbed neck and low-set ears. Ocular hypertelorism along with slanted palpebral fissures are noted. A cleft palate and hypoplasia of the nails and distal phalanges are present. There is increased coarse hair on the body and face. Which of the following best explains the clinical findings found in this newborn?
content_preview: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her first pregnancy and delivery were complicated by iron deficiency anemia and pregnancy-induced hypertension. She has had no routine prenatal care during this pregnancy but was diagnosed with oligohydramnios 4 weeks ago. The remainder of her medical history is not immediately available. A 2400-g (5.4-lb) female newborn is delivered vaginally. Examination of the newborn shows a short, mildly webbed neck and low-set ears. Ocular hypertelorism along with slanted palpebral fissures are noted. A cleft palate and hypoplasia of the nails and distal phalanges are present. There is increased coarse hair on the body and face. Which of the following best explains the clinical findings found in this newborn?
hint: This newborn's symptoms are most likely associated with maternal folate deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize fetal hydantoin syndrome, and recall its association with maternal phenytoin therapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a collection of defects associated with maternal exposure to phenytoin and other hydantoins (e.g., fosphenytoin). Use of these medications interferes with folate metabolism which often induces a deficiency. Common features of fetal hydantoin syndrome include intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial abnormalities (e.g., cleft palate, hypertelorism, slanted palpebral fissures, and low-set ears), a short neck, limb defects (phalanx/fingernail hypoplasia), and excessive hair on the body and face. Other manifestations include cardiac anomalies (e.g., ventricular septal defect), ocular defects, hypospadias, and umbilical and inguinal hernias. Treatment is largely supportive and includes surgery to fix the cleft palate in addition to special education.

Fetal hydantoin syndrome does not typically manifest with neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida), which are usually seen in other types of folate deficiency and may occur as a result of maternal use of other anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine or valproate (see “Overview of antiepileptics to avoid during pregnancy” table).

Fetal posterior urethral valves cause urinary tract obstruction, which can lead to oligohydramnios and subsequent Potter sequence. Although Potter sequence can also cause craniofacial abnormalities, this syndrome is not associated with phalanx/nail hypoplasia or excessive hair growth. Additionally, posterior urethral valves almost exclusively occur in male newborns, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Infants born to diabetic mothers are at risk for caudal regression syndrome, a condition that causes abnormalities in the caudal portion of the body. This infant's features are largely confined to the face and thorax, making caudal regression syndrome unlikely. In addition, infants born to mothers with diabetes tend to have macrosomia, not growth restriction as seen here.

images.title: Caudal regression syndrome
images.description: Lower abdomen and legs of a 2.5-year-old girl of a diabetic mother with poor glycemic control during pregnancy:The hips and lower extremities appear hypoplastic and showed no muscular activity during the clinical examination. Orthopedic deformities included knees in a flexion contracture and equinovarus feet.These findings are consistent with caudal regression syndrome. X-ray and MRI of the spine confirmed total sacral and partial lumbar vertebrae agenesis and termination of the spinal cord at T6.

answers.explanation_why: Maternal alcohol intake can lead to fetal alcohol spectrum disorders, which can cause intrauterine growth restriction, hypoplastic nails, and facial dysmorphisms (e.g., ocular hypertelorism). However, fetal alcohol spectrum disorders typically do not cause cleft palate or excessive hair growth, making it an unlikely cause of this infant's symptoms.

images.title: Clinical findings in fetal alcohol syndrome

answers.explanation_why: Monosomy of the X chromosome leads to Turner syndrome, which may cause a webbed neck and low-set ears in a female newborn. However, Turner syndrome typically does not cause cleft palate, phalanx/fingernail hypoplasia, or excessive hair growth, making it an unlikely cause of this infant's symptoms.

question_text: Three days after delivery, a 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 25 seconds. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past 18 hours. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She appears ill. Her pulse is 123/min, respirations are 50/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Three days after delivery, a 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 25 seconds. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past 18 hours. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She appears ill. Her pulse is 123/min, respirations are 50/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The condition described here is a serious complication of preterm birth.
learning_objective: Recognize intraventricular hemorrhage in preterm infants.

answers.explanation_why: If left untreated, classic galactosemia may manifest with lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures, as seen here. However, the absence of cataracts (typically manifests within the first days of life), jaundice, and hepatomegaly make this diagnosis less likely.

Spinal muscular atrophy is a possible cause of muscular hypotonia in infants. The most severe type (Werdnig-Hoffmann disease) may manifest immediately after birth or up to 6 months of age. Proximal muscles, mostly of the lower extremities, are usually involved symmetrically. However, seizures, a tense anterior fontanelle, impaired pupillary response, and roving eye movements would not be consistent with this diagnosis.

While most patients are asymptomatic at birth, half of the patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) have seizures with cerebral foci, a lag of psychomotor development, and a musty body odor by 4–6 months of age. Additional features include light, pale hair and blue eyes (due to decreased melanin production). Since most patients are asymptomatic until severe and often irreversible complications have occurred, direct measurement of phenylalanine levels is an important part of newborn screening for metabolic disorders. The screening test is performed on the second day after birth using blood obtained from a heel prick.

Hydrocephalus due to congenital causes, such as the Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker malformation, and intrauterine infections, may manifest in neonates with lethargy, tense fontanelles, seizures, and changes in vital signs due to brain stem compression (e.g., irregular breathing). However, elevated intracranial pressure usually manifests with rapidly increasing circumference of the head in neonates, which is not seen in this infant. Furthermore, instead of the roving eye movements, a downward deviation of the eyes (sunset eye sign) would be expected in patients with hydrocephalus.

images.title: Manifestations of increased intracranial pressure in infants

answers.explanation_why:
Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is a common complication in preterm infants and usually occurs within the first five days after birth. This complication is typically seen in neonates of < 1500 g birth weight and born before 32 weeks' gestation due to the fragility of the germinal matrix. Additional risk factors include peripartal chorioamnionitis and hypoxia (as suggested by this patient's low Apgar scores). Most infants with IVH are asymptomatic, but saltatory (over several days) or, more rarely, catastrophic (over minutes to hours) courses are also possible. Symptoms include lethargy, hypotonia, irregular respirations, bulging anterior fontanelle, and neurologic symptoms (e.g., seizures, cranial nerve abnormalities as suggested by poor pupillary light reflexes and roving eye movements), all of which this patient has.

Cranial ultrasonography is the preferred method to diagnose IVH in newborns. Since most patients are asymptomatic, screening ultrasounds are routinely performed in infants with a birth weight < 1500 g and delivery before 30 weeks' gestation.

images.title: Neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
images.description:
Ultrasound head (top row: coronal plane; bottom row: parasagittal plane) of a newbornThe first column shows bleeding confined to the subependymal germinal matrix (red overlay), which is consistent with grade 1 IVH.
The second column shows blood occupying less than 50% of the left lateral ventricle (red overlay), with no enlargement of the lateral ventricles (yellow overlay) or the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay). In addition, the choroid plexus is clearly demarcated (blue overlay). Together, these findings are consistent with grade 2 IVH.
The third column shows blood occupying more than 50% of the lateral ventricles (red overlay) with enlargement of the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay) and both lateral ventricles (yellow overlay). This appearance is consistent with grade 3 IVH.These features suggest impaired progressive posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation (PHVD) due to associated impairment of CSF circulation, which is a potential complication of high-grade IVH.

question_text:
A 2-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after having a seizure. He has had multiple seizures during the past week. His mother also notes that he has become lethargic and has had a weak cry for the past month. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), respirations are 50/min, and pulse is 140/min. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin; there is no splenomegaly. Serum studies show:

Na^+

137 mEq/L

Cl^-

103 mEq/L

K^+

3.9 mEq/L

Glucose
32 mg/dL

Calcium
9.6 mg/dL

Total cholesterol
290 mg/dL

Triglycerides
260 mg/dL

Lactate

4.2 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2)

A deficiency of which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 2-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after having a seizure. He has had multiple seizures during the past week. His mother also notes that he has become lethargic and has had a weak cry for the past month. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. He is at the 20th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), respirations are 50/min, and pulse is 140/min. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin; there is no splenomegaly. Serum studies show: Na+ 137 mEq/L Cl- 103 mEq/L K+ 3.9 mEq/L Glucose 32 mg/dL Calcium 9.6 mg/dL Total cholesterol 290 mg/dL Triglycerides 260 mg/dL Lactate 4.2 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2) A deficiency of which of the following enzymes is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's presentation is consistent with one of the most common glycogen storage disorders (GSDs).
learning_objective: Recognize von Gierke disease, and recall the deficient enzyme.

answers.explanation_why: A deficiency of the glycogen branching enzyme results in Andersen disease (type IV GSD), which may manifest with hepatomegaly. However, some degree of splenomegaly would also be evident, and hypoglycemia does not occur in Andersen disease until liver failure with associated cirrhosis and ascites develops. Hyperlipidemia and increased lactate levels are not typically seen in patients with Andersen disease.

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency results in classic galactosemia, which can manifest with failure to thrive, lethargy, and hepatomegaly. However, patients would typically also have other features such as vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice, and cataracts.

Fructokinase deficiency results in a benign condition called essential fructosuria, which is essentially asymptomatic.

A disorder of fructose metabolism known as hereditary fructose intolerance might manifest with hepatomegaly and severe hypoglycemia leading to seizures. However, this disorder is caused by a deficiency of aldolase B and usually manifests after the age of 6 months, when infants are weaned and given food containing sucrose.

Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is the underlying cause of von Gierke disease (type a), which typically manifests with failure to thrive, lethargy, hepatomegaly, severe fasting hypoglycemia (causing hypoglycemic seizures), hyperlipidemia, and lactic acidosis. Further characteristic findings include hyperuricemia and facial fat deposition (sometimes referred to as a “doll-like” face). Like other GSDs, von Gierke disease can be managed effectively with diet modifications (e.g., uncooked corn starch, glucose preparations), which aim to prevent hypoglycemia and muscle symptoms.

Deficiency of lysosomal acid maltase results in Pompe disease (type II GSD), which may manifest during infancy with lethargy and hepatomegaly. However, infantile Pompe disease characteristically results in generalized hypotonia, macroglossia, and rapidly progressive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, which typically causes respiratory distress and clinical features of cardiomegaly (e.g., a displaced, forceful apex beat). Increased lactate levels, hyperlipidemia, and hypoglycemia are not typically seen in patients with Pompe disease.

question_text: A 6-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of yellowing of her eyes and body, vomiting, and poor feeding for 3 days. She has had diarrhea for the past 2 days. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and the antenatal period was uncomplicated. She appears lethargic. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. Bilateral cataracts are present. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin; there is no splenomegaly. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Serum glucose concentration is 37 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation to prevent long-term complications of this illness?
content_preview: A 6-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of yellowing of her eyes and body, vomiting, and poor feeding for 3 days. She has had diarrhea for the past 2 days. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and the antenatal period was uncomplicated. She appears lethargic. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. Bilateral cataracts are present. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin; there is no splenomegaly. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Serum glucose concentration is 37 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation to prevent long-term complications of this illness?
hint: This newborn presents with jaundice, diarrhea, cataracts, hepatomegaly, and hypoglycemia, all of which suggest galactosemia.
learning_objective: Recognize classic galactosemia, and choose the dietary modification to prevent its long-term complications.

answers.explanation_why: Phototherapy is indicated to treat severe neonatal jaundice. Although phototherapy might help prevent kernicterus in neonates with severe hyperbilirubinemia, it does not address the underlying condition.

Frequent carbohydrate feeds are indicated in patients with certain glycogen storage diseases such as von Gierke disease, which may manifest with severe hypoglycemia, lethargy, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly. Intermittent diarrhea may also occur in some patients. However, patients would have other features such as a doll-like face and abdominal distention. Bilateral cataracts and vomiting are not features of von Gierke disease.

The most common form of galactosemia is galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase deficiency, which leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate and galactitol. The severe manifestations of galactosemia are a direct result of these toxic metabolites. Infantile cataracts are caused by the accumulation of galactitol in the eye lens. Newborns typically become symptomatic after the initiation of breastfeeding or formula feeding. The condition can be diagnosed by the presence of increased levels of galactose in the urine or increased levels of galactose-1-phosphate in the blood. Patients with classic galactosemia must avoid food containing lactose (e.g., cow's milk, breast milk).

Thiamine therapy is indicated for patients with maple syrup urine disease, which may manifest with feeding difficulty, lethargy, vomiting, and hypoglycemia. Although bouts of hypotonia may occur, patients are usually hypertonic. Also, a characteristic maple syrup odor would be present because leucine, isoleucine, and valine, as well as their ketoacids, are excreted in the urine, fecal excretions, and cerumen. Maple syrup urine disease does not manifest hepatomegaly and bilateral cataracts.

Levothyroxine therapy is indicated for neonates with congenital hypothyroidism, which may result in hypotonia, lethargy, feeding difficulties, and prolonged icterus. However, congenital hypothyroidism would manifest with other features such as dry skin, constipation, widely open fontanelles, umbilical hernia, macroglossia, and/or hypothermia. Congenital hypothyroidism does not manifest with hepatomegaly, vomiting, or bilateral cataracts.

question_text: Five weeks after delivery, a 1350 g (3 lb) male newborn has respiratory distress. He was born at 26 weeks' gestation. He required intubation and mechanical ventilation for 1 month following delivery and has been on noninvasive pressure ventilation for 5 days. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 148/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 60/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 40% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions. Scattered crackles are heard in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse granular densities and basal atelectasis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Five weeks after delivery, a 1350 g (3 lb) male newborn has respiratory distress. He was born at 26 weeks' gestation. He required intubation and mechanical ventilation for 1 month following delivery and has been on noninvasive pressure ventilation for 5 days. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 148/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 60/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on 40% oxygen shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows moderate intercostal and subcostal retractions. Scattered crackles are heard in the thorax. An x-ray of the chest shows diffuse granular densities and basal atelectasis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This premature infant was exposed to prolonged mechanical ventilation and oxygen therapy for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize bronchopulmonary dysplasia in premature infants.

answers.explanation_why: Tracheomalacia may be present in this infant as a result of prolonged intubation and the development of chronic lung disease. While tracheomalacia can also cause respiratory distress, this patient's presentation is not consistent with the wheezing and stridor typically seen with tracheomalacia. Moreover, the reported oxygen saturation of 91% on 40% oxygen represents significant hypoxemia; it would be unusual for tracheomalacia alone to cause this degree of desaturation. Also, tracheomalacia would not explain this patient's x-ray findings.

This neonate has several risk factors for the development of pneumonia, including prematurity and prolonged intubation. Although aspects of his clinical presentation are consistent with pneumonia (e.g., hypoxemia and tachypnea), key cardinal features are absent, such as fever, cough, or typical x-ray findings of a lobar process. This patient's x-ray findings are more indicative of a different condition.

Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) due to barotrauma and oxygen toxicity is a complication of prolonged mechanical ventilation in premature infants. This neonate demonstrates the classic presentation of BPD, which includes persistent tachypnea, labored breathing (intercostal and subcostal retractions), the need for oxygen supplementation to maintain a peripheral saturation ≥ 90% at ≥ 28 days of postnatal age, and diffuse granular densities with basal atelectasis on x-ray. Later in the disease course, interspersed cystic areas and diffuse hyperinflation of the lung can develop. Treatment of BPD primarily focuses on limiting oxygen toxicity and preventing complications (specifically pneumothorax, cardiovascular collapse, and neonatal sepsis).

images.title: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia
images.description: X-ray chest (AP view) of an intubated newborn with bronchopulmonary dysplasiaIll-defined reticular markings (examples indicated by red arrowheads) and small rounded lucent areas (examples indicated by green arrowheads) are diffusely present throughout both lungs.An endotracheal tube (green overlay), nasogastric tube (red overlay), and central venous catheter (yellow overlay) are properly positioned. Rotation of the patient to the left has resulted in an appearance of elongation of the left ribs compared to the right ribs and leftward positioning of the cardiomediastinal silhouette.

answers.explanation_why: In neonates, strong risk factors for the development of interstitial emphysema are prematurity and prolonged intubation, both of which are present here. The clinical presentation is extremely variable and can range from asymptomatic to severe hypoxemia secondary to compression of vital cardiopulmonary structures. In these severe cases, complications such as pneumomediastinum or pneumothorax are sometimes present. Typical x-ray findings include cystic radiolucencies in the interstitium radiating from the lung hila rather than the diffuse granular densities and basal atelectasis seen in this patient, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Bronchiolitis obliterans (BO) is classically seen in pediatric patients with a history of severe lung infection, especially adenovirus pneumonia. BO is a possible cause of respiratory distress in an infant and x-ray findings are often nonspecific. However, the presentation of BO is most often vague and consists of coughing, wheezing, and shortness of breath. Although the pathophysiology is not entirely understood, symptoms commonly develop over years. BO would be unlikely in this 5-week-old patient with no history of significant infection.

question_text: A 1710-g (3.77-lb) male newborn is delivered to a 27-year-old woman at 33 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy was uncomplicated, but the mother had a cold and sore throat 2 months before delivery that resolved spontaneously. The newborn appears lethargic. He is at the 15^th percentile for height and weight and at the 1^st percentile for head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. A cranial ultrasound of the newborn shows periventricular calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 1710-g (3.77-lb) male newborn is delivered to a 27-year-old woman at 33 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy was uncomplicated, but the mother had a cold and sore throat 2 months before delivery that resolved spontaneously. The newborn appears lethargic. He is at the 15th percentile for height and weight and at the 1st percentile for head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. Abdominal examination shows hepatosplenomegaly. A cranial ultrasound of the newborn shows periventricular calcifications. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Hearing screening in infants with this condition often reveals sensorineural hearing loss.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

answers.explanation_why: Crigler-Najjar syndrome can cause severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which can subsequently lead to icterus and lethargy. However, patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome appear developmentally normal and would not present with microcephaly or intracranial calcifications.

Cri-du-chat syndrome can cause microcephaly and growth retardation. However, it also causes other facial dysmorphisms, such as ear malformations, hypertelorism, and downslanting palpebral fissures, which are not present in this patient. In addition, cri-du-chat syndrome would not explain this patient's hepatosplenomegaly, scleral icterus, or periventricular calcifications.

Congenital Zika virus infection can cause growth retardation, microcephaly, and intracranial calcifications but infection by the Zika virus is more common in tropical or subtropical regions (e.g., South America, Pacific Islands, Puerto Rico). This patient has no history of travel to an endemic region. In addition, the intracranial calcifications in congenital Zika syndrome are typically located at the junction of gray and white matter unlike the periventricular calcifications that are seen here, and other characteristic features of congenital Zika virus infection such as hypertonia and joint contractures have not been reported in this patient.

images.title: Congenital Zika syndrome TORCH fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) can lead to the triad of facial dysmorphism (including microcephaly), growth retardation, and CNS dysfunction. Rarely, it can also cause neonatal jaundice and hepatomegaly. However, this child's facial dysmorphism (isolated microcephaly) is inconsistent with the facial dysmorphism characteristic of FAS (thin upper lip, smooth philtrum, and short palpebral fissures). In addition, FAS would not explain this child's intracranial calcifications.

Congenital toxoplasmosis can also manifest with neonatal jaundice, microcephaly, and hepatosplenomegaly. However, other typical features of congenital toxoplasmosis include hydrocephalus, chorioretinitis, and diffuse intracranial calcifications (rather than localized periventricular calcifications).

This neonate's low birth weight, jaundice, microcephaly, and periventricular calcifications are all findings associated with congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. Congenital CMV infection is the most common congenital infection and occurs in approx. 1% of live births in the US, although only 10% of these neonates are symptomatic. Other characteristic symptoms include chorioretinitis, sensorineural hearing loss, petechiae, and purpura (blueberry muffin rash). The risk of CMV transmission increases throughout pregnancy, whereas the risk of congenital defects is highest if the fetus is infected in the first trimester. The majority of maternal CMV infections are asymptomatic. This mother's history of a cold and sore throat 2 months prior to delivery are less likely to be related to this neonate's CMV infection.

images.title: Congenital CMV infection TORCH fact sheet
