question_text: A previously healthy 1-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a 10-day history of poor feeding. He struggles to breathe and sweats while feeding. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation following spontaneous vaginal delivery. His mother received no prenatal care. He was 51 cm (20 in) in length and weighed 3660 g (8 lb 1 oz) at birth. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination following delivery showed no abnormalities, and he was discharged at the age of 2 days. Today, he is at the 20th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% and breathing appears labored. Examination shows no cyanosis, but a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. ECG shows left-axis deviation. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged left atrium and ventricle and increased pulmonary vascular markings. Doppler echocardiography confirms the presence of an intracardiac shunt. The development of this patient's current symptoms is most likely a result of which of the following?
content_preview: A previously healthy 1-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a 10-day history of poor feeding. He struggles to breathe and sweats while feeding. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation following spontaneous vaginal delivery. His mother received no prenatal care. He was 51 cm (20 in) in length and weighed 3660 g (8 lb 1 oz) at birth. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination following delivery showed no abnormalities, and he was discharged at the age of 2 days. Today, he is at the 20th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% and breathing appears labored. Examination shows no cyanosis, but a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. ECG shows left-axis deviation. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged left atrium and ventricle and increased pulmonary vascular markings. Doppler echocardiography confirms the presence of an intracardiac shunt. The development of this patient's current symptoms is most likely a result of which of the following?
hint: Heart failure manifests with dyspnea, easy fatigability, and in children, sweating while feeding and failure to thrive. A faint holosystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border is consistent with a large ventricular septal defect (VSD).
learning_objective: Recognize a large ventricular septal defect, and recall the changes in pulmonary vascular resistance postnatally.

answers.explanation_why:
Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) is high in utero and decreases over the first few weeks of life. The progressive decrease in PVR and subsequent decrease in right ventricular pressure lead to increased left-to-right blood flow across the VSD. The enhanced shunting increases the overall volume of blood in pulmonary circulation, which causes increased lung perfusion (as evidenced by increased pulmonary vascular markings), increased pulmonary venous return to the left atrium, and left ventricular volume overload (resulting in left ventricular hypertrophy as evidenced on this patient's ECG and chest x-ray). These changes can lead to heart failure without cyanosis within the first few weeks to months of life, as seen in this child.

If the VSD is not repaired and pulmonary blood flow continues to be high, vascular remodeling in later stages will cause PVR to increase again, resulting first in right ventricular hypertrophy and persistent pulmonary hypertension and, eventually, shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) resulting in heart failure with cyanosis.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Persistent pulmonary hypertension in a patient with a VSD (which is initially a left-to-right shunt) could cause a shunt reversal (Eisenmenger reaction). However, Eisenmenger reaction is associated with cyanosis and right ventricular hypertrophy, and typically only occurs after a left-to-right shunt has persisted for an extended amount of time. The patient's age and the presence of only left ventricular hypertrophy indicate that the heart failure is triggered by a physiological adaptation that occurs during the first few weeks of life.

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) can be caused by the presence of an underdeveloped aortic valve or congenital aortic coarctation, and manifest with left ventricular hypertrophy and heart failure. However, a murmur due to LVOTO typically has a systolic ejection character and is usually heard at the upper sternal borders (with possible radiation to the carotid region) or the interscapular region. The patient's murmur and the finding of an intracardiac shunt indicate a different cause for his symptoms.

The closure of the ductus arteriosus leads to worsening of symptoms in patients with ductal-dependent congenital heart defects (e.g., transposition of the great vessels, hypoplastic left heart syndrome), and these conditions are typically more severe; they manifest with cyanosis soon after birth. A VSD is not a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect. The ductus arteriosus closes within 2 days of birth in children without ductal-dependant congenital heart defects.

An increase in systemic vascular resistance is rarely seen in neonates. If present, it is usually due to vascular pathologies, such as renal vein thrombosis or umbilical artery thrombosis, neither of which are seen in this patient.

question_text: A 4-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz). He now weighs 4300 g (9 lb 1 oz). There is no family history of serious illness. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a grade 3/6 harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
content_preview: A 4-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz). He now weighs 4300 g (9 lb 1 oz). There is no family history of serious illness. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a grade 3/6 harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
hint: This child's heart murmurs point to the most commonly diagnosed congenital heart defect in newborns.
learning_objective: Recognize a ventricular septal defect, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.content: Left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum
answers.explanation_why: A left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum can be seen in patients with an atrial septal defect (ASD). Patients with ASD are typically asymptomatic for years and diagnosed when an incidental systolic murmur is heard. However, an ASD typically causes a systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the left upper sternal border (due to increased pulmonary flow) and a widely split and fixed second heart sound.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum
answers.explanation_why:
A right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum can be seen in patients with tricuspid valve atresia (TVA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). In both conditions, a right-to-left shunt through an atrial septal defect (ASD) is necessary to pump blood to the left side of the heart and, consequently, the systemic circulation. Patients with TVA or TAPVR present with cyanosis in the first few days of life. This patient's lack of cyanosis rules out both of these diagnoses.

A right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum can also be seen in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome secondary to an isolated ASD. However, Eisenmenger syndrome develops only after an extended amount of time (usually a few years) and manifests with cyanosis and features of heart failure.

answers.content: Left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum
answers.explanation_why:
A ventricular septal defect (VSD) causes a left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum. Most VSDs manifest in infancy as a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. The size of the defect is inversely proportional to the intensity of the murmur (i.e., small defects are associated with louder murmurs, while large defects may not have an associated murmur). A mid-diastolic murmur can also sometimes be heard with moderate or large VSDs due to increased flow across the mitral valve secondary to the left-to-right shunt.

After a few years, a VSD can lead to pulmonary hypertension and a shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) resulting in heart failure with cyanosis. With shunt reversal, the murmur of the VSD may disappear.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) secondary to pulmonary infundibular stenosis can be seen in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). Patients with RVOTO would have a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and it would be unlikely for a patient with TOF to present without a history of cyanotic spells.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum
answers.explanation_why:
A right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum can occur in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) who have severe right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO). In such a scenario, the path of least resistance is through the ventricular septal defect (VSD), and not through the pulmonary valve. Patients with RVOTO would have a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and it would be unlikely for a patient with TOF to present without a history of cyanotic spells.

A right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum can also be seen in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome secondary to an isolated VSD. However, Eisenmenger syndrome develops only after an extended amount of time (usually a few years) and manifests with cyanosis and features of heart failure.

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) can be caused by the presence of an underdeveloped aortic valve or congenital aortic coarctation. However, patients with congenital LVOTO usually present soon after birth with features of heart failure. In addition, a murmur due to LVOTO typically has a systolic ejection character and is best heard at the upper sternal borders (with possible radiation to the carotid region) or the interscapular region.

question_text: A 2200-g (4-lb 14-oz) newborn is delivered at term to a 37-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows that he is at the 2^nd percentile for head circumference and at the 10^th percentile for length. He has a small jaw, small eyes, and low-set ears. There is a keyhole-shaped defect in the iris of the left eye. He has seven fingers on each hand. There is an opening in the roof of the mouth extending into the soft and hard palate bilaterally. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. The heels are prominent, with convex-shaped deformity of the plantar surface of the feet. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 2200-g (4-lb 14-oz) newborn is delivered at term to a 37-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows that he is at the 2nd percentile for head circumference and at the 10th percentile for length. He has a small jaw, small eyes, and low-set ears. There is a keyhole-shaped defect in the iris of the left eye. He has seven fingers on each hand. There is an opening in the roof of the mouth extending into the soft and hard palate bilaterally. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. The heels are prominent, with convex-shaped deformity of the plantar surface of the feet. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: This newborn's 1^st-trimester screening likely would have shown decreased PAPP-A, decreased beta-HCG, and increased nuchal translucency, while 2^nd-trimester screening (quad screen test) probably would have been normal.
learning_objective: Recognize trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome).

answers.explanation_why: Cri-du-chat syndrome is a rare condition caused by a deletion on the short arm of chromosome 5. The most characteristic feature of the resulting disorder is cat-like, high-pitched crying. Microcephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, moon facies, widely spaced eyes), and congenital heart defects can also be detected at birth, while intellectual disabilities become evident as the child grows. Although this patient has microcephaly, dysmorphic facial features, and likely congenital heart defect, his symptoms cannot be explained by cri-du-chat syndrome.

Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked dominant genetic disorder that primarily manifests in males with intellectual disability, increased height and head circumference, prominent ears, and large testes, which manifest most clearly during adolescence. The anomalies described in this infant are not consistent with a diagnosis of fragile X syndrome.

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is the most common chromosomal disorder seen in live births. Infants with trisomy 21 are usually diagnosed based on a combination of classic clinical features, including brachycephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, small mouth, flattened nose), a single transverse palmar crease, and sandal toe. Since the single palmar crease and sandal toe are absent in this infant, and a cleft lip and palate are atypical in trisomy 21, this diagnosis is unlikely.

Trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome) is the second most common chromosomal disorder after trisomy 21. Characteristic features include clenched fists with flexion contractures of the fingers, rocker-bottom feet, a prominent occiput, and visceral malformations (e.g., horseshoe kidneys). Further features may include low-set ears, micrognathia, and a cleft lip and palate. Although this infant has some features that are consistent with trisomy 18, his normal head shape, absence of finger contractures, and presence of polydactyly suggest a different diagnosis.

Infants with fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) typically have dysmorphic facial features, including a thin upper lip, a hypoplastic or absent philtrum, epicanthus, and hypertelorism. Heart defects, renal anomalies, and skeletal malformations (e.g., joint contractures, limb dislocations) can also occur. This patient's rocker-bottom feet, cleft lip/palate, and eye anomalies would not be seen in FAS.

images.title: Clinical findings in fetal alcohol syndrome

answers.explanation_why:
Low birth weight, microcephaly (head circumference < 3^rd percentile), coloboma, polydactyly, cleft lip and palate, and rocker-bottom feet (convex foot deformity with prominent heel) are strongly suggestive of trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome). Features in addition to those seen in this newborn include holoprosencephaly, microphthalmia, low-set, malformed ears, congenital heart defects (particularly ventricular septal defect), aplasia cutis congenita, omphalocele, polycystic kidney disease, and capillary hemangioma.

Only supportive treatment is available for infants with Patau syndrome and the prognosis is usually very poor (only 5% of infants survive past 6 months of age), with survival being determined by the extent of microcephaly and visceral malformations.

Williams syndrome is caused by a deletion on chromosome 7. Affected children commonly show characteristic facial features (narrow midface, wide forehead, flattened nose), cardiovascular malformations (e.g., supravalvular aortic stenosis), and intellectual disabilities. This patient has a cleft lip and palate, eye anomalies, and skeletal malformations, which do not occur in children with Williams syndrome.

question_text: A 1900-g (4-lb 3-oz) newborn is delivered at term to a 36-year-old primigravid woman. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. Apgar scores are 7 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He is at the 2^nd percentile for head circumference and 15^th percentile for length. Examination shows a prominent posterior part of the head. The ears are low-set and the jaw is small and retracted. The fists are clenched, with overlapping second and third fingers. The calcaneal bones are prominent and the plantar surface of the foot shows a convex deformity. Abdominal examination shows an omphalocele. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 1900-g (4-lb 3-oz) newborn is delivered at term to a 36-year-old primigravid woman. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. Apgar scores are 7 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He is at the 2nd percentile for head circumference and 15th percentile for length. Examination shows a prominent posterior part of the head. The ears are low-set and the jaw is small and retracted. The fists are clenched, with overlapping second and third fingers. The calcaneal bones are prominent and the plantar surface of the foot shows a convex deformity. Abdominal examination shows an omphalocele. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Prominent occiput, microcephaly, low-set ears, clenched fists with flexion contractures, and convex deformities of the plantar foot (rocker-bottom feet) are all characteristic of Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18).
learning_objective: Recognize Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18), and recall its associated cardiac malformation.

answers.explanation_why:
Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) is characterized by congenital cardiac malformations, particularly ventricular septal defects. Edwards syndrome is the second most common autosomal trisomy found in live births. The prognosis for patients with Edwards syndrome is poor, with the majority dying in utero and only 5–10% surviving past 12 months of age.

Ventricular septal defects are also associated with Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) and Down syndrome (trisomy 21).

Ebstein anomaly is a congenital heart defect characterized by malformed and displaced tricuspid valve leaflets. Ebstein anomaly is often associated with other cardiac malformations such as patent foramen ovale or atrial septal defects. It is generally not inherited, instead arises from sporadic mutations that are not associated with other congenital diseases. Prenatal lithium exposure is also thought to be associated with Ebstein anomaly.

Macroorchidism is seen in fragile X syndrome. While patients with fragile X may also have facial abnormalities, they usually have long facies with a large jaw, large ears, and a larger than normal head circumference, not microcephaly. Also, macroorchidism in patients with fragile X syndrome does not become apparent until puberty. It would therefore not be expected in this newborn. Fragile X is the second most common genetic cause of intellectual disability after Down syndrome.

Pheochromocytoma can be associated with neurofibromatosis type I, multiple endocrine neoplasia II syndrome, and von Hippel-Lindau disease, none of which are associated with the physical malformations seen in this patient.

Holoprosencephaly is commonly seen in Patau syndrome (trisomy 13). While Patau syndrome may also manifest with microcephaly, organ malformations (like omphalocele and congenital heart defects), rocker-bottom feet (convex deformity of the plantar surface of the foot), and low-set ears, it does not manifest in a prominent occiput or clenched fists with overlapping fingers (Patau syndrome usually manifests with polydactyly). Furthermore, Patau syndrome is characterized by severe midline defects, such as cleft lip and palate, that help differentiate it from other trisomy diseases.

Hirschsprung disease is associated with Down syndrome (trisomy 21). While Down syndrome may also manifest with low-set ears and organ malformations such as omphalocele, it is not associated with a prominent occiput, microcephaly, clenched fists with overlapping fingers, and convex deformities of the plantar foot (rocker-bottom feet). Instead, Down syndrome is associated with upslanting palpebral fissures, a broad/flat nasal bridge, and hypertelorism.

question_text: A 3466-g (7-lb 10-oz) female newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 7 and 8, at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has a history of schizophrenia and was treated with lithium until 5 weeks' gestation, when she found out that she was pregnant. The mother was treated for alcohol use disorder 2 years ago. She has been sober for 14 months now. Examination shows that the child has micrognathia, a broad nasal bridge, a short philtrum, and small, low-set ears. Examination of the mouth shows a cleft palate. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur can be heard over the left sternal border. Echocardiography shows a single overriding great vessel arising from the heart. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 3466-g (7-lb 10-oz) female newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 7 and 8, at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has a history of schizophrenia and was treated with lithium until 5 weeks' gestation, when she found out that she was pregnant. The mother was treated for alcohol use disorder 2 years ago. She has been sober for 14 months now. Examination shows that the child has micrognathia, a broad nasal bridge, a short philtrum, and small, low-set ears. Examination of the mouth shows a cleft palate. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur can be heard over the left sternal border. Echocardiography shows a single overriding great vessel arising from the heart. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: A chest x-ray of this neonate would show an absent thymic shadow.
learning_objective: Recognize DiGeorge syndrome, and recall its associated laboratory finding.

answers.explanation_why: Streak gonads are the atretic ovarian follicles seen in Turner syndrome. Other typical features of Turner syndrome are short stature, webbed neck, and a flat chest with broadly spaced nipples. Micrognathia and cleft palate, as seen in this patient, are not typical features. Turner syndrome would also be more likely present with a bicuspid aortic valve or coarctation of the aorta than a single overriding great vessel.

answers.content: Low levels of parathyroid hormone in serum
answers.explanation_why: The clinical presentation of DiGeorge syndrome is variable. Facial abnormalities are common and include micrognathia, cleft palate, a broad nasal bridge, a short philtrum, and low-set ears. Additionally, DiGeorge syndrome is associated with a variety of cardiac defects, including the otherwise rare truncus arteriosus defect (single overriding vessel seen on echocardiography). DiGeorge syndrome also involves impaired development of the parathyroid glands, leading to hypoparathyroidism and hypocalcemia, which may lead to tetany and seizures during infancy.

images.title: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) fact sheet

answers.content: Deletion at chromosome 7 on FISH studies
answers.explanation_why: Williams syndrome, which is caused by a deletion on chromosome 7, is characterized by intellectual disability and facial features such as a broad forehead, wide mouth, full cheeks and lips, and a long, smooth philtrum, none of which are present in this patient. Among the cardiac malformations associated with Williams syndrome, supravalvular aortic stenosis is the most common, which would cause a systolic ejection murmur but not a single great overriding vessel.

answers.content: Double bubble sign on abdominal x-ray
answers.explanation_why: The radiographic double bubble sign is seen in patients with duodenal atresia and is a gastrointestinal finding often seen in Down syndrome (DS). Although this patient has some features of DS, such as small, low-set ears and a broad nasal bridge, she does not have the typical single palmar crease and oblique eye fissures. Furthermore, DS is associated with a variety of heart defects, most commonly atrioventricular septal defect, and rarely manifests with a single overriding great vessel on echocardiography.

Cri-du-chat syndrome involves anomalies similar to those seen in this patient, specifically hypertelorism, micrognathia, and low-set ears. The distinguishing characteristic is the high-pitched, cat-like cry heard in newborns, which is not present in this patient. Additionally, cri-du-chat syndrome is most commonly associated with ventricular septal defects, which would present with a holosystolic murmur rather than an ejection murmur. Even more importantly, a single great overriding vessel is more consistent with a truncus arteriosus defect.

answers.content: Elongated tricuspid valve leaflets on echocardiography
answers.explanation_why: The use of lithium during pregnancy can cause a variety of congenital defects, including Ebstein anomaly. Individuals with Ebstein anomaly typically present with a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border, and echocardiography would show right atrial enlargement, elongation of the tricuspid valve leaflets, and tricuspid regurgitation, none of which is seen here.

Bilateral cataracts in a neonate are typical of congenital rubella syndrome, which often also causes bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and cardiac defects, most commonly patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). However, a PDA would cause a continuous machine-like murmur, unlike the systolic ejection murmur audible in this patient. Furthermore, a PDA would have been detectable on echocardiography because it results in abnormal blood flow.

question_text: A 2400-g (5.29-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 38-year-old woman. The initial examination shows that the child is at the 5th percentile for head circumference and 10th percentile for weight and length. He has a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, and a protruding tongue. An examination of the peripheries reveals a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toes. Ocular examination reveals small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This child's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
content_preview: A 2400-g (5.29-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 38-year-old woman. The initial examination shows that the child is at the 5th percentile for head circumference and 10th percentile for weight and length. He has a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, and a protruding tongue. An examination of the peripheries reveals a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toes. Ocular examination reveals small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This child's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
hint: The characteristic morphological features, Brushfield spots in the eye, and the “double bubble” sign on abdominal x-ray (indicating duodenal atresia) are all suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).
learning_objective: Recognize Down syndrome, and recall its associated cardiac anomalies.

answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASD) are among the most common congenital heart defects and are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, trisomy 21, and Holt-Oram syndrome. Although ASD occurs in approx. 15% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why:
Atrioventricular septal defects (AVSD; also referred to as endocardial cushion defects) are the most common congenital heart defects in patients with Down syndrome, occurring in about 40% of newborns with trisomy 21. AVSDs are usually diagnosed in the prenatal period, and discovery of an AVSD should warrant prompt genetic testing, as there is a strong association with trisomy 21. Down syndrome is diagnosed in approx. 40–50% of children with AVSD.

Diuretics, inotropic agents, and ACE inhibitors are usually given to improve cardiac function. Definitive treatment consists of complete surgical repair.

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) account for approx. 50% of all congenital heart defects, making them the most common cause of congenital heart disease overall. They are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, intrauterine infections, and many genetic syndromes (including trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and trisomy 21). Although VSD occurs in approximately 30% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: A patent ductus arteriosus is most commonly associated with prematurity, fetal alcohol syndrome, birth at high altitude, or congenital rubella infection. Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cause of cyanotic heart disease in children. Most cases arise sporadically, but approx. 15% of patients with TOF have an underlying genetic syndrome (such as Down syndrome or DiGeorge syndrome). Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.explanation_why: Congenital pulmonary valve stenosis usually arises sporadically, but it can be seen in association with other congenital heart defects such as tetralogy of Fallot. It is not commonly associated with Down syndrome.

Transposition of the great arteries accounts for 20% of all cases of cyanotic congenital heart disease. It is associated with maternal diabetes, advanced maternal age, and congenital rubella infection. Unlike many other congenital heart defects, it is rarely associated with any genetic conditions such as Down syndrome.

images.title: Transposition of the great vessels (TGV)
images.description: TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.

question_text: A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was born at term and the pregnancy was uncomplicated. His mother says he has been feeding well and passing adequate amounts of urine. He appears healthy. He is at the 60th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 49/min and blood pressure is 62/40 mm Hg. A grade 5/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border and a thrill is present at the same location. Echocardiography shows a 3-mm membranous ventricular septal defect. There is no evidence of ventricular enlargement and Doppler assessment of pulmonary artery pressure shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was born at term and the pregnancy was uncomplicated. His mother says he has been feeding well and passing adequate amounts of urine. He appears healthy. He is at the 60th percentile for length and 40th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 49/min and blood pressure is 62/40 mm Hg. A grade 5/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border and a thrill is present at the same location. Echocardiography shows a 3-mm membranous ventricular septal defect. There is no evidence of ventricular enlargement and Doppler assessment of pulmonary artery pressure shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis of a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is the most common congenital heart defect (CHD) and causes a holosystolic murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border. Small VSDs (diameter ≤ 3 mm) cause less left-to-right shunting but result in louder murmurs when compared to medium or large VSDs.
learning_objective: Recognize a small ventricular septal defect, and choose the most appropriate management for an asymptomatic patient.

answers.explanation_why: Antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis (e.g., using amoxicillin) is only indicated for patients who are about to undergo certain high-risk procedures (e.g., tooth extraction) and have certain high-risk cardiac features such as a history of recent CHD repair (within the past 6 months), a residual defect after repair of the CHD, or an unrepaired cyanotic CHD. As per current guidelines, patients with unrepaired noncyanotic CHDs such as VSD do not require antibiotic prophylaxis against infective endocarditis.

Surgical closure of VSDs before the age of 2 years is indicated for patients who have persistent heart failure symptoms or develop certain echocardiographic findings (e.g., left ventricular dilation, reversible pulmonary hypertension). This patient is asymptomatic and has no signs of complications. The patients who are most likely to develop complications and therefore require early surgical closure have medium or large VSDs; these VSDs manifest with softer murmurs and are typically not associated with a cardiac thrill.

Prostaglandin E_1 (PGE_1) therapy is used to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and is indicated for duct-dependent CHDs (e.g., pulmonary atresia, transposition of the great vessels, hypoplastic left heart syndrome). Patients with duct-dependent CHDs typically present with cyanosis and/or shock within 24 hours of birth, in contrast to this asymptomatic neonate. This patient has a VSD, which causes a left-to-right shunt, as would a PDA. Treatment with PGE_1 could actually worsen this patient's shunting and cause heart failure.

Small VSDs typically close spontaneously without complication, so asymptomatic patients should be reevaluated at 6 months of age for spontaneous closure. If the patient remains asymptomatic at a 6-month follow-up but their murmur persists, reevaluation at 1 year of age is indicated. Asymptomatic patients should subsequently be reevaluated every 2 years.

If symptoms of heart failure (e.g., tachypnea, distress during feeding, failure to thrive) arise, patients should be referred for evaluation and medical therapy (diuretics, immunoprophylaxis, nutritional support). Surgical closure is indicated for patients who remain symptomatic despite medical therapy or develop certain echocardiographic findings (e.g., left ventricular dilation, reversible pulmonary hypertension).

Indomethacin is used to induce closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which can be asymptomatic but would manifest with a characteristic machine-like continuous murmur on cardiac auscultation. This patient's auscultatory and echocardiographic findings indicate a different diagnosis, for which indomethacin therapy is not indicated.

Cardiac catheterization was commonly used in the past to confirm chamber pressures in the workup of VSDs. However, Doppler echocardiography has largely replaced catheterization in the initial workup of VSD, as it provides almost all of the same information without the associated risks of an invasive procedure.

In a patient with a VSD, cardiac catheterization would be indicated prior to surgical repair if pulmonary hypertension were suspected based on clinical (e.g., loud P_2) or echocardiographic findings. Cardiac catheterization is done to measure the reactivity of pulmonary vasculature to vasodilators because irreversible pulmonary artery hypertension is a contraindication to closure of the VSD.

Closure of the VSD with an Amplatzer^® device via cardiac catheterization is generally reserved for patients with a residual VSD after surgical closure, patients with contraindications for surgical closure (e.g., swiss-cheese septum, poorly accessible muscular VSDs), and for older children with small, restrictive muscular VSDs with significant left-to-right flow. Transcatheter closure is contraindicated in patients with membranous VSDs (which are the most common type of VSDs) because of the high risk of heart block after the procedure.

question_text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because his mother has noticed that he tires easily and sweats while feeding. During the past week, she has noticed that his lips and nails turn blue while crying. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation and weighed 2100 g (4 lb 10 oz); he currently weighs 2300 g (5 lb 1 oz) His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 168/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 72/42 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S_2 is present. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following factors is most responsible for this patient's cyanosis?
content_preview: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because his mother has noticed that he tires easily and sweats while feeding. During the past week, she has noticed that his lips and nails turn blue while crying. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation and weighed 2100 g (4 lb 10 oz); he currently weighs 2300 g (5 lb 1 oz) His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 168/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 72/42 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 is present. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following factors is most responsible for this patient's cyanosis?
hint: The presence of intermittent cyanosis, fatigue, and sweating during periods of exertion in a neonate with a systolic ejection murmur over the left upper sternal border and a single S_2 is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
learning_objective: Recognize tetralogy of Fallot, and recall the factors influencing cyanosis severity.

answers.explanation_why: Although right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) is one of the four features of TOF, it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. RVH is a compensatory mechanism against the outflow tract obstruction, which helps to reduce cyanosis by increasing flow through the stenotic pulmonary vasculature so that deoxygenated blood does not flow through the VSD and into the systemic circulation. However, RVH can only compensate to a small degree to improve normal circulatory flow and is, therefore, only a minor determinant of cyanosis.

answers.content: Degree of right ventricular outflow obstruction
answers.explanation_why:
In patients with TOF, the right ventricular (RV) outflow obstruction due to central pulmonary valve stenosis and hypoplasia determines the severity of cyanosis and the intensity of the systolic heart murmur. Blood preferentially flows via the path of least resistance. When there is a high degree of RV outflow obstruction, blood will flow through the VSD instead of through the pulmonary artery for oxygenation in the lungs. As a result, deoxygenated blood will enter the left ventricle via the VSD and be pumped into the aorta and systemic circulation. If there is minimal RV outflow obstruction, blood will flow through the pulmonary vasculature, and become oxygenated before reaching the left ventricle, resulting in a reduction of cyanosis. In TOF, the single S_2 can result from an attenuated pulmonary component (P_2) that is often not heard on auscultation.

Older children with TOF tend to squat during spells of hypoxia, which relieves symptoms by increasing systemic vascular resistance and, in turn, left ventricular outflow resistance. This creates higher left ventricular pressures, so that blood in the right ventricle will be directed through the pulmonary vasculature rather than the VSD. The increased blood flow across the RV outflow obstruction during squatting is also associated with an increased intensity of the ejection murmur.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.explanation_why: A ventricular septal defect (VSD) is one of the four features of TOF but it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. Rather, it is the pressure differences across the VSD that determine the degree of cyanosis. Specifically, higher right ventricular pressures and/or lower left ventricular pressures are associated with increased right-to-left shunting and, thus, with increased cyanosis.

Although an overriding aorta is one of the four features of TOF, it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. In patients with TOF, the aorta is displaced to the right ventricle, over the VSD, allowing blood from both ventricles to be pumped into the aorta. This causes deoxygenated blood to enter the systemic circulation, contributing to cyanosis. However, another factor has a greater impact on the degree of cyanosis.

Atrial septal defect (ASD) is not one of the four features of TOF. However, in a patient with TOF, the presence of a concomitant ASD could lead to greater right-to-left shunting and thus exacerbate cyanosis.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Degree of left ventricular outflow obstruction
answers.explanation_why: Left ventricular outflow obstruction (e.g., aortic stenosis) is not one of the four features of TOF. However, if aortic stenosis (or any form of increased left ventricular outflow resistance) was present, this would decrease right-to-left shunting by creating higher left-sided pressures and thus reduce, rather than increase, cyanosis.

question_text: A 4-day-old male infant is brought to the physician because of respiratory distress and bluish discoloration of his lips and tongue. He was born at term and the antenatal period was uncomplicated. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 70/46 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border. A single S_2 that does not split with respiration is present. Echocardiography shows defects in the interatrial and interventricular septae, as well as an imperforate muscular septum between the right atrium and right ventricle. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 4-day-old male infant is brought to the physician because of respiratory distress and bluish discoloration of his lips and tongue. He was born at term and the antenatal period was uncomplicated. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 70/46 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. A grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border. A single S2 that does not split with respiration is present. Echocardiography shows defects in the interatrial and interventricular septae, as well as an imperforate muscular septum between the right atrium and right ventricle. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: In this cyanotic neonate, an imperforate atrioventricular septum in the right side confirms the diagnosis of tricuspid valve atresia (TVA).
learning_objective: Recognize tricuspid valve atresia, and recall the associated electrocardiogram finding.

answers.content: Increased pulmonary vascular markings on chest x-ray
answers.explanation_why:
Increased pulmonary vascular markings on chest x-ray due to pulmonary vascular congestion is seen in certain cyanotic congenital heart defects such as transposition of the great arteries (TGA), which would manifest with postnatal cyanosis, tachypnea, and a single loud S_2. However, echocardiography revealed tricuspid atresia, in which pulmonary blood flow and thus pulmonary vascular markings are decreased because of the concomitant pulmonary outflow tract obstruction.

In approximately 25% of cases of tricuspid valve atresia, no pulmonary stenosis is present. In these patients, the presence of a large, nonrestrictive ventricular septal defect (VSD) or a concomitant TGA may result in increased pulmonary blood flow and increased pulmonary markings. However, in those cases, auscultation would reveal a wide split S_2.

images.title: Transposition of the great vessels (TGV)
images.description: TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.

answers.explanation_why: Tracheal bowing and narrowing on an x-ray is characteristic of a double aortic arch, which may manifest with cyanosis and tachypnea due to respiratory distress among newborns as a result of tracheal compression. However, patients would usually have stridor on examination. A double aortic arch would not explain the holosytolic murmur, the single S_2, or the echocardiographic findings.

images.title: Double aortic arch
images.description: Ventral view of mediastinal structuresThere is constriction of the trachea and esophagus as a result of the additional aortic arch (vascular ring anomaly).

answers.explanation_why:
In TVA, blood is unable to pass from the right atrium (RA) to the right ventricle (RV). Consequently, the RV is almost always hypoplastic. Venous blood, therefore, passes from the RA via an atrial septal defect (which, under these circumstances, is essential for survival) to the left atrium, where it mixes with oxygenated blood from the lungs. The mixed blood is pumped from the left ventricle (LV) into the systemic circulation (resulting in cyanosis) and pulmonary circulation (via a patent ductus arteriosus). LV hypertrophy occurs because the LV is single-handedly pumping blood through both the pulmonary and systemic circulation. A combination of RV hypoplasia and LV hypertrophy results in a severe left-axis deviation. Other findings that may be present on ECG include tall P waves (due to right atrial enlargement) and small R waves in the right precordial leads (e.g., V1, V2).

The majority of patients with TVA also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD) and concomitant pulmonary outflow obstruction. The systolic murmur at the left lower sternal border arises from a VSD. In a patient with TVA, a single S_2 that does not split with respiration indicates severely limited blood flow across the pulmonary valve and/or severe pulmonary stenosis. The systolic murmur of a VSD is softer with increasing severity of pulmonary stenosis and/or increasing size of the defect, because both result in a decreased pressure gradient across the VSD. Prostaglandin-E1 is given to maintain PDA patency (thereby increasing pulmonary circulation and blood oxygenation), but definitive treatment is staged surgical repair.

images.title: Tricuspid valve atresia
images.description:
AA: ascending aorta
PT: pulmonary trunk
PV: pulmonary valve
RA: right atrium
SVC: superior vena cava
TV: tricuspid valve

answers.explanation_why: Elf-like features (e.g., small chin, broad forehead, hypertelorism, a depressed nasal bridge, anteverted nares) are seen in patients with Williams syndrome, which is typically associated with supravalvular aortic stenosis. Severe supravalvular aortic stenosis may result in hypotension and a systolic murmur. However, the systolic murmur is best heard at the right upper sternal border, and cyanosis would not be present. In addition, echocardiography would reveal evidence of aortic stenosis.

answers.content: Weak pulses in the femoral arteries
answers.explanation_why: Weak femoral artery pulsations are seen in patients with coarctation of the aorta, for which there is no evidence (e.g., forward diastolic flow, narrowing of the aortic lumen) in this patient. In neonates, severe coarctation of the aorta can result in cyanosis (due to a right-to-left shunt via a patent ductus arteriosus) but cyanosis would only be present in the lower limbs and trunk (differential cyanosis); the upper limbs, lips, and face would appear normal.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

answers.explanation_why: A delta wave on ECG (slurred R upstroke) is characteristic of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome (WPW). Ebstein anomaly is the congenital heart disease that is most frequently associated with WPW. Ebstein anomaly can also manifest with right atrial enlargement, atrial septal defect (ASD), holosystolic murmur (due to tricuspid regurgitation), and neonatal cyanosis (due to mixing of blood through the ASD). However, a wide split S_2 is typically present in Ebstein anomaly, not a single S_2. Moreover, Ebstein anomaly is classically associated with fetal lithium or benzodiazepine exposure, of which there is no history here (e.g., a maternal history of bipolar disorder). The absence of a tricuspid valve on echocardiography indicates a different diagnosis.

images.title: Ebstein anomaly
images.description: In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

answers.explanation_why: Collateral circulation and tortuous dilation of the posterior intercostal arteries can result in notching of the ribs in patients with coarctation of the aorta, for which there is no evidence (e.g., forward diastolic flow, narrowing of the aortic lumen) in this patient. In neonates, severe coarctation of the aorta can result in cyanosis (due to a right-to-left shunt via a patent ductus arteriosus), but it would only be present in the lower limbs and trunk (differential cyanosis); the upper limbs, lips, and face would appear normal. Moreover, rib notching typically occurs in patients with long-standing coarctation of the aorta and is unusual before the age of 5 years.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Focal indentation of the distal aortic arch is seen at the location of aortic coarctation (illustration). An additional finding is inferior rib notching (Roesler sign; examples indicated by arrowheads), which is produced by dilated intercostal arteries.The figure-3 sign of coarctation (indicated by red line) is seen in this patient. It is produced by prestenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery in combination with post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta. The presence of bilateral rib notching indicates that the coarctation is distal to the origin of both subclavian arteries.

question_text: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because his lips turned blue for several minutes while playing earlier that evening. She reports that he has had similar episodes during feeding that resolved quickly. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He is at the 25^th percentile for length and below the 5^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 83/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. During the examination, he sits calmly in his mother's lap. He appears well. The patient begins to cry when examination of his throat is attempted; his lips and fingers begin to turn blue. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because his lips turned blue for several minutes while playing earlier that evening. She reports that he has had similar episodes during feeding that resolved quickly. He was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. He is at the 25th percentile for length and below the 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 42/min, and blood pressure is 83/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 90%. During the examination, he sits calmly in his mother's lap. He appears well. The patient begins to cry when examination of his throat is attempted; his lips and fingers begin to turn blue. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The cyanotic episode described here is characteristic of the tet spells seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
learning_objective: Recognize tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), and recall its characteristic ECG finding.

answers.content: Pulmonary vascular congestion on x-ray of the chest
answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary vascular congestion seen on chest x-ray is a sign of left heart failure, with subsequent “backing up” of blood into the pulmonary vasculature, leading to enlarged pulmonary vessels. Although this finding is classically associated with congestive heart failure in adults (especially in older individuals), some congenital cardiac defects can also cause this finding (e.g., truncus arteriosus, total anomalous pulmonary venous return). In TOF (the most likely diagnosis in this case), there is a right ventricular outflow obstruction, leading to decreased blood flow to the pulmonary vasculature. Chest x-ray would more likely show decreased pulmonary vascular markings and a classic boot-shaped heart.

answers.content: Decreased blood pressure in both lower extremities
answers.explanation_why: Decreased blood pressure in the lower extremities is characteristic of aortic coarctation, which manifests with differential cyanosis (e.g., of the lower extremities) rather than central cyanosis (e.g., blue lips and fingers) as seen in this patient. Moreover, aortic coarctation rarely causes hypoxemia; in the rare case of hypoxemia, it is usually mild. Finally, aortic coarctation causes chronic rather than episodic symptoms.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

answers.explanation_why: Right axis deviation on ECG is typically seen in patients with TOF due to right ventricular hypertrophy. The thickened myocardium in the right ventricle produces increased electrical activity, which shifts the axis of cardiac depolarization. TOF also involves an overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, and pulmonary stenosis. It is the most common congenital cyanotic heart lesion. In addition to these ECG findings, a chest x-ray showing a boot-shaped heart also supports the diagnosis. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.explanation_why: A machine-like murmur over the heart is pathognomonic for patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). PDA is usually an acyanotic congenital condition because most blood passes through normal circulation and thus sufficient oxygen saturation is maintained; only a small amount of blood is pumped through the PDA. Symptoms can vary depending on the degree of patency but may include tachycardia, tachypnea, and poor growth. The infant described here is lagging behind in terms of weight gain, but vital signs are within the normal range for a 5-month old infant (HR 80–160/min, RR 30–60/min). Finally, PDA causes continuous symptoms, as opposed to the episodic symptoms described for this patient.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Anomalous pulmonary venous return on MR angiography
answers.explanation_why: Anomalous pulmonary venous return on MR angiography would be diagnostic of total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). Although TAPVR is survivable and can cause central cyanosis in patients with a right-to-left shunt, symptoms are continuous rather than episodic, as seen here.

images.title: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return
images.description: A congenital heart defect in which the pulmonary veins merge to form a connecting vein that drains into the systemic venous circulation (e.g., the vena cava) rather than the left atrium. Without return of blood to the left heart, there is no systemic circulation. Survival after birth depends on the presence of a right-to-left shunt (usually an atrial septal defect) to allow for blood to enter the left heart, then systemic circulation.

answers.explanation_why: A diminutive left ventricle on echocardiogram is seen in hypoplastic left heart syndrome, which can also manifest with central cyanosis. However, the cyanosis would not be episodic (as in this patient) because the hypoplastic left heart would never be able to adequately perfuse the peripheral tissues.

question_text: One day after a 4700-g (10-lb 6-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman, the newborn has bluish discoloration of the lips and fingernails. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 166/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 68/44 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. Examination shows central cyanosis. A grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border. A single second heart sound is present. Supplemental oxygen does not improve cyanosis. An x-ray of the chest shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with a narrowed mediastinum. Further evaluation of the mother is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: One day after a 4700-g (10-lb 6-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman, the newborn has bluish discoloration of the lips and fingernails. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 166/min, respirations are 63/min, and blood pressure is 68/44 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 81%. Examination shows central cyanosis. A grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard over the left lower sternal border. A single second heart sound is present. Supplemental oxygen does not improve cyanosis. An x-ray of the chest shows an enlarged cardiac silhouette with a narrowed mediastinum. Further evaluation of the mother is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Cyanosis shortly after birth that does not improve with supplemental oxygen and a chest x-ray with the classic egg-on-a-string appearance (i.e., an enlarged heart with narrowed mediastinum due to an overlapping aorta and pulmonary trunk) are suggestive of a diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries (TGA). The holosystolic murmur indicates a coexistent ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is critical for life, as it allows for the mixing of oxygenated blood and its entry into the systemic circulation, especially after ductus arteriosus closure.
learning_objective: Recognize transposition of the great arteries, and recall the maternal condition associated with it.

answers.explanation_why: An increased serum TSH concentration suggests hypothyroidism. Subclinical maternal hypothyroidism can increase the risk for future cognitive impairment, but it is not associated with TGA.

Prenatal alcohol consumption can cause fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD). FASD can manifest with a wide range of cardiac abnormalities, including atrial septal defects, VSD, and great heart vessel defects. However, structural heart defects also typically manifest in combination with other more characteristic FASD findings, such as facial abnormalities (e.g., short palpebral fissures, thin vermillion border, smooth philtrum).

images.title: Clinical findings in fetal alcohol syndrome

answers.explanation_why: Prenatal phenytoin intake is associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome. Although cases of congenital heart defects have been reported with maternal phenytoin use, TGA is rare. Furthermore, fetal hydantoin syndrome manifests with nail hypoplasia, hypoplasia of the digits, and abnormal facial features, none of which is seen in this patient.

Prenatal lithium intake is associated with Ebstein anomaly. This anomaly has a wide range of clinical presentations, including congenital cyanosis from right-to-left shunting. Depending on the severity of the anomaly, patients can develop a holosystolic murmur (due to tricuspid regurgitation), as heard in this patient. However, chest x-ray shows a box-shaped heart (due to the severe right-sided cardiomegaly from hypertrophy), not the egg-on-a-string sign seen in this patient. Furthermore, lithium intake is not associated with TGA.

images.title: Ebstein anomaly
images.description: In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

answers.explanation_why: A positive rapid plasma reagin test suggests a diagnosis of maternal syphilis, which can infect the infant in utero. Most cases of early congenital syphilis are asymptomatic at birth; symptoms do not typically develop until 5 weeks of life. If symptomatic at birth, findings include hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, nasal discharge, generalized lymphadenopathy, skeletal abnormalities, and pemphigus syphiliticus, none of which are seen in this patient. TGA is not associated with congenital syphilis.

TGA is a cyanotic heart condition that is associated with maternal diabetes (see “Commonly associated conditions and risk factors of cyanotic congenital heart defects” table). Mothers with untreated diabetes will have an elevated HbA1c. Other potential neonatal complications from maternal diabetes include macrosomia (seen in this patient), polycythemia, hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and respiratory distress syndrome.

Alprostadil (PGE1) can be administered to this patient to help maintain a patent ductus arteriosus, which allows some oxygenated blood from the pulmonary veins to enter the systemic circulation through the aorta. This is a temporizing measure; surgical correction is the definitive treatment.

images.title: Intracardiac shunt in the transposition of the great vessels
images.description: In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).
