question_text:
A 3-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of yellowing of his skin and eyes. His urine has been clear and stools have been normal. He was born at term by vacuum-assisted delivery and weighed 4000 g (8 lb 8 oz). He is exclusively breastfed. His older sibling had jaundice in the neonatal period. Vital signs are within normal limits. He appears alert and comfortable. Physical examination shows jaundice of the skin and sclerae. There is swelling over the right parietal bone with boundaries limited to the cranial suture lines. The liver is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
17 g/dL

Reticulocyte count
0.5%

Serum

 Bilirubin, total

21.2 mg/dL

 Direct
2 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 3-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of yellowing of his skin and eyes. His urine has been clear and stools have been normal. He was born at term by vacuum-assisted delivery and weighed 4000 g (8 lb 8 oz). He is exclusively breastfed. His older sibling had jaundice in the neonatal period. Vital signs are within normal limits. He appears alert and comfortable. Physical examination shows jaundice of the skin and sclerae. There is swelling over the right parietal bone with boundaries limited to the cranial suture lines. The liver is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 17 g/dL Reticulocyte count 0.5% Serum Bilirubin, total 21.2 mg/dL Direct 2 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This newborn presents with features and laboratory parameters consistent with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia without encephalopathy.
learning_objective: Recognize unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a newborn, and choose the first-line treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous immunoglobulin is used to treat newborns with hyperbilirubinemia secondary to immune-mediated hemolytic anemia (e.g., from Rhesus incompatibility). This newborn's laboratory tests show no signs of hemolysis (normal reticulocyte count and hemoglobin level).

An increased frequency of breastfeeds is recommended in the management of breastfeeding jaundice. In this condition, the lack of calories due to insufficient breast milk intake and subsequently reduced bowel movements lead to a failure to excrete bilirubin, thereby increasing the enterohepatic circulation and reabsorption of bilirubin from the intestines. Jaundice usually develops within the first week. Since this infant is exclusively breastfed without showing signs of weight loss, breastfeeding jaundice is unlikely. Moreover, his high bilirubin levels demand prompt intervention to prevent complications.

Replacing breastfeeding with formula feeds is a treatment option for breast milk jaundice. In this condition, elevated concentrations of β-glucuronidase in breast milk lead to increased deconjugation and reabsorption of bilirubin, thereby causing hyperbilirubinemia. Clinically, jaundice manifests ∼ 1–2 weeks after birth with a simultaneous peak in bilirubin levels, which is unlikely to have developed yet in this 3-day-old newborn. Moreover, his high bilirubin levels demand prompt intervention to prevent complications.

Observation of newborns with jaundice is sufficient if bilirubin levels are below the threshold for therapy (e.g., < 18 mg/dL in a 3-day-old newborn). Since this newborn has a bilirubin level of 21.2 mg/dL, intervention is indicated. Delayed or inadequate treatment increases the risk of developing severe hyperbilirubinemia, with the possibility of either acute or chronic neurological damage (e.g., acute bilirubin encephalopathy, kernicterus).

An MRI is indicated to confirm brain damage in rare cases of neonatal jaundice where bilirubin encephalopathy is suspected. However, the diagnosis of both acute bilirubin encephalopathy and kernicterus is more commonly established based on clinical features, and MRI provides little further data. Since this child is alert and shows no signs of distress or typical neurological deficits (e.g., hypotonia, shrill cry, lethargy), bilirubin encephalopathy can be ruled out.

Phototherapy is the first-line treatment in neonates with total serum bilirubin levels above a threshold specific to age and risk factors (as designated by the American Academy of Pediatrics). In a 3-day-old term newborn who is medically well and lacks certain risk factors (e.g., lethargy, G6PD deficiency, isoimmune hemolytic disease), this threshold is at ≥ 18 mg/dL. If treatment is not initiated swiftly, the risk of neurotoxic damage (e.g., kernicterus) due to hyperbilirubinemia increases.

Exclusively breastfed newborns are at increased risk of developing neonatal jaundice. This patient's jaundice is most likely caused by cephalohematoma acquired during vacuum-assisted delivery. Hemolysis of erythrocytes within the hematoma results in hyperbilirubinemia.

images.title: Neonatal phototherapy
images.description: Neonate under a phototherapy lampExcept for the diaper and socks, the neonate is undressed to expose the greatest skin surface area. The phototherapy goggles protect from potential retinal damage.

answers.explanation_why: Exchange transfusion is indicated in newborns with total bilirubin serum levels above the age-adjusted threshold (≥ 24 mg/dL in a 3-day-old term newborn), an inadequate response to phototherapy, a rapid rise in total serum bilirubin levels, or signs of neurotoxicity (e.g., hypotonia, lethargy, shrill cry).

question_text:
A 33-year-old primigravid woman comes for a follow-up prenatal visit at 18 weeks' gestation. Ultrasonography at 12 weeks' gestation showed a nuchal translucency above the 99^th percentile. At that visit, pregnancy-associated plasma protein A was decreased to 2 standard deviations below the mean. A chorionic villus sampling was performed, which showed a 47, XX karyotype. At today's visit, vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with an 18-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows shortened femur length, shortened middle phalanges of the fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a hypoplastic nasal bone. A quad screening test would most likely show which of the following sets of findings?

α-Fetoprotein
Estriol
β-hCG
Inhibin A

A
Decreased
decreased
increased
increased

B
Normal
normal
normal
normal

C
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased

D
Decreased
decreased
decreased
normal

E
Increased
normal
normal
normal
content_preview: A 33-year-old primigravid woman comes for a follow-up prenatal visit at 18 weeks' gestation. Ultrasonography at 12 weeks' gestation showed a nuchal translucency above the 99th percentile. At that visit, pregnancy-associated plasma protein A was decreased to 2 standard deviations below the mean. A chorionic villus sampling was performed, which showed a 47, XX karyotype. At today's visit, vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with an 18-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows shortened femur length, shortened middle phalanges of the fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a hypoplastic nasal bone. A quad screening test would most likely show which of the following sets of findings? α-Fetoprotein Estriol β-hCG Inhibin A A Decreased decreased increased increased B Normal normal normal normal C Decreased decreased decreased decreased D Decreased decreased decreased normal E Increased normal normal normal
hint: Increased nuchal translucency, decreased pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) levels, shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a hypoplastic nasal bone in a fetus with a 47, XX karyotype are features highly suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).
learning_objective: Recognize Down syndrome, and recall its prenatal diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why:
The quad screen test should be performed at 15–22 weeks' gestation and can help to diagnose Down syndrome and other fetal aneuploidies (e.g., trisomy 18), as well as open neural tube and abdominal wall defects. Down syndrome pregnancies are associated with significantly decreased α-fetoprotein and free estriol levels and a marked increase in β-hCG and inhibin A levels in the maternal serum (see “Overview of quad and triple screening tests” table).

In addition to increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A levels, first trimester screening in a Down syndrome pregnancy would show increased β-hCG levels.

Normal findings in all quad screen markers are consistent with a normal fetus but are concerning for trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) in a fetus with a suspected aneuploidy (based on the 47, XX karyotype). While Patau syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings suggestive of Patau syndrome include rocker-bottom feet, microcephaly or holoprosencephaly, and polydactyly (rather than clinodactyly).

A mild decrease in all quad screen markers is consistent with Turner syndrome. Though Turner syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency (due to lymphatic dysplasia), shortened femur length, and decreased PAPP-A levels, this patient's chorionic villus sampling showed a 47, XX karyotype, which is not consistent with the 45, XO karyotype that is characteristic of Turner syndrome.

A decrease in all quad screen markers is also consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome), though inhibin A can also be normal in this condition. While Edwards syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings typical of Edwards syndrome include rocker-bottom feet and clenched fists with overlapping of the third and fourth digits by the second and fifth digits, respectively (rather than clinodactyly).

A decrease in α-fetoprotein, free estriol, and β-hCG with normal or decreased inhibin A is consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome). While Edwards syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings typical of Edwards syndrome include rocker-bottom feet and clenched fists with overlapping of the third and fourth digits by the second and fifth digits, respectively (rather than clinodactyly).

An isolated increase in α-fetoprotein during pregnancy is characteristic of fetal neural tube defects or open abdominal wall defects such as gastroschisis or omphalocele. While some of these defects (such as omphalocele) may be associated with an increase in nuchal translucency, first-trimester fetal screening would show normal PAPP-A levels and a 46, XX karyotype. Furthermore, none of these conditions would involve shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, or a hypoplastic nasal bone.

question_text: A 37-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician at 13 weeks' gestation for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her only medication is folic acid. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 13-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows a nuchal translucency above the 99^th percentile. Maternal serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A is decreased and human chorionic gonadotropin concentrations are elevated to 2 times the median level. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 37-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician at 13 weeks' gestation for a prenatal visit. She feels well. Her only medication is folic acid. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 13-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows a nuchal translucency above the 99th percentile. Maternal serum pregnancy-associated plasma protein A is decreased and human chorionic gonadotropin concentrations are elevated to 2 times the median level. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: Increased nuchal translucency, elevated β-hCG levels, and decreased pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) indicate a high risk of Down syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize the high risk of Down syndrome, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Chorionic villus sampling for fetal chromosomal analysis is the method of choice to confirm fetal aneuploidy at 10 to 13 weeks' gestation and should be offered to all patients at increased risk (e.g., abnormal first-trimester screening, maternal age ≥ 35 years, previous child with a chromosomal anomaly). From the 15^th week of pregnancy onward, amniocentesis is the preferred method for prenatal genetic diagnosis.

The quadruple marker test is performed at 15–22 weeks' gestation and involves measurements of alpha-fetoprotein, unconjugated estriol, β-hCG, and inhibin A in maternal serum to screen for fetal chromosomal disorders. Since this patient's first-trimester screening already indicated a risk for Down syndrome, more definitive testing rather than further screening should be performed.

Cell-free fetal DNA (cffDNA) testing of maternal blood can be used to screen for fetal aneuploidies. Because of its low false-positive rate for Down syndrome, cffDNA testing is commonly used as a secondary screening test in patients at high risk (e.g., maternal age ≥ 35 years, abnormal first-trimester screening results) in order to avoid invasive procedures. However, cffDNA testing is not diagnostic and fetal chromosomal analysis using an invasive test is still required to confirm Down syndrome.

The triple screening test takes into account serum levels of α-fetoprotein, unconjugated estriol, and β-hCG (free or total). It should be performed in the second trimester, usually between 15–22 weeks of gestation. Since this patient's first-trimester screening already indicated a risk for Down syndrome, more definitive testing rather than further screening should be performed.

Amniocentesis is indicated as a prenatal diagnostic procedure to further evaluate for fetal genetic abnormalities in patients with abnormal screening results. However, it is usually only performed at 15–20 weeks of gestation, as it is associated with a high risk of complications in the first trimester. This patient is only 13 weeks pregnant and should therefore not undergo amniocentesis.

question_text: A 2720-g (6-lb) female newborn is delivered at term to a 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores are 6 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows micrognathia, prominent occiput with flattened nasal bridge, and pointy low-set ears.  The fists are clenched with fingers tightly flexed. The index finger overlaps the third finger and the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border. The nipples are widely spaced and the feet have prominent heels and convex, rounded soles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 2720-g (6-lb) female newborn is delivered at term to a 39-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores are 6 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows micrognathia, prominent occiput with flattened nasal bridge, and pointy low-set ears. The fists are clenched with fingers tightly flexed. The index finger overlaps the third finger and the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. A 3/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the lower left sternal border. The nipples are widely spaced and the feet have prominent heels and convex, rounded soles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: A second-trimester quadruple screening test would have shown ↓ free estriol, ↓ AFP, ↔ inhibin A, and ↓ β-HCG.
learning_objective: Recognize trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome).

answers.explanation_why:
Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is a genetic syndrome characterized by certain congenital anomalies that are also present in this patient, including low-set ears, flexed fingers, and signs of a congenital cardiac defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of ventricular septal defect). However, other key features of trisomy 13 would also be expected, such as cleft lip and palate, microphthalmia, and polydactyly.

Second-trimester quadruple screening test for Patau syndrome would show normal levels of free estriol, AFP, Inhibin A, and β-HCG

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) is the most common chromosomal disorder seen in live births. Infants with trisomy 21 are usually diagnosed based on a combination of classic clinical features including brachycephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, protuberant tongue, flattened nasal bridge, hypertelorism), a single transverse palmar crease, and sandal gap deformity. This child does exhibit some features of Down syndrome, e.g., flattened nasal bridge and upward slanting eyes with small palpebral fissures, but the absence of all other typical features makes this diagnosis highly unlikely.

Second-trimester quadruple screening test for Down syndrome would show ↓ free estriol, ↓ AFP, ↑ Inhibin A, and ↑ β-HCG.

Maternal alcohol intake during pregnancy is the most common cause of teratogenic damage in children. It manifests in a spectrum of features, which are collectively referred to as fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS). This child does present with a few common features of FAS, such as narrow palpebral fissures, micrognathia, and evidence of a congenital cardiac anomaly. However, she lacks most other typical features, such as a hypoplastic philtrum, down-slanting and widely spaced palpebral fissures, and a narrow forehead. Moreover, this patient's rocker-bottom feet, low-set ears, clenched fists, and prominent occiput would not be seen in FAS.

Monosomy X (45,XO) is the karyotype associated with Turner syndrome, which is a common disorder of sex development in females. However, apart from the widely spaced nipples, there are no features typical for Turner syndrome, e.g., lymphedema of the limbs, high arched palate, and webbed neck, present in this child.

This genotype is associated with Cri-du-chat syndrome. The most characteristic feature of the resulting disorder is cat-like, high-pitched crying, which is not present in this child. Other features that this child has in common with Cri-du-chat syndrome are a likely congenital heart defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of VSD) and low birth weight. However, the girl is lacking the typical facial anomalies (e.g., epicanthus, moon facies, widely spaced eyes) and microcephaly.

Fragile X syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder. This condition is characterized by varying degrees of intellectual disability, increased height and head circumference, and prominent ears. This female patient is very unlikely to have fragile X syndrome because it is most commonly symptomatic in males. Moreover, the physical features typically manifest most clearly during adolescence and are rarely noticeable at birth. The anomalies described in this infant, the age, and the gender are all not consistent with a diagnosis of fragile X syndrome.

This infant's features are consistent with trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome). Classic features include a characteristic craniofacial morphology (micrognathia, prominent occiput, and pointy, low-set ears), clenched fists with flexion contractures of the fingers, and rocker-bottom feet (convex foot deformity with prominent heel). The infant also presents with other features that are commonly associated with the syndrome, such as a congenital heart defect (holosystolic murmur suggestive of ventricular septal defect), and low birth weight (suggestive of intrauterine growth restriction).

The prognosis for trisomy 18 is poor, with only up to 10% of infants surviving past 12 months of age.

question_text:
A 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because he is concerned that she appears sickly and lethargic. She has always had a pale complexion, but it has been getting worse over the past month. She was delivered at home at 36 weeks to a 26-year-old woman following an uncomplicated pregnancy. She has not yet been examined by a physician. She is at the 10th percentile for length, 8th percentile for weight, and 2nd percentile for head circumference. Physical examination shows a pale infant with facial features of micrognathia, flat nasal bridge, and microopthalmos. The eyes are set widely apart and strabismus is present. She has a high arched palate and there is fusion of the cervical vertebrae with flaring of the skin around the neck. A grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best on the left chest. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
6.6 g/dL

Hematocrit
20%

Leukocytes
5400/mm^3

Platelets
183,000/mm^3

Mean corpuscular hemoglobin
41.3 pg/cell

Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration
33% Hb/cell

Mean corpuscular volume
125 μm^3

This patient is most likely to have which of the following findings?

She has always had a pale complexion, but it has been getting worse over the past month. She was delivered at home at 36 weeks to a 26-year-old woman following an uncomplicated pregnancy. She has not yet been examined by a physician. She is at the 10th percentile for length, 8th percentile for weight, and 2nd percentile for head circumference. Physical examination shows a pale infant with facial features of micrognathia, flat nasal bridge, and microopthalmos. The eyes are set widely apart and strabismus is present. She has a high arched palate and there is fusion of the cervical vertebrae with flaring of the skin around the neck. A grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur is heard best on the left chest. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 6.6 g/dL Hematocrit 20% Leukocytes 5400/mm3 Platelets 183,000/mm3 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin 41.3 pg/cell Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration 33% Hb/cell Mean corpuscular volume 125 μm3 This patient is most likely to have which of the following findings?
hint: This infant has Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) based on a pronounced normochromic, macrocytic anemia with normal leukocytes and platelets. She also has many nonspecific dysmorphic features that are typical of the disease, including microcephaly, micrognathia, hypertelorism, microphthalmia, a webbed neck, and a VSD.
learning_objective: Recognize Diamond-Blackfan anemia and its association with triphalangeal thumb.

answers.explanation_why: Mild neutropenia can be seen in over 50% of patients with transient erythroblastopenia of childhood (TEC), which can also manifest as a pure red cell aplasia. However, patients with TEC are otherwise normal and do not have congenital malformations (e.g., microcephaly, micrognathia, hypertelorism, microphthalmia, webbed neck, VSD). Furthermore, patients with TEC have normocytic anemia, not macrocytic anemia.

Spherocytes can be seen in hereditary spherocytosis, which can manifest with anemia. However, hereditary spherocytosis is a hemolytic anemia, which causes hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice. Furthermore, spherocytes have an increased MCHC, meaning RBCs are hyperchromic, not normochromic. Since it is typically inherited in an autosomal dominant fashion (recessive also possible), most patients will also have a positive family history (although spontaneous mutations occur in approx. 25% of cases).

Triphalangeal thumb is one of several congenital malformations associated with Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA), although some children will appear physically normal despite the condition. Classic DBA is established when the following diagnostic criteria are met: < 1 year of age, macrocytic anemia with no significant other cytopenias, reticulocytopenia, and normal bone marrow cellularity with paucity of erythroid precursors. This patient will require a bone marrow biopsy for a definitive diagnosis. Treatment consists of corticosteroids with or without blood transfusions.

images.title: Triphalangeal thumb
images.description: X-ray right and left thumb (PA view)A small triangular bone (delta phalanx, or longitudinal epiphyseal bracket; red overlay) is present between the proximal and distal phalanx of each thumb. There is ulnar deviation of the distal thumbs.A delta phalanx can appear as an isolated finding or as part of a wide variety of congenital syndromes and dysplasias.

answers.explanation_why: Target cells can be seen on blood smears in thalassemia, and severe forms of this disease can manifest with profound anemia a few months after birth when fetal hemoglobin levels decline. However, in thalassemia, the anemia is microcytic and hypochromic, not macrocytic and normochromic. Furthermore, dysmorphic features are not associated with thalassemia.

Cafe-au-lait spots are associated with Fanconi anemia. Although patients with Fanconi anemia will have macrocytic anemia, these patients are usually older at presentation than this patient (average age of diagnosis is 8 years) and will have progressive pancytopenia rather than pure red cell aplasia. Various skeletal and organ abnormalities are associated with Fanconi anemia, including hypoplastic thumbs.

Exocrine pancreatic dysfunction is seen in Shwachman-Diamond syndrome, which can cause dysmorphic features and varied hematologic abnormalities due to bone marrow failure. Although patients can have macrocytic anemia, the most common presentation includes neutropenia and recurrent infections, and/or steatorrhea from pancreas insufficiency, none of which are seen in this patient.

Blueberry muffin rash is associated with various prenatal TORCH infections (e.g., rubella, parvovirus B19), which can manifest with pallor, congenital malformations, and anemia. However, anemia due to congenital viral infections is usually normocytic, not macrocytic.

images.title: Blueberry muffin syndrome
images.description: Newborn with acute myeloid leukemia (AML)Multiple bluish-purple macules and nodules are distributed across the face and scalp, with a few extending onto the torso. Jaundice is also present.This appearance is termed “blueberry muffin syndrome.” Differential diagnoses include hematological disorders, other malignancies, and congenital infections (the jaundice in this case may be related to the underlying AML but is not part of the blueberry muffin appearance itself).

answers.explanation_why:
Hypersegmented neutrophils can be seen in folate deficiency, which can manifest with macrocytic anemia as also seen in this patient. It is possible for infants with restricted diets (i.e., feeding exclusively with goat milk, which is deficient in folic acid) or malabsorption issues to develop folate deficiency with anemia. However, folate deficiency would not explain this patient's dysmorphic features.

Hypersegmented neutrophils are also present in vitamin B_12 deficiency, which can additionally manifest with neurological manifestations.

question_text: Two days after delivery, a 2450-g (5-lb 6-oz) male newborn has three episodes of green vomitus. He has passed urine twice daily but has not yet passed stool. He was born at 34 weeks' gestation. He appears irritable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 161/min, respirations are 56/min, and blood pressure is 62/44 mm Hg. Examination shows a distended abdomen; there is diffuse tenderness to palpation over the abdomen. Bowel sounds are decreased. Digital rectal examination is unremarkable. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the abdomen shows dilated bowel loops. Contrast enema demonstrates inspissated meconium plugs in the distal ileum and microcolon. This patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following?
content_preview: Two days after delivery, a 2450-g (5-lb 6-oz) male newborn has three episodes of green vomitus. He has passed urine twice daily but has not yet passed stool. He was born at 34 weeks' gestation. He appears irritable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 161/min, respirations are 56/min, and blood pressure is 62/44 mm Hg. Examination shows a distended abdomen; there is diffuse tenderness to palpation over the abdomen. Bowel sounds are decreased. Digital rectal examination is unremarkable. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the abdomen shows dilated bowel loops. Contrast enema demonstrates inspissated meconium plugs in the distal ileum and microcolon. This patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following?
hint: A distended abdomen and bilious vomiting in a newborn should raise suspicion for a bowel obstruction. Imaging studies confirm small bowel obstruction with meconium plugs in the distal ileum and microcolon. These findings indicate meconium ileus.
learning_objective: Recognize meconium ileus, and recall complications of cystic fibrosis.

answers.explanation_why: Meconium ileus is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF), which may lead to diabetes later in life (CF-related diabetes) caused by the destruction of pancreatic islet cells as a result of chronic pancreatic duct obstruction. CF is not, however, associated with type I diabetes mellitus.

Meconium ileus is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). If the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) protein is defective, viscous mucus obstructs the formation of the vas deferens during the development of the genital tract. This obstruction results in the congenital bilateral absence of the vas deferens in ∼ 98% of male individuals with CF, leading to infertility. Additionally, individuals with CF may have a decreased sperm count, which supports the theory that CFTR might also play a direct role in sperm maturation and development. However, spermatogenesis may be intact and individuals with CF can still have children via sperm retrieval and in vitro fertilization.

Delayed passage of meconium can be seen in Hirschsprung disease, which is associated with Down syndrome (and, consequently, Alzheimer disease). Children with Hirschsprung disease demonstrate failure to pass meconium in the first 24–48 hours. However, the obstruction is most commonly located in the rectal or sigmoid colon (the location of aganglionic colon) and not in the distal ileum (from inspissated meconium causing meconium ileus).

Meconium ileus is associated with cystic fibrosis (CF). While both CF and asthma may cause obstructive lung disease, CF causes chronic respiratory infections and bronchiectasis and is not associated with asthma (which is characterized by bronchial hyperresponsiveness and reversible airway obstruction).

This patient's presentation of meconium ileus is suggestive of cystic fibrosis (CF). While CF can cause fat-soluble vitamin deficiency from exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, there is no association with water-soluble vitamin deficiencies like thiamine deficiency.

question_text: A 4-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned that he is losing weight. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 2980 g (6 lb 9 oz); he currently weighs 2830 g (6 lb 4 oz). Pregnancy was uncomplicated. He passed stool and urine 8 and 10 hours after delivery. He has been exclusively breastfed since birth and feeds 11–12 times daily. His mother says she changes 5–6 heavy diapers daily. Examination shows an open and soft anterior fontanelle. Mucous membranes are moist. Capillary refill time is less than 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned that he is losing weight. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 2980 g (6 lb 9 oz); he currently weighs 2830 g (6 lb 4 oz). Pregnancy was uncomplicated. He passed stool and urine 8 and 10 hours after delivery. He has been exclusively breastfed since birth and feeds 11–12 times daily. His mother says she changes 5–6 heavy diapers daily. Examination shows an open and soft anterior fontanelle. Mucous membranes are moist. Capillary refill time is less than 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This newborn has lost ∼ 5% of his weight since birth.
learning_objective: Recognize normal neonatal weight loss, and choose the most appropriate management for a healthy exclusively breastfed newborn.

answers.explanation_why: Checking serum electrolytes would be a good measure if dehydration was suspected, in which case hypernatremia would be a likely finding. However, an open and soft anterior fontanelle with no diarrhea and/or lethargy means that dehydration is extremely unlikely.

Soy-based formula is indicated for infants with galactosemia, lactase deficiency, or cow milk protein allergy. Since this child has no symptoms that would indicate a pathology (diarrhea, excessive weight loss, dehydration, fatigue, lethargy), there is no need to switch to a soy-based formula.

Checking serum electrolytes would be a good measure if dehydration was suspected, in which case renal function tests (e.g., serum creatinine and urea nitrogen) could reveal more information about the cause of dehydration (e.g., impaired water reabsorption). However, an open and soft anterior fontanelle with no diarrhea and/or lethargy means that dehydration is extremely unlikely.
Solid food should not be introduced before about 4 months of age, as the infant's digestive system cannot yet handle it.

Adding cow's milk-based formula can be considered if weight loss is prolonged and/or excessive. This neonate has lost ∼ 5% of weight since birth, which is well within the normal limit of < 7% for exclusively breastfed neonates aged ≤ 5 days.
For neonates aged ≤ 5 days, daily weight checks are indicated if weight loss exceeds 7% or if the weight is not regained after five days.

A weight loss of < 7% is normal in exclusively breastfed neonates in the first five days of life. The weight loss is the result of reduced intake and urinary excretion of excess fluid. This patient's physical examination findings are consistent with those of a healthy newborn (e.g., soft anterior fontanelle, moist mucous membranes, capillary refill time < 2 seconds); therefore, breastfeeding can be continued. The weight is then gained back by the age of 10–14 days by drinking breast milk and/or formula. This patient has only lost ∼ 5% of weight, which is still well within the normal limits.

question_text: A 3580-g (7-lb 14-oz) male newborn is delivered at 36 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1 after an uncomplicated pregnancy. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 96/min, and respirations are 55/min and irregular. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 65% measured in the right hand. He sneezes and grimaces during suction of secretions from his mouth. There is some flexion movement. The trunk is pink and the extremities are blue. The cord is clamped and the newborn is dried and wrapped in a prewarmed towel. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 3580-g (7-lb 14-oz) male newborn is delivered at 36 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1 after an uncomplicated pregnancy. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 96/min, and respirations are 55/min and irregular. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 65% measured in the right hand. He sneezes and grimaces during suction of secretions from his mouth. There is some flexion movement. The trunk is pink and the extremities are blue. The cord is clamped and the newborn is dried and wrapped in a prewarmed towel. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Infants who are born prematurely, lack muscle tone, or are not breathing or crying may require neonatal resuscitation.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for neonatal resuscitation, and choose the initial resuscitation step.

answers.explanation_why: Naloxone was formerly recommended in infants with respiratory depression and a history of maternal narcotic analgesic use before delivery. This newborn has an impaired respiratory effort (as indicated by his irregular respiratory rate), but there is no history of the mother having used narcotic analgesics. Moreover, the treatment is no longer recommended because of unclear efficacy. Regardless, a different step is more important in correcting hypoxia and would take priority.

Intramuscular vitamin K is given to all newborns as a part of routine care to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn. Since this child was born preterm and has a heart rate < 100/minute, neonatal resuscitation is required. While intramuscular vitamin K injection is certainly indicated, it should be delayed until the newborn has been adequately resuscitated.

Routine care with initiation of skin-to-skin contact with the mother is initiated soon after delivery for term neonates who are breathing well and have a good muscle tone. This child was born preterm and has a heart rate < 100 / minute; neonatal resuscitation is therefore required.

1% erythromycin is routinely applied to the lower conjunctival sac of all newborns to prevent gonococcal neonatal conjunctivitis. However, this procedure is usually delayed for several minutes after birth even among term neonates who are breathing well and have a good muscle tone to allow mother-child bonding immediately after birth. In a preterm child with a heart rate < 100 / minute, erythromycin ointment application would be delayed until the newborn has been adequately resuscitated.

Positive pressure ventilation via bag-and-mask is indicated immediately after birth for neonates with a heart rate < 100 bpm, gasping respiratory effort, or apnea. Ventilation is initiated with 21% O_2 at a rate of 40–60 breaths/minute. While the Apgar score can be an important indicator that additional resuscitation steps are indicated, if the infant is not breathing adequately or is bradycardic, resuscitation should be initiated even before the score is assigned. Routine care with “skin-to-skin contact”, intramuscular vitamin K injections, and application of erythromycin eye ointment would be initiated once the neonate is breathing well, has a heart rate > 100 bpm, and has a good muscle tone.

images.title: Neonatal resuscitation algorithm
images.description:
CPAP: continuous positive airway pressure
CPR: cardiopulmonary resuscitation
ECG: electrocardiogram
FiO_2: fraction of inspired oxygen
HR: heart rate
PPV: positive pressure ventilation
SpO_2: oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry

answers.explanation_why: Endotracheal intubation is indicated if initial steps of resuscitation do not result in clinical improvement, are required for more than a few minutes, and/or if chest compression becomes necessary. An attempt to resuscitate this patient with less invasive methods should be made first.

Intravenous epinephrine is indicated only if the heart rate is below 60 bpm after 30–60 seconds of chest compressions have been performed. Only a small number of newborns that require resuscitation need intravenous epinephrine once all of the other resuscitative measures have been performed correctly.

question_text:
Two hours after a 2280-g (5-lb) male newborn is born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old primigravid woman, he has 2 episodes of vomiting and jitteriness. The mother has noticed that the baby is not feeding adequately. She received adequate prenatal care and admits to smoking one pack of cigarettes daily while pregnant. The newborn's temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 171/min and respirations are 60/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows facial plethora. Capillary refill time is 3 seconds. Laboratory studies show:

Hematocrit
70%

Leukocyte count
7800/mm^3

Platelet count
220,000/mm^3

Serum

 Glucose
42 mg/dL

 Calcium
8.3 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: Two hours after a 2280-g (5-lb) male newborn is born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old primigravid woman, he has 2 episodes of vomiting and jitteriness. The mother has noticed that the baby is not feeding adequately. She received adequate prenatal care and admits to smoking one pack of cigarettes daily while pregnant. The newborn's temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 171/min and respirations are 60/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows facial plethora. Capillary refill time is 3 seconds. Laboratory studies show: Hematocrit 70% Leukocyte count 7800/mm3 Platelet count 220,000/mm3 Serum Glucose 42 mg/dL Calcium 8.3 mg/dL Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: This newborn's elevated venous hematocrit (> 65%) indicates neonatal polycythemia.
learning_objective: Recognize intrauterine hypoxia as a cause of neonatal polycythemia.

answers.explanation_why: Transient tachypnea of the newborn is a common, self-resolving condition that results from excess fluid in the lungs. It classically occurs in full-term neonates born by cesarean delivery and resolves within 4 hours. This patient was not born by cesarean delivery, and transient tachypnea of the newborn would not explain his laboratory abnormalities.

While intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is a potential complication in the newborn, it most commonly occurs in infants with low birth weight (< 1500 g) or premature infants (< 32 weeks' gestation). While IVH can cause irregular respirations, this patient does not have any other symptoms to suggest IVH, including lethargy, hypotonia, irregular eye movements, seizures, or bulging anterior fontanelle. Also, IVH is not consistent with this patient's laboratory abnormalities, especially elevated hemoglobin levels.

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) is the result of a deficiency in pulmonary surfactant within the immature lungs of a premature infant. NRDS classically manifests immediately after birth in premature infants with tachypnea, nasal flaring, intercostal retractions, and/or expiratory grunting. While this patient has developed some symptoms of respiratory distress, this occurred in the first 2 hours after delivery. Furthermore, he was not born prematurely and thus, is unlikely to have NRDS.

Neonatal hyperinsulinism is a possible complication in infants born to mothers with diabetes. Exposure to maternal hyperglycemia causes excess insulin production by the fetal pancreas. Neonatal hyperinsulinism can cause hypoglycemia, which may manifest with jitteriness, poor feeding, respiratory distress, and neonatal polycythemia. However, this patient's mother does not have a history of diabetes mellitus, making hyperinsulinism unlikely. This newborn's hypoglycemia is likely due to polycythemia (from increased glucose uptake by circulating RBCs), which is caused by a different condition.

While infants of diabetic mothers may have cardiac abnormalities, this patient has no murmur to suggest congenital heart disease. Additionally, while cyanotic heart defects may cause symptoms of respiratory distress in the newborn, it would be less likely to explain this patient's laboratory abnormalities.

This patient's neonatal polycythemia is most likely due to intrauterine hypoxia. The hypoxic state leads to increased erythropoiesis, which boosts the production of RBCs to facilitate tissue oxygenation. At birth, newborns typically present with elevated venous hematocrit (> 65%), respiratory distress, cyanosis, apnea, poor feeding, hypoglycemia (due to increased glucose uptake by the circulating RBCs), and plethora. Further manifestations may include lethargy, irritability, jitteriness, seizures, and vomiting. Risk factors for developing neonatal polycythemia include maternal tobacco use, maternal diabetes, small or large size for gestational age, and delayed umbilical cord clamping.

question_text: A 2-week-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of a 1-week history of vaginal discharge. The discharge was initially clear, but now he notices that it is tinged with blood. The father is also concerned about “bruises” on his daughter's back and buttocks. Both parents work so the infant spends most of her time in daycare or with her aunt. She was born at term following a pregnancy complicated by maternal gonococcal infection that was treated with antibiotics. She appears well. Physical examination shows mild acne across her cheeks and forehead. There are multiple large flat gray-blue patches on her back and buttocks. An image of one of the lesions is shown. Firm breast buds are present. Genitourinary examination shows erythema and swelling of the vulva and vagina with an odorless, blood-stained white discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 2-week-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of a 1-week history of vaginal discharge. The discharge was initially clear, but now he notices that it is tinged with blood. The father is also concerned about “bruises” on his daughter's back and buttocks. Both parents work so the infant spends most of her time in daycare or with her aunt. She was born at term following a pregnancy complicated by maternal gonococcal infection that was treated with antibiotics. She appears well. Physical examination shows mild acne across her cheeks and forehead. There are multiple large flat gray-blue patches on her back and buttocks. An image of one of the lesions is shown. Firm breast buds are present. Genitourinary examination shows erythema and swelling of the vulva and vagina with an odorless, blood-stained white discharge. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: In utero exposure to maternal estrogen causes transient changes in many neonates.
learning_objective: Recognize the effects of maternal estrogen exposure in a neonate, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Contacting child protective services is mandatory if abuse of any kind is suspected. Sexually abused children typically present with injuries in the genital, anal, and oral areas, recurrent urinary tract infections, and sexually transmitted infections that may cause bloody vaginal discharge. The perpetrator is most commonly a male that is familiar with the child (e.g., father, uncle, neighbor). Multiple hematomas, multiple fractures at various stages of healing, and injuries that do not correlate with patient history should raise suspicion for physical abuse. While symptoms such as red, swollen labia, blood-tinged vaginal discharge, and hematomas should raise suspicions of child abuse, closer examination will reveal that, in this patient, the vaginal discharge is most likely due to a physiological process and the flat gray-blue patches on her back and buttocks are in fact due to a benign skin condition. Another course of action is therefore indicated.

The findings in this patient are common, benign neonatal conditions that do not require treatment. Blood-tinged, mucoid vaginal discharge, breast bud development, and labial swelling are all effects of intrauterine estrogen exposure. Withdrawal bleeding occurs 1–2 weeks after delivery and is self-limiting. Labial swelling also recedes after a few days. Breast bud development (and even some milky discharge) is physiological in infants of either sex. The patches on this patient's back are congenital dermal melanocytosis (Mongolian spots), which typically resolve within a few years. Because congenital dermal melanocytosis may resemble hematomas, they are often mistaken for signs of child abuse.

Combined therapy with ceftriaxone and doxycycline is indicated in patients with gonorrhea in whom coinfection with Chlamydia trachomatis has not been ruled out and for patients with coinfection. Patients with congenital gonorrhea and/or chlamydia typically present with eye discharge and conjunctivitis that can lead to visual impairment if left untreated. Although the pregnancy was complicated by maternal gonococcal infection, antibiotic treatment likely resolved the infection. Moreover, vaginal discharge in gonorrhea is purulent rather than mucoid. Finally, doxycycline should be avoided in children aged < 8 years because it forms complexes with calcium ions, thereby causing tooth discoloration and inhibited bone growth. Chlamydial infection in newborns is treated with oral erythromycin instead.

GnRH agonists (e.g., leuprolide) would be indicated for precocious puberty with elevated GnRH levels (central precocious puberty), which manifests with significant breast development, menstruation, and/or pubic hair development before the age of 8 in girls. In such cases, leuprolide decreases estrogen levels and suppresses sexual maturation. This patient has only mild breast development and scant vaginal bleeding that is more likely due to exposure to intrauterine maternal estrogen. If breast development or vaginal bleeding were more significant, a hormonal abnormality should be suspected. However, precocious puberty is very rare in infants and more commonly is seen in young children. Moreover, the use of leuprolide in children under 2 years is not recommended.

Fluconazole therapy is indicated in suspected neonatal vaginal yeast infection, which is usually vertically transmitted. Patients with yeast infection typically present with odorless, white, crumbly, and sticky vaginal discharge, strong pruritus, and an erythematous vulva and vagina. While this patient presents with erythema and swelling of the vulva and vagina with an odorless white discharge, the traces of blood in the discharge in addition to firm breast buds indicate a physiological, rather than infectious, condition.

Ceftriaxone therapy is indicated in cases of gonococcal infection. Patients with congenital gonorrhea typically present with purulent conjunctivitis (gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum) 2–7 days after birth. This condition can lead to visual impairment if left untreated. Less commonly, localized infection of the pharynx, vagina, urethra, and/or anus or disseminated gonococcal infection occur. Although the pregnancy was complicated by maternal gonococcal infection, the infection was treated by antibiotics and should have resolved. Moreover, vaginal discharge in gonorrhea is not odorless and mucoid, but purulent, yellow-green, and malodorous.

images.title: Infant with gonococcal ophthalmic disease
images.description: The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

answers.explanation_why: An MRI of the brain is indicated in suspected central precocious puberty, which would manifest with breast development before the age of 8 in girls, pubertal LH levels, and possibly visual disturbances and signs of increased intracranial pressure due to a sellar tumor compressing the optic pathways. Brain lesions that involve the hypothalamus/pituitary region (e.g., sellar and/or suprasellar tumors) may result in premature activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis and thus cause central precocious puberty. The development of sexual characteristics before one year of age is very rare. While this patient's mild breast bud development, swollen labia, and blood-tinged vaginal discharge are hormonally-mediated, they are much less severe than would be expected in precocious puberty.

images.title: Pineal region meningioma
images.description: Cranial MRI (T1-weighted, transverse and sagittal views, with contrast)Round lesion in the pineal region (green overlay) showing pronounced and homogeneous enhancement (snowball appearance). There is no perifocal edema, which indicates slow tumor growth. The discretely dilated third ventricle (3) is located in front of the lesion, the dilated lateral ventricle (1) is located laterally (upper image) and cranially (lower image) to the lesion, and the cistern of the great cerebral vein (2, white hatched outline) can be seen caudal to it.

answers.explanation_why: Coagulation studies are indicated in suspected hemorrhagic diathesis, which may manifest with significant bruising and bleeding as seen in von Willebrand disease, hemophilia, or other coagulation factor deficiencies (e.g., factors II, VII, IX, and X due to vitamin K deficiency). The large, flat, gray-blue spots on the patient's back and buttocks are benign melanocytic changes, which are easily mistaken for hematomas. The infant's vaginal discharge only contains small amounts of blood, which makes hemorrhagic diathesis unlikely. Moreover, the patient lacks a family history of bleeding disorders.

images.title: Congenital dermal melanocytosis (Mongolian spot)
images.description: An approx. 5 cm, blue-gray macule with irregular borders is visible on the back. The macule has no evidence of hypertrichosis.

question_text: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of frequent contractions. The contractions last 40 seconds each, occur every 2 minutes, and have been increasing in intensity. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. Her current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg. Contractions are felt on the abdomen. There is clear fluid in the vulva and the introitus. The cervix is dilated to 5 cm, 70% effaced, and station of the head is -2. A fetal ultrasound shows polyhydramnios, a median cleft lip, and fused thalami. The corpus callosum, 3^rd ventricle, and lateral ventricles are absent. There is a four-chamber heart. The spine shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of frequent contractions. The contractions last 40 seconds each, occur every 2 minutes, and have been increasing in intensity. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. Her current medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg. Contractions are felt on the abdomen. There is clear fluid in the vulva and the introitus. The cervix is dilated to 5 cm, 70% effaced, and station of the head is -2. A fetal ultrasound shows polyhydramnios, a median cleft lip, and fused thalami. The corpus callosum, 3rd ventricle, and lateral ventricles are absent. There is a four-chamber heart. The spine shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This fetus has alobar holoprosencephaly, a rare malformation where the cerebral hemispheres do not divide. This congenital anomaly will very likely lead to stillbirth.
learning_objective: Recognize alobar holoprosencephaly, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: A cesarean section is conducted when vaginal delivery is not possible or is too risky for the mother and/or the fetus. While this patient's malformations are very unlikely to be compatible with life, they would not hinder a natural birth (in contrast to, e.g., severe hydrocephalus). Cesarean delivery is generally not as safe as vaginal delivery, even after a previous lower uterine segment cesarean delivery, making it less desirable in this patient.

Vaginal delivery is desirable in this case because it is generally safer for the mother than cesarean delivery (resulting in fewer postoperative complications and a shorter recovery period), even after a previous lower uterine segment cesarean delivery. However, some women in this situation may insist on cesarean delivery so they can avoid the experience of labor and giving birth to a stillborn fetus. Patients also require thorough counseling about the benefits and risks of vaginal versus cesarean delivery to ensure they are able to provide fully informed consent.

Tocolysis (e.g., with indomethacin) is used to delay the onset of labor for up to 48 hours so that antenatal corticosteroids can be administered to preterm fetuses. However, tocolysis is contraindicated if cervical dilation is already > 4 cm and/or the fetus has lethal congenital abnormalities.

To induce labor and delivery, misoprostol (a prostaglandin E1 analog) can be administered to induce cervical ripening, dilation, and passing of the fetus. This patient is already in labor and the cervix is becoming wider and more effaced on its own (high Bishop score), making this procedure unnecessary.

For elective termination of a pregnancy, surgical abortion may be performed (dilation and curettage with vacuum aspiration). This patient is already in labor, however, and will likely deliver on her own very soon. The risks of this procedure outweigh the benefits in this patient.

Tocolysis (e.g., with nifedipine) is used to delay the onset of labor for up to 48 hours so that antenatal corticosteroids can be administered to preterm fetuses. However, tocolysis is contraindicated if cervical dilation is already > 4 cm and/or the fetus has lethal congenital abnormalities.

question_text: Twelve hours after delivery, a 2700-g (5-lb 15-oz) male newborn has 3 episodes of bilious vomiting. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. The mother has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily and has a history of intravenous cocaine use. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a distended upper abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. An x-ray of the abdomen shows 3 gas shadows in the upper abdomen with a gasless distal abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Twelve hours after delivery, a 2700-g (5-lb 15-oz) male newborn has 3 episodes of bilious vomiting. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman. Pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. The mother has smoked one half-pack of cigarettes daily and has a history of intravenous cocaine use. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a distended upper abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. An x-ray of the abdomen shows 3 gas shadows in the upper abdomen with a gasless distal abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The abdominal x-ray shows the triple bubble sign.
learning_objective: Recognize jejunal atresia in a newborn.

answers.explanation_why: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) can present with abdominal distention and emesis. However, patients in the early stages of NEC will also have diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and abdominal tenderness. Furthermore, this newborn lacks pneumatosis intestinalis on abdominal x-ray, which would confirm NEC. Lastly, NEC is most common in premature infants, but usually occurs 2– 4 weeks after birth, once oral feeding has been started. It would be rare for NEC to present within the first few hours of life.

images.title: Necrotizing enterocolitis
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view; supine) of a neonateMultiple distended bowel loops in the right hemiabdomen are accompanied by small lucencies indicating the presence of intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis).Pneumatosis intestinalis is a feature of necrotizing enterocolitis. It can appear as bubbly (green overlay), curvilinear (yellow overlay), or linear (red overlay) lucencies on an abdominal radiograph.

answers.explanation_why: Duodenal atresia can present with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and a prenatal history of polyhydramnios. However, abdominal x-ray would show a double bubble sign, not a triple bubble sign.

images.title: Duodenal atresia in a newborn
images.description: X-ray of the abdomenDilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

answers.explanation_why: Malrotation with volvulus can manifest with abdominal distention and bilious emesis, due to intestinal obstruction from twisting of the bowel. However, infants with midgut volvulus are usually acutely ill, present with hemodynamic instability, and, in case of perforation, signs of peritonitis (e.g., abdominal rigidity). A plain abdominal x-ray may be completely normal, reveal a double bubble sign (indicating duodenal obstruction), or demonstrate pneumoperitoneum (indicating perforation) but a triple bubble sign is not typical.

A distended abdomen and bilious emesis in combination with a triple bubble sign on abdominal x-ray suggest jejunal atresia. This malformation occurs due to a vascular accident in utero, resulting in necrosis and reabsorption of the jejunum. Maternal use of vasoconstrictive drugs (e.g., cocaine, MDMA, or cigarettes) increases the risk for this malformation.

Intestinal atresia of any origin is suggested by a prenatal history of polyhydramnios, resulting from the inability of the fetus to ingest amniotic fluid due to intestinal obstruction.

images.title: Triple bubble sign in jejunal atresia
images.description: X-ray abdomen (A and B: supine) of two neonates with abdominal distension and bilious vomitingDilatation of the stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum (A) is characteristic of the triple bubble sign of jejunal atresia. Multiple dilated bowel loops (B) may alternatively be seen in jejunal atresia, and the number of loops may increase in conjunction with a more distal location of the atresia.1: gastric air-fluid level; 2: duodenal air-fluid level; 3: jejunal air-fluid level

answers.explanation_why: Hirschsprung disease can present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis secondary to obstruction from an aganglionic portion of the rectosigmoid colon. Failure to pass meconium for > 48 hours and a positive squirt sign would support this diagnosis. This patient is still within the expected time frame for meconium passage and his gasless distal abdomen on x-ray suggests a bowel obstruction more proximal than the rectosigmoid colon, as dilated loops of the large bowel would be expected in Hirschsprung disease.

images.title: Hirschsprung disease
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newbornA massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.Yellow overlay: gastric bubble

answers.explanation_why: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) can present with abdominal distention and emesis, due to obstruction at the pylorus. Maternal cigarette smoking during pregnancy and male gender are risk factors for the development of IHPS. However, the emesis is non-bilious and projectile and will not present until the pylorus has had time to hypertrophy several weeks after birth. A palpable, olive-shaped mass is also usually present, and abdominal x-ray will show distention of the stomach only. This infant's bilious emesis, age, and triple bubble sign suggest another diagnosis.

Meconium ileus can present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis, due to ileal obstruction from impacted stool. This diagnosis is suspected when meconium fails to pass within the first 48 hours of life, which virtually rules out this diagnosis in this newborn 12 hours after delivery. Abdominal x-ray would show dilated loops of the small bowel above the terminal ileum and rectal enema would reveal a microcolon. This infant's abdominal x-ray shows an obstruction more proximal to the ileum.

images.title: Microcolon and bowel perforation in meconium ileus
images.description: Barium enema (AP view) of a neonate with meconium ileusMultiple dilated gas-filled loops of small bowel are visible and opaque barium contrast outlines a microcolon (sections of microcolon indicated by green outlines). The findings are consistent with meconium ileus.Contrast is also seen in multiple locations within the peritoneal space (examples indicated by red overlay) as a result of bowel perforation.Blue overlay: ECG electrodes

question_text: One week after delivery, a 3550-g (7-lb 13-oz) male newborn has multiple episodes of bilious vomiting and abdominal distention. He passed urine 14 hours after delivery and had his first bowel movement 3 days after delivery. He was born at term to a 31-year-old woman. Pregnancy was uncomplicated and the mother received adequate prenatal care. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 50/min. Examination shows a distended abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Digital rectal examination shows increased anal sphincter tone and an empty rectal vault. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the underlying cause of these findings?
content_preview: One week after delivery, a 3550-g (7-lb 13-oz) male newborn has multiple episodes of bilious vomiting and abdominal distention. He passed urine 14 hours after delivery and had his first bowel movement 3 days after delivery. He was born at term to a 31-year-old woman. Pregnancy was uncomplicated and the mother received adequate prenatal care. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 50/min. Examination shows a distended abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Digital rectal examination shows increased anal sphincter tone and an empty rectal vault. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the underlying cause of these findings?
hint: Abdominal distention, multiple episodes of bilious vomiting, and a dilated large bowel loop suggest lower intestinal obstruction. The delayed passage of meconium, empty rectal vault, and a narrow sigmoid colon with a dilated segment on x-ray support the diagnosis of Hirschsprung disease. Patients with this condition may also present with a squirt sign.
learning_objective: Recognize Hirschsprung disease, and recall its pathogenesis.

answers.content: Defective migration of neural crest cells
answers.explanation_why:
Defective migration of neural crest cells from the proximal to the distal bowel is the underlying mechanism of Hirschsprung disease. This phenomenon typically results in an aganglionic rectum and distal sigmoid, which prevents the internal anal sphincter from relaxing in response to rectal distension, leading to intestinal obstruction and megacolon. The diagnosis is confirmed with a rectal biopsy, which usually shows aganglionosis and/or hypertrophy of parasympathetic fibers.

See “Differential diagnosis of intestinal obstruction in neonates” table.

images.title: Etiopathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease
images.description: The affected colon (right) is missing both the Meissner and Auerbach nerve plexus.

answers.content: Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum
answers.explanation_why: Disruption of blood flow to the fetal jejunum is responsible for jejunal atresia, which can also manifest with bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and delayed meconium passage. However, symptoms usually appear in feeding infants within 24 hours of birth and an x-ray of the abdomen would show a triple bubble sign.

images.title: Triple bubble sign in jejunal atresia
images.description: X-ray abdomen (A and B: supine) of two neonates with abdominal distension and bilious vomitingDilatation of the stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum (A) is characteristic of the triple bubble sign of jejunal atresia. Multiple dilated bowel loops (B) may alternatively be seen in jejunal atresia, and the number of loops may increase in conjunction with a more distal location of the atresia.1: gastric air-fluid level; 2: duodenal air-fluid level; 3: jejunal air-fluid level

answers.explanation_why: A mutation in the CFTR gene is the underlying cause of cystic fibrosis, which may result in abdominal distention and bilious vomiting due to intestinal obstruction as a result of thickened, inspissated meconium within the distal ileum (meconium ileus). However, although delayed (3 days after delivery), this patient already passed meconium, and bowel sounds would typically be hyperactive in mechanical bowel obstruction. Furthermore, an x-ray in meconium ileus would typically show small bowel distention or a soap-bubble appearance (Neuhauser sign), rather than a distended descending colon, as seen here.

images.title: Microcolon and bowel perforation in meconium ileus
images.description: Barium enema (AP view) of a neonate with meconium ileusMultiple dilated gas-filled loops of small bowel are visible and opaque barium contrast outlines a microcolon (sections of microcolon indicated by green outlines). The findings are consistent with meconium ileus.Contrast is also seen in multiple locations within the peritoneal space (examples indicated by red overlay) as a result of bowel perforation.Blue overlay: ECG electrodes

answers.content: Invagination of bowel loop into adjacent bowel loop
answers.explanation_why: Intussusception is more common in males and may result in abdominal distention, bilious vomiting, and dilated bowel loops on x-ray due to intestinal obstruction. However, the small bowel would be distended (not the large bowel), since intussusception typically occurs at the ileocolic junction, and bowel sounds would be increased. Moreover, intussusception usually occurs between 5 months and 3 years of age; it is extremely rare in the neonatal period. Finally, blood in the rectum is often found on digital rectal examination, which was not the case here.

Intestinal malrotation may manifest within the first month of life with bilious vomiting and abdominal distention due to intestinal obstruction caused by Ladd bands or by a midgut volvulus. However, bowel sounds would likely be increased and an x-ray would show a double bubble sign, or multiple air-fluid levels proximal to the site of obstruction, in contrast to the distended descending colon in this patient.

images.title: Malrotation with midgut volvulus
images.description: Fluoroscopy (upper GI series)The distal duodenum and proximal jejunum has a spiral configuration (green overlay) and fail to cross the midline into the left upper quadrant. This appearance, referred to as the corkscrew sign, is produced by the twisting of small bowel loops on a shortened mesentery.The corkscrew sign is characteristic of intestinal malrotation with midgut volvulus.

answers.content: Hemorrhagic inflammation of the intestinal wall
answers.explanation_why: Hemorrhagic inflammation of the intestinal wall is seen in necrotizing enterocolitis, which may manifest with abdominal distention and bilious vomiting shortly after birth, However, an x-ray would typically show bowel wall edema, pneumatosis intestinalis, and/or free air within the abdomen (due to perforation of a viscus). Also, patients typically have a history of bloody diarrhea (unlike this neonate, who had delayed meconium passage) and the child would appear seriously ill with cardiopulmonary instability. Moreover, this patient lacks the risk factors commonly associated with necrotizing enterocolitis, such as preterm birth and neonatal asphyxia.

images.title: Necrotizing enterocolitis
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view; supine) of a neonateMultiple distended bowel loops in the right hemiabdomen are accompanied by small lucencies indicating the presence of intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis).Pneumatosis intestinalis is a feature of necrotizing enterocolitis. It can appear as bubbly (green overlay), curvilinear (yellow overlay), or linear (red overlay) lucencies on an abdominal radiograph.

answers.content: Failed recanalization of the fetal duodenum
answers.explanation_why: Failed recanalization of the fetal duodenum results in duodenal atresia, which would also manifest with bilious vomiting and delayed meconium passage. However, abdominal distention is typically not as prominent, and symptoms are usually evident on the first day after birth with the initiation of feeds. Additionally, the prenatal period is often complicated by polyhydramnios, and an x-ray of the abdomen would show a double bubble sign and absence of gas in the small and large intestine.

images.title: Duodenal atresia in a newborn
images.description: X-ray of the abdomenDilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

answers.explanation_why: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which is more common in males, may result in vomiting in the neonatal period. However, the vomiting is nonbilious, projectile, occurs following feeds, and usually begins 2 weeks after birth. An x-ray of the abdomen would show a distended stomach with minimal distention of the bowels. Other clinical features include decreased soiling of diapers (due to decreased urine output), as well as a hypertrophic “olive” in the epigastric region and/or a gastric peristaltic wave on examination.

images.title: Hirschsprung disease
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newbornA massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.Yellow overlay: gastric bubble
