question_text: An 18-day-old newborn has difficulty feeding and diarrhea for 2 days. During this period he has vomited after each of his feeds. He was born at 28 weeks' gestation and weighed 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz). His feeds consist of breast milk and cow milk-based formula. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 67/min and blood pressure is 70/35 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness; bowel sounds are absent. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,000/mm^3 and platelet count is 118,000/mm^3. A nasogastric tube is placed. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 18-day-old newborn has difficulty feeding and diarrhea for 2 days. During this period he has vomited after each of his feeds. He was born at 28 weeks' gestation and weighed 1100-g (2-lb 7-oz). His feeds consist of breast milk and cow milk-based formula. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 67/min and blood pressure is 70/35 mm Hg. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness; bowel sounds are absent. Test of the stool for occult blood is positive. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.8 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,000/mm3 and platelet count is 118,000/mm3. A nasogastric tube is placed. An x-ray of the abdomen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The x-ray shows gas within the wall of the intestine (i.e., pneumatosis intestinalis) and evidence of portal venous gas, which is diagnostic of this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize necrotizing enterocolitis in a premature infant.

answers.explanation_why: Hirschsprung disease can manifest with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and an inability to pass stool secondary to obstruction from an aganglionic portion of the rectosigmoid colon. Failure to pass meconium for > 48 hours and a positive squirt sign further support this diagnosis. If the disease is complicated by enterocolitis, explosive bloody diarrhea is common. This patient developed symptoms > 2 weeks after delivery, which makes another diagnosis more likely. Moreover, an abdominal x-ray of Hirschsprung disease would show an absence of gas in the distal colon with a dilated bowel proximally rather than the pneumatosis intestinalis seen here.

images.title: Hirschsprung disease
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newbornA massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.Yellow overlay: gastric bubble

answers.explanation_why: Meckel diverticulum is the most likely cause of painless hematochezia in children < 2 years old. Patients are often asymptomatic but may present with abdominal pain and hematochezia in case of infection, secondary volvulus, or bowel obstruction due to secondary intussusception. Meckel diverticulum cannot be visualized on a plain abdominal x-ray but requires a technetium-99m pertechnetate scan and is not associated with pneumatosis intestinalis.

Meconium ileus can present with abdominal distention and bilious emesis, due to ileal obstruction from impacted stool. This diagnosis is suspected when meconium fails to pass within the first 48 hours of life and is strongly associated with cystic fibrosis (∼ 90% of cases). Abdominal x-ray of meconium ileus shows dilated loops of small bowel above the terminal ileum. Although this patient presents with abdominal distention, absent bowel sounds, and vomiting, a diagnosis of meconium ileus is inconsistent with his diarrhea, the x-ray findings of pneumatosis intestinalis, and the onset of symptoms > 2 weeks after delivery.

images.title: Small bowel obstruction
images.description: X-ray abdomen (with oral contrast; AP view) of an infant with cystic fibrosisMultiple dilated loops of small bowel are seen. Two loops in the right lower quadrant are opacified with contrast, while others are gas-filled. No gas has passed into the colon. The cause for obstruction proved to be inspissated meconium (not visible) in the distal ileum. An nasogastric tube is present in the stomach.

answers.explanation_why: Malrotation with volvulus can manifest with abdominal distention and bilious emesis, due to intestinal obstruction from twisting (i.e., volvulus) of the bowel. Bright red blood per rectum may also be present due to intestinal necrosis. Abdominal x-ray may show a coffee bean sign in sigmoid volvulus. Pneumatosis intestinalis on this infant's x-ray rules out malrotation.

Cow milk protein allergy (CMA) is the most common food allergy in children and either manifests with symptoms occurring immediately after ingestion of cow milk protein (IgE-mediated), such as anaphylaxis, urticaria, and angioedema, or with symptoms with delayed onset (non-IgE-mediated), such as protein-induced proctocolitis and/or enterocolitis. Infants with protein-induced proctocolitis may present with rectal bleeding but otherwise appear well. Patients with food protein-induced enterocolitis present with diarrhea, severe vomiting 1–3 hours following antigen ingestion, dehydration, and lethargy. An x-ray in protein-induced colitis would show air-fluid levels rather than pneumatosis intestinalis.

Patients with intussusception typically present with the classic triad of episodic abdominal pain, vomiting, and currant-jelly stool (composed of blood and mucus). While this patient presents with abdominal tenderness, vomiting, and lower gastrointestinal bleeding, he is younger than would be expected for this diagnosis (i.e., children 3-month to 6-years of age) and also does not have a characteristic sausage-shaped abdominal mass. In intussusception, an abdominal x-ray does not show pneumatosis intestinalis, but may reveal a soft tissue mass (typically in the upper right quadrant in children) with proximal bowel obstruction (e.g., air-fluid levels and bowel dilation).

images.title: Target sign in intussusception
images.description: Ultrasound abdomen (bowel; transverse plane)Concentric alternating hyperechoic and hypoechoic rings are visible. The hyperechoic rings (green overlay) are formed by mucosa and the hypoechoic rings (red overlay) by submucosa. Together the alternating layers produce a target-like appearance (target sign; bull's eye sign).

answers.explanation_why: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) can manifest with abdominal distention, severe postprandial, nonbilious, projectile vomiting, and failure to thrive starting 2–6 weeks after birth, but it is not typically associated with diarrhea or hematochezia. Moreover, a palpable, olive-shaped mass is usually present in the epigastrium (hypertrophic pylorus) in patients with HPS. Abdominal x-ray in HPS may show stomach distention only but not pneumatosis intestinalis.

Duodenal atresia manifest with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and a prenatal history of polyhydramnios (since the fetus cannot drink the amniotic fluid due to the intestinal obstruction) but does not cause bloody diarrhea. Abdominal x-ray would also show a double bubble sign rather than pneumatosis intestinalis.

images.title: Double bubble sign
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a newborn with duodenal atresiaA nasogastric tube terminates in the gastric antrum. Gaseous distention of the stomach and pyloric channel (green overlay) and dilatation of the duodenal bulb (red overlay) are seen. Bowel distal to the duodenal bulb does not contain gas.This appearance has been termed the “double-bubble sign.” This sign is seen with duodenal atresia and several other congenital and acquired causes of duodenal obstruction.

answers.explanation_why:
Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is the most common cause of acute abdomen in premature infants with low birth weight. It typically occurs 2–4 weeks after birth, once oral feeding has begun. Infants present with poor feeding, lethargy, vomiting, diarrhea, hematochezia, thrombocytopenia, and/or a distended abdomen with decreased bowel sounds.

If uncomplicated NEC (i.e., without perforation/peritonitis) is diagnosed, blood cultures, broad-spectrum IV antibiotics, and supportive care (i.e., bowel rest, total parenteral nutrition, fluid replacement, and cardiovascular/respiratory support) are the management of choice. Surgical treatment is warranted when there is evidence of perforation (e.g., pneumomediastinum) or no response to optimal medical therapy.

images.title: Necrotizing enterocolitis
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a premature neonateMultiple loops of gas-filled bowel are seen, some of which are accompanied by linear (example indicated by red arrowhead) and bubbly (examples indicated by green arrowheads) lucencies that indicate intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis; areas in green circles). Subtle linear lucencies (examples indicated by black arrowheads) projecting over the right upper quadrant might indicate portal venous gas. There is no pneumoperitoneum.An NG tube (yellow overlay) terminates in the stomach.

question_text: An 18-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit at 20 weeks' gestation. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy and well-nourished. The uterus is palpated up to the level of the umbilicus. Laboratory studies show a maternal serum α-fetoprotein concentration of 640 ng/ml (N = 10–150). Ultrasonography shows a defect in the fetal abdominal wall to the right of the umbilical cord. A part of the fetus's bowels herniates through the abdominal defect and is suspended freely in the amniotic fluid. Which of the following extraintestinal structural abnormalities is most likely to be found on further evaluation of the fetus?
content_preview: An 18-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit at 20 weeks' gestation. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy and well-nourished. The uterus is palpated up to the level of the umbilicus. Laboratory studies show a maternal serum α-fetoprotein concentration of 640 ng/ml (N = 10–150). Ultrasonography shows a defect in the fetal abdominal wall to the right of the umbilical cord. A part of the fetus's bowels herniates through the abdominal defect and is suspended freely in the amniotic fluid. Which of the following extraintestinal structural abnormalities is most likely to be found on further evaluation of the fetus?
hint: This fetus has gastroschisis, a condition in which the intestines herniate freely through an abdominal defect in the paraumbilical area. By contrast, omphalocele is a condition in which the intestines protrude at the midline through the navel but are contained in a hernia sac. Both abdominal wall defects are associated with an elevated 2^nd-trimester maternal serum α-fetoprotein (MSAFP) concentration.
learning_objective: Recognize gastroschisis as an isolated defect.

answers.explanation_why: Brachycephaly is a common feature seen in patients with trisomy 21. Omphalocele rather than gastroschisis is frequently observed in patients with trisomy 21. Gastroschisis occurs relatively late in development and is rarely associated with chromosomal abnormalities.

Spina bifida is an open neural tube defect that can cause elevated MSAFP, but it is not associated with abdominal wall defects. MSAFP is elevated in open neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida, anencephaly), abdominal wall defects (e.g., omphalocele, gastroschisis), fetal death, and placental abnormalities (e.g., placental abruption).

answers.content: No extraintestinal structural abnormalities are expected
answers.explanation_why: Gastroschisis is a congenital ventral wall defect that is usually isolated. By contrast, omphalocele is commonly associated with structural abnormalities of extraintestinal organs (e.g., heart, neural tube) and often occurs in the context of syndrome complexes (e.g., chromosomal trisomies, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome). In gastroschisis, the absence of a hernia sac results in an edematous, erythematous, and dull intestinal wall. This condition is mainly seen in premature infants and those with intrauterine growth restriction, and can be associated with cryptorchidism, gastrointestinal stenoses, and atresia, the latter of which can result in short bowel syndrome. Because gastroschisis is not covered by a hernia sac, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) can diffuse freely into the amniotic fluid and maternal circulation, leading to elevated MSAFP, which can be detected by a screening test.

images.title: Congenital malformations of the anterior abdominal wall
images.description: Omphalocele: herniation of intraabdominal contents through an anterior abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord caused by the failure of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity after its physiological herniation through the umbilical ring. Accordingly, the hernial sac is formed by the amniotic membrane and peritoneum, and the umbilical cord lies at the apex of the hernia.Gastroschisis: a developmental defect of the anterior abdominal wall in the paraumbilical region through which intraabdominal contents prolapse. As it is the anterior abdominal wall that fails to develop correctly, there is no outer peritoneal or membranous covering.Congenital umbilical hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through a patent umbilical orifice, which typically closes by 2 years of age. The sac of a paraumbilical hernia is the peritoneum.Diastasis recti: an abnormally wide separation of the right and left rectus abdominis muscles. The abdominal fascia are intact. There is therefore no herniation, but a midline bulge is visible on straining (e.g., when trying to sit up).

answers.explanation_why: Bladder exstrophy can be observed in rare cases of patients with omphalocele, but it is extremely rare in gastroschisis. In this fetus, the intestines herniate through the abdominal wall, but no bladder or urethra is visualized.

Organomegaly is a feature of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS). BWS is the most common genetic abnormality associated with omphalocele, but it is not associated with gastroschisis. BWS should be suspected in patients who present with macroglossia, macrosomia, and midfacial hypoplasia.

Congenital heart diseases, such as ventricular septal defects (VSDs), are seen in 30–50% of fetuses with omphalocele and are also associated with trisomies, fetal alcohol syndrome, and TORCH infections. However, VSDs are not associated with gastroschisis. VSDs are usually detected in utero by echocardiography. In the neonatal period, VSD should be suspected in patients with poor eating, failure to thrive, tachypnea, and/or dyspnea.

question_text: Two days after delivery, a 4300-g (9-lb 8-oz) male newborn has difficulty feeding and has become increasingly lethargic. His cry has become weak. He was born at term. His mother has a history of intravenous drug use. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 70/48 mm Hg. Examination shows midfacial hypoplasia, diaphoresis, and tremor of the lower extremities. Macroglossia is present. There are folds in the posterior auricular cartilage. The left lower extremity is larger than the right lower extremity. Abdominal examination shows an umbilical hernia. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Neurologic examination shows decreased tone in all extremities. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
content_preview: Two days after delivery, a 4300-g (9-lb 8-oz) male newborn has difficulty feeding and has become increasingly lethargic. His cry has become weak. He was born at term. His mother has a history of intravenous drug use. His temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 70/48 mm Hg. Examination shows midfacial hypoplasia, diaphoresis, and tremor of the lower extremities. Macroglossia is present. There are folds in the posterior auricular cartilage. The left lower extremity is larger than the right lower extremity. Abdominal examination shows an umbilical hernia. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Neurologic examination shows decreased tone in all extremities. Administration of which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
hint: This newborn has macrosomia, macroglossia, midfacial hypoplasia, hepatomegaly, and hemihypertrophy. These features are suggestive of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize the signs of hypoglycemia in neonates with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, and choose the most appropriate intervention.

answers.explanation_why: Calcium gluconate is indicated in cases of hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia. In hyperkalemic patients, calcium gluconate is used as a cardioprotective agent that stabilizes the cell membrane of cardiac myocytes to decrease the likelihood of arrhythmia. Patients with hypocalcemia benefit from direct elevation of serum calcium. Although both hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia can cause weakness, the patient's physical examination strongly suggests an underlying genetic condition.

Thyroxine supplementation is essential for treating congenital hypothyroidism. This patient has some features consistent with hypothyroidism, especially umbilical hernia and macroglossia. However, the presence of other abnormalities, such as hemihypertrophy, hepatomegaly, and midface hypoplasia, is not consistent with congenital hypothyroidism. Most importantly, deficiency of thyroxine is very unlikely to produce an acute change in health, as seen in this patient.

Administration of hypertonic (3%) saline would be the treatment of choice for severe hyponatremia, which often arises from vomiting or diarrhea without proper volume/sodium replacement. This patient has no history of significant volume loss. Moreover, the presentation of hyponatremia in neonates can be quite variable, with only the most extreme presentations requiring hypertonic (3%) saline. In these cases, patients appear acutely ill and often present with seizures, altered sensorium, and possibly coma. Given the lack of severe neurological dysfunction (e.g., seizure or coma), it is unlikely that this patient is suffering from severe hyponatremia.

The congenital hyperinsulinism associated with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome can cause serious hypoglycemic episodes in neonates. In this patient, poor feeding likely further exacerbated the effects of hyperinsulinemia, ultimately resulting in signs of hypoglycemia such as weak cry, diminished muscle tone, diaphoresis, tachycardia, and tremor. Normalizing blood sugar levels through prompt administration of glucose should alleviate these abnormalities.

Patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at increased risk of developing nephroblastoma, hepatoblastoma, neuroblastoma, and adrenal tumors; serial screening with abdominal ultrasound and alpha-fetoprotein levels is recommended.

Ampicillin and gentamicin are widely considered first-line agents to treat neonatal sepsis. Certain elements of this patient's presentation could raise suspicion of sepsis, including hypothermia, poor feeding, and lethargy. The presence of other abnormalities (hemihypertrophy, hepatomegaly, and midface hypoplasia), however, points instead to an underlying genetic syndrome that requires different treatment at this time.

Naloxone is used to reverse the effects of opioids, most often in cases of overdose. Neonates born to mothers exposed to opioids (either medicinally or recreationally) are at risk of overdose, which manifests with respiratory depression or apnea. This patient is tachypneic, making opioid overdose unlikely.

question_text: A 4080-g (9-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows both feet pointing downwards and inwards. Both forefeet are twisted medially in adduction, with the hindfeet elevated and the midfeet appearing concave. Both Achilles tendons are taut on palpation. There are skin creases on the medial side of both feet. The deformity persists despite attempts to passively straighten the foot. X-rays of both feet confirm the suspected diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4080-g (9-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows both feet pointing downwards and inwards. Both forefeet are twisted medially in adduction, with the hindfeet elevated and the midfeet appearing concave. Both Achilles tendons are taut on palpation. There are skin creases on the medial side of both feet. The deformity persists despite attempts to passively straighten the foot. X-rays of both feet confirm the suspected diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This newborn presents with in-toeing, an elevated hindfoot, and a cavus deformity of the midfoot bilaterally. This presentation is consistent with club foot, a common congenital foot deformity.
learning_objective: Recognize club foot, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Foot abduction bracing prevents relapses after the initial correction of the club foot. At this point in the patient's presentation, however, another intervention aimed at correcting the deformity is first needed.

Surgery is not considered a first-line approach for the vast majority of club foot cases. Cases that require surgery are often those in which parents/caregivers have difficulty following the non-surgical treatment plan or those in which the deformity is so severe that conservative treatment is unlikely to alleviate the issues. In the event that other treatment options fail, surgery would be indicated to correct deformities in the tendons, ligaments, and joints of the foot and ankle.

Reassurance is inappropriate in this patient because the deformity is rigid on examination, making the likelihood of spontaneous resolution very low. Club foot specifically is known to cause permanent deformity if not corrected in a timely manner.

Repositioning and serial casting is the recommended treatment for patients with club foot. On clinical exam, the deformity cannot be passively corrected, indicating that intervention will be necessary to prevent future gait disorders. If repositioning and casting are initiated within 24 hours and continued through musculoskeletal development, the prognosis for this patient is excellent and surgery can likely be avoided.

images.title: Congenital clubfoot in a newborn
images.description: Right lower leg and foot of a newborn, ventral view of the back of the foot The achilles tendon is shortened, resulting in plantar flexion and the foot pointing downwards (hindfoot equinus). The calcaneus is supinated (hindfoot varus). The forefoot is adducted and supinated and rotates medially (forefoot varus). The midfoot cavus cannot be seen from this perspective.

answers.explanation_why: Physical therapy (PT) is an important element of caring for patients with club feet because it helps to provide optimal alignment, mobility, and range of motion. However, a primary correction of the deformity is required before PT can be initiated.

question_text: A 4700-g (10-lb) male newborn is delivered at 37 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn appears pale. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 180/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination in the delivery room shows midfacial hypoplasia, infraorbital creases, and a large tongue. The right side of the body is larger than the left. Abdominal examination shows that the abdominal viscera protrudes through the abdominal wall at the umbilicus; the viscera are covered by the amniotic membrane and the peritoneum. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 48 mg/dL. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows enlarged kidneys bilaterally. In addition to surgical closure of the abdominal wall, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4700-g (10-lb) male newborn is delivered at 37 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The newborn appears pale. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 180/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Examination in the delivery room shows midfacial hypoplasia, infraorbital creases, and a large tongue. The right side of the body is larger than the left. Abdominal examination shows that the abdominal viscera protrudes through the abdominal wall at the umbilicus; the viscera are covered by the amniotic membrane and the peritoneum. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Fingerstick blood glucose concentration is 48 mg/dL. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows enlarged kidneys bilaterally. In addition to surgical closure of the abdominal wall, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This newborn is large for gestational age and presents with facial abnormalities, macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, organomegaly, and hypoglycemia. These features are consistent with the diagnosis of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, and choose the most appropriate surveillance strategy.

answers.explanation_why: Elevated serum IGF-1 with elevated growth hormone levels is diagnostic of a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma, which can present as gigantism in children. It would be very rare, however, for a newborn to present with a pituitary adenoma, which would also not explain this boy's hemihyperplasia and omphalocele. Serum IGF-1 has no diagnostic utility in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Deregulation of the IGF-2 gene, however, is one of several genes implicated in the development of the syndrome.

Low free T_4 levels would confirm hypothyroidism, which can be associated with macroglossia and abdominal wall defects (most commonly umbilical hernias). In congenital hypothyroidism, however, a newborn would not be expected to be large for gestational age nor have signs of hemihyperplasia or organomegaly.

Elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels confirm the diagnosis of 21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency, the most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Although patients with 21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency can have hypoglycemia during a salt-losing adrenal crisis, other findings would also be expected (e.g., hypotension, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia). Furthermore, male neonates with congenital adrenal hyperplasia do not usually have any physical anomalies (i.e., macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, or organomegaly), which are seen in this patient.

A growth hormone-producing pituitary adenoma, which can result in organomegaly and a newborn being large for gestational age, can be diagnosed with a cranial MRI. It would be extremely rare, however, for a neonate to present with a pituitary adenoma. Cranial MRI has no diagnostic utility in Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, which is the most likely diagnosis here. A baseline MRI of the abdomen to screen for tumors should be considered and would likely be part of the workup for this patient.

Patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are at increased risk for various tumors, including nephroblastoma, hepatoblastoma, and neuroblastoma. Abdominal ultrasounds with views of the kidneys are recommended every 3 months until 8 years of age to screen for these tumors. Additionally, serum α-fetoprotein levels should also be measured every 2–3 months until 4 years of age to screen for hepatoblastoma. Although measurement of urinary catecholamines has been proposed as a screening method for neuroblastomas, it has not been incorporated into most protocols.

Karyotyping can confirm the diagnosis of various genetic disorders, including trisomy 13 and trisomy 18, both of which can be associated with omphalocele. This patient, however, does not have other features of trisomy 13 (e.g., microphthalmia, polydactyly, and congenital heart defects) or trisomy 18 (e.g., prominent occiput, low-set ears, micrognathia, and rocker-bottom feet). In addition, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is caused by deregulation of imprinting in certain genes, which would not be detected with karyotyping.

question_text:
A 3500-g (7-lb 10-oz) female newborn is delivered at 39 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother had regular prenatal visits throughout the pregnancy. She did not smoke or drink alcohol. She took multivitamins as prescribed by her physician. The newborn appears active. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 55/35 mm Hg. Examination in the delivery room shows clitoromegaly. One day later, laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
15.8 g/dL

Leukocyte count
6000/mm^3

Platelet count
240,000/mm^3

Serum

 Na^+

133 mEq/L

 K^+

5.2 mEq/L

 Cl^−

101 mEq/L

 HCO_3^−

21 mEq/L

 Urea nitrogen
15 mg/dL

 Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL

Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis shows normal uterus and normal ovaries. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this newborn patient?
content_preview: A 3500-g (7-lb 10-oz) female newborn is delivered at 39 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother had regular prenatal visits throughout the pregnancy. She did not smoke or drink alcohol. She took multivitamins as prescribed by her physician. The newborn appears active. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 55/35 mm Hg. Examination in the delivery room shows clitoromegaly. One day later, laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 15.8 g/dL Leukocyte count 6000/mm3 Platelet count 240,000/mm3 Serum Na+ 133 mEq/L K+ 5.2 mEq/L Cl− 101 mEq/L HCO3− 21 mEq/L Urea nitrogen 15 mg/dL Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis shows normal uterus and normal ovaries. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this newborn patient?
hint: This female newborn presents with hypotension, clitoromegaly, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, which is characteristic of 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Further lab testing would show ↑ 17-hydroxyprogesterone, ↓ 11-deoxycorticosterone, ↓ corticosterone, and likely metabolic acidosis (bicarbonate is slightly decreased).
learning_objective: Recognize 21-hydroxylase deficiency, and choose the most appropriate initial therapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Lifelong glucocorticoid therapy is the mainstay treatment for patients with 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Hydrocortisone replaces deficient cortisol and thereby decreases ACTH levels to reduce adrenal hyperandrogenism that contributes to virilization in females (e.g., clitoromegaly). Fludrocortisone replaces aldosterone to raise blood pressure and correct electrolyte abnormalities (e.g., hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis).

Since the adrenal glands cannot appropriately titrate corticosteroid levels, the dose of hydrocortisone must be increased during periods of stress (e.g., illness). Otherwise, patients may have an adrenal crisis.
Estrogen replacement therapy is used in the treatment of female patients with hypogonadism (e.g., Turner syndrome). However, 21-hydroxylase deficiency does not affect ovarian estrogen production.

Prednisolone can replace deficient cortisol in patients with 21-hydroxylase deficiency and has the benefit of an intermediate duration of action within the steroid family, which allows patients to take the medication only once or twice a day. However, due to its high potency, it has a high risk of adverse events in infants, such as growth suppression and Cushing syndrome (e.g., weight gain, muscle atrophy, hyperglycemia), and therefore would not be the first-line treatment.

Prednisolone would be an appropriate cortisol replacement choice for adults in whom growth suppression is no longer a concern.

Reconstruction surgery can be considered in infants with ambiguous genitalia, although the ideal timing of surgery (infancy versus adolescence) has not yet been fully established. Regardless, due to this patient's insufficient corticosteroid production, she is at risk for a salt-wasting crisis, and medical therapy to replace these hormonal deficits should be initiated first.

Dexamethasone can replace deficient cortisol in patients with 21-hydroxylase deficiency and has the benefit of a long duration of action within the steroid family to allow for less frequent dosing. However, it has a high risk of adverse events in infants, such as growth suppression and Cushing syndrome (e.g., weight gain, muscle atrophy, hyperglycemia), and therefore would not be the first-line treatment.

Dexamethasone would be an appropriate cortisol replacement choice for adults in whom growth suppression is no longer a concern.

Spironolactone administration can treat elevated 11-deoxycorticosterone (DOC) levels that are associated with the less common forms of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), specifically 11β-hydroxylase deficiency and 17α-hydroxylase deficiency. Although all forms of CAH can manifest with ambiguous genitalia at birth, this patient shows hypotension, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia, which is characteristic of 21-hydroxylase deficiency. Since DOC levels are decreased in 21-hydroxylase deficiency, spironolactone therapy would only exacerbate her condition.

question_text: Twenty minutes after delivery by lower segment cesarean section at 38 weeks' gestation, a 4630-g (10-lb 3-oz) male newborn has respiratory distress. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother, a 23-year-old primigravid woman, smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily during her pregnancy. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus. The newborn's temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 155/min; and respirations are 72/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Grunting and mild intercostal and subcostal retractions are present. Diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. An x-ray of the chest shows increased lung volume and fluid within the interlobar fissures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Twenty minutes after delivery by lower segment cesarean section at 38 weeks' gestation, a 4630-g (10-lb 3-oz) male newborn has respiratory distress. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother, a 23-year-old primigravid woman, smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily during her pregnancy. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus. The newborn's temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 155/min; and respirations are 72/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Grunting and mild intercostal and subcostal retractions are present. Diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. An x-ray of the chest shows increased lung volume and fluid within the interlobar fissures. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Tachypnea, increased breathing effort, and diffuse crackles on auscultation in a full-term, macrosomic newborn born via cesarean delivery indicate transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN). Gestational diabetes mellitus is a known risk factor for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize transient tachypnea of the newborn, and choose the initial supportive care measure.

answers.explanation_why:
TTN is a benign condition that can occur up to 2 hours after delivery and usually resolves without complications within 72 hours. Therapy consists of supportive care, including providing supplemental oxygen by hood or nasal cannula (with a goal O_2 saturation of ≥ 90 %), maintaining a neutral thermal environment, and providing adequate nutrition. TTN rarely requires a higher level of care; however, nasal continuous positive airway pressure should be initiated if the required inspired O_2 concentration is > 40 %, or if the newborn stays tachypneic with increased work of breathing despite other supplemental O_2 delivery methods. Finally, other causes of respiratory distress (e.g., pneumonia, neonatal sepsis, congenital heart condition) should be excluded.

TTN is caused by delayed resorption of fetal lung fluid and most commonly occurs after cesarean delivery, which does not allow fluid to be squeezed out of the neonate's lungs (compared to vaginal delivery).

Broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy would be the therapy of choice for suspected neonatal sepsis. Although this patient is in respiratory distress, he lacks signs of infection (e.g., temperature instability, tachycardia, lethargy). Additionally, he has no neonatal risk factors (e.g., intrapartum fetal tachycardia, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, Apgar score ≤ 6) or maternal risk factors (e.g., Group B Streptococcus colonization, maternal fever, chorioamnionitis, prolonged rupture of membranes) for sepsis. However, given his clinical presentation, a CBC with differential should be obtained to rule out an infection. If tachypnea is persistent or if a complete blood count and differential suggests an infection, then blood cultures should be obtained and empiric antibiotics (e.g., ampicillin and gentamicin) should be initiated.

Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) should be initiated when neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) is suspected. NRDS typically manifests with tachypnea, nasal flaring, moderate to severe retractions, and expiratory grunting. However, this condition usually affects premature infants who have insufficient surfactant levels. Also, chest x-ray in infants with NRDS would show bilateral ground-glass opacities with air bronchograms and decreased lung volumes; not fluid in the lung fissures. Additionally, breath sounds would be diminished on auscultation. While nasal CPAP may eventually be used, it is not the first step in the management of TTN.

Indomethacin is used to close a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) in neonates. Large PDAs can cause signs of heart failure, including respiratory distress. However, it would be unlikely for this patient to present with respiratory distress due to heart failure within minutes after birth from a PDA. Furthermore, there is no evidence of a murmur to suggest a PDA.

Surfactant therapy is effective in reducing morbidity and mortality in preterm infants with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) who fail an initial nasal continuous positive airway pressure trial. Although this patient is in respiratory distress, he is full-term and should have adequate surfactant levels. Furthermore, his chest x-ray is not consistent with NRDS, as bilateral ground-glass opacities with air bronchograms and decreased lung volumes would be expected. Additionally, breath sounds would be diminished on auscultation in NRDS.

Endotracheal intubation would be indicated for neonates with persistent respiratory distress despite non-invasive ventilatory means (e.g., nasal cannula followed by continuous positive airway pressure). TTN rarely requires endotracheal intubation.

Nitric oxide (NO) therapy would be indicated in patients with persistent pulmonary hypertension (PPHN) who do not respond to supportive measures. Inhaled NO reduces the ratio of pulmonary to systemic vascular resistance to improve blood oxygenation. Although PPHN can manifest with respiratory distress, the chest x-ray is typically normal.

question_text: A 3402-g (7-lb 8-oz) female newborn is delivered at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling of bilateral upper and lower extremities and low-set ears. The posterior hairline is low and the chest appears broad. There are skin folds running down the sides of the neck to the shoulders. A grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur and systolic click are heard at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's swelling?
content_preview: A 3402-g (7-lb 8-oz) female newborn is delivered at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows swelling of bilateral upper and lower extremities and low-set ears. The posterior hairline is low and the chest appears broad. There are skin folds running down the sides of the neck to the shoulders. A grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur and systolic click are heard at the apex. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's swelling?
hint: This newborn's systolic ejection murmur and systolic click at the apex suggest a functional bicuspid aortic valve.
learning_objective: Recognize Turner syndrome-associated lymphedema.

answers.explanation_why: Renal retention of sodium can be a compensatory response to decreased kidney perfusion (resulting from, e.g., heart failure or chronic kidney disease) and can cause edema of the extremities. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, which is associated with both cardiovascular abnormalities (e.g., bicuspid aortic valve, hypertension) and kidney disease (e.g., horseshoe kidneys) that can progress to severe cardiac or renal insufficiency with consequent renal hypoperfusion. However, this child has no other signs and symptoms to suggest cardiac or renal insufficiency. In addition, edema of the hands and feet in neonates with Turner syndrome has a different underlying mechanism.

Dysfunction of the lymphatic system is characteristic of Turner syndrome and typically leads to congenital lymphedema of the hands and feet starting in the neonatal period. The precise cause of lymphatic dysfunction in Turner syndrome is unknown. This patient also has other typical features of the condition, such as a female phenotype, shield chest, a short, webbed neck, low-set ears, and signs of a bicuspid aortic valve (grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur and systolic click at the apex).

Impaired protein synthesis (e.g., in liver disease) can lead to decreased intravascular oncotic pressure and subsequent accumulation of fluid in the extracellular space. However, fluid primarily builds up in the peritoneal cavity in the form of ascites, rather than in the hands and feet. Additionally, this newborn has no other signs of liver disease, such as jaundice. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.

Excessive urinary protein loss (e.g., in nephrotic syndrome) can lead to decreased serum colloid osmotic pressure and subsequent edema. However, nephrotic syndrome is rare in newborns and the edema in nephrotic syndrome typically begins in the periorbital region rather than the extremities. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.

Impaired left ventricular (LV) function can cause increased hydrostatic pressure and subsequent edema via two main mechanisms: increased renal sodium retention (as a response to decreased renal perfusion) and increased venous pressure. This newborn has a systolic murmur that suggests a bicuspid aortic valve, which could progress to aortic stenosis or insufficiency and cause left-sided heart failure (LHF). However, LHF typically manifests with signs of pulmonary (e.g., tachypnea, basilar rales) rather than peripheral edema. Furthermore, this patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.

Increased capillary permeability (e.g., due to inflammation, burns, allergic reactions) can lead to extravasation of fluid into the tissue and subsequent edema. However, edema is usually localized to the area of tissue injury or generalized in systemic reactions (e.g., sepsis, anaphylaxis). Peripheral edema of the hands and feet bilaterally would be untypical. Furthermore, this patient shows no symptoms of localized tissue damage such as erythema, and her normal vital signs make a systemic reaction unlikely. This patient's presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, in which edema of the hands and feet is caused by a different mechanism.

question_text: Three hours after delivery, a 1800-g (3-lb 15-oz) male newborn develops respiratory distress. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old primigravid woman. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 69/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows nasal flaring and expiratory grunting. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: Three hours after delivery, a 1800-g (3-lb 15-oz) male newborn develops respiratory distress. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old primigravid woman. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 69/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows nasal flaring and expiratory grunting. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: The x-ray shows diffuse ground-glass opacities and air bronchograms.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, and recall its primary cause.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient most likely has neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) due to surfactant deficiency. NRDS is most common in premature infants because adequate surfactant concentration is not reached until 34 weeks' gestation. Without sufficient surfactant, increased surface tension of alveolar air sacs leads to their collapse, resulting in atelectasis, and decreased lung compliance. NRDS manifests up to 72 hours after birth with signs and symptoms of acute respiratory distress such as tachypnea (i.e., respiratory rate > 60/min), cyanosis, nasal flaring, expiratory grunting, intercostal retractions, and decreased breath sounds. Treatment primarily consists of noninvasive ventilation via nasal continuous positive airway pressure. If ventilation alone is unsuccessful, artificial surfactant can be administered endotracheally (see “Overview of NDRDS and its differential diagnoses” table).

As the lungs mature, lecithin levels, the major component of surfactant, increases. Therefore, amniotic fluid lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio can be used to assess for lung maturity, since sphingomyelin remains relatively constant. A ratio > 2 indicates adequate levels of surfactant.

images.title: Alveolar collapse in surfactant deficiency
images.description: Surfactant reduces alveolar surface tension. In surfactant deficiency, increased surface tension results in increased alveolar collapse during expiration and decreased alveolar expansion during inspiration.

answers.explanation_why: Persistent pulmonary hypertension (PPHN) can also lead to respiratory distress. With high pulmonary pressures, right-to-left shunting through fetal circulatory pathways (e.g., ductus arteriosus, foramen ovale) results in deoxygenated blood entering systemic circulation, causing hypoxia and cyanosis. Since the lung parenchyma is normal in PPHN, the chest x-ray would show clear lungs with decreased pulmonary vasculature due to shunting.

Increased lung vascular permeability (secondary to damage to the alveolar-capillary interface) can cause acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in adults. This newborn's respiratory distress is due to another underlying cause.

images.title: Pathophysiology of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)

answers.explanation_why: Patients with primary ciliary dyskinesia have impaired ciliary function and thus impaired lung mucus clearance, which can result also in respiratory distress. However, primary ciliary dyskinesia is an extremely rare condition that has no association with premature delivery. Another cause of this patient's respiratory distress is more likely.

Delayed reabsorption of lung fluid can result in transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN), which also causes respiratory distress. However, TTN occurs most commonly in newborns > 35 weeks' gestation who are delivered by cesarean section without labor. Moreover, a chest x-ray would show hyperinflation, perihilar streaking, and fluid in the fissures.

answers.content: Misplacement of aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: Transposition of the great vessels (TGV) can manifest with respiratory distress (due to impaired oxygenation of the blood), but there would likely be a single loud S2 and a systolic heart murmur from an accompanying VSD on auscultation. Additionally, a chest x-ray would show normal lung parenchyma, increased pulmonary vascular markings, and an “egg on a string” appearance of the heart.

Pneumonia due to group B streptococcus (GBS) can cause respiratory distress. Moreover, a chest x-ray, although results vary, could show bilateral alveolar densities that can be similar in appearance to what this patient has. However, this diagnosis is less likely especially because of this patient's prematurity and the lack of any predisposing maternal factors for GBS pneumonia (e.g., GBS genitourinary or gastrointestinal colonization, fever, chorioamnionitis, prolonged/premature rupture of membranes).

Aspiration of meconium during delivery can also lead to respiratory distress. However, meconium aspiration syndrome usually occurs in term or post-term neonates (because meconium usually first develops after 34 weeks' gestation) who have evidence of meconium in the amniotic fluid. Moreover, a chest x-ray would show patchy infiltrates, and hyperinflation secondary to air trapping from sticky meconium.

images.title: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome
images.description: X-ray chest (frontal view) of a premature infantThe lungs are opacified and have a granular appearance. Air bronchograms (green overlay) extend to the lung periphery. An endotracheal tube (red outlines) is well-positioned above the carina.In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), surfactant deficiency results in alveolar collapse and noncompliant lungs. Air bronchograms are visible when aerated bronchi and bronchioles are surrounded by acinar atelectasis.

question_text: Two hours after delivery, a 1900-g (4-lb 3-oz) female newborn develops respiratory distress. She was born at 32 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy was complicated by pregnancy-induced hypertension. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 140/min and respirations are 64/min. Examination shows bluish extremities. Grunting and moderate subcostal retractions are present. There are decreased breath sounds bilaterally on auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows reduced lung volume and diffuse reticulogranular densities. Supplemental oxygen is administered by nasal cannula. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Two hours after delivery, a 1900-g (4-lb 3-oz) female newborn develops respiratory distress. She was born at 32 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy was complicated by pregnancy-induced hypertension. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 140/min and respirations are 64/min. Examination shows bluish extremities. Grunting and moderate subcostal retractions are present. There are decreased breath sounds bilaterally on auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows reduced lung volume and diffuse reticulogranular densities. Supplemental oxygen is administered by nasal cannula. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Signs of increased breathing effort (tachypnea, subcostal retractions), cyanosis, grunting, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation in a preterm neonate indicate neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). The x-ray with low lung volumes and diffuse reticulogranular (ground-glass) densities confirms the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Nitric oxide therapy would be indicated in patients with persistent pulmonary hypertension (PPHN) who do not respond to supportive measures but has no role in the treatment of NRDS. Although PPHN can manifest with acute respiratory distress, an chest x-ray would show clear lungs with decreased pulmonary vasculature due to shunting rather than reduced lung volume and diffuse reticulogranular densities.

Antenatal corticosteroid therapy should be given to all pregnant mothers between 23–34 weeks' gestation who are at high risk for preterm delivery within the next week. Steroids help with lung maturation and increase surfactant production to reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with preterm delivery. However, corticosteroids are only a preventative measure and have no role in the treatment of NRDS after delivery.

Endotracheal intubation is appropriate for neonates with NRDS who fail initial therapy but is not the first step because management with intubation is associated with more complications (e.g., bronchopulmonary dysplasia, lung injury).

Partial exchange transfusion is indicated for neonates with polycythemia who remain symptomatic (e.g., cyanosis, apnea, poor feeding) despite supportive measures (e.g., IV hydration). Most patients with polycythemia are asymptomatic, and this patient has NRDS, which would not respond to partial exchange transfusion.

Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) ventilation applying positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) is the first step in management of NRDS. Surfactant deficiency in NRDS leads to increased surface tension in the alveolar sacs that results in alveolar collapse, atelectasis, and ventilation-perfusion mismatch. PEEP helps to prevent alveolar collapse by providing pressure at the end of expiration when alveoli are most prone to collapse. After initiation of CPAP, an arterial blood gas analysis should be obtained to assess the effectiveness of respiratory support. If FiO_2 > 0.4 or pH < 7.25, endotracheal intubation and surfactant administration are warranted. The younger the gestational age of the neonate, the greater the chance of CPAP failure and poor outcomes.

Because nasal CPAP is a noninvasive procedure, it should be attempted before surfactant therapy, which requires intubation and is associated with more complications (e.g., pulmonary injury, misplacement of the endotracheal tube).

images.title: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome
images.description: X-ray chest (frontal view) of a premature infantThe lungs are opacified and have a granular appearance. Air bronchograms (green overlay) extend to the lung periphery. An endotracheal tube (red outlines) is well-positioned above the carina.In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS), surfactant deficiency results in alveolar collapse and noncompliant lungs. Air bronchograms are visible when aerated bronchi and bronchioles are surrounded by acinar atelectasis.

answers.explanation_why: Ampicillin and gentamicin therapy would be appropriate empiric antibiotics if a neonatal infection was suspected. Although Group B Streptococcus (GBS) pneumonia can resemble ARDS on chest x-ray, this patient has no maternal (e.g., GBS genitourinary or gastrointestinal colonization, maternal fever, chorioamnionitis, prolonged rupture of membranes) or neonatal risk factors (e.g., intrapartum fetal tachycardia, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, Apgar score less than or equal to 6) for infection. Moreover, antibiotics would not be initiated before respiratory support was provided.

Surfactant administration within 2 hours postpartum has been shown to reduce mortality in neonates with NRDS. However, surfactant therapy requires endotracheal intubation, which is associated with complications such as pulmonary injury and misplacement of the endotracheal tube. Therefore, a less invasive therapy is the preferred initial step in management. Intubation and surfactant administration are warranted if the neonate continues to be in respiratory distress and cannot maintain oxygen saturation despite initial therapy.

question_text: A 4670-g (10-lb 5-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 26-year-old woman after prolonged labor. Apgar scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes. Examination in the delivery room shows swelling, tenderness, and crepitus over the left clavicle. There is decreased movement of the left upper extremity. Movement of the hands and wrists is normal. Grasping reflex is normal in both hands. An asymmetric Moro reflex is present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An anteroposterior x-ray confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4670-g (10-lb 5-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 26-year-old woman after prolonged labor. Apgar scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes. Examination in the delivery room shows swelling, tenderness, and crepitus over the left clavicle. There is decreased movement of the left upper extremity. Movement of the hands and wrists is normal. Grasping reflex is normal in both hands. An asymmetric Moro reflex is present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An anteroposterior x-ray confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This neonate's physical examination findings (tenderness, swelling, and crepitus over the left clavicle, decreased mobility of the left upper extremity, asymmetric Moro reflex) are consistent with a neonatal clavicle fracture. Both prolonged labor and macrosomia increase the risk of this birth trauma.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal clavicle fracture, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Nerve conduction studies are not indicated in cases of uncomplicated neonatal clavicle fracture. This patient's reduced movement of the left upper extremity is most likely a manifestation of pseudoparalysis, not true brachial plexus injury, especially since his hand movement is normal. Decreased ipsilateral extremity movement is believed to take strain off the clavicle and reduce discomfort for the child. If this infant does not recover function by one month of age, a nerve conduction study should be considered to evaluate for underlying nerve damage.
Surgical fixation may be indicated for clavicle fractures in adults, but neonatal clavicle fractures usually do not require surgery.
Physical therapy can enhance recovery for adults with clavicle fractures, but there is no indication for it in neonates.

Parents of a neonate who has a clavicle fracture should be reassured and advised to handle the affected arm gently (e.g., while dressing). To reduce discomfort, the patient's sleeve can be pinned to the front of their shirt with the arm flexed at 90 degrees. Analgesics may also be considered. After 2 weeks, proper healing should be confirmed either via clinical examination (palpable callus formation) or x-ray. The condition usually self-resolves within 2–3 weeks, and long-term complications are not expected.

Neonatal clavicle fracture is most often a clinical diagnosis but an x-ray can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Splinting is not indicated for neonatal clavicle fractures.

MRI is not needed for the diagnosis of a neonatal clavicle fracture. Clinical examination is most often sufficient to establish the diagnosis. For uncertain cases, an anteroposterior x-ray is the preferred imaging modality.

question_text: Thirty minutes after delivery, a 1780-g (3-lb 15-oz) male newborn develops respiratory distress. He was born at 30 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 64/min, and blood pressure is 61/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows pale extremities. Grunting and moderate subcostal retractions are present. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Thirty minutes after delivery, a 1780-g (3-lb 15-oz) male newborn develops respiratory distress. He was born at 30 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 64/min, and blood pressure is 61/32 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Examination shows pale extremities. Grunting and moderate subcostal retractions are present. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This newborn's respiratory distress is most likely due to surfactant deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize respiratory distress syndrome in preterm newborns.

answers.explanation_why: Transient tachypnea of the newborn can also manifest with respiratory distress shortly after birth. However, this condition most commonly occurs in term neonates delivered by cesarean section, not preterm infants born by vaginal delivery. Furthermore, diffuse crackles rather than decreased breath sounds are typically heard on lung auscultation due to pulmonary edema.

Apnea of prematurity (AOP) is caused by immature respiratory control and is commonly seen in preterm neonates or neonates with very low birth weight. While this patient's prematurity puts him at increased risk of developing AOP, the condition characteristically manifests with episodes of breathing pauses (usually > 20 seconds) that are frequently accompanied by hypoxemia and/or bradycardia. This patient has no evidence of prolonged apnea and his pulmonary findings are suggestive of a lung pathology rather than a lack of respiratory drive.

Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) affects approx. 10% of preterm infants and typically manifests with tachypnea (i.e., respiratory rate > 60/min), low O_2 saturation, cyanosis, nasal flaring, expiratory grunting, subcostal retractions, and decreased breath sounds. A chest x-ray showing diffuse, ground-glass densities with atelectasis confirms the diagnosis. Treatment of NRDS primarily involves emergent resuscitative measures, including nasal continuous positive airway pressure and stabilizing blood sugar levels and electrolytes.

See “Overview of NRDS and its differential diagnoses” table.

images.title: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome
images.description: X-ray chest of a premature infant

answers.explanation_why: Meconium aspiration syndrome can also manifest with respiratory distress. However, this condition most commonly affects term or postterm neonates. Furthermore, there is usually some evidence of meconium in the amniotic fluid.

Although severe forms of tracheomalacia can also manifest with respiratory distress (especially when the condition is exacerbated by stress and/or respiratory tract infections), this is usually a benign condition that resolves with airway maturation. More pertinently, this newborn lacks expiratory stridor and wheezing, which typically occurs in tracheomalacia due to tracheal collapse.

Although neonatal pneumonia can also manifest with respiratory distress, this patient lacks other signs of infection (e.g., temperature instability, lethargy). He also has no maternal (e.g., GBS genitourinary or gastrointestinal colonization, fever, chorioamnionitis, prolonged rupture of membranes, premature rupture of membranes) or neonatal risk factors (e.g., intrapartum fetal tachycardia, meconium-stained amniotic fluid, Apgar score below than or equal to 6) for infection.

Tracheoesophageal fistula can also manifest with respiratory distress shortly after birth, usually from aspiration of secretions or feeds into the lungs. However, because the upper esophagus ends in a blind pouch, neonates usually exhibit drooling and choking from difficulties in handling their secretions. Inability to pass an orogastric tube would confirm this diagnosis.

Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD) can manifest with signs of respiratory distress. However, BPD is a chronic lung condition that develops in preterm infants who are exposed to prolonged (>28 days) mechanical ventilation and O_2 therapy. Although this patient will be put at risk for BPD if he receives mechanical ventilation, he has no features of this condition at the moment.

question_text: Two hours after delivery, a 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) female newborn has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother has noticed that the bluish lip discoloration worsens when she feeds and improves when she cries. The newborn's pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: Two hours after delivery, a 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) female newborn has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother has noticed that the bluish lip discoloration worsens when she feeds and improves when she cries. The newborn's pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The newborn's condition is associated with CHARGE syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize bilateral choanal atresia, and recall its diagnostic finding.

answers.content: Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray
answers.explanation_why: Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray are seen in neonates with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). NRDS is typically seen in premature infants due to impaired synthesis and secretion of surfactant. Affected newborns have tachypnea, expiratory grunting, and cyanosis immediately following birth. However, auscultation of the lungs in newborns with NRDS shows decreased breath sounds, and breathing would not normalize after crying.

Acrocyanosis (blue extremities and a pink trunk) is common in neonates and is not necessarily a sign of a concerning pathology. In premature infants, even transient apnea is not unusual, as their regulatory functions are not yet fully developed. However, this patient shows signs of central cyanosis and intermittent dyspnea, which are unusual, especially for a full-term infant.

A boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray is a typical finding in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), the most common congenital cyanotic heart disease. In addition to persistent mild cyanosis, patients with TOF may develop recurrent episodes of cyanosis and hypoxia during feeding and crying. However, these tet spells are more common between the ages of 2 and 4 months rather than immediately following birth. In addition, this patient's cyanosis worsens with feeding rather than during a physiologic stressor and improves with crying, which is unlikely in patients with TOF.

images.title: Boot-shaped heart in tetralogy of Fallot
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of FallotThe cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

answers.content: Inability to pass a gastric catheter through the mouth
answers.explanation_why: Insertion of a gastric catheter through the mouth would be impossible in patients with esophageal atresia (EA), in which the upper and lower esophagus are not connected. This congenital defect is often associated with a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) between the lower esophagus and trachea. Patients develop cyanotic attacks, excessive foamy secretions at the mouth, and coughing spells immediately after birth. Normalization of breathing after crying suggests another diagnosis.

answers.content: Inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavity
answers.explanation_why: This patient is presenting shortly after birth with difficulty breathing and cyanosis that worsens when feeding and improves when crying, which are typical symptoms of bilateral choanal atresia. Patients with this condition have complete blockage of both nasal cavities and, therefore, are only able to breathe through their mouths, which results in cyanosis when the mouth is blocked during feeding. The inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavities supports the presumptive diagnosis of choanal atresia. Confirmatory testing by CT scan or contrast rhinography in the supine position should follow. Unilateral choanal atresia is twice as prevalent as its bilateral counterpart. However, the bilateral type is most frequently associated with other congenital anomalies, most commonly CHARGE syndrome.

images.title: Choanal atresia
images.description: Retropalatal endoscopic viewUnilateral choanal atresia can be seen.

answers.explanation_why: A scaphoid abdomen and barrel-shaped chest are typical findings in patients with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). In CDH, herniation of bowel contents into the chest cavity results in pulmonary hypoplasia, and patients develop tachypnea, respiratory distress, and cyanosis. However, in patients with CDH, an absence of breath sounds would be present on auscultation of the ipsilateral chest, and if on the left side (most common), bowel sounds would be present, unlike the normal auscultatory findings in this patient. In addition, the degree of cyanosis would not change during feeding and crying.

question_text: A 5-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at term to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. The patient's Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He is 48.5 cm (19 in) in length and weighs 3080 g (6 lb 13 oz). He appears pale. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 167/min, and respirations are 56/min. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. The lungs are clear to auscultation. No murmurs are heard. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.6 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 73 μm^3. Genetic testing for hemoglobinopathies shows 3 missing alleles. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?
content_preview: A 5-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at term to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. The patient's Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He is 48.5 cm (19 in) in length and weighs 3080 g (6 lb 13 oz). He appears pale. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 167/min, and respirations are 56/min. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin, and the spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. The lungs are clear to auscultation. No murmurs are heard. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.6 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume is 73 μm3. Genetic testing for hemoglobinopathies shows 3 missing alleles. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?
hint: A newborn with microcytic anemia, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and 3 missing alleles on genetic testing for hemoglobinopathies indicates a type of alpha thalassemia.
learning_objective: Recognize alpha thalassemia intermedia (HbH disease), and recall the characteristic laboratory finding.

answers.explanation_why: A low reticulocyte count with anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and pathological jaundice is seen in congenital infections with bone marrow suppression (e.g., rubella, parvovirus B19), and neonatal leukemias, which are extremely rare. However, key features of these conditions are missing and normocytic anemia would be expected (not microcytic anemia). Patients with anemia due to thalassemia typically have a high reticulocyte count and RBC count because of increased production in response to hemolysis.

Increased spherocyte count is seen in patients with hereditary spherocytosis, which manifests with jaundice, splenomegaly, and pallor. However, patients typically develop normocytic anemia rather than microcytic anemia. Furthermore, thalassemias usually manifest with target cells and/or teardrop cells on peripheral blood smear, not spherocytes.

Schistocytes are seen in patients with microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA). Causes of MAHA with jaundice during the neonatal period include large hemangiomas (Kasabach-Merritt syndrome), congenital thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, and DIC due to sepsis. There is, however, no thrombocytopenia on the CBC to suggest any of these diagnoses. There is also no evidence of a hemangioma, petechiae/purpura, or risk factors associated with neonatal sepsis (e.g., preterm delivery, meconium-stained fluid, admission to a neonatal ICU).

Low serum ferritin is seen in patients with iron deficiency anemia (IDA), which may occur in neonates as a result of decreased iron stores and increased iron requirement (due to rapid growth during early infancy). IDA would manifest as microcytic anemia but would not be expected at birth unless the mother had a severe iron deficiency as well. Jaundice, hepatomegaly, and missing alleles on genetic testing suggest thalassemia, in which serum ferritin levels are typically normal or even elevated (due to repeated transfusions).

The production of alpha-globin is controlled by 2 genes (i.e., 4 alleles) on chromosome 16. The severity of alpha thalassemia is determined by the number of missing alleles. The absence of 3 alleles, as in this patient, indicates hemoglobin H disease (HbH disease), also referred to as alpha thalassemia intermedia (see “Overview of thalassemia” table). This condition is characterized by the presence of beta-globin tetramers, known as hemoglobin H (β4).

During the first weeks of life, newborns express fetal gamma-globin rather than beta-globin. In newborns with HbH disease, the relative deficiency of alpha-globin chains causes the fetal gamma-globin chains to tetramerize and form hemoglobin Barts (γ4); in unaffected newborns, hemoglobin F (α2,γ2) would be produced instead. Although hemoglobin Barts can arise in any type of alpha thalassemia (e.g., it accounts for 3–8% of the total hemoglobin in alpha thalassemia minor), newborns with HbH disease usually have 20–40% hemoglobin Barts at birth; hemoglobin Barts is occasionally used as a newborn screening parameter for these conditions. Four to six weeks after birth, beta-globin levels become sufficiently high for hemoglobin H to form, which can be seen on electrophoresis. Further expected findings in HbH disease include an elevated RBC count and reticulocyte count; these features can be used to distinguish between HbH disease and other types of anemia, such as iron deficiency anemia.

The presence of hemoglobin Barts is most pronounced in the absence of all 4 alleles (i.e., hemoglobin Barts disease), which typically leads to hydrops fetalis.

A compensatory increase of HbA_2 (α_2,δ_2) and HbF (α2,γ2) due to decreased beta-globin chain synthesis is expected in patients with beta thalassemia. Severe forms of beta thalassemia (beta thalassemia major) manifest with pallor, microcytic anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, and jaundice (due to hemolysis). However, the symptoms of beta thalassemia major usually appear after 4–6 months, when most of the beta-globin production occurs. Moreover, the production of beta-globin is controlled by a single gene (i.e., only 2 alleles). The absence of 3 alleles on genetic analysis and the onset of symptoms at birth suggest a diagnosis of alpha thalassemia. In alpha thalassemia, alpha-globin synthesis is affected and elevated HbA_2 is therefore not expected.
