question_text: A 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother has noticed that the girl's head is always tilted to the right. She was delivered at term, and childbirth was complicated by a breech position. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy. She is at 60^th percentile for length and weight. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 42/min. Examination shows the head tilted toward the right, and the chin rotated towards the left. Range of motion of the neck is limited. There is a palpable, firm, well-circumscribed mass in the right lower side of the neck. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician because her mother has noticed that the girl's head is always tilted to the right. She was delivered at term, and childbirth was complicated by a breech position. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy. She is at 60th percentile for length and weight. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 42/min. Examination shows the head tilted toward the right, and the chin rotated towards the left. Range of motion of the neck is limited. There is a palpable, firm, well-circumscribed mass in the right lower side of the neck. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The firm mass is within the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital torticollis, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the neck can help to clarify an undefined neck mass (e.g., retropharyngeal abscess), predict potential malignancy, and reveal a tumor's extent and location. However, the location of this patient's neck mass, history of intrauterine breeching position, tilted/rotated head, and restricted range of motion are classic features for a specific diagnosis that does not require CT imaging.

Botulinum toxin injection is an experimental second-line treatment for congenital torticollis. Although a few studies suggest that botulinum toxin may be beneficial, its efficacy is not yet confirmed.

This patient's presentation is consistent with congenital torticollis, which typically manifests with a tilted head toward the affected side, rotation of the chin towards the opposite side, and a limited range of motion of the neck. A palpable, well-circumscribed mass within the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM) due to fibrosis is also common. Ultrasound of the SCM can confirm the muscular origin of the mass. First-line treatment of congenital torticollis involves early initiation of physiotherapy with positioning exercises and passive stretching therapy to strengthen neck muscles, lengthen the SCM, and improve the cervical range of motion. The majority of cases of congenital torticollis resolve after 2–6 months of conservative management. In patients who do not improve after 12 months of conservative management, surgery (e.g., myotomy) is indicated to prevent complications such as cervical scoliosis and/or craniofacial asymmetry.

images.title: Congenital muscular torticollis
images.description: Congenital muscular torticollis (CMT) is caused by fibrosis and/or contraction of a sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle, resulting in neck flexion toward the affected SCM and chin rotation toward the opposite side. Physical examination typically shows limited passive range of motion (limited rotation and flexion of the neck). If untreated, CMT can result in craniofacial asymmetry.

answers.explanation_why: An x-ray of the cervical spine is indicated for suspected cervical trauma, atlantoaxial joint lesions, and other congenital bony anomalies (e.g., hemivertebrae, congenital scoliosis) that can lead to a rotated head position. Cervical spine injury during birth is very rare and would present with further symptoms such as neck pain and tenderness. Although this patient has a twisted and rotated head, she shows no signs of an acute injury and no symptoms of associated anomalies in other organ systems that are common in patients with congenital bony anomalies.

Fine needle aspiration (FNA) is indicated for neck masses that suggest pathologies such as lymphoma, thyroid cancer, salivary gland neoplasms, inflammatory lymphadenopathy, or metastases. If history and physical examination are inconclusive, FNA is indicated to exclude malignant conditions that require treatment. While this patient has a solitary neck mass, she lacks signs of infection (e.g., fever, painful lymph nodes, upper respiratory tract infection) that could have caused reactive lymphadenopathy. Signs of malignancy (e.g., fatigue, unexplained fever, night sweats, and/or weight loss) are also absent. Instead, this patient's head position suggests a diagnosis that does not require FNA.

A surgical approach (e.g., myotomy or bipolar release of the SCM) is only indicated in patients with congenital muscular torticollis who have failed 12 months of conservative management. However, more than 90% of children improve after 2–6 months of conservative therapy and do not require surgery. Since this patient has not yet received conservative treatment, a myotomy is not indicated.

question_text: A 4-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of a generalized rash. He was born at term. The mother had no prenatal care and has a history of gonorrhea, which was treated 4 years ago. The newborn is at the 50^th percentile for head circumference, 60^th percentile for length, and 55^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 152/min, and respirations are 51/min. Examination shows an erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules with an erythematous base over the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 4-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of a generalized rash. He was born at term. The mother had no prenatal care and has a history of gonorrhea, which was treated 4 years ago. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for head circumference, 60th percentile for length, and 55th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 152/min, and respirations are 51/min. Examination shows an erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules with an erythematous base over the trunk and extremities, sparing the palms and soles. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A pustular smear from this newborn will show eosinophils.
learning_objective: Recognize erythema toxicum neonatorum.

answers.explanation_why: Congenital candidiasis can manifest with an erythematous maculopapular rash and pustules on an erythematous base. However, the lesions typically appear soon after birth and the palms and soles are frequently involved. A history of premature rupture of membranes or maternal vaginal candidiasis would also be present.

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome may present 3–7 days after birth with areas of cutaneous erythema over the trunk and limbs, but the infant would be febrile and have flaccid blisters rather than pustules.

Infantile acropustulosis can appear as an erythematous maculopapular rash with pustules. However, lesions typically appear after 2 months, recur periodically, and the palms and soles are preferentially involved.

Erythema toxicum neonatorum appears within the first week of life as small, red macules and papules that progress to pustules with surrounding erythema. It is most likely caused by the immaturity of the sweat glands and follicles. The rash appears on the trunk and proximal extremities, but the palms and soles are typically spared. Although erythema toxicum sounds ominous, the condition is benign and requires no treatment. Complete resolution of the rash occurs within 7–14 days.

Milia may be seen in neonates and typically appear as pearly, white raised lesions over the face, gingiva, and palate, as opposed to the erythematous maculopapular and pustular rash over the trunk and extremities seen in this neonate.

Transient neonatal pustular melanosis may result in pustules over the trunks and limbs. However, patients typically have fine scales around the pustules (due to exfoliation) and hyperpigmented macules. Moreover, other sites, such as the neck and forehead, would also be affected, and sparing of the palms and soles would not occur.

images.title: Transient neonatal pustular melanosis
images.description: Multiple pustules and erosions are visible on this neonate's trunk.

answers.explanation_why: Cutis marmorata is seen in neonates and would appear as a red skin lesion, but it would be flat with a lacy or reticulate pattern, in contrast to the papular and pustular lesions seen here.

images.title: Cutis marmorata in decompression sickness
images.description: Photograph of a 35-year-old male patient with type 1 decompression sicknessViolaceous reticulate macules in a marbled pattern are visible on this patient's abdomen (red ink used for tracking changes in size).

answers.explanation_why: Congenital syphilis may appear as an erythematous maculopapular and/or pustular rash. However, the rash typically affects the palms and soles. Other manifestations such as nonimmune hydrops fetalis, anemia, hepatosplenomegaly, rhinitis, and/or a history of premature birth would also be present in congenital syphilis.

question_text: A 4390-g (9-lb 11-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus. Labor was prolonged by the impaction of the fetal shoulder and required hyperabduction of the left upper extremity. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination in the delivery room shows a constricted left pupil. There is drooping of the left eyelid. Active movement of the left upper extremity is reduced. Further evaluation of this newborn is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 4390-g (9-lb 11-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 28-year-old primigravid woman. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus. Labor was prolonged by the impaction of the fetal shoulder and required hyperabduction of the left upper extremity. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination in the delivery room shows a constricted left pupil. There is drooping of the left eyelid. Active movement of the left upper extremity is reduced. Further evaluation of this newborn is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Shoulder dystocia is a complication that can occur in macrosomic neonates born to mothers with diabetes mellitus. Obstetric maneuvers used to help deliver babies with shoulder dystocia can cause brachial plexus injury.
learning_objective: Recognize Klumpke palsy, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: Moderate to severe hypoxic encephalopathy will cause generalized hypotonia. Although this patient's complicated birthing process puts him at increased risk for hypoxic encephalopathy due to perinatal asphyxia, other findings would also be expected in this condition (e.g., lethargy, decreased response to physical stimuli, and/or irregular breathing), which are not evident given his high Apgar scores.

Crepitus in the upper chest suggests a clavicular fracture for which this infant is at increased risk because of his traumatic birthing process. Although a clavicular fracture is usually asymptomatic, it can manifest as pseudoparalysis with reduced movement of the arm (due to pain), as seen in this infant. However, the presence of ptosis and miosis suggests a brachial plexus injury and not pseudoparalysis.

A unilateral wrist drop can occur after injury to the radial nerve (e.g., mid-shaft fracture of the humerus) or injury to the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (e.g., penetrating trauma below the clavicle). However, neither radial nerve injury nor posterior cord injury would manifest with ptosis and miosis, which suggests that this patient has a different brachial plexus injury.

images.title: Radial nerve neuropathy
images.description:
Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP jointsSensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2^nd and 3^rd fingers. The 1^st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumbProximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

answers.explanation_why: An absent nasolabial fold suggests a cranial nerve (CN) VII injury, which most commonly results from a forceps-assisted delivery. Although this patient has other facial abnormalities (ptosis and miosis), these findings are due to sympathetic nerve injury originating from the brachial plexus. CN VII fibers do not run within the brachial plexus, and thus facial droop is not associated with this condition.

Klumpke palsy is due to injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8–T1), which can result from hyperabduction (excessive upward traction) of the arm during delivery. Concurrent injury to cervical sympathetic fibers may result in Horner syndrome (miosis and ptosis). Since C8 and T1 nerve fibers supply the ipsilateral intrinsic hand muscles, Klumpke palsy causes an absent grasp reflex. Treatment for Klumpke palsy consists of passive range of motion exercises, and most infants will gain normal strength within the first couple of months of life.

Spina bifida cystica can manifest with a lower back mass due to protrusion of the meninges (i.e., meningocele) and spinal cord (i.e., myelomeningocele). Although these patients will have symptoms of spinal cord dysfunction, spina bifida cystica of the lower cord would cause lower extremity weakness, not unilateral arm deficits and facial sympathetic nerve dysfunction, as seen in this infant.

answers.content: Decreased movement of unilateral rib cage
answers.explanation_why: Unilateral phrenic nerve palsy can cause decreased movement of the ipsilateral rib cage and respiratory distress in the newborn. Phrenic nerve palsy can be a rare complication of a brachial plexus injury. Although this infant has evidence of brachial plexus injury (i.e., ptosis, miosis, decreased arm movement), he has no respiratory issues and normal vital signs, making phrenic nerve palsy unlikely.

question_text: A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. She has no personal history of serious illness. Medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 24-week gestation. A 1-hour 50-g glucose challenge shows a glucose concentration of 155 mg/dL (N < 135). A 100-g oral glucose tolerance test shows glucose concentrations of 205 mg/dL (N < 180) and 154 mg/dL (N < 140) at 1 and 3 hours, respectively. She refuses treatment with insulin. If the mother's condition is left untreated, evaluation of the infant after birth will most likely show which of the following?
content_preview: A 29-year-old primigravid woman at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She feels well. She has no personal history of serious illness. Medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 24-week gestation. A 1-hour 50-g glucose challenge shows a glucose concentration of 155 mg/dL (N < 135). A 100-g oral glucose tolerance test shows glucose concentrations of 205 mg/dL (N < 180) and 154 mg/dL (N < 140) at 1 and 3 hours, respectively. She refuses treatment with insulin. If the mother's condition is left untreated, evaluation of the infant after birth will most likely show which of the following?
hint: Although most infants who develop this condition are asymptomatic, this abnormality could result in prolonged QTc, poor feeding, and even seizures.
learning_objective: Recognize gestational diabetes, and recall its neonatal complications.

answers.explanation_why: Infants born to diabetic mothers are at increased risk for polycythemia (hematocrit > 65%), not anemia. Fetal hyperinsulinemia results in an increased metabolic demand that can lead to fetal hypoxia and increased RBC production to compensate.

Infants of mothers with diabetes are at risk for transient hypoglycemia. Because glucose is passively transferred through the placenta, persistently elevated glucose concentrations in the mother throughout pregnancy leads to hyperinsulinemia in the developing fetus in order to maintain euglycemia. After birth, the combination of high insulin levels and the cessation of high glucose transfer from the mother results in transient hypoglycemia. Insulin production may take several hours to days to return to physiological levels; therefore, infants may require exogenous glucose administration to prevent life-threatening complications.

Infants born to diabetic mothers are not at increased risk for developing an omphalocele. However, they are at increased risk for small left colon syndrome, which presents as the delayed passage of meconium.

images.title: Congenital malformations of the anterior abdominal wall
images.description: Omphalocele: herniation of intraabdominal contents through an anterior abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord caused by the failure of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity after its physiological herniation through the umbilical ring. Accordingly, the hernial sac is formed by the amniotic membrane and peritoneum, and the umbilical cord lies at the apex of the hernia.Gastroschisis: a developmental defect of the anterior abdominal wall in the paraumbilical region through which intraabdominal contents prolapse. As it is the anterior abdominal wall that fails to develop correctly, there is no outer peritoneal or membranous covering.Congenital umbilical hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through a patent umbilical orifice, which typically closes by 2 years of age. The sac of a paraumbilical hernia is the peritoneum.Diastasis recti: an abnormally wide separation of the right and left rectus abdominis muscles. The abdominal fascia are intact. There is therefore no herniation, but a midline bulge is visible on straining (e.g., when trying to sit up).

answers.explanation_why: Infants born to diabetic mothers are at increased risk for hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, not dilated cardiomyopathy. Fetal hyperinsulinemia results in an increased metabolic demand that can lead to fetal hypoxia, triggering RBC production and redistribution of iron from cardiac tissue into hemoglobin. The combination of cardiac tissue iron deficiency and hypoxemia can impair cardiac modeling, usually in the septal regions, and cause hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

Very low birth weight is a complication of various pregnancy-related conditions, including low calcium supplementation, premature delivery, and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). Although infants born to mothers with pregestational diabetes are at an increased risk for IUGR, this patient has gestational diabetes, which is more commonly associated with fetal macrosomia as a result of excessive insulin secretion.

Potter sequence is a complication of intrauterine growth restriction, which can occur as a result of oligohydramnios. Infants born to diabetic mothers, however, have an increased risk for polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios; fetal hyperglycemia results in fetal polyuria and thus increased amniotic fluid.

Infants born to mothers with pregestational diabetes, not gestational diabetes, are at risk for caudal regression syndrome. This mother has no evidence of diabetes prior to pregnancy that would place her infant at increased risk for caudal regression syndrome.

Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk for hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. Although the exact mechanism is not fully understood, it is thought that hypocalcemia may be due to abnormal maternal calcium-phosphorus metabolism, decreased concentrations of maternal vitamin D, and/or low levels of maternal magnesium levels that impair PTH release, which results in hypoparathyroidism. Routine screening for hypocalcemia is not performed in otherwise healthy infants born to mothers with diabetes.

question_text:
A 23-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician at 36 weeks' gestation for her first prenatal visit. She confirmed the pregnancy with a home urine pregnancy kit a few months ago but has not yet followed up with a physician. She takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
10.6 g/dL

Serum

 Glucose
88 mg/dL

 Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative

 Hepatitis C antibody
negative

 HIV antibody

positive

 HIV load

11,000 copies/mL

Ultrasonography shows an intrauterine fetus consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time?
content_preview: A 23-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician at 36 weeks' gestation for her first prenatal visit. She confirmed the pregnancy with a home urine pregnancy kit a few months ago but has not yet followed up with a physician. She takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 10.6 g/dL Serum Glucose 88 mg/dL Hepatitis B surface antigen negative Hepatitis C antibody negative HIV antibody positive HIV load 11,000 copies/mL Ultrasonography shows an intrauterine fetus consistent in size with a 36-week gestation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management at this time?
hint: The risk of vertical transmission of HIV from the mother to the fetus is highest during childbirth.
learning_objective: Choose the management strategy to reduce vertical transmission of HIV in pregnancy.

answers.content: Plan for vaginal delivery with intrapartum zidovudine administration when labor occurs
answers.explanation_why: Intrapartum zidovudine reduces the risk of vertical transmission of HIV during labor and should be administered if the maternal viral load is > 1000 copies/mL, and in patients with a viral load ≥ 50 copies/mL after the risks and benefits have been discussed. However, intrapartum zidovudine alone is not sufficient for reducing the risk of transmission. Furthermore, vaginal delivery is not recommended in pregnant women with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL near the time of delivery.

answers.content: Start combined antiretroviral therapy and schedule cesarean delivery with intrapartum zidovudine administration at 38 weeks' gestation
answers.explanation_why:
Combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) is recommended throughout pregnancy in all pregnant women with HIV infection and should be initiated as soon as possible to reduce the viral load and risk of transmission. Effective maternal cART (and neonatal zidovudine therapy) can reduce perinatal HIV transmission to < 2%, compared to a transmission rate of 30% in untreated individuals. In pregnant women with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL, as seen in this patient, cesarean delivery should be scheduled at 38 weeks to avoid vaginal delivery, which is associated with an increased risk of transmission. In addition, intrapartum zidovudine is indicated to further reduce the risk of neonatal HIV infection (see “Intrapartum management of HIV” table).

Infant antiretroviral prophylaxis is recommended in all newborns of mothers with HIV infection and includes either zidovudine alone for 4 weeks (viral load < 50 copies/mL) or cART for 6 weeks (viral load ≥ 50 copies/mL).

answers.content: Start combined antiretroviral therapy and schedule vaginal delivery with induction of labor at 38 weeks' gestation
answers.explanation_why: Combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) is recommended throughout pregnancy and should be initiated as soon as possible to reduce the viral load and risk of transmission. Although vaginal delivery may be considered in pregnant women with a viral load ≤ 1000 copies/mL, it is not recommended in patients with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL because it is associated with a significant risk of intrapartum transmission. cART generally reduces the viral load considerably within one month, which is not sufficient in this patient at 36 weeks' gestation.

answers.content: Schedule cesarean delivery with intrapartum zidovudine administration at 38 weeks' gestation
answers.explanation_why: Intrapartum zidovudine reduces the risk of vertical transmission of HIV during labor and should be administered if the maternal viral load is > 1000 copies/mL, and in patients with a viral load ≥ 50 copies/mL after the risks and benefits have been discussed. However, intrapartum zidovudine alone is not sufficient for reducing the risk of transmission. Cesarean delivery at 38 weeks of gestation is recommended in all pregnant women with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL because it is associated with a lower risk of intrapartum HIV transmission than other methods of delivery.

answers.content: Schedule vaginal delivery with induction of labor at 38 weeks' gestation
answers.explanation_why: Vaginal delivery is not recommended in women with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL near the time of delivery because it is associated with an increased risk of HIV transmission. Furthermore, all individuals infected with HIV (regardless of CD4 count) should begin combined antiretroviral therapy (cART) as soon as possible to reduce HIV-associated morbidity and the risk of transmission.

Cesarean delivery is recommended in all pregnant women with a viral load > 1000 copies/mL because it is associated with a lower risk of intrapartum HIV transmission than other methods of delivery. However, the patient is in the 36^th week of pregnancy and the maternal HIV infection does not justify immediate cesarean delivery. This should be scheduled at 38 weeks.

question_text: A 2300-g (5-lb 1-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 29-year-old primigravid woman at 38 weeks' gestation via cesarean delivery. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy. Her HIV viral load was 45 copies/mL 1 week prior to delivery. Delivery was uncomplicated. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Physical examination of the newborn shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this newborn?
content_preview: A 2300-g (5-lb 1-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 29-year-old primigravid woman at 38 weeks' gestation via cesarean delivery. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy. Her HIV viral load was 45 copies/mL 1 week prior to delivery. Delivery was uncomplicated. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Physical examination of the newborn shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this newborn?
hint: Postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) is recommended for infants born to mothers with HIV infection to decrease the risk of transmission.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate postexposure prophylaxis for a newborn born to a mother with HIV.

answers.explanation_why: HIV RNA testing is indicated 14–21 days, 1–2 months, and 4–6 months after birth in infants exposed to HIV.
HIV antibody testing is not advised for children < 18 months of age, as maternal antibodies still present in the infant's bloodstream can act as confounding factors and invalidate the test.

Zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine are recommended for HIV PEP in infants born to HIV-positive mothers with HIV and a viral load of ≥ 50 copies/mL. However, a three-drug regimen is not recommended for a mother with a viral load < 50 copies/mL because of the greater risk of adverse effects, such as neutropenia and anemia.

Because HIV transmission will have severe consequences for the neonate, minimization of transmission risk is of paramount importance. Simple reassurance is inappropriate, as other options can help reduce the rate of transmission.

Lamivudine and nevirapine can be used in combination with zidovudine for HIV PEP in infants if the mother's viral load is ≥ 50 copies/mL. However, this combination is not indicated if the viral load is < 50 copies/mL because of the greater risk of adverse effects.

For infants born to mothers with HIV and a viral load < 50 copies/mL, PEP with zidovudine for 4 weeks is recommended to prevent neonatal transmission of HIV. If the mother's viral load is ≥ 50 copies/mL, a two-drug regimen (zidovudine and nevirapine) or a three-drug regimen (zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine or raltegravir) is recommended.

See "Intrapartum management of HIV" table.

question_text:
A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of poor feeding, irritability, and vomiting for 2 weeks. She was born at 36 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was uncomplicated. She is at 5^th percentile for length and at 3^rd percentile for weight. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 49/min. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Serum

 Na^+

138 mEq/L

 K^+

3.1 mEq/L

 Cl^-

115 mEq/L

 Ammonia

23 μmol/L (N = 11–35)

Urine

 pH

6.9

 Blood
negative

 Glucose
negative

 Protein
negative

Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.28

pO_2

96 mm Hg

HCO_3^-
12 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of poor feeding, irritability, and vomiting for 2 weeks. She was born at 36 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was uncomplicated. She is at 5th percentile for length and at 3rd percentile for weight. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 112/min, and respirations are 49/min. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Serum Na+ 138 mEq/L K+ 3.1 mEq/L Cl- 115 mEq/L Ammonia 23 μmol/L (N = 11–35) Urine pH 6.9 Blood negative Glucose negative Protein negative Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.28 pO2 96 mm Hg HCO3- 12 mEq/L Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: Failure to thrive in an infant with a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, a urine pH > 5.5, and hypokalemia is suggestive of renal tubular acidosis type 1 (type 1 RTA).
learning_objective: Recognize renal tubular acidosis type 1, and recall its underlying defect.

answers.explanation_why: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia caused by severe 21β-hydroxylase deficiency can manifest during infancy with failure to thrive, vomiting, poor feeding, and hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis. However, urine pH would be < 5.5, and patients would be hyperkalemic as well as hyponatremic as a result of aldosterone deficiency (type 4 renal tubular acidosis). Clitoromegaly or ambiguous genitalia would also be present in this infant if she had severe 21β-hydroxylase deficiency.

answers.content: Impaired metabolism of branched-chain amino acids
answers.explanation_why: Impaired metabolism of branched-chain amino acids is the underlying pathology in maple syrup urine disease, which may manifest with poor feeding, irritability, vomiting, and failure to thrive. However, the onset of symptoms occurs during the early neonatal period, and patients have an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis (due to the accumulation of intermediate ketoacids). Moreover, the newborn screening test would have been positive, and the patient's urine would have a characteristic sickly sweet odor of maple syrup.

answers.content: Inability of Henle's loop to reabsorb Cl^-
answers.explanation_why: An inability of the ascending limb of Henle's loop to reabsorb Cl^- is seen in Bartter syndrome, which may manifest with preterm delivery, vomiting, a failure to thrive, and hypokalemia. Irritability and poor feeding may also occur as a result of severe dehydration (due to polyuria). However, there is no history to suggest polyuria (e.g., frequent changing of diapers), or evidence of severe dehydration in this patient (e.g., tenting of skin, sunken eyes, tachypnea, hypotension). Moreover, Bartter syndrome typically causes metabolic alkalosis, not metabolic acidosis.

answers.content: Inability of the proximal tubule to reabsorb HCO_3^-
answers.explanation_why: Inability of the proximal convoluted tubule to reabsorb HCO_3^- would result in type 2 RTA, which can manifest with a failure to thrive, vomiting, hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis, and hypokalemia. However, patients with type 2 RTA would typically have a urine pH < 5.5 (due to increased H^+ secretion by the distal tubule in an attempt to correct metabolic acidosis).

A CFTR mutation is responsible for cystic fibrosis (CF), which may manifest with a failure to thrive. Irritability, vomiting, and poor feeding may also occur as a result of respiratory infections or intestinal obstruction. However, a cough or clinical features of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, cyanosis, nasal flaring) are absent in this patient, and there is no history of abdominal distention or obstipation. Additionally, CF typically results in hypochloremia with respiratory acidosis and/or metabolic alkalosis. Lastly, a positive newborn screening test for CF was not reported.

answers.content: Inability of the distal tubule to secrete H^+
answers.explanation_why: Type 1 RTA is associated with decreased activity of the H^+/K^+ATPase antiporter on the apical surface of intercalated cells, which inhibits the distal tubule from secreting H^+and reabsorbing K^+ from the lumen of the tubule. This subsequently results in hypokalemia and hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis with urine that cannot be acidified to a pH < 5.5. The most likely cause of type 1 RTA in an infant is an inherited genetic defect. However, an ultrasound is usually performed to rule out other causes, such as nephrocalcinosis, medullary sponge kidney, and reflux nephropathy. Treatment of type 1 RTA consists of alkalization therapy with orally administered sodium bicarbonate or sodium citrate.

images.title: Transport in the connecting tubule and collecting duct
images.description: The connecting tubule is the most distal part of the distal tubule. The physiological function of the connecting tubule and the collecting duct is to fine-tune the composition of the urine, which can also be regulated by hormones (not shown here). There are different types of cells:1) Principal cells (upper part of the image) reabsorb water via aquaporins and contribute to sodium resorption via aldosterone-controlled sodium channels.2) Intercalated cells mainly participate in the regulation of blood pH and are divided into Type A/α and Type B/β cells. α-Intercalated cells (middle part of the image) secrete protons into the lumen and transport bicarbonate into the Interstitium. β-Intercalated cells (lower part of the image) transport protons into the Interstitium and secrete bicarbonate into the lumen.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) may result in vomiting, poor feeding, failure to thrive, and irritability during infancy. However, patients would have a raised serum ammonium level and respiratory alkalosis with tachypnea (due to stimulation of the respiratory center by hyperammonemia). Moreover, OTC deficiency is an X-linked recessive disease that primarily affects boys and typically presents during the neonatal period.

question_text: A 2500-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 35 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 78%. Examination in the delivery room shows that the newborn's skin appears blue. He has a weak cry with irregular breathing and gasping. The nose is flat with prominent bilateral epicanthal folds. The ears are low-set with broad auricles. The lower jaw is abnormally displaced backwards. The right lower limb appears shorter than the left lower limb with displaced right great toe. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral dilatation of the renal pelvis and ureters. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 2500-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 35 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 78%. Examination in the delivery room shows that the newborn's skin appears blue. He has a weak cry with irregular breathing and gasping. The nose is flat with prominent bilateral epicanthal folds. The ears are low-set with broad auricles. The lower jaw is abnormally displaced backwards. The right lower limb appears shorter than the left lower limb with displaced right great toe. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral dilatation of the renal pelvis and ureters. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This newborn has features suggestive of Potter sequence: respiratory distress, Potter facies, limb anomalies, and a pregnancy complicated by oligohydramnios.
learning_objective: Recognize Potter sequence, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why:
Voiding cystourethrogram is the test of choice to diagnose posterior urethral valves (PUV), which is the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction (UTO) in newborn males. Lower UTO, indicated by the presence of bilateral hydronephrosis on renal ultrasound, results in reduced urine output and oligohydramnios. The decreased amount of amniotic fluid leads to the development of Potter sequence. Moreover, oligohydramnios can affect the development of the fetal lung resulting in lung hypoplasia, which is the most likely cause of this patient's cyanosis and hypoxia.

Once the vital functions have been stabilized, temporary insertion of a urinary catheter can relieve the UTO and allow for correction of possible electrolyte imbalances. Definitive treatment of PUV is either primary valve ablation during cystoscopy (first-line) or vesicostomy (in preterm boys or if ablation is not possible).

Echocardiography is used to confirm congenital heart defects. Cyanotic heart defects may present shortly after birth with respiratory distress and cyanosis. Some of these defects are associated with certain genetic/chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot or persistent truncus arteriosus with DiGeorge syndrome), which often present with craniofacial anomalies. However, the patient's hydronephrosis and limb abnormalities cannot be explained by this diagnosis.

Karyotyping confirms chromosomal abnormalities, which are frequently associated with dysmorphic facial and limb abnormalities. Low-set ears and retrognathia can be seen in patients with Edwards syndrome. A flattened nose and epicanthus are features of Down syndrome. The combination of oligohydramnios, hydronephrosis, and respiratory distress in the newborn period would not be typical for a chromosomal aberration. Certain causes of Potter sequence are associated with chromosomal aberrations. However, these abnormalities usually account for bilateral renal agenesis, whereas this infant's ultrasound confirms the presence of two kidneys.

Blood cultures are essential in a newborn with respiratory distress to rule out sepsis. Early-onset sepsis (≤ 72 hours after birth) is often due to chorioamnionitis or bacterial colonization of the maternal genital tract (e.g., with group B Streptococcus). While the symptoms of neonatal sepsis may be nonspecific, infants with neonatal pneumonia typically present with dyspnea and decreased breath sounds, as seen in the vignette. However, neonatal pneumonia would not explain hydronephrosis and dysmorphia in this child.

In patients with Potter sequence, chest x-ray may reveal pulmonary hypoplasia as the cause of this patient's respiratory distress, but it does not reveal the underlying mechanism of the condition. Chest x-ray is used, however, for diagnosing infant respiratory distress syndrome (IRDS) and meconium aspiration. IRDS manifests most frequently in preterm infants, usually immediately after birth, with signs of increased breathing effort, hypoxia, cyanosis, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation. However, the additional clinical features seen in this neonate (e.g., craniofacial dysmorphism, limb abnormalities, and hydronephrosis) could not be explained by this diagnosis. Meconium aspiration syndrome manifests with respiratory distress or unresponsiveness usually in postterm rather than preterm infants. Furthermore, the absence of a green amniotic fluid makes the diagnosis unlikely in this patient.

question_text: A 6-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 1800 g (3 lb 15 oz); he currently weighs 1700 g (3 lb 12 oz). His mother has Graves disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 180/min, and respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 6-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 1800 g (3 lb 15 oz); he currently weighs 1700 g (3 lb 12 oz). His mother has Graves disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 180/min, and respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This neonate, born to a mother with Graves disease, has features highly suggestive of neonatal thyrotoxicosis: irritability, restlessness, tachycardia, goiter, diaphoresis, increased bowel movement, and poor weight gain despite an adequate appetite.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal thyrotoxicosis, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why: Up to 5% of infants born to mothers with Graves disease develop thyrotoxicosis due to the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory TSH receptor antibodies (TRAb). Symptoms may appear directly after birth or can be delayed up to 10 days as a result of transplacental maternal antithyroid medication (e.g., propylthiouracil, carbimazole). The thyrotoxicosis is transient and usually resolves within 12 weeks, when the maternal TRAb disappears from the infant's circulation. Before resolution, though, neonatal thyrotoxicosis should be treated as soon as it is diagnosed to prevent complications such as cardiac failure, intellectual disability, and craniosynostosis. Methimazole is administered to achieve a euthyroid state, which can take up to a few weeks. During this period, a beta blocker (e.g., propranolol) should be coadministered to rapidly control the thyrotoxic symptoms.

Potassium iodide is preferred as an adjunctive treatment of thyrotoxicosis refractory to treatment with antithyroid drugs and beta blockers. Its therapeutic benefit is limited because the thyroid gland overcomes the iodide block within a few weeks.

Naloxone is an opioid antagonist which is used in the management of opioid toxicity. Given that this mother has a history of IV heroin use, this newborn may have been exposed in-utero, which would put him at risk of developing drug withdrawal symptoms (neonatal abstinence syndrome or NAS). Although patients with NAS due to heroin can present with irritability and restlessness, they mostly become symptomatic within 1–3 days after birth due to the short half-life of heroin. Other common symptoms of NAS are also not present, such as a high-pitched cry, feeding difficulties, vomiting, and refusal to sleep and to be consoled. Moreover, naloxone is not used in the treatment of NAS. NAS due to heroin withdrawal is treated with opioid therapy (e.g., morphine, methadone) with gradual tapering and discontinuation.

Dextrose therapy is indicated in the management of neonatal hypoglycemia. The neonate in this vignette is at risk of developing hypoglycemia because of his low birth weight and diarrhea. Although irritability, diaphoresis, and tachycardia are important symptoms of hypoglycemia, the frequent feeds, and goiter cannot be explained by hypoglycemia. In contrast, a hypoglycemic infant will be listless, hypotonic, have a shrill cry, and feed poorly (due to fatigue).

Empirical administration of ampicillin and gentamicin may be indicated for neonatal sepsis. Although sepsis in a neonate can manifest as irritability, tachycardia, and tachypnea, it does not cause goiter. A neonate with sepsis would also have poor feeding and hypo/hyperthermia. Additionally, this neonate has no risk factors for the development of neonatal sepsis, such as prolonged rupture of membranes, prematurity, maternal chorioamnionitis.

Calcium gluconate therapy is indicated in the management of neonatal hypocalcemia, which is commonly asymptomatic but can also manifest with muscle twitches/jerks or seizures. Risk factors for the development of neonatal hypocalcemia include maternal diabetes/hyperparathyroidism and prematurity (for early-onset hypocalcemia, < 2 days after birth) and cow's milk/high-phosphate formula feeds (for late-onset hypocalcemia, > 3 days after birth). Late-onset hypocalcemia is very rare. In this neonate, the presence of a goiter and a maternal history of Graves' disease make the diagnosis of hypocalcemia unlikely.

question_text: A 5-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a red lesion on her scalp that was first noticed 2 months ago. The lesion has been slowly increasing in size. It is not associated with pain or pruritus. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Her older sister is currently undergoing treatment for a fungal infection of her feet. Examination shows a solitary, soft lesion on the vertex of the scalp that blanches with pressure. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 5-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a red lesion on her scalp that was first noticed 2 months ago. The lesion has been slowly increasing in size. It is not associated with pain or pruritus. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Her older sister is currently undergoing treatment for a fungal infection of her feet. Examination shows a solitary, soft lesion on the vertex of the scalp that blanches with pressure. A photograph of the lesion is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This infant presents with infantile hemangioma (strawberry hemangioma), one of the most common vascular tumors of infancy, characterized by a rapid proliferation of endothelial cells.
learning_objective: Recognize infantile hemangioma, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Laser ablation is a treatment option for strawberry hemangiomas that grow rapidly, ulcerate, or manifest in problematic areas (e.g., periorbital region, airway) and do not respond to the recommended first-line treatment. Since this patient has a slowly growing strawberry hemangioma that does not cause significant functional impairment or disfigurement, laser ablation is not indicated at this point.

Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits angiogenesis and could, in theory, aid in the treatment of a strawberry hemangioma. However, the intended use of bevacizumab is not strawberry hemangioma and the lesion in this patient does not cause significant enough functional impairment or disfigurement to warrant treatment with bevacizumab.

Topical corticosteroids such as clobetasol have previously been used for small superficial strawberry hemangiomas. However, because topical corticosteroids are associated with considerable adverse effects including skin atrophy, hypertrichosis, and hypopigmentation, they are no longer routinely used.

Ketoconazole cream or shampoo can be used in severe cases of infantile seborrheic dermatitis, which manifests as erythematous, scaling plaques and greasy, yellow, adherent scales. It does not cause solitary, soft vascular lesions that blanch with pressure.

Shave excision would be a viable treatment option for a symptomatic superficial cherry, not strawberry, hemangioma. In patients with cherry hemangiomas, shave excision is also used for diagnostic purposes to rule out malignancy. Although cherry hemangiomas can appear similar to the lesion seen here, they are tumors of middle-aged and elderly rather than pediatric patients.

Oral propranolol is the treatment of choice for strawberry hemangiomas that grow rapidly, ulcerate, or manifest in problematic areas (e.g., periorbital region, airway). This patient has a slowly growing strawberry hemangioma that does not cause significant functional impairment or disfigurement. Therefore, treatment with propranolol is not indicated at this point.

Systemic griseofulvin would be the treatment of choice for tinea capitis, which mostly affects children. This patient's sibling is currently undergoing treatment for a fungal infection of her feet, which puts this patient at risk of contracting this disease. However, tinea capitis causes pruritus and alopecia in the affected area.

images.title: Tinea capitis
images.description: There are multiple confluent, scaly lesions with central redness and hair loss visible on the scalp.This is the typical appearance of tinea capitis due to infection with microsporum canis

answers.explanation_why: Strawberry hemangiomas are common benign vascular tumors that occur in up to 10% of infants and more commonly in girls. These lesions usually appear within the first days to months of life. The vast majority of these tumors resolve spontaneously by age 5–8 years without treatment. Management comprises active nonintervention, which includes regular monitoring to evaluate the clinical course of the hemangioma. Active intervention is necessary for complicated hemangiomas, such as those with a problematic location (e.g., periorbital region, airway). Other indications for active intervention include ulcerated lesions and tumors that cause significant disfigurement or functional impairment. In this patient, no further management besides reassurance and follow-up is necessary at this point.

images.title: Infantile superficial hemangioma
images.description: The scalp has a solitary, ovoid, bright red nodule with irregular texture.This finding is suggestive of superficial hemangioma.

question_text: A 26-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding and lethargy for 2 weeks. During this period, he has had a raspy cry. The child was delivered at term at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. He is at the 90^th percentile for head circumference, 50^th percentile for length, and 60^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows scleral icterus and an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is distended and there is a reducible, soft protruding mass at the umbilicus. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 26-day-old newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding and lethargy for 2 weeks. During this period, he has had a raspy cry. The child was delivered at term at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. He is at the 90th percentile for head circumference, 50th percentile for length, and 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows scleral icterus and an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is distended and there is a reducible, soft protruding mass at the umbilicus. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: If left untreated, this child is likely to develop intellectual disability.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital hypothyroidism due to thyroid dysgenesis.

answers.explanation_why: This patient has features consistent with congenital hypothyroidism (poor feeding and lethargy, a raspy/hoarse cry, prolonged newborn jaundice, umbilical hernia, increased head circumference, muscle hypotonia, macroglossia). The most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions is thyroid dysgenesis (i.e., thyroid hypoplasia, dysplasia, or aplasia). Early initiation of thyroxine supplementation is essential to prevent the patient from developing permanent intellectual disability. If the mother has clinical or subclinical hypothyroidism, the manifestations of congenital hypothyroidism may be apparent at birth; if the mother is euthyroid, the manifestations of congenital hypothyroidism develop a few weeks to months after birth because the placenta supplies the fetus with maternal thyroid hormone. Therefore, neonatal screening for thyroid deficiency is indicated even if the neonate is asymptomatic; screening is mandatory in the US and typically performed by measuring TSH levels 24–48 hours after birth.

Acid maltase deficiency leads to Pompe disease, which may present with macroglossia, poor feeding, and muscle hypotonia during the first few weeks to months of life. However, affected patients usually also have signs of cardiomyopathy (e.g., shortness of breath, tachypnea, tachycardia, jugular venous distention), which are absent here. Also, Pompe disease would not account for this patient's jaundice, raspy cry, umbilical hernia, and increased head circumference.

Trisomy 21 (i.e., Down syndrome) can also manifest with muscle hypotonia, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. However, the absence of classic clinical features of Down syndrome such as brachycephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, hypertelorism, flattened nose), Brushfield spots, a single transverse palmar crease, and sandal toes, makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Biliary atresia may present with delayed neonatal jaundice that becomes apparent at around 2 weeks of life. While this patient presents with scleral icterus, biliary atresia would not account for this newborn's raspy cry, umbilical hernia, macrocephaly, muscle hypotonia, and macroglossia.

A deficiency of α-L-iduronidase causes Hurler syndrome. While patients with Hurler syndrome may also present with abdominal distention (due to hepatosplenomegaly) and umbilical hernia, they generally do not become symptomatic until 6 months to 1 year of age. Hurler syndrome can cause a broad range of clinical symptoms, including musculoskeletal abnormalities (joint contractures, spinal deformity), developmental delay, coarse facial features, and corneal clouding. However, muscle hypotonia, macroglossia, and a raspy cry just 2 weeks after birth would not be expected.

An alteration of the short arm of chromosome 11 can cause Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS), which can manifest with macroglossia, abdominal distention (due to organ enlargement), and umbilical hernia. However, other classic findings of BWS such as macrosomia, hemihyperplasia, and hypoglycemia are not present in this patient.

question_text:
Three days after delivery, a 3850-g (8.5-lb) male newborn has several episodes of right-sided arm and leg twitching and lip-smacking. These shaking episodes have occurred about six times over the last hour and have lasted for about 40 seconds. He has also had rapid breathing and poor feeding. He has not had a fever or trauma. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. There is no family history of serious illness. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 212/min, and respirations are 70/min. He appears irritable and jittery. There are intermittent spasms present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Leukocyte count
9300/mm^3

Segmented neutrophils
60%

Eosinophils
2%

Lymphocytes
33%

Monocytes
5%

Serum

Calcium
6 mg/dL

PTH
5 pg/mL

Echocardiography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: Three days after delivery, a 3850-g (8.5-lb) male newborn has several episodes of right-sided arm and leg twitching and lip-smacking. These shaking episodes have occurred about six times over the last hour and have lasted for about 40 seconds. He has also had rapid breathing and poor feeding. He has not had a fever or trauma. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. There is no family history of serious illness. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 212/min, and respirations are 70/min. He appears irritable and jittery. There are intermittent spasms present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Leukocyte count 9300/mm3 Segmented neutrophils 60% Eosinophils 2% Lymphocytes 33% Monocytes 5% Serum Calcium 6 mg/dL PTH 5 pg/mL Echocardiography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: Calcium homeostasis is influenced by a delicate interplay of hormones (e.g., PTH, Vitamin D) and electrolytes (e.g., Ca^2+, Mg^2+). During pregnancy, the fetus' metabolic balance largely depends on regulatory processes in the mother's body. When these maternal regulatory processes cease after birth, the newborn may experience rebound symptoms (as seen with neonatal hypoglycemia in response to maternal diabetes).
learning_objective: Recognize maternal familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia.

answers.explanation_why: This newborn's mother most likely has familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH). In this condition, a decreased sensitivity to renal and parathyroid Ca^2+-sensing receptors causes a need for higher levels of Ca^2+ to suppress PTH. To satisfy this need, renal Ca^2+ reabsorption increases and, in turn, leads to hypocalciuria and hypercalcemia with an inappropriately normal or increased PTH. Because affected individuals are usually asymptomatic, the condition may go unnoticed, as is likely the case in the mother here. During pregnancy, maternal hypercalcemia causes fetal hypercalcemia and suppresses the fetal parathyroid glands. After birth, when the mother is not supplying the child with calcium via the placenta anymore, the neonate's suppressed PTH levels result in hypocalcemia, as seen here.

answers.content: Defective fetal development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches
answers.explanation_why: Defective fetal development of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches is the underlying etiology of DiGeorge syndrome. In this syndrome, hypoplastic parathyroids result in decreased PTH production and subsequent symptoms of hypocalcemia (e.g., jitteriness, seizures). Although this diagnosis could explain this newborn's symptoms and serum studies (i.e., low calcium and low PTH), the absence of other typical features of DiGeorge syndrome, such as dysmorphic facial features, lymphopenia, and signs of congenital heart disease (e.g., cyanosis, abnormal echocardiogram), makes the diagnosis less likely.

answers.content: Neonatal ingestion of formula with high phosphate load
answers.explanation_why: High phosphate levels may cause neonatal hypocalcemia, possibly due to high phosphate and calcium deposition in the bones and/or antagonistic effects of phosphate on PTH. Therefore, the use of cow's milk or formulas with a high phosphate concentration should be avoided. In contrast to this patient's early-onset hypocalcemia, infants with hypocalcemia due to high phosphate intake usually present at 5–10 days of age (i.e., late-onset hypocalcemia).

Increased neonatal thyroid hormone secretion is seen in neonatal hyperthyroidism, which may also manifest with irritability and tachycardia. However, this disorder is very rare and usually occurs in children whose mother suffers from Graves' disease (due to transplacental transfer of maternal stimulating TRAb). The absence of a history of Graves' disease in the mother and the patient's hypocalcemia, which could not be explained by this diagnosis, make neonatal hyperthyroidism unlikely.

Neonatal abstinence syndrome may manifest 1–3 days after birth with tachycardia, poor feeding, jerking, seizures, and irritability, as seen in this child. However, opioid withdrawal would not explain the patient's hypocalcemia and decreased PTH level.

question_text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of 4 episodes of vomiting that occurred that morning. The parents report that the vomit was yellowish-green with no blood in it. The patient was born at 38 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery and has generally been healthy. He has passed normal stools each day. There is no family history of serious illness. He appears irritable and pale. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 146/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, mildly distended abdomen with no masses or organomegaly. A nasogastric tube is inserted, and intravenous fluid resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of 4 episodes of vomiting that occurred that morning. The parents report that the vomit was yellowish-green with no blood in it. The patient was born at 38 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery and has generally been healthy. He has passed normal stools each day. There is no family history of serious illness. He appears irritable and pale. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 146/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, mildly distended abdomen with no masses or organomegaly. A nasogastric tube is inserted, and intravenous fluid resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This 3-week-old neonate presents with acute-onset bilious vomiting and a mildly distended abdomen, which should raise suspicion for midgut obstruction, most likely due to intestinal malrotation.
learning_objective: Recognize midgut obstruction in a neonate, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: CT imaging should not be performed on this patient. This patient has features that are most concerning for an anatomical obstruction in the midgut, and other diagnostic tests provide better visualization of this region. Moreover, a CT scan would expose this neonate to unnecessary radiation.

Laparoscopy would be indicated if further diagnostic workup did not establish a definitive diagnosis or was suggestive of malrotation with a complicating volvulus. In this neonate, further studies should be performed first to confirm the diagnosis.

An upper gastrointestinal contrast series is the most sensitive exam to visualize the duodenum in infants and the gold standard for diagnosis of intestinal malrotation with midgut volvulus. The obvious signs of malrotation are a misplaced ligament of Treitz and duodenojejunal junction on the right of the midline. A twisted and thus corkscrew-like appearance of the duodenum and duodenal blockage with a distended stomach would reflect midgut volvulus. See “Imaging in intestinal malrotation and midgut volvulus” table.

Given this neonate's hemodynamic stability, there is no indication for emergency surgery, but the Ladd procedure is recommended as soon as possible to minimize the risk of future volvulus.

images.title: Malrotation with midgut volvulus
images.description: Fluoroscopy (upper GI series)The distal duodenum and proximal jejunum has a spiral configuration (green overlay) and fail to cross the midline into the left upper quadrant. This appearance, referred to as the corkscrew sign, is produced by the twisting of small bowel loops on a shortened mesentery.The corkscrew sign is characteristic of intestinal malrotation with midgut volvulus.

answers.explanation_why: Water-soluble contrast enema is used as a confirmatory test and therapeutic tool for intussusception, which also manifests in infants with vomiting. However, as most cases of intussusception are ileocecal, bilious vomiting occurs only in progressive disease. Additionally, patients typically present between 3–12 months of age and usually also have acute cyclical abdominal pain (every 15–30 minutes) and possibly a palpable mass on abdominal exam.

Emergency exploratory laparotomy is indicated in cases of hemodynamic instability and/or bowel ischemia or perforation. This patient is hemodynamically stable, is afebrile, and has a soft abdomen, indicating that further diagnostic workup is safe. Should he decompensate and develop profound tachycardia, hypotension, signs of perforation (e.g., free air under the diaphragm on repeat plain film), or signs of bowel infarction (e.g. hematochezia), emergency surgery would be indicated.

Abdominal ultrasound is an important imaging modality for differentiating between causes of abdominal pain in children. It is most helpful in establishing the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis, which also manifests with acute-onset emesis and abdominal pain. Classically, an olive-shaped mass can be felt on abdominal exam; this patient's abdominal exam is notable for mild distention but no mass is evident. Moreover, the patient described here has bilious vomiting, a finding that is less likely with an obstruction caused by a hypertrophic pylorus, which is proximal to the ampulla of Vater and is therefore more commonly associated with nonbilious vomiting. While ultrasonography can be used in the diagnosis of intestinal malrotation and midgut volvulus, it is not the most sensitive diagnostic technique. For this reason, it is not the most appropriate next step in management.

Flexible sigmoidoscopy is used to treat sigmoid volvulus in patients who have no signs or symptoms of peritonitis (e.g., rebound tenderness, hemodynamic instability). Sigmoid volvulus is most commonly seen in elderly adults and manifests with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and bloating. This young patient most likely has a more proximal intestinal pathology, meaning that sigmoidoscopy would not be appropriate.

question_text: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She was born at 32 weeks' gestation and weighed 1616 g (3 lb 9 oz); she currently weighs 2466 g (5 lb 7 oz). She is exclusively breastfed and receives vitamin D supplementation. She received a single intramuscular dose of vitamin K at birth. Physical examination shows no abnormalities apart from low height and weight. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. She was born at 32 weeks' gestation and weighed 1616 g (3 lb 9 oz); she currently weighs 2466 g (5 lb 7 oz). She is exclusively breastfed and receives vitamin D supplementation. She received a single intramuscular dose of vitamin K at birth. Physical examination shows no abnormalities apart from low height and weight. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications?
hint: Laboratory studies would show an increased red blood cell distribution width (RDW).
learning_objective: Recall the complications associated with preterm birth related to nutrition.

answers.explanation_why:
Preterm infants have lower iron stores, smaller total blood volume, lower placental iron transfer, and greater blood loss through phlebotomy than infants born at term. Because these infants are rapidly growing, they have greater daily iron needs than infants born at term. As breast milk does not contain enough iron to meet these requirements, daily iron supplementation is necessary until consuming the recommended daily intake of iron through diet.

Furthermore, all exclusively breastfed infants should receive Vitamin D supplementation from birth until meeting the recommended daily vitamin D intake through diet to prevent rickets. A single dose of vitamin K after birth prevents vitamin K deficiency bleeding of the newborn.

Intussusception is usually idiopathic, although it is often associated with a viral gastrointestinal infection. Less often, it is associated with a lead point (e.g., Meckel diverticulum). Since this infant is currently being breastfed, she has a decreased risk of gastrointestinal infection, which also decreases the risk of intussusception.

Scurvy is the clinical manifestation of vitamin C deficiency and is an extremely rare disease in western, industrialized countries. Symptoms include swollen gums, poor wound healing, mucosal bleeding, corkscrew hair on the body, and generalized weakness and fatigue. Because this newborn is breastfed and breast milk contains sufficient vitamin C, she does not have an increased risk of scurvy.

Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of gastroenteritis. Breast milk contains antibodies and is, therefore, an important source of protection against numerous infectious diseases. The most abundant antibody found in breast milk is IgA, which is an integral part of mucosal immunity, which also helps to protect the gastrointestinal mucosa of the infant against gastroenteritis.

Subacute combined degeneration is caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and can lead to severe neural tube defects and developmental disabilities. Vitamin B_12 deficiency during pregnancy can arise if the mother follows a strict vegan diet and is not receiving enough vitamin B_12 from, e.g., fortified foods or supplements. Unless the mother already had a deficiency during pregnancy or insufficient dietary consumption of vitamin B_12 now, her breast milk should supply enough vitamin B_12 to the child.

Newborns usually have low vitamin K stores. Since the neonatal intestine is sterile and vitamin K does not cross the placental barrier, these low stores increase the risk of vitamin K deficiency bleeding (VKDB), which can manifest as spontaneous mucosal, gastrointestinal, intraventricular, or subgaleal bleeds. Because breast milk does not contain vitamin K, all newborns in the US receive a vitamin K injection at birth to mitigate the risk of hemorrhage.

question_text: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his 33-year-old mother for a well-child examination. He was born at term and delivered at home because his parents wanted a natural childbirth. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. According to the mother, delivery was fast and without complications. He is being exclusively breastfed. He appears healthy. He is at 35^th percentile for length and at 40^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications at this time?
content_preview: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his 33-year-old mother for a well-child examination. He was born at term and delivered at home because his parents wanted a natural childbirth. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. According to the mother, delivery was fast and without complications. He is being exclusively breastfed. He appears healthy. He is at 35th percentile for length and at 40th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following complications at this time?
hint: Natural childbirth is childbirth without routine medical intervention. This patient most likely did not receive the standard postpartum care.
learning_objective: Recall the importance of vitamin K prophylaxis in newborns.

answers.explanation_why: Secondary hyperparathyroidism is caused by hypocalcemia, which can result from maternal hypocalcemia or diabetes, preterm birth, newborn sepsis, asphyxia, or vitamin D deficiency. Vitamin D deficiency is a concern in exclusively breastfed infants who do not receive vitamin D prophylaxis. However, only a prolonged and severe vitamin D deficiency would result in hypocalcemia, and this condition is therefore unlikely in a 2-week-old patient. Furthermore, breast milk supplies the infant with abundant calcium, which makes hypocalcemia and secondary hyperparathyroidism very unlikely.

Newborns have an increased risk of hemorrhage resulting from low vitamin K values, due to the lack of vitamin K-producing gut flora, limited liver capacity, and poor placental transfer of vitamin K. Breast milk contains very low amounts of vitamin K, so the risk of bleeding does not decrease with breastfeeding. All newborns typically receive an intramuscular vitamin K shot at birth to mitigate this risk. Because this child was delivered at home without any medical intervention, it is very likely that he did not receive vitamin K prophylaxis and is consequently at increased risk of bleeding, including potentially severe brain hemorrhage.

Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of gastroenteritis. Breast milk contains antibodies and is therefore an important source of protection against numerous infectious diseases. The most abundant antibody found in breast milk is IgA, an integral part of mucosal immunity, which also helps to protect the gastrointestinal mucosa of the infant against gastroenteritis.
Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of childhood cancers, including leukemias and lymphomas.

Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is primarily a concern in preterm infants because of their lower stores of iron, although it can also be caused by blood loss during or after birth. However, this newborn was born at term and the delivery did not involve any complications. Breastfed infants are also at risk of IDA because breast milk contains only limited amounts of iron. To prevent IDA in breastfed infants, they should receive an additional iron source starting by 4 months of age in full-term infants and by 2 weeks of age in premature infants. Although this infant is being exclusively breastfed, he is not at increased risk of IDA at this time, as most full-term newborns have sufficient iron stores for up to 4 months.
Breastfeeding is associated with a decreased risk of both type 1 diabetes mellitus and type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Scurvy is the clinical manifestation of vitamin C deficiency and is an extremely rare disease in high-income countries. Symptoms include swollen gums, poor wound healing, mucosal bleeding, corkscrew hair on the body, and generalized weakness and fatigue. Because this newborn is being breastfed and breast milk contains sufficient vitamin C, he does not have an increased risk of scurvy.

Subacute combined degeneration is caused by vitamin B_12 deficiency and can lead to severe neural tube defects and developmental disability. Unless the mother already had a deficiency during pregnancy or has a lack of vitamin B_12 now, her breast milk should supply enough vitamin B_12 to the child.

Intussusception is generally an idiopathic condition, but is often associated with a triggering viral gastrointestinal infection or less often with lead points. Since this infant is currently being breastfed, he has a decreased risk of gastrointestinal infections, which thereby also decreases his chances of developing intussusception
