question_text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2 comes to the physician requesting advice on breastfeeding. Three weeks ago, she delivered a healthy girl. Delivery was uncomplicated, and she and her child received adequate postnatal care. Three days ago, she was diagnosed with mastitis, which is managed with cold compresses and ibuprofen. She has chronic hepatitis B infection and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her other medication is pantoprazole. She uses cocaine once every 1–2 months and smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily. An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is positive for CMV antibodies. The patient is apprehensive about taking care of her baby and asks for information on breastfeeding. Which of the following is most likely a contraindication for breastfeeding in this patient?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2 comes to the physician requesting advice on breastfeeding. Three weeks ago, she delivered a healthy girl. Delivery was uncomplicated, and she and her child received adequate postnatal care. Three days ago, she was diagnosed with mastitis, which is managed with cold compresses and ibuprofen. She has chronic hepatitis B infection and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Her other medication is pantoprazole. She uses cocaine once every 1–2 months and smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily. An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is positive for CMV antibodies. The patient is apprehensive about taking care of her baby and asks for information on breastfeeding. Which of the following is most likely a contraindication for breastfeeding in this patient?
learning_objective: Recognize contraindications to breastfeeding related to maternal substance use.

answers.explanation_why: Pantoprazole is minimally excreted into breast milk and is not known to cause adverse effects in breastfed infants. Therefore, it is not a contraindication to breastfeeding. Medications such as amiodarone, antineoplastics, chloramphenicol, tetracyclines, and radiopharmaceuticals are among a small list of drugs that are contraindications to breastfeeding.

Mastitis is partially a consequence of the inability to fully empty the breast during breastfeeding, resulting in breast milk stasis and an increased risk for infection. Although mastitis often causes pain and swelling, it is not a contraindication to breastfeeding, and nursing mothers should be encouraged to continue breastfeeding. This recommendation usually also applies when the management of mastitis includes ibuprofen or a first-line antibiotic (e.g., dicloxacillin) since both substances are excreted in the milk in small enough quantities to be considered safe to use in breastfeeding.

Mother-to-child transmission of hepatitis B may occur during birth. There is no evidence, however, that transmission occurs via breast milk. If the newborn receives hepatitis B immune globulin and hepatitis B vaccine after birth (which is likely in this newborn who had adequate postnatal care), active hepatitis B infection is not a contraindication to breastfeeding.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is found in low concentrations in a variety of bodily fluids, including breast milk. However, the risk of transmission is very low in normal weight and full-term infants and does not exceed the benefits of breastfeeding. Active CMV infection is, therefore, not a contraindication to breastfeeding.

Certain recreational drugs that are excreted in breast milk (e.g., cocaine, phencyclidine) may lead to acute toxicity and long-term negative effects on neurobehavioral development in the breastfeeding infant. Therefore, active use of these substances is a contraindication to breastfeeding. In addition, breastfeeding may be contraindicated during periods in which the mother uses certain medications (e.g., tetracycline, chloramphenicol, chemotherapy agents, lithium) or has certain infections (e.g., herpes with breast lesions). Absolute contraindications to breastfeeding include maternal HIV infection (except in resource-limited countries where formula may not be available), maternal Ebola virus disease, and infant galactosemia (because of the presence of galactose in breast milk).

Marijuana is also detectable in breast milk, but according to the American Academy of Pediatrics, evidence of adverse effects in breastfeeding infants is limited. Although marijuana use is not contraindicated, it is still strongly discouraged during breastfeeding. In addition, mothers should be strongly advised to abstain from any kind of smoking because of the increased risk of sudden infant death syndrome.

Regular cigarette smoking should be strongly discouraged in mothers who are breastfeeding because of the increased risk of sudden infant death syndrome. However, because there is no evidence of direct introduction of toxins or other contaminants into breast milk, smoking is not a contraindication to breastfeeding. Breastfeeding (even in mothers who smoke) is associated with better infant respiratory and immunological development compared to formula.

question_text:
A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of progressive yellowing of his skin for 2 days. The mother reports that the yellowing started on the face and on the forehead before affecting the trunk and the limbs. She states that she breastfeeds every 2–3 hours and that the newborn feeds well. She also says her son passed four loose, yellow stools and had six wet diapers on the previous day. The patient was born at 38 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery and has been healthy. His newborn screening was normal. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and widespread jaundice. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:

Bilirubin, total
8 mg/dL

 Direct
0.3 mg/dL

AST
16 U/L

ALT
16 U/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of progressive yellowing of his skin for 2 days. The mother reports that the yellowing started on the face and on the forehead before affecting the trunk and the limbs. She states that she breastfeeds every 2–3 hours and that the newborn feeds well. She also says her son passed four loose, yellow stools and had six wet diapers on the previous day. The patient was born at 38 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery and has been healthy. His newborn screening was normal. His vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and widespread jaundice. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show: Bilirubin, total 8 mg/dL Direct 0.3 mg/dL AST 16 U/L ALT 16 U/L Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This well newborn presents with jaundice and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia that started on his third day of life. These features indicate physiological neonatal jaundice.
learning_objective: Recognize physiological neonatal jaundice, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Phenobarbital may be used in the diagnosis and treatment of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II, as it causes the residual UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity to increase and prevents or limits clinical manifestations. Both Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I and II can manifest with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia and neonatal jaundice. Type II disorder tends to be less severe and is often asymptomatic at birth. Although this patient's findings could be due to Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II, the timing, duration, and severity of jaundice are more suggestive of a physiologic process. For this reason, and because there is no family history of neonatal jaundice, diagnostic evaluation or treatment for Crigler-Najjar syndrome is not indicated at this point.

Phototherapy is the primary treatment in neonates with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, it is only indicated in neonates with total serum bilirubin above a certain threshold specific to age and risk factors, as designated by the American Academy of Pediatrics. In the case of this healthy 5-day-old newborn, the threshold is 21 mg/dL. Below this threshold, the risk of complications (e.g., kernicterus, acute bilirubin encephalopathy) is low and does not outweigh the possible side effects of phototherapy (e.g., diarrhea, dehydration, and skin rashes).

Insufficient breast milk intake (< 8–12 times within 24 hours) can lead to breastfeeding failure jaundice, which is characterized by dehydration, weight loss, and a decreased number of wet diapers. The mother reports breastfeeding her son frequently without difficulty, and the newborn has an adequate amount of wet and soiled diapers. Therefore, increasing the frequency of breastfeeding is not necessary.

Exchange transfusion is the most rapid method for lowering serum bilirubin concentrations. It is indicated if the total serum bilirubin (TSB) exceeds a certain threshold (e.g., > 25 mg/dL in a full-term infant at 5 days), the TSB rises > 1 mg/dL in less than 6 hours, the response to phototherapy is inadequate, or in the case of severe underlying causes (e.g., hemolytic disease, severe anemia) or complications (e.g., acute bilirubin encephalopathy). This patient does not meet any of the criteria for this treatment option.

Abdominal sonography is indicated in the diagnosis of extrahepatic cholestasis (e.g., biliary atresia or choledochal cysts). Both conditions can manifest with neonatal jaundice and hyperbilirubinemia. However, since the excretion of bilirubin via bile into the intestine is disrupted, the direct bilirubin would be elevated. In addition, acholic stools (because bilirubin does not reach the intestine to be converted to urobilin and stercobilin) and dark urine (due to excretion of bilirubin via the urine) would be expected in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Hepatomegaly and mild to moderate elevation of the aminotransferases are also usually present. In this neonate with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, an extrahepatic obstruction is unlikely.

Intravenous immunoglobulin is indicated in severe cases of hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN). Although neonates with HDFN typically present with jaundice, the yellowing of the skin is usually present at birth or develops within the first 24 hours of life, and the total serum bilirubin levels would be higher. In addition, patients with severe HDFN would have signs of hemolysis and anemia (e.g., hepatosplenomegaly, hypoxia) as a result of the rapid breakdown of antigen-antibody complexes and fetal red blood cells in the spleen.

Reassurance is the most appropriate next step in management in a newborn with physiological neonatal jaundice and total bilirubin levels below a threshold specific to age and risk factors (e.g., 21 mg/dLin a healthy 5-day-old). Physiological neonatal jaundice, which is caused by a physiological rise in unconjugated bilirubin, is very common (affecting around half of term infants) and typically occurs between the second and eighth day of life. Because newborns have a higher hematocrit (due to relative hypoxia during the fetal period) and a shorter life span of fetal red blood cells (RBCs), RBC turnover is increased within the first 3 months of life, resulting in higher bilirubin production. In addition, the hepatic conjugation and elimination pathways for bilirubin are still immature due to decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. The enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin is also increased because the concentration of bacteria in the neonatal digestive tract is low and therefore only a small amount of bilirubin is converted to urobilinogen and subsequently excreted.

Jaundice occurring within the first 24 hours of life or persisting > 1 week should raise suspicion for underlying pathology and warrants further diagnostic tests. Additional symptoms such as poor feeding and drowsiness would also warrant further evaluation.

question_text:
A 4-day-old newborn male is brought to the physician because of increasing yellowish discoloration of his skin for 2 days. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 2466 g (5 lb 7 oz); he currently weighs 2198 g (4 lb 14 oz). Pregnancy was complicated by pregnancy-induced hypertension. The mother says he breastfeeds every 4 hours and has 2 wet diapers per day. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, and respirations are 53/min. Examination shows jaundice and scleral icterus. The anterior fontanelle is mildly sunken. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:

Bilirubin, total
16 mg/dL

Direct
0.8 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 4-day-old newborn male is brought to the physician because of increasing yellowish discoloration of his skin for 2 days. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 2466 g (5 lb 7 oz); he currently weighs 2198 g (4 lb 14 oz). Pregnancy was complicated by pregnancy-induced hypertension. The mother says he breastfeeds every 4 hours and has 2 wet diapers per day. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, and respirations are 53/min. Examination shows jaundice and scleral icterus. The anterior fontanelle is mildly sunken. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show: Bilirubin, total 16 mg/dL Direct 0.8 mg/dL Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: This 4-day-old presents with jaundice due to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, significant weight loss (> 10% since birth), and signs of dehydration (low number of wet diapers, sunken fontanelle, tachycardia).
learning_objective: Recognize inadequate breastfeeding as a cause of neonatal jaundice.

answers.explanation_why: Proximal bile ducts could be congenitally absent in the case of biliary atresia, which also manifests with jaundice in a neonate. However, jaundice caused by this condition is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and signs of biliary atresia, such as acholic stools, dark urine, and hepatomegaly, which are not present in this child.

UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for hepatic conjugation of bilirubin, is absent in Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I. This inherited hyperbilirubinemia syndrome also manifests with neonatal jaundice. However, jaundice is usually severe with total bilirubin concentrations reaching 20–50 mg/dL, which often causes neurological symptoms due to kernicterus (e.g., seizures, cerebral paresis, hearing impairment, vertical gaze palsy). Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I should be suspected in neonates with excessive, persistent jaundice despite adequate treatment. Another diagnosis is more likely in this neonate with new-onset jaundice and moderately elevated total bilirubin levels.

images.title: Hereditary hyperbilirubinemia
images.description: Defects in the bilirubin conjugation and excretion pathways within hepatocytes result in hyperbilirubinemia. Red indicators link hereditary hyperbilirubinemias with corresponding dysfunctional enzymes and transporters.

answers.explanation_why: Increased breakdown of fetal RBCs is one of the main underlying causes of physiologic neonatal jaundice. Physiological neonatal jaundice most commonly manifests with indirect hyperbilirubinemia that appears between the second and eighth day of life. However, total bilirubin levels usually do not exceed 15 mg/dL. Moreover, this patient presents with signs of dehydration (low number of wet diapers, sunken fontanelle, tachycardia) and significant weight loss, which should raise concern for a pathological etiology.

Elevated concentration of β-glucuronidase in breast milk is seen in cases of breast milk jaundice. However, breast milk jaundice typically manifests around 2 weeks after birth. Moreover, this type of jaundice is usually associated with adequate breastfeeding (i.e., 8–12 breastfeedings within 24 hours, ≥ 4 wet diapers per day at the age of 4 days), which is not the case here.

Insufficient breast milk intake can lead to neonatal weight loss, dehydration, and breastfeeding jaundice. The decreased intake of fluid and calories leads to hypovolemia and increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin (due to decreased frequency of bowel movements), resulting in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, typically within the first week of life. This newborn is only fed every four hours, which is usually not adequate for proper weight gain and hydration. A newborn should be nursed whenever he appears to be hungry or every three hours since the last breastfeeding session (whichever comes first), resulting in around 8–12 breastfeedings within 24 hours. In the first days of life, a newborn with adequate breast milk intake should have ≥ 1 wet diaper per day of age (e.g., ≥ 4 wet diapers in a 4-day-old) and at least one stool per day.

A gram-negative infection can cause neonatal sepsis. An early-onset infection/sepsis could manifest within 72 hours after delivery with neonatal jaundice, poor feeding, and signs of dehydration. However, sepsis would typically manfiest with features such as temperature changes, irritability, and lethargy.

Alpha-globin chain defects of hemoglobin are seen in α-thalassemia and are due to faulty synthesis. In its most severe form (hemoglobin Bart disease), death of the neonate would occur shortly after birth. A milder form of α-thalassemia (hemoglobin H disease) can manifest in the neonatal period with jaundice. However, the associated jaundice is usually more severe and is accompanied by clinical features like hepatosplenomegaly and anemia.

question_text:
A 6-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of yellowing of his skin and eyes for the past day. The mother reports that she breastfeeds her son about 6 times per day. She also states that her son had two wet diapers and two bowel movements the day before. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 3500 g (7 lb 10 oz); he currently weighs 3000 g (7 lb). His newborn screening was normal. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 160/min, and blood pressure is 75/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, widespread jaundice, and dry mucous membranes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:

Bilirubin, total
9 mg/dL

Direct
0.5 mg/dL

AST
15 U/L

ALT
15 U/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
content_preview: A 6-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother for the evaluation of yellowing of his skin and eyes for the past day. The mother reports that she breastfeeds her son about 6 times per day. She also states that her son had two wet diapers and two bowel movements the day before. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 3500 g (7 lb 10 oz); he currently weighs 3000 g (7 lb). His newborn screening was normal. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 160/min, and blood pressure is 75/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, widespread jaundice, and dry mucous membranes. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show: Bilirubin, total 9 mg/dL Direct 0.5 mg/dL AST 15 U/L ALT 15 U/L Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
hint: This 6-day-old presents with jaundice due to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, significant weight loss (> 10% since birth), and signs of dehydration (low number of wet diapers and bowel movements, dry mucous membranes, tachycardia).
learning_objective: Recognize breastfeeding failure jaundice, and choose the most appropriate management to address dehydration and weight loss.

answers.explanation_why: Intravenous immunoglobulin is indicated in severe cases of hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN). Although neonates with HDFN typically present with jaundice, the yellowing of the skin is usually present at birth or develops within the first 24 hours of life. Furthermore, the total serum bilirubin levels would be higher than in this infant. In addition, patients with severe HDFN would have signs of hemolysis and anemia (e.g., hepatosplenomegaly, hypoxia) as a result of the rapid breakdown of antigen-antibody complexes and fetal red blood cells in the spleen.

Reassurance is adequate in cases of physiologic neonatal jaundice, a condition characterized by otherwise asymptomatic yellowing of the skin between the second and the eighth day of life. This patient presents with signs of dehydration (decreased number of wet diapers and bowel movements, dry mucous membranes) and significant weight loss, for which reassurance is not appropriate.

Phenobarbital may be used in the diagnosis and treatment of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II, as it causes the residual UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity to increase and prevents or limits clinical manifestations. Both Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I and II may present with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and neonatal jaundice. However, type II disorder tends to be less severe. Although this patient's findings could be due to Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II, the absence of a family history of neonatal jaundice makes this diagnosis unlikely. In addition, weight loss and signs of dehydration suggest a different cause of hyperbilirubinemia.

Insufficient breast milk intake can lead to neonatal weight loss and breastfeeding failure jaundice. The decreased intake of fluid and calories leads to hypovolemia and an increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin (due to decreased frequency of bowel movements), resulting in unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, typically within the first week of life. Problems with breastfeeding may be due to inadequate milk production or extraction (e.g., infrequent feeding, ineffective latch-on or suckling, and separation of baby and mother). This newborn is only fed six times per day, which is usually not adequate for proper weight gain and hydration. A newborn should be nursed whenever he appears to be hungry or every three hours since the last breastfeeding session (whichever comes first), resulting in around 8–12 breastfeedings within 24 hours.

Breastfeeding failure jaundice is different from breast milk jaundice. While breastfeeding failure jaundice results from insufficient breast milk intake, breast milk jaundice is directly caused by elevated β-glucuronidase in the breast milk.

Abdominal sonography is indicated in the diagnosis of extrahepatic cholestasis, such as biliary atresia and choledochal cysts. Both conditions may manifest with neonatal jaundice and hyperbilirubinemia. However, since the excretion of bilirubin via bile into the intestine is disrupted, direct bilirubin would be elevated. In addition, acholic stools (because bilirubin does not reach the intestine to be converted to urobilin and stercobilin), and dark urine (due to excretion of bilirubin via the urine) would be expected in conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Furthermore, hepatomegaly and mild to moderate elevations of the aminotransferases are usually present. In this neonate with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, an extrahepatic obstruction is unlikely, and therefore, abdominal sonography is not necessary.

Exchange transfusion is the most rapid method for lowering serum bilirubin concentrations. Exchange transfusion is indicated if the total serum bilirubin (TSB) exceeds a certain threshold (e.g., > 25 mg/dL in a full-term infant at 6 days), the TSB rises > 1 mg/dL in less than 6 hours, the response to phototherapy was inadequate, or in case of severe underlying causes (e.g., hemolytic disease, severe anemia) or complications (e.g., acute bilirubin encephalopathy). This patient does not meet any of the criteria for this treatment option.

Phototherapy is the primary treatment in neonates with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. However, it is only indicated in neonates with total serum bilirubin above a certain threshold specific to age and risk factors, as designated by the American Academy of Pediatrics. In the case of this healthy 6-day-old newborn, the threshold is 21 mg/dL. Below this threshold, the risk of complications due to hyperbilirubinemia (e.g., kernicterus, acute bilirubin encephalopathy) is low and does not outweigh the possible side effects of phototherapy (e.g., diarrhea, dehydration, and skin rashes).

question_text:
A 2-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of increasing yellow discoloration of her eyes and skin for 2 days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation and weighed 3066 g (6 lb 12 oz); she now weighs 3200 g (7 lb 1 oz). She is exclusively breastfed. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 145/min, and respirations are 40/min. Examination shows yellow discoloration extending to the palms and soles. The liver is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:

Hematocrit
51%

Serum

 Bilirubin, total

14.1 mg/dL

 Direct
0.7 mg/dL

 Alkaline phosphatase
28 U/L

 AST
14 U/L

 ALT
16 U/L

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 2-week-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of increasing yellow discoloration of her eyes and skin for 2 days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation and weighed 3066 g (6 lb 12 oz); she now weighs 3200 g (7 lb 1 oz). She is exclusively breastfed. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 145/min, and respirations are 40/min. Examination shows yellow discoloration extending to the palms and soles. The liver is palpated 1 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show: Hematocrit 51% Serum Bilirubin, total 14.1 mg/dL Direct 0.7 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 28 U/L AST 14 U/L ALT 16 U/L Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Increased β-glucuronidase activity, which promotes enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin, can cause this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize breast milk jaundice.

answers.explanation_why: Biliary atresia is a concerning cause of direct hyperbilirubinemia. Patients with biliary atresia can demonstrate normal development in the first two weeks of life. However, the onset of jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, and early cirrhosis may occur soon thereafter. This neonate has indirect hyperbilirubinemia, which is not seen with biliary atresia.

Physiologic neonatal jaundice is common in term and preterm neonates. It most often occurs between the second and eighth day of life in term infants with indirect hyperbilirubinemia (< 9 mg/dL) without other concerning signs or symptoms on physical examination. Although this patient has indirect hyperbilirubinemia, her bilirubin concentrations are much higher and she presents later than would be expected with physiologic neonatal jaundice.

Jaundice due to congenital hypothyroidism results from decreased gut mobility, reduced appetite, and a diminished rate of bilirubin conjugation. While congenital hypothyroidism can also manifest with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, other features such as lethargy, hypotonia, a hoarse cry, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, poor weight gain, and cool and edematous skin are absent in this patient.

Isoimmune mediated hemolysis (also known as hemolytic disease of the newborn) is a less common cause of neonatal jaundice in modern practice, due largely to the widespread use of anti-D immunoglobulin. This condition most often causes jaundice that appears within the first 24 hours of life, as the newborn becomes unable to completely clear bilirubin on his or her own after birth (the placenta helps eliminate bilirubin in utero). The hallmark laboratory finding is anemia; this patient, however, has a normal hematocrit.

Breast milk jaundice is common in exclusively breastfed neonates and classically manifests with indirect hyperbilirubinemia and moderate jaundice in an otherwise healthy infant within two weeks after birth. When establishing the diagnosis, it is important to identify the absence of concerning signs of dehydration (tachycardia, dry membranes, poor capillary refill; seen in breastfeeding failure jaundice) or anemia (tachycardia, decreased hematocrit; seen in hemolysis causing hyperbilirubinemia). Breastfeeding should be continued in neonates with breast milk jaundice, as bilirubin levels usually normalize spontaneously within 2–3 months. Phototherapy and evaluation for other causes of hyperbilirubinemia may be necessary if total bilirubin levels rise above an age-specific threshold.

In neonates, a normal liver can be palpated up to 3 cm below the costal margin. Livers larger than this may be considered enlarged and warrant further attention.

Breastfeeding failure jaundice is a common cause of neonatal jaundice within the first week of life and typically manifests with hypovolemia. Hypovolemia in neonates manifests with tachycardia, decreased urine output (usually fewer wet diapers), cool or clammy skin, and irritability or drowsiness. However, this patient appears healthy and did not have jaundice until 12 days old, making breastfeeding failure an unlikely cause of her jaundice.

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1 is a rare but concerning cause of indirect hyperbilirubinemia. Because of an absent UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity, newborns present within the first week with excessive neonatal jaundice (20–50 mg/dL unconjugated serum bilirubin; absent conjugated bilirubin) and neurological symptoms (e.g., athetosis) caused by kernicterus. This patient presents at 2 weeks with much lower bilirubin levels and milder symptoms.

question_text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the hospital because of poor weight gain since birth. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via normal vaginal delivery. He weighed 3005 g (6 lb 10 oz) at birth and currently weighs 2835 g (6 lb 4 oz). He has been latching on and breastfeeding well since birth. His mother has a history of Graves disease and underwent near-total thyroidectomy in the second trimester of her pregnancy after her symptoms could not be controlled with antithyroid drugs. She is currently receiving L-thyroxine therapy. The patient's temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 176/min, and respirations are 42/min. He appears irritable. Examination shows a diaphoretic infant with a paucity of subcutaneous fat. There is swelling of the neck at the midline. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
content_preview: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the hospital because of poor weight gain since birth. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation via normal vaginal delivery. He weighed 3005 g (6 lb 10 oz) at birth and currently weighs 2835 g (6 lb 4 oz). He has been latching on and breastfeeding well since birth. His mother has a history of Graves disease and underwent near-total thyroidectomy in the second trimester of her pregnancy after her symptoms could not be controlled with antithyroid drugs. She is currently receiving L-thyroxine therapy. The patient's temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 176/min, and respirations are 42/min. He appears irritable. Examination shows a diaphoretic infant with a paucity of subcutaneous fat. There is swelling of the neck at the midline. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
hint: This neonate has features highly suggestive of neonatal thyrotoxicosis: irritability, tachycardia, goiter, diaphoresis, and poor weight gain since birth despite an adequate appetite. The mother's history of Graves disease provides a clue for the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal thyrotoxicosis, and recall its etiology.

answers.explanation_why: Thyroglobulin antibodies (TgAbs) are found in approx. 50–70% of patients with Graves disease and > 80% of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although this patient's mother has a history of Graves disease and the antibodies can pass the placenta, TgAbs are not thought to be involved in the pathogenesis of hyperthyroidism in Graves disease. Rather, they are believed to be a response to rapid cell destruction/disordered growth and subsequent release of circulating free thyroglobulin into the bloodstream. They are therefore not likely to be the cause of this infant's symptoms.

answers.content: Activating mutation of the TSH receptor gene
answers.explanation_why: An activating mutation (or gain-of-function mutation) of the TSH receptor gene is the underlying pathophysiology of toxic adenoma. Since toxic adenomas produce large amounts of thyroid hormones, independent of normal hypothalamic-pituitary feedback regulation, they also cause hyperthyroidism. However, the condition is most common in adults between 30–50 years of age and would be unlikely in a neonate.

answers.content: Transplacental passage of thyroid peroxidase antibodies
answers.explanation_why: Thyroid peroxidase antibodies (TPOAbs) are present in ∼ 70% of patients with Graves disease and > 90% of patients with Hashimoto thyroiditis. Although this patient's mother has a history of Graves disease and the antibodies can pass the placenta, TPOAbs are not known to be involved in the pathogenesis of hyperthyroidism in Graves disease, but rather result from the autoimmune nature of the condition. They are therefore not likely to be the cause of this infant's symptoms.

answers.content: Transplacental passage of TSH receptor antibodies
answers.explanation_why: Up to 5% of infants born to mothers with Graves disease develop thyrotoxicosis due to the transplacental passage of maternal stimulatory TSH-receptor antibodies (TRAbs). TRAbs are present in ∼ 90% of patients with Graves disease and cause increased growth and function of the thyroid gland and the subsequent development of hyperthyroidism and goiter. Neonatal thyrotoxicosis is transient and usually resolves within 12 weeks, when maternal TRAbs disappear from the infant's circulation. Although the condition is transient, symptomatic neonatal thyrotoxicosis should be treated as soon as it is diagnosed to prevent complications such as cardiac failure, intellectual disability, and craniosynostosis. Therapy consists of methimazole to achieve a euthyroid state and a beta blocker (e.g., propranolol) to rapidly control the thyrotoxic symptoms.

Although L-thyroxine has a long half-life (6–7 days), L-thyroxine only minimally crosses the placenta and is considered a category A drug during pregnancy, i.e., controlled human studies showed no risk for the fetus. It would therefore be an unlikely cause of this patient's symptoms.

question_text: A 2-month-old male infant is brought to the physician because of inconsolable crying for the past 3 hours. For the past 3 weeks, he has had multiple episodes of high-pitched unprovoked crying every day that last up to 4 hours and resolve spontaneously. He was born at term and weighed 2966 g (6 lb 9 oz); he now weighs 3800 g (8 lb 6 oz). He is exclusively breastfed. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F) and pulse is 140/min. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 2-month-old male infant is brought to the physician because of inconsolable crying for the past 3 hours. For the past 3 weeks, he has had multiple episodes of high-pitched unprovoked crying every day that last up to 4 hours and resolve spontaneously. He was born at term and weighed 2966 g (6 lb 9 oz); he now weighs 3800 g (8 lb 6 oz). He is exclusively breastfed. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F) and pulse is 140/min. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This infant's high-pitched crying for no apparent reason for ≥ 3 hours per day, ≥ 3 days per week, and for ≥ 3 weeks in an otherwise healthy infant is referred to as infantile colic.
learning_objective: Recognize infantile colic, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: A lumbar puncture should be performed in suspected meningitis, which may also manifest with high-pitched crying and irritability. There should be a very low threshold for suspecting meningitis in young children since the classic triad of meningitis (i.e., fever, headache, and neck stiffness) is frequently not present. However, this patient is generally well, afebrile, and lacks further symptoms of meningitis such as an altered mental status, vomiting, and/or a bulging fontanelle (due to increased ICP).

Since swallowed air is suspected as an underlying mechanism, simethicone has been promoted as a treatment for infantile colic to help eliminate gas from the gastrointestinal tract. However, new systematic reviews have not demonstrated the efficacy of its use. Excess gas should rather be eliminated by changing feeding techniques such as bottle-feeding in a vertical position using a curved bottle (to allow frequent burping and reduce air-swallowing).

Administration of acid-suppressing pantoprazole is indicated in infants with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Although patients with GERD may also be irritable, this infant lacks signs of esophagitis such as regurgitation and/or vomiting of food shortly after feeding, poor appetite, weight loss, failure to thrive, and/or respiratory complications (e.g., wheezing, stridor, chronic cough).

This patient's parents can be reassured that the symptoms of infantile colic usually resolve spontaneously by 3–4 months of age. First-line interventions in patients with infantile colic include parental support, changes to feeding (e.g., changing the volume of feeds, adequate burping), and initiation of soothing techniques (e.g., use of a pacifier, placing the child in a swing, rocking the infant).

answers.content: Recommend the use of Gripe water
answers.explanation_why: Gripe water is a mixture of herbs (e.g., dill and fennel) and water that is recommended by some alternative practitioners as a natural option for treating infantile colic. However, it is not recommended by the Food and Drug Administration. Also, its efficacy is unproven and the mixture may be contaminated with bacteria, toxins, or alcohol that place the infant at risk.

question_text: A 3-day-old male newborn develops several episodes of complete body shaking while at the hospital. The episodes last for about 10–20 seconds. He has not had a fever or trauma. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and has been healthy. The mother did not have routine prenatal care. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient appears irritable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows reddening of the face. His hematocrit is 68%. Neuroimaging of the head shows several cerebral infarctions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
content_preview: A 3-day-old male newborn develops several episodes of complete body shaking while at the hospital. The episodes last for about 10–20 seconds. He has not had a fever or trauma. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and has been healthy. The mother did not have routine prenatal care. There is no family history of serious illness. The patient appears irritable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows reddening of the face. His hematocrit is 68%. Neuroimaging of the head shows several cerebral infarctions. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
hint: This newborn's plethora (reddening of the face) and elevated hematocrit indicate neonatal polycythemia (Hct > 65%), which can lead to hyperviscosity syndrome and consequently cerebral infarctions (explaining this patient's seizures). The most likely cause of this patient's polycythemia is also associated with neonatal hypoglycemia and hypocalcemia.
learning_objective: Recognize gestational diabetes mellitus as a cause of neonatal polycythemia and seizures.

answers.explanation_why: Gestational diabetes mellitus leads to fetal hyperglycemia and hyperinsulinemia, thereby increasing the overall metabolic rate and oxygen demand of the fetus. Placental capacity is exhausted and hypoxemia develops, leading to increased erythropoiesis. Polycythemia develops, which can cause hyperviscosity syndrome after birth and may result in cerebral infarctions that lead to seizures. Hypoglycemia is also common in neonates born to mothers with gestational diabetes mellitus because of hyperinsulinemia that can persist in infants up to several days after birth. Additionally, hypocalcemia occurs more often in infants of diabetic mothers, although its mechanism is not entirely understood.

Microdeletion of chromosome 22 causes DiGeorge syndrome, which often manifests with cardiac abnormalities, abnormal face, thymus aplasia, cleft palate, and hypocalcemia (summarized by the acronym CATCH-22). Although the cause of this patient's polycythemia is also associated with hypocalcemia, none of these features are present. Additionally, DiGeorge syndrome would not explain this patient's polycythemia.

Early-onset (<5 days) neonatal infection with Listeria monocytogenes can manifest with seizures. However, this newborn lacks additional features of this infection, such as disseminated abscesses, respiratory distress syndrome, and meningitis. Moreover, Listeria infection is not associated with newborn polycythemia.

Maternal toxoplasmosis can lead to congenital toxoplasmosis, which can cause seizures. However, it also manifests with thrombocytopenia, purpuric rash, chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and/or intracranial calcifications, none of which are described in this patient. Additionally, congenital toxoplasmosis would not explain this patient's polycythemia.

A JAK2 mutation causes polycythemia vera. Although this patient's polycythemia, as well as the cerebral infarctions due to hyperviscosity syndrome, could be explained by this mutation, the mean age of onset for polycythemia vera is around 60 years of age. Moreover, JAK2 mutation is a somatic mutation, and therefore, it is extremely unlikely to be present in a 3-day-old newborn. Another cause of this patient's polycythemia is much more likely.

Mutated factor V (also called Factor V Leiden) is the most common cause of hypercoagulability in white populations. Patients often present in early adulthood with repeat venous thromboembolism. However, factor V mutation is not associated with neonatal polycythemia.

Maternal consumption of alcohol during pregnancy causes fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FAS). However, unlike this patient, affected children present with dysmorphic features (smooth philtrum, thin upper lip, narrow forehead) and may have a cognitive delay. Moreover, FAS does not cause newborn polycythemia.

images.title: Clinical findings in fetal alcohol syndrome

answers.explanation_why: Maternal hypothyroidism leads to congenital hypothyroidism in infants. Although congenital hypothyroidism may cause polycythemia, this newborn lacks other characteristic features associated with this condition, such as prolonged newborn jaundice, hypotension, decreased activity, hoarse cry, and macroglossia.

question_text: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of a gush of clear fluid from her vagina that occurred 1 hour prior. She reports painful pelvic cramping at regular 5-minute intervals. She has missed most of her prenatal care visit because of financial problems from her recent divorce. Her first child was delivered vaginally at 27 weeks' gestation due to spontaneous preterm labor. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years but has reduced her intake to 2–3 cigarettes per day since finding out she was pregnant. She continues to use cocaine once a week. Vital signs are within normal limits. Sterile speculum examination shows fluid pooling in the vagina, and nitrazine paper testing confirms the presence of amniotic fluid. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for preterm delivery in this patient?
content_preview: A 36-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of a gush of clear fluid from her vagina that occurred 1 hour prior. She reports painful pelvic cramping at regular 5-minute intervals. She has missed most of her prenatal care visit because of financial problems from her recent divorce. Her first child was delivered vaginally at 27 weeks' gestation due to spontaneous preterm labor. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years but has reduced her intake to 2–3 cigarettes per day since finding out she was pregnant. She continues to use cocaine once a week. Vital signs are within normal limits. Sterile speculum examination shows fluid pooling in the vagina, and nitrazine paper testing confirms the presence of amniotic fluid. Which of the following is the strongest risk factor for preterm delivery in this patient?
hint: This patient presents with several risk factors for preterm labor and delivery; however, one of them is particularly strong.
learning_objective: Recognize history of spontaneous preterm birth as a strong risk factor for preterm delivery.

answers.explanation_why: Low maternal socioeconomic status, maternal income, and educational level, as well as single marital status and help from professional agencies, are known risk factors associated with preterm delivery. Although this woman has financial problems and recently had a divorce (factors that may be associated with preterm birth), her socioeconomic status is not the strongest risk factor.

Lack of (especially early) prenatal care is often associated with a low maternal socioeconomic status, which is in turn is associated with mainly behavioral risk factors of preterm delivery. This woman has missed several prenatal care visits, which contributes to an increased risk for preterm birth. However, it is not the strongest risk factor.

Maternal smoking during pregnancy is an independent risk factor for preterm delivery. Furthermore, it is associated with placental abruption, placenta previa, intrauterine growth restriction, and premature rupture of membranes, all predisposing factors for preterm birth. However, the relationship is only moderate and also dose-dependent, accounting only for a weak increase in risk in this woman who cut down her cigarette consumption.

Substance abuse during pregnancy is associated with premature birth. Especially the use of cocaine increases the risk of placental abruption, placental insufficiency, and preterm labor, all of which can result in preterm delivery. However, this woman's substance abuse is not the strongest risk factor for preterm birth.

This woman had a recent divorce, which suggests psychosocial stress during pregnancy. Although it is difficult to study this relationship, stress has been shown to moderately increase the risk of preterm birth. However, it is not the strongest risk factor in this patient.

Both young (< 21 years) and advanced (> 35 years) maternal age are associated with preterm delivery. This may be partially due to confounding factors, such as a lower socioeconomic status and immaturity of the genital organs for young mothers, chronic diseases and obesity for older mothers, or undesired pregnancies in both age groups. In this patient's case, there is a stronger risk factor for preterm delivery.

This patient presents with preterm premature rupture of membranes and possibly preterm labor (suggested by painful pelvic cramping at regular 5-minute intervals), which are both concerning for imminent preterm delivery. A history of spontaneous preterm birth (PTB) is the strongest predisposing factor for recurrence. The risk increases with the number of previous PTBs and decreases with the number of term deliveries between the PTB and the current pregnancy. The timing of the recurrent PTB is often similar to the previous one(s). This patient's first child was delivered at 27 weeks' gestation, and she does not have a history of term delivery since then. Therefore, she is at increased risk for preterm delivery during this pregnancy, especially since the fetus is almost the same gestational age.

question_text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She reports feeling fatigued, but she is otherwise feeling well. Pregnancy and delivery of her first 2 children were complicated by iron deficiency anemia. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. She has a history of a seizure disorder controlled by lamotrigine; other medications are folic acid, iron supplements, and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 144/96 mm Hg. She recalls that during blood pressure self-monitoring yesterday morning her blood pressure was 140/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including serum concentrations of glucose and thyroid-stimulating hormone, are within normal limits. This patient's child is most likely to develop which of the following?
content_preview: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She reports feeling fatigued, but she is otherwise feeling well. Pregnancy and delivery of her first 2 children were complicated by iron deficiency anemia. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. She has a history of a seizure disorder controlled by lamotrigine; other medications are folic acid, iron supplements, and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 144/96 mm Hg. She recalls that during blood pressure self-monitoring yesterday morning her blood pressure was 140/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies, including serum concentrations of glucose and thyroid-stimulating hormone, are within normal limits. This patient's child is most likely to develop which of the following?
hint: What effect can maternal high blood pressure potentially have on the baby?
learning_objective: Recognize chronic hypertension in pregnancy, and recall its fetal complications.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic hypertension in pregnancy is associated with an increased risk of pregnancy complications. About 25% of women with chronic hypertension go on to develop preeclampsia during pregnancy. Fetal complications of preeclampsia include intrauterine growth restriction and subsequent small for gestational age neonates, as well as abruptio placentae, premature delivery, and intrauterine fetal death. Pregnant women with hypertension therefore require close surveillance to detect if the condition progresses to preeclampsia.

The mother's history and clinical findings do not put her child at increased risk for intellectual disability. Among the many important maternal risk factors are age > 35 years (↑ risk for aneuploidies), alcoholism (↑ risk for fetal alcohol syndrome), and infections (e.g., congenital rubella infection).

Polyhydramnios can occur as a result of gestational diabetes mellitus that causes hyperglycemia and subsequent polyuria in the fetus, as well as rhesus incompatibility that results in hemolytic disease of the newborn. Fetal conditions that are associated with polyhydramnios include esophageal or duodenal atresia, CNS anomalies, congenital TORCH infections, and chromosomal aberrations. Oligohydramnios, on the other hand, can occur secondary to preeclampsia. Regular ultrasound follow-ups are required in order to monitor the amniotic fluid volume and initiate timely management if necessary.
Infants of diabetic mothers are at an increased risk of developing caudal regression syndrome. The mother has no history of diabetes mellitus, making this diagnosis very unlikely.

Fetal hydantoin syndrome is caused by maternal intake of phenytoin during pregnancy. The syndrome manifests with intellectual disability, microcephaly, hypertelorism, a sunken nasal bridge, and congenital heart defects. Other common features include hypoplastic fingers and a cleft lip or palate. However, the mother's seizures are controlled with lamotrigine, not phenytoin.

question_text: A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She is asymptomatic and has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 16-week gestation. A quadruple screening test shows maternal serum α-fetoprotein level of 3 times the median and normal levels of serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin, estriol, and inhibin A. Which of the following is most likely to account for these findings?
content_preview: A 32-year-old primigravid woman at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. She is asymptomatic and has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F) and blood pressure is 108/60 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 16-week gestation. A quadruple screening test shows maternal serum α-fetoprotein level of 3 times the median and normal levels of serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin, estriol, and inhibin A. Which of the following is most likely to account for these findings?
hint: Isolated elevation of maternal serum α-fetoprotein (MSAFP) levels can be seen in a certain developmental defect associated with folate deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize elevated maternal serum α-fetoprotein in neural tube defects.

answers.explanation_why: MSAFP levels are not typically increased in cases of isolated fetal hydrocephalus.
A molar pregnancy typically results in low levels of MSAFP, low levels of unconjugated estriol, increased levels of inhibin A, and extremely high levels of β-hCG.

Increased levels of MSAFP with normal levels of β-hCG, inhibin A, and unconjugated estriol are characteristic of open neural tube defects (e.g., myelomeningocele, anencephaly) and abdominal wall defects (gastroschisis, omphalocele). The diagnosis can be confirmed prenatally in most cases via ultrasound.

Other possible causes of elevated MSAFP include miscalculated gestational age, multiple gestations, fetal death, and placental abnormalities.
Fetal trisomy 18 would typically result in decreased levels of MSAFP, unconjugated estriol, and β-hCG.
Fetal trisomy 21 would typically result in decreased levels of MSAFP and unconjugated estriol as well as increased levels of inhibin A and β-hCG.

question_text:
A primigravid 42-year-old woman at 18 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has had an uncomplicated pregnancy. At 10 weeks' gestation, she underwent cell-free fetal DNA testing, which showed a low risk of fetal aneuploidy, and XX fetal sex chromosomes. At today's visit, transabdominal ultrasound is performed and suggests the fetus has male external genitalia. Which of the following sets of values is most likely to be seen in the infant after birth?

Blood pressure
Serum [K^+]
Serum cortisol

A
High
decreased
normal

increased
normal

increased

decreased
normal

content_preview: A primigravid 42-year-old woman at 18 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has had an uncomplicated pregnancy. At 10 weeks' gestation, she underwent cell-free fetal DNA testing, which showed a low risk of fetal aneuploidy, and XX fetal sex chromosomes. At today's visit, transabdominal ultrasound is performed and suggests the fetus has male external genitalia. Which of the following sets of values is most likely to be seen in the infant after birth? Blood pressure Serum [K+] Serum cortisol A High decreased normal B High increased normal C Low increased decreased D Low decreased normal E High decreased increased F Low increased normal G High decreased decreased
hint: Prenatal virilization is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), which is most commonly caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital adrenal hyperplasia, and recall its associated findings.

answers.explanation_why: Causes of hypertension with hypokalemia and normal cortisol levels during infancy include hyperreninemia due to renal artery stenosis (e.g., umbilical artery catheterization) or renal parenchymal disease, as well as certain rare conditions such as Liddle syndrome, glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism, and apparent mineralocorticoid excess syndrome. However, none of these conditions are associated with intrauterine virilization.

During infancy, hypertension with hyperkalemia and normal cortisol levels can be seen with renal failure that develops as a result of renal parenchymal disease (e.g., infantile polycystic kidney disease). However, renal parenchymal diseases would typically result in oligohydramnios, and intrauterine virilization would not be expected.

Deficiency of 21-hydroxylase results in decreased synthesis of both glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol, deoxycortisol) and mineralocorticoids (e.g., aldosterone, deoxycorticosterone). Hypoaldosteronism causes hypotension and hyperkalemia. Hypocortisolism leads to an increase in the secretion of ACTH from the pituitary gland. Stimulation of the adrenal cortex by ACTH results in an increase in the production of adrenal androgens, which cause masculinization of the genital tubercle. The diagnosis of congenital adrenal hyperplasia can be established by screening for increased 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels in fetal blood.

images.title: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia on steroid pathway and affecting drugs

answers.explanation_why: In a newborn, hypotension with hypokalemia and normal cortisol levels can be seen with neonatal forms of Bartter syndrome, type 1 renal tubular acidosis and type 2 renal tubular acidosis, and conditions that result in severe diarrhea (e.g., gastrointestinal tract infections, cystic fibrosis). However, none of these conditions are associated with masculinization of external genitalia.

Hypertension with hypokalemia and increased cortisol levels can be seen in Cushing syndrome. Cushing syndrome appearing in infancy is almost always caused by McCune-Albright syndrome, which is more common among female patients. McCune-Albright syndrome is not, however, associated with masculinization of external genitalia. Other causes of pediatric Cushing syndrome, such as primary pigmented nodular adrenocortical disease, may result in virilization, but the onset of virilization typically occurs in late childhood.

During infancy, causes of hypotension with hyperkalemia and normal cortisol levels include aldosterone synthase deficiency and type 1 pseudohypoaldosteronism. However, neither of these conditions is associated with masculinization of external genitalia.

In a newborn, hypertension with hypokalemia and decreased cortisol levels can be seen in 11β-hydroxylase deficiency. This condition also results in virilization of infants with 46, XX genotype due to adrenal overproduction of androgens. However, 21-hydroxylase deficiency is approx. 10 times more common than 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, being responsible for > 90% of cases of CAH. Therefore, 21-hydroxylase deficiency is much more likely in this patient.

question_text: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 38 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department in active labor. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. The patient's blood type is Rh-negative. She received all of her prenatal care for this pregnancy including a dose of anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks' gestation. Four hours after arrival, a healthy 3650-g (8-lb) female newborn is delivered. Delivery of the fetus is followed by placental retention and heavy vaginal bleeding. One hour later, the placenta is manually removed and the bleeding ceases. The mother's temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect of each thigh. The neonate's blood type is Rh-positive. The rosette test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 27-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 38 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department in active labor. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. The patient's blood type is Rh-negative. She received all of her prenatal care for this pregnancy including a dose of anti-D immunoglobulin at 28 weeks' gestation. Four hours after arrival, a healthy 3650-g (8-lb) female newborn is delivered. Delivery of the fetus is followed by placental retention and heavy vaginal bleeding. One hour later, the placenta is manually removed and the bleeding ceases. The mother's temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows blood on the vulva, the introitus, and on the medial aspect of each thigh. The neonate's blood type is Rh-positive. The rosette test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: In order to prevent Rh sensitization in nonsensitized Rh-negative mothers, anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) is administered at 28 weeks' gestation (typically a single standard dose without confirmation of the fetal blood type) and, if the newborn is Rh-positive, within 72 hours following delivery. The risk of Rh sensitization is proportional to the amount of fetomaternal hemorrhage (FMH).
learning_objective: Recognize fetomaternal hemorrhage in an Rh-negative mother, and choose the most appropriate test to quantify it.

answers.explanation_why:
The risk of FMH is highest in the peripartum period and is further increased if the mother has antenatal or peripartum hemorrhage. The standard dose of RhoGAM to prevent Rh sensitization can neutralize approx. 15 mL of fetal RBCs (or approx. 30 mL of fetal whole blood volume). The dosage of RhoGAM that should be given in the postpartum period is determined by the amount of FMH. Therefore, fetomaternal hemorrhage tests are indicated before the administration of RhoGAM. The rosette test, which is sensitive in detecting FMH, is used as the initial screening test but it is a qualitative test. If the patient has a positive rosette test, a quantitative test such as the Kleihauer-Betke test (KB test) or flow cytometry should be performed to determine the amount of FMH and the exact dosage of RhoGAM required.

Flow cytometry is more expensive and less readily available than the KB test but is necessary if the mother has a concomitant hemoglobinopathy because the KB test is unreliable in this scenario. If for any reason, laboratory testing to detect and quantify FMH cannot be performed within 72 hours after delivery (the ideal time for RhoGAM administration), blood samples for these tests should be drawn before administering the first dose of RhoGAM.

answers.content: Administer a dose of anti-D immunoglobulin
answers.explanation_why: In Rh(D)-negative mothers with Rh(D)-positive newborns, anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) is administered within 72 hours after delivery to prevent Rh sensitization. A single standard dose of RhoGAM can be given at 28 weeks' gestation but in the postpartum period, a different step needs to be performed first in order to determine the amount of RhoGAM that should be administered.

An indirect Coombs test, which can detect the presence of anti-D antibodies, is performed in Rh-negative women at the first prenatal visit and the end of the second trimester to rule out maternal sensitization before anti-D immunoglobulin (RhoGAM) is administered (since RhoGAM only works in nonsensitized women). RhoGAM has a half-life of 6 weeks and once RhoGAM is administered, as was done here, maternal anti-D antibody screening will yield a false-positive result for approx. 6–7 months. Moreover, anti-D antibody screening does not provide any information in the peripartum period about FMH.
An Rh-negative mother who gives birth to an Rh-positive baby is at risk for Rh sensitization. This patient requires additional management to prevent Rh sensitization.

question_text: Twenty-four hours after delivery, a 2888-g (6-lb 6-oz) male newborn is not feeding well, has a high-pitched cry, and is diaphoretic. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, after an uncomplicated delivery. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She takes codeine syrup frequently for dry cough. The infant's temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 165/min, and blood pressure is 83/50 mm Hg. Examination shows hyperreflexia, tremors, and an excessive startle response. The baby is swaddled to prevent excoriations, and fluid resuscitation is initiated, which provides only minimal improvement in his symptoms. Complete blood count and serum levels of glucose, bilirubin, and calcium are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this newborn?
content_preview: Twenty-four hours after delivery, a 2888-g (6-lb 6-oz) male newborn is not feeding well, has a high-pitched cry, and is diaphoretic. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, after an uncomplicated delivery. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother did not receive prenatal care. She takes codeine syrup frequently for dry cough. The infant's temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 165/min, and blood pressure is 83/50 mm Hg. Examination shows hyperreflexia, tremors, and an excessive startle response. The baby is swaddled to prevent excoriations, and fluid resuscitation is initiated, which provides only minimal improvement in his symptoms. Complete blood count and serum levels of glucose, bilirubin, and calcium are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this newborn?
hint: This neonate, whose mother has a history of opioid use, presents with gastrointestinal symptoms (poor feeding), flu-like symptoms (sweating, fever), and CNS stimulation (high-pitched crying, irritability, hyperreflexia, tremors) within 24 hours of birth. These features are associated with opioid withdrawal and suggest a diagnosis of neonatal abstinence syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal abstinence syndrome, and choose the most appropriate pharmacological treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Management of neonatal abstinence syndrome includes supportive care (e.g., swaddling, IV fluids, reduced sensory stimulation), which is often sufficient in infants with mild symptoms. In moderate to severe cases (e.g., inability to sleep or feed, severe diarrhea with dehydration) or if supportive treatment is unsuccessful, as seen here, opioid replacement is indicated to treat the withdrawal and ensure that infants can gain weight. First-line pharmacological treatment options include oral morphine, buprenorphine, and methadone. Second-line treatment includes phenobarbital and clonidine.

Oral clonidine may be used in the treatment of neonatal abstinence syndrome. Clonidine reduces noradrenergic hyperactivity and autonomic symptoms without causing respiratory depression. However, it is not currently recommended as first-line treatment; an alternate therapy is more effective for this patient's condition.

IV calcium gluconate is used to treat hypocalcemia, which may also manifest with irritability, poor feeding, tremors, and hyperreflexia in infants. However, this infant does not have any risk factors for hypocalcemia (e.g., preterm birth, intrauterine growth restriction) and his serum calcium level is normal.

Therapeutic hypothermia is used to treat neonatal encephalopathy. While mild cases may also present with irritability, hyperreflexia, crying, and poor feeding, this infant does not have any risk factors for this disease (e.g., drop in maternal blood pressure causing cerebral hypoxia).

A combination of IV ampicillin and gentamicin can be used to treat certain neonatal infections (e.g., meningitis). While the presentation in infants can be nonspecific and similar to those seen here, the absence of leukocytosis and lack of risk factors for neonatal infection (e.g., maternal infection, premature birth) make this diagnosis unlikely.
Dextrose infusion is used to treat neonatal hypoglycemia, which may present with similar symptoms (e.g., irritability, sweating, poor feeding). However, this patient's glucose level is normal.

question_text: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of a productive cough. Over the past month, she has had several episodes of watery stools. She is exclusively breastfed every 3–4 hours for 15–20 minutes. She was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother reports that her child is not gaining weight. The mother had no prenatal care. The infant has not received any immunizations. She is at the 5^th percentile for height and weight. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows white plaques covering the tongue and the palate. Cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. On pulmonary examination, crackles are heard over the lung fields bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 5-day history of a productive cough. Over the past month, she has had several episodes of watery stools. She is exclusively breastfed every 3–4 hours for 15–20 minutes. She was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother reports that her child is not gaining weight. The mother had no prenatal care. The infant has not received any immunizations. She is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows white plaques covering the tongue and the palate. Cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. On pulmonary examination, crackles are heard over the lung fields bilaterally. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: This patient's symptoms (respiratory infection, chronic diarrhea, failure to thrive, lymphadenopathy, thrush) are most likely the result of an impaired immune system. Her mother did not attend any prenatal visits, increasing the possibility of a congenital infection.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital HIV infection, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Karyotyping can confirm the diagnosis of several genetic disorders such as Down syndrome. Patients with Down syndrome have a higher susceptibility to respiratory infections, but cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy, white plaques on the tongue, and chronic diarrhea indicate a more generalized immunodeficiency. In addition, this patient lacks characteristic physical findings of Down syndrome such as micrognathia, flat nasal bridge, hypertelorism, and epicanthal folds.

The dihydrorhodamine test is positive in patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). CGD commonly manifests with failure to thrive, lymphadenopathy, respiratory infections, and diarrhea in the first year of life. However, infections in CGD are typically recurrent and other manifestations such as skin, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary granulomas are expected. In addition, this disorder is caused by an X-linked recessive defect, but the patient is female, which makes a diagnosis of CGD very unlikely.

DNA testing for CFTR mutation is used for the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis (CF). Although patients with CF also have failure to thrive and pulmonary infections, they additionally often develop meconium ileus, and foul-smelling diarrhea due to fat malabsorption, in contrast to this patient's watery diarrhea. Moreover, CF alone would not explain this patient's inguinal and cervical lymphadenopathy and thrush.

Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test is used in the diagnosis of congenital syphilis. Although this patient's mother did not have any prenatal care, and syphilis is a possible congenital infection (TORCH), it typically presents with nasal discharge, hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, skeletal abnormalities, and skin manifestations, none of which are present in this patient.

Flow cytometry of B lymphocytes is used for diagnosing immunodeficiencies due to B-cell abnormalities, such as X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA), which usually manifests 3–6 months after birth with recurrent bacterial infections (e.g., pneumonia). However, fungal infections, such as candida, are not typical in XLA. Furthermore, lymphoid tissue is not found in patients with XLA, whereas this patient has lymphadenopathy. In addition, XLA is an X-linked recessive disease that typically appears in boys and is therefore not the most likely diagnosis for this female patient.

images.title: Bruton agammaglobulinemia fact sheet
images.description: BTK: B-cell tyrosine kinase

answers.content: Polymerase chain reaction for viral genes
answers.explanation_why:
This patient's presentation suggests vertical transmission of HIV, for which lack of prenatal care, vaginal delivery, and breastfeeding are risk factors. A polymerase chain reaction test (PCR test) is used to diagnose HIV in children < 18 months of age. An enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) cannot be used in children < 18 months of age, because maternal HIV IgG antibodies are able to cross the placenta, possibly leading to false-positive results.

HIV testing is recommended for all pregnant women in the first trimester. In pregnant patients with HIV and an unknown viral load, scheduled cesarean delivery is usually recommended at 38 weeks' gestation to decrease the risk of vertical transmission. In mothers with HIV who have infants without HIV, breastfeeding should be avoided if possible. However, in resource-limited countries, breastfeeding may be considered. Maternal adherence to antiretroviral therapy decreases the risk of HIV transmission from breast milk.

Analysis of T-cell receptor excision circles is used for the diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Although SCID typically manifests with respiratory infections, chronic diarrhea, thrush, and failure to thrive, it is most often inherited in an X-linked pattern and thus unlikely in a female patient. In addition, lymph nodes and tonsils may be absent in SCID, unlike the lymphadenopathy seen in this girl.
