question_text: Three weeks after birth, a newborn girl develops episodes of respiratory arrest. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past two days and today experienced two episodes in which she stopped breathing for 10 seconds. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation and weighed 1600 g (3 lb 8 oz). Apgar scores were 4 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 185/min, respirations are 60/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 70/35 mm Hg. She appears pale. Physical examination shows pallor of the mucous membranes and no other abnormalities. Hemoglobin is 6.5 g/dL, reticulocyte count is 0.5%, and mean corpuscular volume is 92 μm^3. Leukocyte count, platelet count, total bilirubin, and indirect bilirubin are all within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's anemia?
content_preview: Three weeks after birth, a newborn girl develops episodes of respiratory arrest. She has become increasingly lethargic over the past two days and today experienced two episodes in which she stopped breathing for 10 seconds. She was born at 31 weeks' gestation and weighed 1600 g (3 lb 8 oz). Apgar scores were 4 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She takes no medications. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 185/min, respirations are 60/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 70/35 mm Hg. She appears pale. Physical examination shows pallor of the mucous membranes and no other abnormalities. Hemoglobin is 6.5 g/dL, reticulocyte count is 0.5%, and mean corpuscular volume is 92 μm3. Leukocyte count, platelet count, total bilirubin, and indirect bilirubin are all within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's anemia?
hint: This patient presents with severe anemia and episodes of apnea, which are most likely caused by poor tissue oxygenation. Her condition manifests in premature infants typically at the age of 3–12 weeks.
learning_objective: Recognize anemia of prematurity, and recall its primary cause.

answers.explanation_why: Impaired synthesis of hemoglobin β-chain causes beta thalassemia. The switch from fetal HbF, which contains hemoglobin gamma-chains instead of beta-chains, to HbA, which contains beta-chains, happens gradually after birth. Therefore, newborns with beta thalassemia are typically asymptomatic until around 6 months of age, unlike this patient.

An x-linked recessive defect in δ-aminolevulinic acid synthase is the genetic defect that gives rise to inherited cases of sideroblastic anemia, which typically presents as microcytic anemia (MCV < 80 μm^3). While X-linked recessive disorders predominantly present in men, about ⅓ of cases of X-linked sideroblastic anemias are middle-aged women, due to X chromosome inactivation in red cell progenitors that can occur with advancing age. Sideroblastic anemia would be a very unlikely diagnosis in a 3-week-old female infant.

Bone marrow suppression results in aplastic anemia and can be caused by inherited disorders (e.g., Fanconi anemia), medication side effects/toxicity, and infections such as parvovirus B19, hepatitis viruses, Epstein-Barr virus, and HIV. Congenital conditions such as Fanconi anemia or Diamond-Blackfan anemia typically manifest with skeletal abnormalities (e.g., microcephaly, thumb malformations), which are absent in this newborn. She also has no signs of infection (e.g., fever) and does not receive medications. Lastly, aplastic anemia would present with pancytopenia.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency is an X-linked recessive disorder that very rarely presents in female individuals. Additionally, it is a hemolytic anemia that presents after a sudden surge in oxidative stress, such as infection or medications. As this infant has normal levels of total bilirubin and indirect bilirubin, without any recent infection or medication use, she likely does not have hemolytic anemia.

images.title: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency fact sheet
images.description: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway and oxidizes glucose-6-P to 6-phosphogluconate while reducing NADP to NADPH. NADPH is essential for converting oxidized glutathione back to its reduced form (GSH). The reduced glutathione is capable of neutralizing reactive oxygen species (e.g., hydrogen peroxide) and free radicals, thereby protecting red blood cells from oxidative damage.In G6PD deficiency, glutathione cannot be reduced and erythrocytes become susceptible to oxidative stress, resulting in damage to the erythrocyte membrane, and thus intravascular and extravascular hemolysis.

answers.explanation_why: Premature infants are at a higher risk for iron deficiency anemia due to shortened maternal-fetal iron transfer and reduced gastrointestinal absorption after birth. However, iron deficiency typically results in microcytic, hypochromic anemia when symptomatic rather than this patient's normocytic anemia.

Impaired production of erythropoietin (EPO) is the primary cause of anemia of prematurity (AOP). EPO is produced by the fetal liver as well as fetal kidneys and production increases with gestational age. EPO levels and erythropoiesis show a physiological decrease after birth, as the onset of breathing and the closure of the ductus arteriosus increase tissue oxygenation. Preterm children are born with a lower hematocrit than full-term newborns, which is complicated by the physiologically reduced EPO production after birth. This effect results in AOP. Poor oxygen delivery to the tissue leads to clinical signs and symptoms of AOP (e.g., episodes of apnea). Laboratory findings for AOP include normocytic, normochromic anemia with a low-normal reticulocyte count, all of which are present in this patient.

Management of AOP includes limitation of blood withdrawals, iron supplementation (routinely done in preterm infants), and RBC transfusions if necessary (taking into account restrictive guidelines for transfusions in neonates). Erythropoiesis-stimulating agents (e.g., recombinant EPO) are not routinely administered due to limited efficacy and severe side effects (e.g., retinopathy of prematurity). Anemia is typically self-limiting and resolves around three to six months of age.

question_text: A 3-week-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was delivered at 30 weeks' gestation via cesarean section and was cyanotic at birth, requiring resuscitation and admission to the neonatal intensive care unit. His mother received no prenatal care; she has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She was not tested for sexually transmitted infections during the pregnancy. The infant appears well. Ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels. There are well-demarcated areas of nonvascularized retina in the periphery. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's retinal findings?
content_preview: A 3-week-old boy is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He was delivered at 30 weeks' gestation via cesarean section and was cyanotic at birth, requiring resuscitation and admission to the neonatal intensive care unit. His mother received no prenatal care; she has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. She was not tested for sexually transmitted infections during the pregnancy. The infant appears well. Ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels. There are well-demarcated areas of nonvascularized retina in the periphery. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's retinal findings?
hint: This infant's ophthalmologic examination shows tortuous retinal vessels and areas of nonvascularized peripheral retina, which are consistent with retinopathy of prematurity (ROP).
learning_objective: Recognize retinopathy of prematurity due to oxygen toxicity.

answers.explanation_why: Retinoblastoma is an important cause of ocular disease in infants and is caused by mutations in the RB1 tumor suppressor gene that are often inherited. However, this patient has no family history of malignancy and the ophthalmologic findings are not consistent with retinoblastoma.

This premature infant likely received supplemental oxygen at birth, which is a major contributing factor in the development of ROP. Higher arterial oxygen tension in a premature infant inhibits the production of VEGF, leading to apoptosis of endothelial cells and cessation of normal retinal vascular formation. Switching to room air results in relative hypoxia due to the lower oxygen concentration, increased metabolic demand of the growing retina, and poor vascular network, leading to the production of proangiogenic growth factors (e.g., VEGF) and uncontrolled neovascularization. The formation of new blood vessels can cause hemorrhages, form fibrovascular membranes, and ultimately lead to retinal detachment or blindness.

images.title: Plus disease of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP)
images.description: Fundus photography of a right eyeThe retina shows tortuous and dilated retinal vessels.This finding is an example of plus disease, which indicates a risk for progression to ROP.

answers.explanation_why: Glucocorticoid deficiency is associated with an increased risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, as glucocorticoids play a vital role in promoting fetal lung maturity by stimulating the production of surfactant. However, glucocorticoid deficiency is not a risk factor for the development of ROP.

Maternal diabetes causes chronic fetal hyperglycemia and can lead to a wide range of complications in the infant. This newborn's mother did not receive prenatal care, which means she was neither screened nor treated for diabetes during pregnancy. Maternal diabetes also increases the risk of prematurity, the single greatest risk factor for ROP. This infant does not have features consistent with chronic hyperglycemia, however, such as macrosomia, neonatal hypoglycemia, cardiac anomalies, and respiratory distress. While this patient's ROP could be related to prematurity caused by maternal diabetes, another factor is much more likely responsible for his ROP.

Syphilis is one of several congenital infections (TORCH infections) that can cause ocular abnormalities in affected infants. Congenital syphilis can manifest with uveitis, keratitis, glaucoma, and congenital cataracts. However, this infant's fundoscopy findings are highly indicative of ROP, and, although infection may worsen the course of ROP, it is not a contributing factor to the development of this condition.

Head trauma as a result of rotational and shearing forces can cause shaken baby syndrome. This condition manifests with retinal and intracranial hemorrhages but does not contribute to the development of ROP.

Mothers receiving routine prenatal care are screened for chlamydia infection to eliminate the risk of chlamydial conjunctivitis in the newborn. This mother's lack of prenatal care puts the infant at risk of this disease, which often manifests 1–2 weeks after birth. However, ocular findings include mucopurulent or watery discharge, eyelid swelling, and chemosis. This disease does not affect the retina.

question_text: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the 3^rd trimester of pregnancy. Examination of the newborn shows watery discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
content_preview: A 15-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician for evaluation of red eyes with discharge for 3 days. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother received irregular prenatal care during the 3rd trimester of pregnancy. Examination of the newborn shows watery discharge in both eyes and mild eyelid swelling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
hint: A gram stain of this patient's discharge would yield a negative result.
learning_objective: Recognize chlamydial conjunctivitis in a newborn, and recall its cause.

answers.explanation_why: Silver nitrate exposure can lead to chemical conjunctivitis, which usually manifests in the 1^st day of life with mild watery discharge and conjunctival injections. Discharge and eyelid swelling was observed in this patient 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of bacterial conjunctivitis in adults and typically presents with unilateral conjunctival injection, chemosis, and thick purulent discharge. This patient has watery eye discharge. Moreover, Staphylococcus aureus is not a common cause of conjunctivitis in neonates.

Chlamydial conjunctivitis, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, typically manifests at 5–14 days after birth with watery or mucopurulent ocular discharge in addition to mild eyelid swelling, as seen in this patient. Oral erythromycin is the treatment for chlamydial conjunctivitis.

Gonococcal conjunctivitis, which is caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, typically manifests 2–7 days after delivery with profuse, purulent, ocular discharge in addition to a pronounced eyelid swelling. This patient, meanwhile, has a mild eyelid swelling and watery discharge observed 12 days after delivery, which makes this diagnosis unlikely.

Herpes simplex virus 2 is a common cause of viral conjunctivitis in neonates. It typically manifests within the first 14 days of life with nonpurulent, ocular discharge, corneal ulceration, and periocular vesicles. This patient lacks corneal ulceration and periocular vesicles, which make this diagnosis unlikely.

question_text: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because his mother has noticed her son has occasional bouts of "turning blue in the face" while crying. He also tires easily and sweats while feeding. He weighed 2150 g (4 lb 11 oz) at birth and has gained 200 g (7 oz). The baby appears mildly cyanotic. Examination shows a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S_2 is present. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following factors is the main determinant of the severity of this patient's cyanosis?
content_preview: A 2-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician because his mother has noticed her son has occasional bouts of "turning blue in the face" while crying. He also tires easily and sweats while feeding. He weighed 2150 g (4 lb 11 oz) at birth and has gained 200 g (7 oz). The baby appears mildly cyanotic. Examination shows a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 is present. Echocardiography confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following factors is the main determinant of the severity of this patient's cyanosis?
hint: The presence of (intermittent) cyanosis, fatigue, and sweating during periods of exertion in a neonate with a systolic ejection murmur and a single S_2 is suggestive of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
learning_objective: Recognize tetralogy of Fallot, and recall the factors determining cyanosis severity.

answers.explanation_why: In patients with TOF, the right ventricular outflow obstruction (RVOO) due to central pulmonary valve stenosis and hypoplasia determines cyanosis severity and systolic heart murmur intensity. The higher the degree of RVOO, the more (unoxygenated) blood will bypass pulmonary circulation and shunt straight through the VSD to the left ventricle (LV). The lower the degree of RVOO, the more blood flows through the lungs and becomes oxygenated before reaching the LV, resulting in a reduction of cyanosis. In TOF, the single S_2 can result from an attenuated pulmonary component (P_2) that is often not heard on auscultation.

Left ventricular outflow obstruction (e.g., aortic stenosis) is not one of the four features of TOF. However, if aortic stenosis (or any form of increased left ventricular outflow resistance) were present, this would decrease right-to-left shunting by creating higher left-sided pressures and thus reduce, rather than increase, cyanosis.

Although right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) is one of the four features of TOF, it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. RVH is a compensatory mechanism against the outflow tract obstruction, which helps to reduce cyanosis by increasing flow through the stenotic pulmonary vasculature, so that deoxygenated blood does not flow through the VSD and into the systemic circulation. However, RVH can only compensate to a small degree to improve normal circulatory flow and is, therefore, only a minor determinant of cyanosis.

A ventricular septal defect (VSD) is one of the four features of TOF but it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. Rather, it is the pressure differences across the VSD that determine the degree of cyanosis. Specifically, higher right ventricular pressures and/or lower left ventricular pressures are associated with increased right-to-left shunting and, thus, with increased cyanosis.

Although an overriding aorta is one of the four features of TOF, it is not the main determinant of cyanosis. In patients with TOF, the aorta is displaced to the right ventricle, over the VSD, allowing blood from both ventricles to be pumped into the aorta. This causes deoxygenated blood to enter the systemic circulation, contributing to cyanosis. However, another factor has a greater impact on the degree of cyanosis.

Atrial septal defect (ASD) is not one of the four features of TOF. However, in a patient with TOF, the presence of a concomitant ASD could lead to greater right-to-left shunting and thus exacerbate cyanosis.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 14-weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Routine first trimester screening shows increased nuchal translucency, decreased β-hCG concentration, and decreased levels of pregnancy-associated plasma protein A. Amniocentesis shows trisomy of chromosome 13. This fetus is at increased risk for which of the following?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 14-weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. Routine first trimester screening shows increased nuchal translucency, decreased β-hCG concentration, and decreased levels of pregnancy-associated plasma protein A. Amniocentesis shows trisomy of chromosome 13. This fetus is at increased risk for which of the following?
hint: Trisomy 13 is the karyotype of Patau syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome), and recall its associated clinical features.

answers.explanation_why: Optic gliomas are associated with Neurofibromatosis type 1 (von Recklinghausen disease). Ocular disorders associated with Trisomy 13 include coloboma and ocular hypotelorism.

Cutis aplasia is characteristic of trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome). Other externally visible clinical features include microcephaly, cleft lip and cleft palate, microphthalmia, polydactyly, and rocker-bottom feet. Patients have approximately an 80% risk of having congenital heart defects (particularly ventricular septal defect and patent ductus arteriosus) and often visceral and genital anomalies (especially the kidneys and ureter).

First trimester screening for Trisomy 13 shows increased nuchal translucency on ultrasound, as well as serum levels of decreased β-hCG concentration and significantly decreased levels of PAPP-A. Only 5% of infants with trisomy 13 survive past 6 months of age.

An increased risk of duodenal atresia is seen in ∼ 30% patients with trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). While Down syndrome would also show increased nuchal translucency on ultrasound and decreased levels of PAPP-A, the β-hCG concentration would be elevated. While trisomy 13 can cause visceral and genital anomalies, especially of the kidneys and ureter, it is not typically associated with malformations of the gastrointestinal tract.

Cystic hygromas are associated with Turner syndrome (monosomy X). While Trisomy 13 can present with vascular tumors of the skin, it is most often associated with external capillary hemangiomas as opposed to internal cavernous lymphangiomas (cystic hygroma).

Prominent occiput is characteristic of trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome). While first trimester screening tests would also show nuchal translucency on ultrasound, decreased β-hCG, and decreased PAPP-A, trisomy 18 additionally causes a decrease in free estriol, alpha fetoprotein, and inhibin A levels, unlike in this patient. Additional features of Trisomy 18 include low-set ears, micrognathia, and cleft lip and cleft palate.

question_text: One day after a 4700-g (10-lb 6-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman, he has bluish discoloration of his lips and fingernails. Oxygen saturation on room air is 81%. Examination shows central cyanosis. A continuous machine-like murmur is heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 heart sound is present. Supplemental oxygen does not improve cyanosis. Echocardiography shows the pulmonary artery arising from the posterior left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle with active blood flow between the right and left ventricles. Further evaluation of the mother is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: One day after a 4700-g (10-lb 6-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman, he has bluish discoloration of his lips and fingernails. Oxygen saturation on room air is 81%. Examination shows central cyanosis. A continuous machine-like murmur is heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 heart sound is present. Supplemental oxygen does not improve cyanosis. Echocardiography shows the pulmonary artery arising from the posterior left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle with active blood flow between the right and left ventricles. Further evaluation of the mother is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Echocardiography showing a pulmonary artery arising from the left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle confirms the diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries (TGA) which is an important cause of neonatal cyanosis that will not improve with supplemental oxygen. The continuous machine-like murmur indicates a coexistent patent ductus arteriosus, which is critical for life, as it allows mixing of oxygenated blood and its entry into the systemic circulation. Patients may also have coexistent arterial or ventricular septal defects that allow mixing of blood between the two circuits.
learning_objective: Recognize transposition of the great arteries, and recall the maternal condition associated with its development.

answers.explanation_why: Prenatal lithium intake is associated with Ebstein anomaly, which can have a wide range of clinical presentations, including congenital cyanosis from right-to-left shunting. Depending on the severity of the anomaly, the patient may have a holosystolic murmur (due to tricuspid regurgitation), as heard in this patient. However, echocardiography would show right-sided cardiomegaly with apical displacement of the tricuspid valve and tricuspid regurgitation, not the TGA seen in this patient.
Elevated serum TSH levels suggest hypothyroidism. Subclinical maternal hypothyroidism may increase the risk for future cognitive impairment, but it is not associated with TGA.

Prenatal alcohol consumption can cause fetal alcohol spectrum disorder. FASD can present with a wide range of cardiac abnormalities, including atrial septal defect, VSD, and great heart vessel defects. However, structural heart defects would also usually present with other more characteristic FASD findings, such as facial abnormalities (short palpebral fissures, thin vermillion border, smooth philtrum) and growth retardation.

Prenatal phenytoin intake is associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome. Although cases of congenital heart defects have been reported with maternal phenytoin use, transposition of the great arteries is rare. Furthermore, fetal hydantoin syndrome also presents with nail hypoplasia, hypoplasia of the digits, and abnormal facial features, which are all absent in this patient.

A positive rapid plasma reagin test suggests maternal syphilis, which can infect the infant in utero. Most cases of early congenital syphilis are asymptomatic at birth and do not develop symptoms until 5 weeks of life. If symptomatic at birth, findings include hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, nasal discharge, generalized lymphadenopathy, skeletal abnormalities, and/or and pemphigus syphiliticus, none of which are present in this infant. Transposition of the great arteries is not associated with congenital syphilis.

TGA is a cyanotic heart condition that is associated with maternal diabetes, caused by abnormal rotation of the pulmonary artery and aorta during fetal development. Mothers with untreated diabetes will have elevated fasting blood glucose levels. Other potential neonatal complications from maternal diabetes include fetal macrosomia (seen in this patient), polycythemia, hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

images.title: Transposition of the great vessels (TGV)
images.description: TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.

question_text: A 19-year-old primigravid woman at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of headache and blurred vision. She has had no prenatal care. She is diagnosed with preeclampsia. Amniocentesis shows a lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio of 0.7. If delivery is induced at this time, the newborn is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 19-year-old primigravid woman at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of headache and blurred vision. She has had no prenatal care. She is diagnosed with preeclampsia. Amniocentesis shows a lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio of 0.7. If delivery is induced at this time, the newborn is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: A low lecithin-sphingomyelin ratio in amniotic fluid (< 1.5) indicates fetal lung immaturity, placing the fetus at increased risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. Other amniotic fluid markers of fetal lung immaturity include a low foam stability index (< 0.48) and a low surfactant-albumin ratio.
learning_objective: Recognize preeclampsia and fetal lung immaturity, and recall the respiratory complications of premature infants.

answers.explanation_why: Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is associated with increased pulmonary vascular resistance due to hypoxemia and, therefore, increased rather than decreased right ventricular afterload.

answers.content: Increased diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide
answers.explanation_why: The diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide (DL_CO) depends on the effective alveolar surface area available to participate in gas exchange. In neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, surfactant deficiency results in alveolar atelectasis. This decreases effective alveolar surface area and thus decreases rather than increases DL_CO. Increased DL_CO is expected in conditions such as polycythemia and obesity.

Premature infants are at increased risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), which is characterized by low levels of surfactant (lecithin). As a result, alveolar surface tension increases, causing alveolar atelectasis and decreased lung compliance. This alveolar atelectasis also increases work of breathing and decreases all lung volumes including functional residual capacity. Hypoxemia caused by NRDS would result in increased pulmonary vascular resistance and increased risk of persistent ductus arteriosus.

Increased lung compliance indicates pliability and low elastic recoil of the airways, which is observed in conditions such as emphysema due to alveolar wall destruction. However, in neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, insufficient surfactant production results in alveolar atelectasis, interstitial edema, and hyalinization of small airways. These changes contribute to stiffer lung parenchyma and decreased rather than increased lung compliance.

Anatomic dead space is the volume of air in airways that do not participate in gas exchange. Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome is caused by the collapse of alveoli (i.e., atelectasis). The conducting airways, however, are not affected, meaning that the anatomic dead space is unchanged, not increased.

question_text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
hint: The boot-shaped heart on this boy's x-ray is caused by right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). His harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border is caused by pulmonary stenosis. These findings, along with his acute hypoxic spells (which cause cyanosis), indicate a diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
learning_objective: Recognize right ventricular outflow obstruction.

answers.content: Persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: A persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery characterizes a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), an acyanotic heart defect that can cause cyanosis if Eisenmenger syndrome develops. However, patients with a PDA and Eisenmenger syndrome typically develop differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Additionally, PDA causes a continuous, machine-like murmur heard throughout systole and diastole (unlike this patient's systolic murmur), and chest x-ray shows a prominent mediastinum caused by an enlarged pulmonary artery and aortic knob (not a boot-shaped heart).

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Hypoplasia of the left ventricle is caused by hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS), a heart condition that is typically acyanotic in the early postnatal period because a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) ensures systemic perfusion. Cyanosis develops when the PDA closes, usually within a few days of birth (not as late as 3 months as in this case). Neonates with HLHS also have weak peripheral pulses, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis as the hypoplastic left ventricle cannot maintain adequate cardiac output. Additionally, HLHS does not cause a murmur, and findings on chest x-ray are variable (e.g., small, normal, or enlarged heart and increased pulmonary venous markings) but do not include a boot-shaped heart.

answers.content: Narrowing of the distal aortic arch
answers.explanation_why: Narrowing of the distal aortic arch, or coarctation of the aorta, manifests variably depending on the degree of aortic stenosis (AS) and the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Patients with significant AS and PDA present with differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Once the PDA closes (usually within a few days after birth), heart failure develops and manifests as dyspnea, sweating during feeds, and poor weight gain. Examination shows pallor (rather than cyanosis), features of inadequate left ventricular output (absent or weak femoral pulses, brachio-femoral delay), and signs of right heart failure (e.g., raised jugular venous pressure, edema, and hepatomegaly). Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary venous markings, not a boot-shaped heart.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

answers.explanation_why:
Right ventricular outflow obstruction (RVOO) in this patient is caused by pulmonary stenosis, which is one of the components of TOF, along with RVH, an overriding aorta, and a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Exertion, such as crying or feeding, increases the RVOO. This results in cyanosis (tet spells) due to right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood through the VSD instead of the pulmonary valve, which in turn causes the murmur to become softer. The right ventricle hypertrophies because it chronically pumps against high resistance caused by the RVOO.

Older children with TOF tend to squat during a tet spell. Squatting increases systemic vascular resistance, which increases left ventricular pressure and decreases the right-to-left shunting of blood through the VSD. Infants who are having a tet spell should be placed with their knees toward their chest to achieve the same effect.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Anatomic reversal of aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: Anatomic reversal of the aorta and pulmonary artery is known as transposition of the great vessels (TGV). This condition causes cyanosis because the aorta arises from the right ventricle and thus results in systemic circulation of deoxygenated blood. However, unlike this patient, cyanosis in TGV manifests immediately after birth. Additionally, chest x-ray in TGV shows an egg-on-a-string appearance due to an enlarged heart with a narrowed mediastinum, which resembles an egg lying on its side.

images.title: Intracardiac shunt in the transposition of the great vessels
images.description: In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

answers.explanation_why: Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) in infants is usually due to a malformed and displaced tricuspid valve in Ebstein anomaly. These infants may develop cyanosis only if there's an associated ASD or PFO that allows for right-to-left shunting of blood. Auscultation would reveal a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border, like in this patient, with a widely split S2. However, a chest x-ray in Ebstein anomaly will show right atrial enlargement (due to chronic reflux of blood from the right ventricle into the right atrium) - not a boot-shaped heart as seen in this infant.

images.title: Ebstein anomaly
images.description: In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

images.title: Boot-shaped heart in tetralogy of Fallot
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of FallotThe cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

question_text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents because they noticed that his head has been tilted to the left since birth. Physical examination shows the head turned toward the left side and the chin rotated toward the right. He cries during an attempt to rotate the head to the right. There is a firm, well-circumscribed mass on the left lower side of the neck. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents because they noticed that his head has been tilted to the left since birth. Physical examination shows the head turned toward the left side and the chin rotated toward the right. He cries during an attempt to rotate the head to the right. There is a firm, well-circumscribed mass on the left lower side of the neck. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
hint: This newborn's head tilt, limited passive range of motion of the neck, and palpable lower neck mass are consistent with a diagnosis of congenital torticollis. The mass seen here is the shortened, thickened segment of the sternocleidomastoid muscle that was injured in-utero or during delivery.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital torticollis, and recall its predisposing factors.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased intrauterine space during pregnancy (e.g., due to fetal macrosomia, multiple gestation, oligohydramnios) is a risk factor for the development of torticollis as it may lead to fetal malpositioning and/or decreased intrauterine fetal movement. In addition, fetal macrosomia, breech presentation, and assisted vaginal delivery can cause perinatal trauma to the sternocleidomastoid muscles, which is another risk factor for the development of congenital torticollis.

Cesarean delivery is not a proven risk factor for the development of congenital torticollis. C-section is less likely than assisted vaginal delivery to cause traction to the neonate's neck, which is a known risk factor for congenital torticollis.

Vertex presentation is the most common form of cephalic presentation; it is not a predisposing factor for the development of congenital torticollis. However, breech presentation may lead to congenital torticollis as it has a higher risk of perinatal trauma to the sternocleidomastoid muscles during delivery than a vertex presentation.

Dopamine receptor antagonists such as haloperidol can cause acute dystonia, which manifests with torticollis if the sternocleidomastoid muscle is involved. However, dystonic torticollis does not manifest with a palpable mass in the sternocleidomastoid muscle, as seen in this infant.

Polyhydramnios increases intrauterine space; it is not a predisposing factor for the development of congenital torticollis. Oligohydramnios, however, may cause congenital torticollis due to intrauterine restriction of the fetus.

Preterm birth is not a direct risk factor for the development of congenital torticollis. Conditions associated with preterm birth include neonatal respiratory distress syndrome, retinopathy of prematurity, necrotizing enterocolitis, persistent fetal circulation, intracranial hemorrhage, and sepsis.

question_text: A 2600-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 34 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman. The mother did not have prenatal care. Upon examination in the delivery room, the newborn's skin appears blue. He is gasping and breathing irregularly. The ears are low-set with broad auricles, and the nasal tip is flattened. The lower jaw is small and displaced backward. The right foot is clubbed. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 2600-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 34 weeks' gestation to a 22-year-old woman. The mother did not have prenatal care. Upon examination in the delivery room, the newborn's skin appears blue. He is gasping and breathing irregularly. The ears are low-set with broad auricles, and the nasal tip is flattened. The lower jaw is small and displaced backward. The right foot is clubbed. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This newborn presents with low-set ears, flat nose, micrognathia, foot clubbing, and respiratory distress, which suggests Potter sequence. Compression of growing fetal tissue in utero due to oligohydramnios is the underlying etiology for Potter sequence.
learning_objective: Recognize Potter sequence due to posterior urethral valves.

answers.explanation_why: Fetal anemia (e.g., due to alloimmunization in utero) causes a state of high cardiac output, which in turn increases urine production and may subsequently result in polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios.

Pulmonary hypoplasia is a classic complication of Potter sequence, which results in respiratory distress and cyanosis, as seen in this patient. However, it is not the underlying cause of this patient's overall presentation, but rather the consequence of a problem in the earlier stages of fetal development.

Esophageal atresia causes polyhydramnios because of the fetus' inability to swallow and digest amniotic fluid. Certain types of esophageal atresia that occur in conjunction with tracheoesophageal fistulas may present with respiratory distress as a result of recurrent aspiration. However, esophageal atresia would not explain this patient's facial and limb abnormalities.

Maternal diabetes causes hyperglycemia in both the mother and the fetus. Hyperglycemia in the fetus results in osmotic diuresis and, consequently, increased fetal urine output, which leads to polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios. Maternal diabetes is associated with fetal caudal regression syndrome, which is characterized by agenesis of the sacrum and/or lumbar spine, paralysis of the legs, and anal atresia; this is not consistent with this fetus' malformations.

images.title: Caudal regression syndrome
images.description: Lower abdomen and legs of a 2.5-year-old girl of a diabetic mother with poor glycemic control during pregnancy:The hips and lower extremities appear hypoplastic and showed no muscular activity during the clinical examination. Orthopedic deformities included knees in a flexion contracture and equinovarus feet.These findings are consistent with caudal regression syndrome. X-ray and MRI of the spine confirmed total sacral and partial lumbar vertebrae agenesis and termination of the spinal cord at T6.

answers.explanation_why: Fetal anencephaly results in the inability to swallow and digest amniotic fluid, followed by subsequent polyhydramnios. Anencephaly is marked by a severely dysmorphic skull and the absence of a brain, which is (in almost all cases) fatal within the first few hours after birth.

Common causes of oligohydramnios include chronic placental insufficiency, chronic amniotic fluid leakage, and decreased fetal renal output. Prenatal posterior urethral valves lead to a bladder outlet obstruction and a decrease in fetal renal output. Other causes of decreased fetal renal output include bilateral renal agenesis and autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease.

The decreased amount of amniotic fluid may result in the development of deformities in the face (Potter facies) and limbs. Oligohydramnios can also affect fetal lung development, resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. This infant's cyanosis and respiratory distress are likely due to pulmonary hypoplasia, which is also the most common cause of death in Potter sequence.

question_text: A 26-year-old primigravid woman at 25 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has no history of serious illness and her only medication is a daily prenatal vitamin. A 1-hour 50-g glucose challenge shows a glucose concentration of 167 mg/dL (N < 135). A 100-g oral glucose tolerance test shows glucose concentrations of 213 mg/dL (N < 180) and 165 mg/dL (N < 140) at 1 and 3 hours, respectively. If she does not receive adequate treatment for her condition, which of the following complications is her infant at greatest risk of developing?
content_preview: A 26-year-old primigravid woman at 25 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has no history of serious illness and her only medication is a daily prenatal vitamin. A 1-hour 50-g glucose challenge shows a glucose concentration of 167 mg/dL (N < 135). A 100-g oral glucose tolerance test shows glucose concentrations of 213 mg/dL (N < 180) and 165 mg/dL (N < 140) at 1 and 3 hours, respectively. If she does not receive adequate treatment for her condition, which of the following complications is her infant at greatest risk of developing?
hint: Glucose readily crosses the placenta, meaning that elevated maternal glucose levels lead to elevated fetal blood glucose and, accordingly, cause physiologic changes that can lead to complications in the newborn infant.
learning_objective: Recognize gestational diabetes, and recall its fetal complications.

answers.explanation_why: Infants born to mothers with pregestational diabetes, not gestational diabetes, are at risk for intrauterine growth restriction. Infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes are at increased risk for macrosomia due to the anabolic effects of high insulin levels.

Infants of diabetic mothers are at risk for hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia. Although the exact mechanism is not fully understood, this type of hypocalcemia may be due to abnormal maternal calcium-phosphorus metabolism, and/or decreased maternal vitamin D concentrations. Infants of diabetic mothers are also at risk for hypomagnesemia due to maternal renal loss of magnesium from glycosuria. These low levels of magnesium can impair parathyroid hormone release, resulting in hypoparathyroidism that may also contribute to hypocalcemia.

Hyperplasia of islet cells, the pancreatic cells responsible for producing insulin, can occur in utero in response to elevated maternal blood glucose levels, e.g., due to gestational diabetes. This can cause infantile hyperinsulinemia and put the infant at risk for hypoglycemia once the maternal placental transfer of glucose ceases after birth.

Infants born to diabetic mothers have an increased risk for polyhydramnios, or increased amniotic fluid, not oligohydramnios. Fetal hyperglycemia results in fetal polyuria and, thus, increased amniotic fluid production.

Untreated diabetes during pregnancy can have teratogenic effects, putting infants at increased risk for congenital malformations including hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and small left colon syndrome. They are not, however, at increased risk for omphalocele. Pregestational diabetes (but not gestational diabetes) puts infants at increased risk of caudal regression syndrome.

Infants born to diabetic mothers are at increased risk for polycythemia (Hct > 65%), not anemia. Fetal hyperinsulinemia results in an increased metabolic demand that can lead to fetal hypoxia and increased RBC production to compensate. Infants with polycythemia are at increased risk for RBC sludging, ischemia, and infarction.

question_text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after falling out from a chair and injuring her right leg. During the past 2 years, she has had two long bone fractures. She is at the 5^th percentile for height and 20^th percentile for weight. Her right lower leg is diffusely erythematous. The patient withdraws and yells when her lower leg is touched. A photograph of her face is shown. An x-ray of the right lower leg shows a transverse mid-tibial fracture with diffusely decreased bone density. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after falling out from a chair and injuring her right leg. During the past 2 years, she has had two long bone fractures. She is at the 5th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Her right lower leg is diffusely erythematous. The patient withdraws and yells when her lower leg is touched. A photograph of her face is shown. An x-ray of the right lower leg shows a transverse mid-tibial fracture with diffusely decreased bone density. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient presents with growth retardation, recurrent bone fractures, blue sclera, and osteopenia, all of which are consistent with the diagnosis of osteogenesis imperfecta.
learning_objective: Recognize osteogenesis imperfecta, and recall its associated collagen defect.

answers.explanation_why: The vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (type 4) arises from an autosomal mutation in collagen type 3. This condition manifests predominantly in the cardiovascular system and often goes undiagnosed until it becomes apparent through some sort of vascular damage/injury (e.g., aortic dissection, ruptures arterial aneurysm, subarachnoid hemorrhage). The child presents with easy bruising, as evidenced by the ecchymosis, which is also a feature of Ehlers-Danlos type 4. However, the child's history of frequent fractures after minor trauma, the blue sclerae, and growth retardation are not consistent with this condition.

Type 5 collagen is a regulator of type 1 collagen fibrillogenesis. Type 5 collagen defects usually manifest as classic Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is characterized by chronic joint and bone issues. Rather than frequent bone fractures, the major symptoms are joint instability, early onset of osteoarthritis, hyperflexible joints, and scoliosis.

A mutation in type 1 collagen causes osteogenesis imperfecta type 1, the mildest and most common form of osteogenesis imperfecta. In fact, some patients with osteogenesis imperfecta type 1 appear normal and without obvious deformities to the casual observer despite requiring special accommodations for their bone fragility. This child presents with blue sclera, short stature, and growth retardation, recurrent fractures from minor falls, and decreased bone density – all classic symptoms of osteogenesis imperfecta.

images.title: Osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease) fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Mutations to the genes encoding type 4 collagen can present as Alport syndrome. This disorder usually affects boys, who present with intermittent gross hematuria, hearing loss, and ocular disturbances, none of which are seen here. Recurrent bone fractures, growth retardation, and blue sclerae are not features of Alport syndrome.

Type 2 collagen defects predominantly affect tissues such as cartilage and the vitreous humor. Various conditions are associated with type 2 collagen defects (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia, or osteoarthritis) and these differ substantially in presentation and age of onset. While some conditions could explain the growth retardation observed in this patient (e.g., hypochondrogenesis, Kniest dysplasia), blue sclerae and recurrent bone fractures in an otherwise healthy child would not be consistent with any type 2 collagen defect.

images.title: Scleral manifestations of osteogenesis imperfecta
images.description: The sclerae show a distinct blue-gray tint.

question_text: A 5-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of poor feeding, irritability, and noisy breathing. The mother did not receive any prenatal care. His respirations are 26/min. Physical examination shows sunken fontanelles, tightly clenched fists, and erythema around the umbilical cord stump. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of the disease process in this patient?
content_preview: A 5-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of poor feeding, irritability, and noisy breathing. The mother did not receive any prenatal care. His respirations are 26/min. Physical examination shows sunken fontanelles, tightly clenched fists, and erythema around the umbilical cord stump. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of the disease process in this patient?
hint: This newborn has several risk factors (lack of maternal prenatal care, umbilical cord stump infection) that should raise concern for neonatal tetanus.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal tetanus, and recall its pathogenesis involving glycine release inhibition.

answers.explanation_why: Infant botulism is due to ingestion of botulinum toxin produced by Clostridium botulinum. The toxin inhibits the release of acetylcholine from the neuromuscular junction (NMJ) and causes muscle paralysis. Although infant botulism also manifests with breathing difficulty, poor feeding, and irritability, it causes descending flaccid paralysis, while this patient has spastic paralysis.

images.title: Infant botulism
images.description: This child's ptosis and flaccid facial muscles are characteristic of infant botulism.

answers.explanation_why: Inhibition of voltage-gated sodium channels in the nervous system can occur shortly after ingestion of seafood that is contaminated with tetrodotoxin or ciguatoxin. These neurotoxin blocks the formation of action potentials in neurons and thereby blocks neural signals from passing to muscles. Tetrodotoxin or ciguatoxin poisoning would not be expected in this 5-day-old neonate who has not yet been weaned.

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is a postinfectious autoimmune reaction in which molecular mimicry results in formation of antiganglioside antibodies and subsequent destruction of Schwann cells. GBS causes ascending flaccid paralysis rather than spastic paralysis (tightly clenched fists).

Neonatal tetanus is caused by tetanospasmin, which is produced by ubiquitous Clostridium tetani spores that then contaminate wounds (e.g., umbilical cord). The toxin reaches the CNS via retrograde axonal transport and blocks the release of glycine and GABA from inhibitory interneurons (Renshaw cells). This causes uncontrolled activation of alpha motor neurons, which results in tonic and clonic spasms (difficulty opening the mouth and feeding due to trismus, clenched hands). The most effective measure to prevent neonatal tetanus is immunization of women who are pregnant or of childbearing age. Vaccinated women produce antibodies against tetanospasmin that can cross the placenta, which provided passive immunity for the neonate.

Poliomyelitis is a viral disease that causes destruction of anterior horn cells. Although difficulty breathing, poor feeding, and irritability are clinical features of poliomyelitis, it causes ascending flaccid paralysis rather than the spastic paralysis (tightly clenched fists) seen in this patient. Furthermore, poliomyelitis has been eradicated from the United States and most other countries due to widespread vaccination.

question_text: A 7-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of lethargy, vomiting, poor feeding, and diarrhea for 4 days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation. Vital signs are within normal limits. Bilateral cataracts and icterus are present. Examination shows jaundice of the skin, and the liver is palpated 5-cm below the right costal margin. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Serum glucose concentration is 40 mg/dL. Which of the following metabolites is most likely to be increased in this patient?
content_preview: A 7-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician because of lethargy, vomiting, poor feeding, and diarrhea for 4 days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation. Vital signs are within normal limits. Bilateral cataracts and icterus are present. Examination shows jaundice of the skin, and the liver is palpated 5-cm below the right costal margin. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Serum glucose concentration is 40 mg/dL. Which of the following metabolites is most likely to be increased in this patient?
hint: This newborn has diarrhea, cataracts, jaundice/icterus, and hepatomegaly with hypoglycemia, which are indicative of classic galactosemia.
learning_objective: Recognize classic galactosemia, and recall the associated metabolite accumulation.

answers.explanation_why: Sphingomyelin accumulates in Niemann-Pick disease. Although eye involvement and hepatomegaly are clinical features of Niemann-Pick disease, the eye manifestation is cherry-red spot on the macula rather than cataracts. In addition, Niemann-Pick disease is uncommon in the first week of life; instead, clinical manifestations usually start to develop in early childhood, and hypoglycemia is not expected.

Uric acid accumulates in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. Clinical features include developmental delay, dystonia, spasticity, gouty arthritis, urate nephropathy, and self-injurious behavior, which are not seen in this patient. In addition, Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease that primarily affects males, and bilateral cataracts and hypoglycemia are not expected.

Branched-chain amino acids accumulate in maple syrup urine disease. Although lethargy, poor feeding, vomiting, and hypotonia are clinical features of maple syrup urine disease, this newborn lacks the characteristic maple syrup odor in the urine. In addition, bilateral cataracts are not expected in maple syrup urine disease.

The most common form of galactosemia is galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT) deficiency (classic galactosemia). Infantile cataracts are caused by accumulation of galactitol in the eye lens. Hypoglycemia develops because galactose cannot be used for glycolysis, and in breastfeeding newborns, lactose (broken down into glucose and galactose) is the main source of nutrition. If galactosemia is left untreated, complications such as cirrhosis, renal failure, hypogonadism, seizures, and brain damage can occur. Another milder form of galactosemia is galactokinase deficiency, which also causes infantile cataracts but does not cause damage to other organs such as the liver damage in this patient. Since these manifestations can be prevented by avoiding milk products, guidelines in the US state that all newborns should be screened for galactosemia.

Neonates with classic galactosemia are at increased risk of developing sepsis due to E. coli.

images.title: Galactose metabolism
images.description: Illustration of the galactose metabolism in the liverGalactose is added to the glucose metabolism by activating it through galactokinase at the C1 atom via phosphorylation. A UDP molecule is then transferred to the resulting galactose-1-phosphate. This molecule is provided by UDP-glucose and transferred through Gal-1-P uridylyltransferase; in this process, glucose-1-phosphate is released that can be converted to glucose-6-phosphate and introduced to the glycolysis. Next, UDP-glucose 4-epimerase can transfer UDP-galactosis to the UDP-glucose; then, it can be either directly used for the glycosynthesis or react with another molecule to galactose 1-phosphate.

answers.explanation_why: Limit dextrins accumulate in Cori disease. Although lethargy, poor feeding, hypotonia, and hepatomegaly are clinical features of Cori disease, bilateral cataracts are not expected. In addition, newborns affected with Cori disease are usually healthy during the first few months of life, and hypoglycemia is uncommon.

question_text: A 3000-g (6.6-lb) female newborn is delivered at term to a 23-year-old primigravid woman. The mother has had no prenatal care. Immunization records are not available. Cardiac examination shows a continuous heart murmur. There are several bluish macules on the skin that do not blanch with pressure. Slit lamp examination shows cloudy lenses in both eyes. The newborn does not pass auditory screening tests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3000-g (6.6-lb) female newborn is delivered at term to a 23-year-old primigravid woman. The mother has had no prenatal care. Immunization records are not available. Cardiac examination shows a continuous heart murmur. There are several bluish macules on the skin that do not blanch with pressure. Slit lamp examination shows cloudy lenses in both eyes. The newborn does not pass auditory screening tests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The newborn presents with cataracts, auditory defects, and a murmur suggestive of patent ductus arteriosus, which is a triad of symptoms characteristic of a particular congenital infection. In adults, this infection typically presents with flu-like symptoms and polyarthralgia.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital rubella infection.

answers.explanation_why: Congenital parvovirus B19 infections can cause fetal hydrops and aplastic anemia, which can result in miscarriage. This newborn may have anemia, but she does not display signs of hydrops, such as edema of the subcutaneous tissue or scalp, ascites, or pleural effusions. Also, congenital parvovirus B19 infection does not cause cataracts, auditory defects, or a continuous heart murmur.

Newborns with congenital toxoplasmosis typically have chorioretinitis, intracranial calcifications, and hydrocephalus, none of which are seen in this patient. Bilateral cataracts, auditory defects, and heart murmurs are not typical features of intrauterine infection with toxoplasmosis.

The classic triad of congenital rubella infection is bilateral cataracts, sensorineural hearing loss (secondary to a cochlear dysfunction), and a heart defect – typically patent ductus arteriosus or pulmonary artery stenosis. Other, less specific findings include petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash). Congenital rubella syndrome usually only results if the infection occurs during organogenesis (i.e., during the first 1–8 weeks of gestation). If the transmission occurs after 16 weeks' gestation, the risk of developing congenital rubella syndrome is extremely low. This infection could have been prevented with appropriate vaccination prior to pregnancy.

See “Overview of congenital TORCH infections” table.

images.title: Congenital rubella infection TORCH fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Congenital cytomegalovirus infections typically manifest with sensorineural hearing loss, chorioretinitis, periventricular calcifications, and microcephaly. A congenital cytomegalovirus infection could cause an auditory defect and blueberry muffin rash, but it does not cause bilateral cataracts or a heart murmur.

images.title: Congenital CMV infection TORCH fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Though congenital syphilis can cause sensorineural hearing loss, this is typically a late finding that does not occur until children have reached 8–10 years of age. Findings of early congenital syphilis include rhinorrhea with a white or bloody nasal discharge, a maculopapular rash on palms and soles, skeletal abnormalities (e.g., saber shins, saddle nose), dental abnormalities (e.g., notched teeth, mulberry molars), and nontender generalized lymphadenopathy, none of which are seen in this patient.

question_text:
A 2800-g (6.2-lb) newborn is delivered at term to a 44-year-old woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. At 10 weeks' gestation, the patient underwent cell-free fetal DNA testing, which showed a low risk of fetal aneuploidy and XY fetal sex chromosomes. Examination shows infantile female external genitalia. Serum studies show a decreased level of 17-hydroxypregnenolone. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely found in this patient?

Blood pressure
Serum [K^+]
Serum cortisol

A
High
decreased
normal

B
High
increased
normal

C
High
decreased
decreased

D
High
decreased
increased

E
Low
increased
normal

F
Low
increased
decreased
content_preview: A 2800-g (6.2-lb) newborn is delivered at term to a 44-year-old woman. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. At 10 weeks' gestation, the patient underwent cell-free fetal DNA testing, which showed a low risk of fetal aneuploidy and XY fetal sex chromosomes. Examination shows infantile female external genitalia. Serum studies show a decreased level of 17-hydroxypregnenolone. Which of the following sets of changes is most likely found in this patient? Blood pressure Serum [K+] Serum cortisol A High decreased normal B High increased normal C High decreased decreased D High decreased increased E Low increased normal F Low increased decreased
hint: The discordance between sexual genotype and phenotype is an example of male pseudohermaphroditism. In this patient with decreased serum 17-hydroxypregnenolone levels, 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency, a rare form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, is most likely.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 17-hydroxylase deficiency, and recall its associated findings.

answers.explanation_why: Causes of hypertension with hypokalemia and normal cortisol levels during infancy include hyperreninemia due to renal artery stenosis (e.g., umbilical artery catheterization) or renal parenchymal disease, as well as certain rare conditions such as Liddle syndrome, glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism, and apparent mineralocorticoid excess syndrome. However, none of these conditions are associated with male pseudohermaphroditism.

During infancy, hypertension with hyperkalemia and normal cortisol levels can be seen with renal failure that develops as a result of renal parenchymal disease (e.g., infantile polycystic kidney disease). However, renal parenchymal diseases would typically result in oligohydramnios, and male pseudohermaphroditism would not be expected.

17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency results in decreased synthesis of both sex hormones (e.g., androstenedione, testosterone, estradiol) and glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol, deoxycortisol). Hypocortisolism leads to an increase in the secretion of ACTH from the pituitary gland. Stimulation of the adrenal cortex by ACTH results in an increase in the production of mineralocorticoids (e.g., aldosterone, deoxycorticosterone). While hyperaldosteronism causes hypertension and hypokalemia, the deficiency of androgens is responsible for male pseudohermaphroditism. Patients with XX genotype are usually diagnosed later because of lack of developing secondary sexual development and primary amenorrhea.

images.title: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia on steroid pathway and affecting drugs

answers.explanation_why: Hypertension with hypokalemia and increased cortisol levels can be seen in Cushing syndrome. Cushing syndrome appearing in infancy is almost always caused by McCune-Albright syndrome, which is more common among females. McCune-Albright syndrome is not associated with male pseudohermaphroditism.

During infancy, causes of hypotension with hyperkalemia and normal cortisol levels include aldosterone synthase deficiency and type 1 pseudohypoaldosteronism. However, neither of these conditions is associated with pseudohermaphroditism.

The most common form of congenital adrenal hyperplasia, 21-beta-hydroxylase deficiency, would present after birth with hypotension, hyperkalemia, and hypocortisolism. It is associated with prenatal virilization of females, not male pseudohermaphroditism, and would present with elevated levels of serum 17-hydroxypregnenolone.

question_text: A 2300-g (5.07-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 39-year-old woman. Examination shows a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, a protruding tongue, a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toe. There are small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
content_preview: A 2300-g (5.07-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 39-year-old woman. Examination shows a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, a protruding tongue, a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toe. There are small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
hint: The characteristic morphological features, Brushfield spots in the eye, and the “double bubble” sign on abdominal x-ray (indicating duodenal atresia) are all suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).
learning_objective: Recognize atrioventricular septal defect associated with Down syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: A patent ductus arteriosus is most commonly associated with prematurity, fetal alcohol syndrome, birth at high altitude, or congenital rubella infection. Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASDs) are among the most common congenital heart defects and are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome and trisomy 21. Although ASD occurs in approx. 15% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Atrioventricular septal defects (AVSD; also referred to as endocardial cushion defects) are the most common congenital heart defects in patients with Down syndrome, occurring in about 40% of newborns with trisomy 21. AVSDs are usually diagnosed in the prenatal period, and discovery of an AVSD should warrant prompt genetic testing, as there is a strong association with trisomy 21. Down syndrome is diagnosed in approx. 40–50% of children with AVSD.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cause of cyanotic heart disease in children. Most cases arise sporadically, but approx. 15% of patients with TOF have an underlying genetic syndrome (such as Down syndrome or DiGeorge syndrome). Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.explanation_why: Ventricular septal defects (VSDs) account for approx. 50% of all congenital heart defects, making them the most common cause of congenital heart disease overall. They are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, intrauterine infections, and many genetic syndromes (including trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and trisomy 21). Although VSD occurs in approx. 30% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood
