question_text:
A 37-year-old woman comes for a follow-up prenatal visit at 18 weeks' gestation. At 12 weeks' gestation, ultrasonography showed increased nuchal translucency and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) was decreased by 2 standard deviations. Chorionic villus sampling showed a 47, XX karyotype. During this visit, ultrasonography shows a hypoplastic nasal bone, shortened femur length, shortened middle phalanges of the fifth digits with clinodactyly. A quadruple marker test would most likely show which of the following sets of findings?

α-Fetoprotein (AFP)
Estriol
β-Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG)
Inhibin A

A
↓
↓
↓
normal

B
↓
↓
↑
↑

C
Normal
normal
normal
normal

D
↓
↓
↓
↓

E
↑
normal
normal
normal
content_preview: A 37-year-old woman comes for a follow-up prenatal visit at 18 weeks' gestation. At 12 weeks' gestation, ultrasonography showed increased nuchal translucency and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A) was decreased by 2 standard deviations. Chorionic villus sampling showed a 47, XX karyotype. During this visit, ultrasonography shows a hypoplastic nasal bone, shortened femur length, shortened middle phalanges of the fifth digits with clinodactyly. A quadruple marker test would most likely show which of the following sets of findings? α-Fetoprotein (AFP) Estriol β-Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) Inhibin A A ↓ ↓ ↓ normal B ↓ ↓ ↑ ↑ C Normal normal normal normal D ↓ ↓ ↓ ↓ E ↑ normal normal normal
hint: Increased nuchal translucency, decreased levels of PAPP-A, shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and a small nasal bone in a fetus with a 47, XX karyotype are features highly suggestive of trisomy 21 (i.e., Down syndrome).
learning_objective: Recognize fetal trisomy 21, and recall its associated quadruple marker test findings.

answers.explanation_why: A decrease in AFP, free estriol, and β-HCG with normal or decreased inhibin A is consistent with trisomy 18 (i.e., Edwards syndrome). While Edwards syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings typical of Edwards syndrome include rocker-bottom feet and clenched fists with overlapping of the third and fourth digits by the second and fifth digits, respectively (rather than clinodactyly).

The quadruple screening test is ideally performed between 15 and 22 weeks' gestation and can help to diagnose Down syndrome and other fetal aneuploidies, as well as open neural tube defects. Patients with Down syndrome typically have significantly decreased AFP and free estriol with a marked increase in β-HCG and inhibin A.

Normal findings in all quadruple screening markers are consistent with a normal fetus, but are concerning for trisomy 13 (i.e., Patau syndrome) in a fetus with a suspected aneuploidy (based on the (47, XX karyotype). While Patau syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency and decreased PAPP-A during first-trimester screening, as well as a 47, XX karyotype, this patient's shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, and hypoplastic nasal bone are indicative of Down syndrome. Ultrasound findings suggestive of Patau syndrome include rocker-bottom feet, microcephaly or holoprosencephaly, and polydactyly (rather than clinodactyly).

A mild decrease in all quadruple screening markers is consistent with Turner syndrome. While Turner syndrome can also manifest with increased nuchal translucency (due to lymphatic dysplasia), shortened femur length, and decreased PAPP-A levels, this patient's chorionic villus sampling revealed a 47, XX karyotype, which is not consistent with the 45, XO karyotype that is characteristic of Turner syndrome.

An isolated increase in AFP during pregnancy is characteristic of fetal neural tube defects or open abdominal wall defects such as gastroschisis or omphalocele. While some of these defects (such as omphalocele) may be associated with an increase in nuchal translucency, first-trimester fetal screening would show normal PAPP-A levels and a 46, XX karyotype. Furthermore, none of these conditions would involve shortened femur length, shortened fifth digits with clinodactyly, or a hypoplastic nasal bone.

question_text: An 8-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of vomiting and poor feeding. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, and he was born at full term. He appears pale and lethargic. Physical examination shows diffusely increased muscle tone. His urine is noted to have a sweet odor. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by the accumulation of which of the following?
content_preview: An 8-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of vomiting and poor feeding. The pregnancy was uncomplicated, and he was born at full term. He appears pale and lethargic. Physical examination shows diffusely increased muscle tone. His urine is noted to have a sweet odor. This patient's symptoms are most likely caused by the accumulation of which of the following?
hint: Poor feeding, vomiting, lethargy, and hypertonia are nonspecific symptoms; however, the presence of a sweet-smelling urine strongly raises the suspicion of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD).
learning_objective: Recognize maple syrup urine disease, and recall the amino acids that accumulate.

answers.explanation_why: Accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (valine, leucine, isoleucine) due to a deficiency of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase causes MSUD. If untreated, affected neonates develop severe CNS damage, which can lead to coma and death. MSUD can be diagnosed by the presence of alpha-ketoacids of branched chain amino acids in serum. Treatment involves avoidance of dietary branched-chain amino acids and thiamine supplementation.

Phytanic acid accumulation occurs in patients with Refsum disease. Patients with this condition typically develop scaly skin, ataxia, sensorineural hearing loss, and vision loss during adolescence but are asymptomatic during childhood. Refsum disease does not cause sweet-smelling urine.

Homogentisic acid accumulation occurs in patients with homogentisate oxidase deficiency (alkaptonuria). Patients with this condition can develop ochronosis as adults but are typically asymptomatic during childhood. Urine may become darker on prolonged exposure to air but alkaptonuria does not cause sweet-smelling urine.

Homocysteine accumulation occurs with hereditary deficiency of cystathionine synthase or methionine synthase. Neonates with either of these deficiencies are typically asymptomatic but older children can present with osteoporosis, marfanoid habitus, lens subluxation, cardiovascular disease (e.g., stroke, coronary artery disease), and/or failure to thrive. Homocystinuria does not cause sweet-smelling urine.

Phenylalanine accumulation occurs in patients with phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency (phenylketonuria). This condition causes a musty odor in the urine, not a sweet-smelling odor. Moreover, symptoms of phenylketonuria (e.g. seizures, delayed development, intellectual disability, eczema) do not manifest until 2–4 weeks after birth due to the presence of maternal phenylalanine hydroxylase in the baby's serum.

question_text: A healthy 33-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 15 weeks' gestation comes to the genetic counselor for a follow-up visit. Her uncle had recurrent pulmonary infections, chronic diarrhea, and infertility, and died at the age of 28 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. The results of a genetic analysis show a deletion of Phe508 on chromosome 7. This patient's fetus is at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
content_preview: A healthy 33-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 15 weeks' gestation comes to the genetic counselor for a follow-up visit. Her uncle had recurrent pulmonary infections, chronic diarrhea, and infertility, and died at the age of 28 years. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. The results of a genetic analysis show a deletion of Phe508 on chromosome 7. This patient's fetus is at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
hint: A ΔF508 mutation (deletion of phenylalanine at position 508) of the CFTR gene is the most common etiology of cystic fibrosis.
learning_objective: Recognize cystic fibrosis due to ΔF508 mutation, and recall its neonatal complications.

answers.explanation_why: Duodenal atresia is a congenital malformation that manifests with delayed meconium passage, bilious vomiting, and the classic double bubble sign on x-ray. Duodenal atresia is associated with Down syndrome, not cystic fibrosis.

Congenital megacolon (Hirschsprung disease) is caused by a failure of the neural crest cells to migrate, which leads to aganglionic colon segments and failure to pass meconium. Congenital megacolon is associated with Down syndrome, not cystic fibrosis.
Cardiac defects are associated with a number of syndromes, including fetal alcohol syndrome, trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and trisomy 21. However, cystic fibrosis is not associated with cardiac defects.

Meconium ileus is one of the first manifestations of cystic fibrosis seen in newborns, due to defective ATP-gated chloride channels. In response to impaired chloride secretion into the gastrointestinal (GI) lumen, sodium and water secretion in the GI tract is decreased, resulting in hyperviscous mucous in the lumen and increasing the risk of ileus. This pathophysiology is also responsible for the increased chloride concentration of the skin, which can be measured via the pilocarpine-induced sweat test.

Neural tube defects describe several conditions characterized by incomplete neural tube closure (e.g., spina bifida, meningomyelocele, anencephaly). The most common cause is folate deficiency during pregnancy. Neural tube defects are not associated with cystic fibrosis.

Risk factors for pyloric stenosis include positive family history, being male, smoking during pregnancy, macrolide exposure, premature birth, and bottle feeding. Pyloric stenosis is not caused by a point mutation and is not associated with cystic fibrosis.

question_text: A 6-day-old female infant is brought to the emergency department because of poor feeding and irritability for two days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation, and the pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F). She appears lethargic and makes occasional twitching movements in both upper extremities. The anterior fontanelle is soft and full. A lumbar puncture is performed and analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid shows increased protein and decreased glucose. Cerebrospinal fluid culture shows gram-positive, intracellular rods with tumbling motility. Infection of a healthy adult with the pathogen affecting this infant would most likely present with which of the following clinical conditions?
content_preview: A 6-day-old female infant is brought to the emergency department because of poor feeding and irritability for two days. She was born at 39 weeks' gestation, and the pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F). She appears lethargic and makes occasional twitching movements in both upper extremities. The anterior fontanelle is soft and full. A lumbar puncture is performed and analysis of the cerebrospinal fluid shows increased protein and decreased glucose. Cerebrospinal fluid culture shows gram-positive, intracellular rods with tumbling motility. Infection of a healthy adult with the pathogen affecting this infant would most likely present with which of the following clinical conditions?
hint: This baby has signs and symptoms of meningitis. Gram-positive intracellular rods with tumbling motility is suggestive of infection with Listeria monocytogenes.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal meningitis caused by Listeria monocytogenes, and recall its presentation in healthy adults.

answers.explanation_why: Escherichia coli is the most common pathogen implicated in cystitis. E. coli can cause neonatal meningitis, as seen in this patient. However, E. coli is a gram-negative rather than a gram-positive rod, and, therefore, is not the pathogen responsible for this patient's condition. Listeria monocytogenes is not typically known to cause cystitis.

Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most commonly implicated pathogen for pneumonia in healthy adults. Although it is a common pathogen responsible for meningitis in infants (1 month to 2 years), it is uncommon in neonates. Listeria monocytogenes is not a common cause of pneumonia in healthy adults.

Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are the most common bacteria responsible for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) in adolescents and adults. Although these bacteria can cause neonatal infections, these typically manifest with conjunctivitis and not with the meningitis seen in this patient. Listeria monocytogenes is not known to cause PID.

Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis are the most commonly implicated bacterial pathogens in meningitis in healthy adults. Although these are also the most common pathogens responsible for meningitis in infants (1 month to 2 years), they are uncommon in neonates. Listeria monocytogenes, the pathogen responsible for this patient's presentation, can cause meningitis in adults; however, it typically only affects older adults (> 60 years) or immunocompromised individuals. Another condition is more likely in a healthy adult with L. monocytogenes.

Listeria monocytogenes most commonly causes self-limited gastroenteritis in healthy adults. It classically is accompanied by a history of dairy product or deli meat consumption (it grows well at refrigeration temperatures). Although typically a self-limiting condition in healthy adults, Listeria infection is more concerning in infants, older adults, and those with compromised immune systems. These high-risk individuals should be treated with ampicillin.

question_text: A 3500-g (7-lb 11-oz) healthy female newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) in the first trimester showed a trisomy of chromosome 21 but the pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated. Physical examination of the newborn is normal. Chromosomal analysis at birth shows a 46, XX karyotype. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the prenatal chromosomal abnormality?
content_preview: A 3500-g (7-lb 11-oz) healthy female newborn is delivered at 38 weeks' gestation. Chorionic villus sampling (CVS) in the first trimester showed a trisomy of chromosome 21 but the pregnancy was otherwise uncomplicated. Physical examination of the newborn is normal. Chromosomal analysis at birth shows a 46, XX karyotype. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the prenatal chromosomal abnormality?
hint: This genetic phenomenon occurs in about 1–2% of all pregnancies in which chorionic villus sampling (CVS) is performed.
learning_objective: Recall the concept of confined placental mosaicism.

answers.explanation_why: Locus heterogeneity occurs when mutations in genes at different chromosomal loci cause the same phenotype. This means that two individuals with the same disease might have a different genotype; however, this would not cause a genetic discrepancy within an individual's tissue and does not explain the normal phenotype of the newborn.

Maternal uniparental disomy is a genetic anomaly in which the individual inherits two of the same chromosomes from one parent and none from the other. Uniparental disomy does not lead to polysomy and therefore would not explain the presence of trisomy 21 in the placental tissue.

Trisomy 21 is an example of phenotypic pleiotropy, in which one gene contributes to different phenotypic effects. Affected patients may display several developmental deformities, such as a palmar crease, upward slanting palpebral fissure, and cardiac defects. However, pleiotropy would not explain this patient's normal phenotype or the discrepancy between her placental and actual genotype.

Incomplete penetrance is the phenomenon by which not all individuals with a mutant genotype express the corresponding phenotype. However, trisomy 21 is typically not associated with incomplete penetrance. Furthermore, it would not explain the chromosomal discordance between the chorionic villus sample and the newborn tissue.

Maternal heteroplasmy refers to the presence of heterogeneous mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) in an individual. Because all mitochondria are inherited from the mother, mitochondrial diseases that develop in utero are a result of unequal distribution of normal and mutated mtDNA molecules during mitosis. Thus, genetic discrepancies in a patient can be observed depending on which cells are sampled. However, trisomy 21 is a polysomy that affects the nuclear genome, not the mitochondrial genome.

images.title: Heteroplasmy
images.description: Following de novo mutations in mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), cells have both mutated and normal mitochondria, which is known as heteroplasmy. When there is heteroplasmy in the parental cell (P), levels of heteroplasmy can increase, decrease, or stay the same in subsequent filial generations (F1, F2), resulting in variable disease expression. Severity often correlates with the proportion of mutated mtDNA. In some conditions, the disease phenotype is only expressed once the proportion of mutated mtDNA is above a certain threshold.

answers.explanation_why: Variable expressivity is the mechanism by which mutations result in varying degrees of phenotypic severity. Patients with trisomy 21 often have varying degrees of clinical severity despite having the same genetic anomaly. However, variable expressivity does not explain the genetic discordance between the newborn and placental tissue.

In CVS, a sample from the placenta is taken to test for chromosomal abnormalities, rather than direct fetal tissue. In rare cases, there is a discrepancy between the sampled placental genotype and that of the fetus (mosaicism of the placenta). In confined placental mosaicism, the CVS may show an abnormal genotype but the fetus has a normal genotype, as seen here.

question_text:
A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the physician because of worsening feeding difficulty since birth. Examination shows a grade 2/6 harsh holosystolic murmur, heard most clearly at the left lower sternal border, and a soft mid-diastolic rumble over the cardiac apex. Echocardiography shows shunting of blood through the ventricular septum during systole. The patient undergoes surgery for closure of the defect. Which of the following sets of changes are expected after successful repair of this cardiac defect?

Left atrial pressure
Left ventricular pressure
Right ventricular pressure

A
↓
↑
no change

B
↓
↑
↓

C
↑
↑
↑

D
↓
↓
↓

E
↑
↑
↓
content_preview: A 2-week-old newborn is brought to the physician because of worsening feeding difficulty since birth. Examination shows a grade 2/6 harsh holosystolic murmur, heard most clearly at the left lower sternal border, and a soft mid-diastolic rumble over the cardiac apex. Echocardiography shows shunting of blood through the ventricular septum during systole. The patient undergoes surgery for closure of the defect. Which of the following sets of changes are expected after successful repair of this cardiac defect? Left atrial pressure Left ventricular pressure Right ventricular pressure A ↓ ↑ no change B ↓ ↑ ↓ C ↑ ↑ ↑ D ↓ ↓ ↓ E ↑ ↑ ↓
hint: The newborn presented with symptoms of decreased cardiac output (poor feeding) and heart murmurs; he was found to have a ventricular septal defect (VSD), which allowed for abnormal shunting of blood from the left to the right ventricle. Successful repair of this defect will restore normal cardiac output.
learning_objective: Recall the cardiac pressure changes that would occur after successful repair of a ventricular septal defect.

answers.explanation_why: Mitral stenosis (MS) causes a left atrial outflow obstruction. The left atrium has to contract against the partially closed mitral valve, which results in an increased left atrial pressure. Once repaired, left atrial outflow increases, thereby decreasing the left atrial pressure. The left ventricular input increases, thereby increasing the left ventricular pressure. The right ventricular pressure remains unchanged. These hemodynamic changes would not, however, be expected after the closure of a VSD.

A VSD causes left-to-right shunting of blood because the left ventricular pressure is physiologically higher than the right ventricular pressure due to the thicker ventricular wall and higher force of contraction. Closure of a VSD would, therefore, increase the amount of blood in the left ventricle and decrease the amount of blood in the right ventricle during each cardiac cycle. This results in an increase in left ventricular pressure and a decrease in right ventricular pressure as well as right ventricular output, which translates to a decrease in the amount of blood flowing into the left atrium and therefore a decrease in left atrial pressure.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: An increase in the pressure of all the chambers of the heart would be expected following fluid resuscitation in patients with hypovolemic shock. These hemodynamic changes would not be expected after the closure of a VSD.

A decrease in the pressure in all the chambers of the heart would be expected following pericardiotomy for constrictive pericarditis or following aspiration of a hemopericardium. These hemodynamic changes would not be expected after the closure of a VSD.

Both atrial septal defect repair, which stops shunting of blood from the left atrium to the right atrium, and pulmonary stenosis repair, which removes the right ventricular outflow obstruction, would decrease right ventricular pressure and increase left atrial as well as left ventricular pressure by increasing the amount of blood in the left side of the heart. These hemodynamic changes would not, however, be expected after the closure of a VSD.

question_text: A 3000-g (6-lb 10-oz) male newborn delivered at 38 weeks' gestation develops respiratory distress shortly after birth. Physical examination shows low-set ears, retrognathia, a flattened nose, and club feet. Within a few hours, the newborn dies. Examination of the liver at autopsy shows periportal fibrosis and dilatation of the peripheral intrahepatic ducts. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following?
content_preview: A 3000-g (6-lb 10-oz) male newborn delivered at 38 weeks' gestation develops respiratory distress shortly after birth. Physical examination shows low-set ears, retrognathia, a flattened nose, and club feet. Within a few hours, the newborn dies. Examination of the liver at autopsy shows periportal fibrosis and dilatation of the peripheral intrahepatic ducts. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following?
hint: Compression of the fetus secondary to maternal oligohydramnios results in club feet and craniofacial abnormalities such as retrognathia and low-set ears (Potter sequence). Insufficient amniotic fluid also causes pulmonary hypoplasia, which results in respiratory distress after birth. The concurrent presence of periportal fibrosis is the key to the correct answer!
learning_objective: Recognize Potter sequence, and recall its association with ARPKD.

answers.explanation_why: Bilateral renal hypoplasia or agenesis can cause oligohydramnios leading to Potter sequence, as observed in this case. However, this patient's autopsy revealed periportal fibrosis, which is not consistent with renal hypoplasia. The combination of Potter sequence and hepatic involvement suggests a different renal pathology.

answers.content: Mutation on the short arm of chromosome 16
answers.explanation_why: A mutation of the polycystin-1 gene on chromosome 16 is the most common cause of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Patients with ADPKD typically present in adulthood and have chronic renal failure and hepatic cyst formation. The combination of Potter sequence and hepatic fibrosis in this neonate suggests a renal pathology caused by a defect on a different chromosome.

Posterior urethral valves are the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction in newborn males. Obstructive uropathy can cause oligohydramnios leading to Potter sequence, as observed in this patient. However, the presence of posterior urethral valves is not associated with congenital liver fibrosis.

Nondisjunction of chromosome 18 can cause trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome), which causes a variety of clinical features, including distinctive craniofacial abnormalities and rocker bottom feet. Other important features of Edwards syndrome that are absent in this patient include finger contractures (causing clenched fists) and congenital heart defects. This patient's renal disease is associated with a genetic defect on a different chromosome.

This neonate has autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), which is caused by a mutation in the fibrocystin (PKHD1) gene on the short arm of chromosome 6. This mutation leads to cystic dilation of the distal nephron and collecting ducts. ARPKD can cause in-utero renal failure, subsequently leading to maternal oligohydramnios and Potter sequence. ARPKD is also associated with progressive hepatic fibrosis, which can cause portal hypertension and liver failure.

question_text: A 22-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit at 10 weeks' gestation. She has no history of serious illness. She has been using cocaine for the past two years. Without cessation of cocaine use, which of the following complications is most likely to occur?
content_preview: A 22-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit at 10 weeks' gestation. She has no history of serious illness. She has been using cocaine for the past two years. Without cessation of cocaine use, which of the following complications is most likely to occur?
hint: Cocaine can cause vasoconstriction, which is the widely accepted mechanism for fetal and placental damage.
learning_objective: Recall the complications of cocaine use during pregnancy.

answers.explanation_why: Due to its vasoconstrictor effects on the placental vessels, cocaine in pregnant women can lead to premature delivery. Further consequences may include placental abruption, low birth weight, and IUGR.

One of the major causes of obstructed labor is fetal macrosomia, a condition associated with maternal diabetes mellitus. Cocaine use in pregnant women, however, is not associated with obstructed labor.

A variety of teratogens can cause congenital heart defects in unborn children. These include antiepileptic drugs (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine, or phenytoin), lithium, and maternal diabetes mellitus. Cocaine use in pregnant women, however, is not known to cause congenital heart defects.
answers.explanation_but: There have been discussions about cocaine's teratogenic effects, especially congenital heart defects, but abnormal anatomic outcomes that are solely due to cocaine abuse cannot be confirmed to date.

answers.explanation_why: A variety of teratogens can cause neural tube defects in unborn children. These include antiepileptic drugs (e.g., valproate, carbamazepine, or phenytoin), folate antagonists (e.g., methotrexate), and maternal diabetes. Cocaine use in pregnant women, however, is not known to cause neural tube defects.

Cocaine use in pregnant women typically does not cause polyhydramnios, but rather oligohydramnios. Other maternal conditions, such as maternal diabetes or infection (e.g., toxoplasmosis), may cause polyhydramnios.

question_text: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician for evaluation of poor feeding and recurrent episodes of facial grimacing. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He is at the 3^rd percentile for length and 5^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows yellow discoloration of skin, a broad nasal bridge, hepatomegaly, and decreased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum studies show increased concentrations of very long-chain fatty acids. Examination of the liver cells from this neonate is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 3-week-old male infant is brought to the physician for evaluation of poor feeding and recurrent episodes of facial grimacing. He was delivered at term after an uncomplicated pregnancy. He is at the 3rd percentile for length and 5th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows yellow discoloration of skin, a broad nasal bridge, hepatomegaly, and decreased muscle tone in the extremities. Serum studies show increased concentrations of very long-chain fatty acids. Examination of the liver cells from this neonate is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: A combination of hypotonia, abnormal facial grimacing suggestive of seizures, icterus, hepatomegaly, and elevated serum levels of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in a neonate indicates Zellweger syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize Zellweger syndrome, and recall its cellular pathology.

answers.explanation_why: Centrilobular necrosis is seen in ischemic liver damage, alcohol-associated hepatitis, and various toxic liver damage cases (e.g., acetaminophen overdose). Although these conditions can cause liver failure and jaundice, they are not associated with neonatal seizures, hypotonia, or facial dysmorphism and would not explain the serum elevation of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

Eosinophilic apoptotic bodies (Councilman bodies) can be seen in the liver in infectious diseases like viral hepatitis (e.g., hepatitis B, hepatitis C) or yellow fever. Although these diseases can cause liver failure and jaundice, they are not associated with neonatal seizures, hypotonia, or facial dysmorphism, and would not explain the accumulation of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

Zellweger syndrome is characterized by a defect in peroxisome formation, which prevents catabolism of VLCFAs, leading to their accumulation in cells and impairing multiple organ systems. Zellweger syndrome has a poor prognosis, with death within the first year of life and no available treatment options.

Accumulation of PAS-positive granules in hepatocytes can be seen in glycogen storage diseases, as PAS will stain polysaccharides. Although glycogen storage diseases can cause neonatal seizures, hepatomegaly, and myopathy, they are not associated with facial dysmorphism and would not explain the high serum concentration of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

Accumulation of cells with a foamy cytoplasm, i.e., lipid-laden macrophages, is seen in diseases like Niemann-Pick disease and Gaucher's disease (so-called Gaucher cells), or other causes of hepatic steatosis. Although these diseases can cause hepatomegaly and seizures, they are not generally associated with facial dysmorphism and would not explain the high serum concentrations of VLCFAs seen in this patient.

images.title: Foam cells
images.description: Microscopic image of the splenic red pulp (H&E stain)Macrophages with a lipid-laden cytoplasm (examples: green overlay). Those cells are often referred to as “foam cells” and are a typical finding in Niemann-Pick disease.

answers.explanation_why: Biliary atresia is seen in Alagille syndrome. Although Alagille syndrome can be associated with hepatomegaly, jaundice, and dysmorphic facial features, it would not cause hypotonia or the serum elevation of VLCFAs seen in this patient. Additionally, Alagille syndrome often presents with congenital heart defects (e.g., peripheral pulmonary stenosis) and ocular findings like posterior embryotoxon.

question_text: A 1-month-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding, a hoarse cry, and lethargy for 1 week. The boy was born in Mozambique, from where he and his parents emigrated 2 weeks ago. He is at the 95^th percentile for head circumference, 50^th percentile for length, and 70^th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, an enlarged tongue, and generalized hypotonia. The abdomen is distended and there is a reducible, soft protruding mass at the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 1-month-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding, a hoarse cry, and lethargy for 1 week. The boy was born in Mozambique, from where he and his parents emigrated 2 weeks ago. He is at the 95th percentile for head circumference, 50th percentile for length, and 70th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, an enlarged tongue, and generalized hypotonia. The abdomen is distended and there is a reducible, soft protruding mass at the umbilicus. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: If left untreated, this child is likely to develop intellectual disability.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital hypothyroidism due to thyroid dysgenesis.

answers.explanation_why: Biliary atresia may present with delayed neonatal jaundice that becomes apparent at around 2 weeks of life. While this patient presents with scleral icterus, biliary atresia would not account for this newborn's hoarse cry, umbilical hernia, macrocephaly, muscle hypotonia, or macroglossia.

This patient has features consistent with congenital hypothyroidism, such as poor feeding and lethargy, a hoarse cry, prolonged newborn jaundice, umbilical hernia, increased head circumference, muscle hypotonia, and macroglossia. The most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions is thyroid dysgenesis, i.e., thyroid hypoplasia, dysplasia, or aplasia. Early initiation of thyroxine supplementation is essential in this patient to prevent intellectual disability. Most children with congenital hypothyroidism do not display symptoms at the time of birth because the placenta supplies the fetus with maternal thyroid hormone. Therefore, neonatal screening is crucial even if children are asymptomatic.

Neonatal screening is mandatory in the US and includes measurement of TSH levels 24–48 hours after birth.

Acid maltase deficiency leads to Pompe disease (type 2 glycogen storage disease), which may present with macroglossia, poor feeding, and muscle hypotonia during the first few weeks to months of life. However, affected patients usually also have signs of cardiomyopathy (e.g., shortness of breath, tachypnea, tachycardia, jugular venous distention), which are absent in this patient. Also, Pompe disease would not account for this patient's jaundice, hoarse cry, umbilical hernia, or increased head circumference.

A deficiency of α-L-iduronidase causes Hurler syndrome. While patients with Hurler syndrome may also present with abdominal distention (due to hepatosplenomegaly) and umbilical hernia, they generally do not become symptomatic until 6 months to 1 year of age. Hurler syndrome can cause a broad range of clinical symptoms, including musculoskeletal abnormalities (joint contractures, spinal deformity), developmental delay, coarse facial features, and corneal clouding. However, muscle hypotonia, macroglossia, and a hoarse cry just 2 weeks after birth would not be expected.

While Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) can manifest with macroglossia, abdominal distention (due to organ enlargement), and umbilical hernia, other classic findings of BWS such as macrosomia, hemihyperplasia, and hypoglycemia are not present in this patient. Furthermore, BWS would not account for this patient's jaundice or hoarse cry.

Congenital toxoplasmosis can present with neonatal jaundice, enlarged head circumference (due to hydrocephalus), lethargy, and abdominal distention (due to hepatosplenomegaly), as seen in this patient. However, it does not account for this patient's macroglossia, umbilical hernia, and hoarse cry. Also, this patient does not have any other features of congenital toxoplasmosis such as chorioretinitis or seizures.

Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome) can also present with muscle hypotonia, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia. However, the absence of classic clinical features of Down syndrome such as brachycephaly, dysmorphic facial features (e.g., epicanthus, hypertelorism, flattened nose), Brushfield spots, a single transverse palmar crease, and sandal toes makes this diagnosis unlikely.

question_text: A male newborn is evaluated 24 hours after delivery for high-pitched crying, poor feeding, rhinorrhea, and low-grade fever. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation at 2514 g (5 lb 9 oz) to a 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, by an uncomplicated cesarean section. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother did not receive prenatal care. The infant's temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 170/min, and blood pressure is 71/39 mm Hg. Examination shows hyperreflexia, tremors, and an excessive startle response. These symptoms are most likely due to maternal use of which of the following?
content_preview: A male newborn is evaluated 24 hours after delivery for high-pitched crying, poor feeding, rhinorrhea, and low-grade fever. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation at 2514 g (5 lb 9 oz) to a 28-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, by an uncomplicated cesarean section. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother did not receive prenatal care. The infant's temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 170/min, and blood pressure is 71/39 mm Hg. Examination shows hyperreflexia, tremors, and an excessive startle response. These symptoms are most likely due to maternal use of which of the following?
hint: The irritability, poor feeding, evidence of sympathetic hyperactivity (diaphoresis, hyperthermia, tremors), and hyperreflexia in this neonate is consistent with neonatal abstinence syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal abstinence syndrome, and recall its associated maternal drug use.

answers.explanation_why: GABA_A receptor agonists (e.g., alcohol and phenobarbital) are teratogens. Neonates exposed to alcohol during pregnancy may develop fetal alcohol syndrome, which manifests with cardiac and facial malformations not seen in this patient. Similarly, exposure to phenobarbital during pregnancy increases the risk of developing a cleft palate. Neither drugs cause the high-pitched cry or autonomic instability seen in this patient.
answers.explanation_but: Benzodiazepines are also GABA_A receptor agonists that have an unclear teratogenicity during pregnancy.

answers.explanation_why: This infant presents with symptoms of neonatal abstinence syndrome, which suggests maternal use of opioids (mu receptor agonist) during pregnancy. In infants with mild opiate withdrawal symptoms, supportive care (e.g., swaddling, IV fluids, quiet room) is preferred. For infants with more severe symptoms, as seen in this infant, administration of oral morphine is recommended to treat the withdrawal.

Nicotine, a nicotinic acetylcholine receptor agonist, is associated with preterm birth and intrauterine growth restriction, which are not present in this patient. It also does not cause the high-pitched cry or autonomic instability seen in this patient.

Cocaine (a monoamine reuptake antagonist) exposure during pregnancy is associated with a high-pitched cry and irritability in neonates within 2–3 days of birth, as seen in this patient. However, it is associated with hyperactivity and milder autonomic instability, and it does not cause the fever and poor feeding seen in this patient.

Thyroperoxidase inhibitors (e.g. ,. propylthiouracil [PTU] and methimazole) treat hyperthyroidism. Methimazole crosses the placenta more readily than PTU and causes aplasia cutis congenita, while PTU has unclear teratogenicity. Neither cause irritability, poor feeding, high-pitched cry, or autonomic instability (diaphoresis, hyperthermia, tremors) in neonates.
answers.explanation_but: Propylthiouracil is used to treat maternal hyperthyroidism during the first trimester because it is less likely to cross the placenta, but the risk of maternal hepatotoxicity increases over time. Methimazole is used in place of PTU after 10–12 weeks' gestation when the fetus produces its own thyroid hormone and is no longer dependent on maternal thyroxine.

question_text: An exclusively breast-fed, 5-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a routine examination. He was born at term and delivery was uncomplicated. He received all standard treatment and testing prior to being discharged from the hospital 3 days ago. Examination shows no abnormalities. Without receiving additional supplementation at this time, this newborn is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
content_preview: An exclusively breast-fed, 5-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother for a routine examination. He was born at term and delivery was uncomplicated. He received all standard treatment and testing prior to being discharged from the hospital 3 days ago. Examination shows no abnormalities. Without receiving additional supplementation at this time, this newborn is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
hint: A deficiency of this micronutrient can lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism.
learning_objective: Recognize the nutritional needs of exclusively breastfed infants, and recall the risk of vitamin D deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: A deficiency of niacin, also known as pellagra, could result in scaly dermatitis, diarrhea, and eventually neurological symptoms (e.g., dementia). However, niacin does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. In the absence of comorbidities (e.g., malnutrition, Hartnup disease), pellagra is unlikely to develop in this patient.

A deficiency in vitamin K greatly increases the risk of developing an intracranial bleed in early infancy. All newborn infants receive an injection of intramuscular vitamin K at birth to prevent this deficiency. This patient has already received this intervention as part of standard hospital care, and no more supplementation is necessary. Although levels of vitamin K in breast milk are low, most infants do not require additional supplementation after the initial injection, unless comorbidities are present (e.g., chronic diarrhea or long-term antibiotic treatment).

Underlying iron deficiency can manifest as microcytic anemia. Premature infants have lower iron stores and increased demand, and thus require supplementation in addition to the iron found in breast milk. However, exclusively breastfed infants < 4 months of age who were not born prematurely should receive adequate iron from breast milk alone. Exclusively breastfed infants ≥ 4 months of age should receive iron supplementation.

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to peripheral neuropathy. However, most breastfed infants receive adequate vitamin B12 from their mother's breast milk. Vitamin B12 supplementation during infancy is typically only required when the patient's mother follows a strict vegan diet because vitamin B12 mostly comes from animal products (e.g., meat, fish, and dairy).

The vitamin D content of breast milk is not considered to be high enough to prevent complications from developing in infants. Therefore, vitamin D supplementation is recommended in all exclusively breastfed infants until the recommended daily vitamin D intake through diet is met. Dietary sources of vitamin D include ≥ 34 oz/day of infant formula, solid foods, and, once the infant is 12 months old, vitamin D-fortified whole milk. This supplementation protects against hypocalcemia and rickets, a disease of bone deformities in children due to a deficiency of vitamin D. Rickets is characterized by impaired calcification of the bones, delayed closure of the fontanelles, frontal bossing, prominence of costochondral junctions (“rachitic rosary”), and genu valgum or genu varum. Children with rickets present with varying degrees of pain, poor growth, motor delays, and an increased risk of infections.

images.title: Rickets secondary to vitamin D deficiency fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Scurvy, caused by a deficiency of vitamin C, leads to impaired collagen synthesis that would manifest with petechiae, hyperkeratosis, and coiled hairs. Vitamin C does not typically need to be supplemented in infants' diets as adequate amounts are found in both breast milk and in most formulas. Therefore, in the absence of severe malnutrition or malabsorption, this patient is unlikely to need additional vitamin C supplementation.

question_text: Six hours after delivery, a 3100-g (6-lb 13-oz) male newborn has an episode of bilious projectile vomiting. He was born at term to a 21-year-old woman. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. The mother smoked a pack of cigarettes daily during the pregnancy. Physical examination shows a distended upper abdomen. An x-ray of the abdomen shows 3 distinct, localized gas collections in the upper abdomen and a gasless distal abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Six hours after delivery, a 3100-g (6-lb 13-oz) male newborn has an episode of bilious projectile vomiting. He was born at term to a 21-year-old woman. The pregnancy was complicated by polyhydramnios. The mother smoked a pack of cigarettes daily during the pregnancy. Physical examination shows a distended upper abdomen. An x-ray of the abdomen shows 3 distinct, localized gas collections in the upper abdomen and a gasless distal abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The 3 localized gas collections (“triple bubble sign”) are in 3 separate portions of the GI tract proximal to an obstruction.
learning_objective: Recognize jejunal atresia.

answers.explanation_why: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) can manifest with abdominal distention and emesis. However, patients in the early stages of NEC also have diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and abdominal tenderness. Furthermore, this newborn lacks pneumatosis intestinalis on abdominal x-ray, which would confirm NEC. Lastly, NEC is most common in premature infants and usually occurs 2–4 weeks after birth, once oral feeding has been started. It would be rare for NEC to manifest within the first few hours of life.

images.title: Necrotizing enterocolitis
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view; supine) of a neonateMultiple distended bowel loops in the right hemiabdomen are accompanied by small lucencies indicating the presence of intramural gas (pneumatosis intestinalis).Pneumatosis intestinalis is a feature of necrotizing enterocolitis. It can appear as bubbly (green overlay), curvilinear (yellow overlay), or linear (red overlay) lucencies on an abdominal radiograph.

answers.explanation_why: Duodenal atresia can manifest with abdominal distention, bilious emesis, and a prenatal history of polyhydramnios. However, abdominal x-ray would show a double bubble sign rather than the triple bubble sign seen here. In about a third of cases, duodenal atresia is associated with chromosomal abnormalities, especially Down syndrome, of which there are no signs (i.e., dysmorphic features) in this patient. Finally, maternal use of a vasoconstrictive drug (tobacco) during pregnancy makes another diagnosis more likely.

images.title: Double bubble sign
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a newborn with duodenal atresiaA nasogastric tube terminates in the gastric antrum. Gaseous distention of the stomach and pyloric channel (green overlay) and dilatation of the duodenal bulb (red overlay) are seen. Bowel distal to the duodenal bulb does not contain gas.This appearance has been termed the “double-bubble sign.” This sign is seen with duodenal atresia and several other congenital and acquired causes of duodenal obstruction.

answers.explanation_why: Meconium ileus can manifest with abdominal distention and bilious emesis due to ileal obstruction from the impacted stool. This diagnosis should be suspected if meconium fails to pass within the first 48 hours of life, whereas this newborn is only 6 hours old. Abdominal x-ray would show dilated loops of the small bowel above the terminal ileum, and rectal enema would reveal a microcolon. This infant's abdominal x-ray shows an obstruction more proximal to the ileum.

images.title: Microcolon and bowel perforation in meconium ileus
images.description: Barium enema (AP view) of a neonate with meconium ileusMultiple dilated gas-filled loops of small bowel are visible and opaque barium contrast outlines a microcolon (sections of microcolon indicated by green outlines). The findings are consistent with meconium ileus.Contrast is also seen in multiple locations within the peritoneal space (examples indicated by red overlay) as a result of bowel perforation.Blue overlay: ECG electrodes

answers.explanation_why: Malrotation with volvulus can manifest with abdominal distention and bilious emesis due to intestinal obstruction from twisting of the bowel. Infants with midgut volvulus are usually acutely ill and present with hemodynamic instability and, in the case of perforation, signs of peritonitis (e.g., abdominal rigidity). Plain abdominal x-ray may be completely normal, reveal a double bubble sign (indicating duodenal obstruction), or demonstrate pneumoperitoneum (indicating perforation). This patient's history of polyhydramnios and triple bubble sign on x-ray suggest a different diagnosis.
answers.explanation_but: Because malrotation and midgut volvulus often disrupt the intestinal blood supply, they can predispose to this patient's condition.

answers.explanation_why: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) can manifest with abdominal distention and emesis due to obstruction at the pylorus and maternal cigarette smoking during pregnancy and male sex are risk factors for the development of IHPS. However, the emesis is non-bilious and projectile and will not present until the pylorus has had time to hypertrophy several weeks after birth. A palpable, olive-shaped mass is also usually present, and abdominal x-ray will show distention of the stomach only. This infant's bilious emesis, age, and triple bubble sign suggest another diagnosis.

A distended abdomen and bilious emesis suggest an intestinal obstruction distal to the pylorus. A triple bubble sign on abdominal x-ray confirms the diagnosis of jejunal atresia. This malformation occurs due to a vascular disruption of the mesenteric blood vessels in utero, resulting in necrosis and segmental reabsorption of the intestine. The residual small bowel distal to the atresia may wind around the stalk of the ileocolic artery in spirals, resembling an apple peel (apple peel atresia). Maternal use of vasoconstrictive drugs (e.g., cocaine, MDMA, or cigarettes) increases the risk for this malformation.

Intestinal atresia of any origin is suggested by a prenatal history of polyhydramnios, since the fetus cannot drink the amniotic fluid due to the intestinal obstruction.

images.title: Triple bubble sign in jejunal atresia
images.description: X-ray abdomen (A and B: supine) of two neonates with abdominal distension and bilious vomitingDilatation of the stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum (A) is characteristic of the triple bubble sign of jejunal atresia. Multiple dilated bowel loops (B) may alternatively be seen in jejunal atresia, and the number of loops may increase in conjunction with a more distal location of the atresia.1: gastric air-fluid level; 2: duodenal air-fluid level; 3: jejunal air-fluid level

answers.explanation_why: Hirschsprung disease can manifest with abdominal distention and bilious emesis secondary to obstruction from an aganglionic portion of the rectosigmoid colon. Failure to pass meconium for > 48 hours and a positive squirt sign would support this diagnosis. This patient is still within the expected time frame for meconium passage, however, and his gasless distal abdomen on x-ray suggests a bowel obstruction more proximal than the rectosigmoid colon. Dilated loops of the large bowel would be expected in Hirschsprung disease.

images.title: Hirschsprung disease
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newbornA massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.Yellow overlay: gastric bubble

question_text: Four days after delivery, a 1400-g (3-lb 1-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 30 seconds. Over the past 24 hours, he has become increasingly lethargic. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 4 and 5 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He appears ill. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 53/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 67/35 mm Hg. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
content_preview: Four days after delivery, a 1400-g (3-lb 1-oz) newborn has a tonic seizure that lasts for 30 seconds. Over the past 24 hours, he has become increasingly lethargic. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation. Antenatal period was complicated by chorioamnionitis. Apgar scores were 4 and 5 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. He appears ill. His pulse is 130/min, respirations are 53/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 67/35 mm Hg. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The pupils are equal and react sluggishly to light. Examination shows slow, conjugate back and forth movements of the eyes. Muscle tone is decreased in all extremities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
hint: The condition described here is a serious complication of preterm birth.
learning_objective: Recognize germinal matrix hemorrhage in preterm infants.

answers.explanation_why: Galactose-1-phosphate uridylyltransferase deficiency is the underlying cause of galactosemia, which, if left untreated, may present with lethargy, hypotonia, and seizures, as seen here. However, the absence of cataracts (may present within the first days of life), jaundice, and hepatomegaly, make this diagnosis less likely.
answers.explanation_but: Galactosemia can cause coagulopathy and increased risk of bleeding, which may predispose children to the condition of this patient.

answers.explanation_why: Apoptosis of lower motor neurons is the underlying mechanism of spinal muscular atrophy, which is a possible cause of muscular hypotonia in infants. The most severe type (Werdnig-Hoffmann disease) may manifest immediately after birth or up to 6 months of age. Proximal muscles, mostly of the lower extremities, are usually involved symmetrically. However, this patient's seizures, bulging anterior fontanelle, impaired pupillary response, and roving eye movements would not be consistent with this diagnosis.

Hydrocephalus due to congenital causes, such as the Arnold-Chiari malformation, Dandy-Walker malformation, and intrauterine infections, may present in neonates with lethargy, tense fontanelles, seizures, and changes in vital signs due to brain stem compression (e.g., irregular breathing). However, elevated intracranial pressure usually manifests with rapidly increasing circumference of the head in neonates, which is not seen in this infant. Furthermore, instead of the roving eye movements, a downward deviation of the eyes (sunset eye sign) would be expected in patients with hydrocephalus.

images.title: Manifestations of increased intracranial pressure in infants

answers.explanation_why: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency is the underlying cause of phenylketonuria. While most patients are asymptomatic at birth, half of patients with phenylketonuria (PKU) have seizures with cerebral foci, a lag of psychomotor development and a musty body odor by 4–6 months of age. Additional features include light, pale hair and blue eyes (due to decreased melanin production). Since most patients are asymptomatic until severe and often irreversible complications have occurred, direct measurement of phenylalanine levels is an important part of newborn screening for metabolic disorders. The screening test is performed on the second day after birth using blood obtained from a heel prick.

Germinal matrix hemorrhage is the underlying cause of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) in preterm infants. IVH is a common complication in preterm infants that usually occurs within the first five days after birth. It is typically seen in neonates weighing < 1500 g and born before 32 weeks' gestation due to the fragility of the germinal matrix. Additional risk factors include peripartal chorioamnionitis and hypoxia (as suggested by this patient's low Apgar scores). Most infants with IVH are asymptomatic, but saltatory (over several days) or, more rarely, catastrophic (over minutes to hours) courses are also possible. Symptoms include lethargy, hypotonia, irregular respirations, seizures, bulging anterior fontanelle, cranial nerve abnormalities (e.g., pupil reacting sluggishly to light), and changes in eye movement (e.g., roving eye movements), all of which this patient has.

Cranial ultrasonography is the preferred method to diagnose IVH in the newborn. Since most patients are asymptomatic, screening ultrasounds are routinely performed in infants with a birth weight < 1500 g and delivery before 30 weeks' gestation.

images.title: Neonatal intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH)
images.description:
Ultrasound head (top row: coronal plane; bottom row: parasagittal plane) of a newbornThe first column shows bleeding confined to the subependymal germinal matrix (red overlay), which is consistent with grade 1 IVH.
The second column shows blood occupying less than 50% of the left lateral ventricle (red overlay), with no enlargement of the lateral ventricles (yellow overlay) or the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay). In addition, the choroid plexus is clearly demarcated (blue overlay). Together, these findings are consistent with grade 2 IVH.
The third column shows blood occupying more than 50% of the lateral ventricles (red overlay) with enlargement of the cavum septi pellucidi (green overlay) and both lateral ventricles (yellow overlay). This appearance is consistent with grade 3 IVH.These features suggest impaired progressive posthemorrhagic ventricular dilatation (PHVD) due to associated impairment of CSF circulation, which is a potential complication of high-grade IVH.

question_text:
A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother because of yellowish discoloration of the skin for the past 2 days. The discoloration first appeared on his face and then spread to his trunk. He was born at 38 weeks’ gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery and weighed 3500 g (7.7 lb); he currently weighs 3600 g (7.9 lb). He is exclusively breastfed every 2–3 hours. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice of the face, chest, and abdomen. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
17.6 g/dL

Reticulocytes
0.5%

Maternal blood group
A, Rh-negative

Fetal blood group
O, Rh-positive

Serum

 Bilirubin, total

7 mg/dL

Direct
0.6 mg/dL

Free T_4

1.1 ng/dL

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother because of yellowish discoloration of the skin for the past 2 days. The discoloration first appeared on his face and then spread to his trunk. He was born at 38 weeks’ gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery and weighed 3500 g (7.7 lb); he currently weighs 3600 g (7.9 lb). He is exclusively breastfed every 2–3 hours. Examination shows scleral icterus and jaundice of the face, chest, and abdomen. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 17.6 g/dL Reticulocytes 0.5% Maternal blood group A, Rh-negative Fetal blood group O, Rh-positive Serum Bilirubin, total 7 mg/dL Direct 0.6 mg/dL Free T4 1.1 ng/dL Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This newborn's condition is most likely due to decreased activity of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase.
learning_objective: Recognize physiological neonatal jaundice.

answers.explanation_why: Congenital hypothyroidism is associated with decreased bilirubin clearance, which can lead to indirect hyperbilirubinemia and neonatal jaundice. However, further typical manifestations of congenital hypothyroidism include umbilical hernia, large fontanelles, hypotonia, dry skin, and hypothermia. In addition, this patient's normal free T_4 levels exclude this diagnosis.

Rhesus incompatibility leading to immune-mediated hemolysis (also known as hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn; HDFN) is an uncommon cause of neonatal jaundice in contemporary practice, largely because of the widespread use of anti-D immunoglobulin. This condition most often causes jaundice and severe indirect hyperbilirubinemia that appear within the first 24 hours of life. Although this newborn's incompatibility with his mother's Rhesus type puts him at risk for HDFN, his normal hemoglobin and low reticulocyte count make hemolysis unlikely.

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is caused by defects in the biliary transport protein MRP2. Although patients with this condition can develop hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice, the onset of symptoms usually occurs during adolescence. In addition, laboratory studies in patients with Dubin-Johnson syndrome show direct hyperbilirubinemia caused by defective excretion of conjugated bilirubin, not the indirect hyperbilirubinemia seen in this newborn.

Physiological neonatal jaundice is a common condition that manifests between the second and the eighth day of life with jaundice and mild indirect hyperbilirubinemia in an otherwise healthy newborn. This condition is caused by several components of bilirubin metabolism in newborns, including immaturity of the pathways for hepatic conjugation and elimination (due to decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase), increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin (due to low bacteria in the gastrointestinal tract and certain breast milk components), and the short life span of erythrocytes in newborns. Treatment of neonatal jaundice by phototherapy is indicated if bilirubin levels increase above a defined threshold.

Exclusively breastfed newborns are more likely to develop physiological neonatal jaundice.

Breastfeeding jaundice is caused by insufficient breast milk intake and manifests with indirect hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice in the first week of life. However, newborns with breastfeeding jaundice usually also show signs of dehydration (e.g., few wet diapers), irritability, and weight loss. This newborn has already surpassed his birth weight and the mother reports breastfeeding him frequently without difficulty, making insufficient breastfeeding an unlikely cause of his jaundice.

Biliary atresia leads to neonatal jaundice by blocking the excretion of bile into the intestines and causing direct bilirubin to be returned to circulation. This condition manifests with direct hyperbilirubinemia rather than the indirect hyperbilirubinemia seen in this newborn. In addition, biliary atresia causes acholic stools (because bilirubin does not reach the intestine to be converted to urobilin and stercobilin) and dark urine (due to excretion of bilirubin via the urine), neither of which are seen here.

answers.content: ABO hemolytic disease of the newborn
answers.explanation_why: ABO hemolytic disease of the newborn is caused by ABO incompatibility, which leads to immune-mediated hemolysis. This disease typically results in mild indirect hyperbilirubinemia and neonatal jaundice. ABO hemolytic disease of the newborn usually becomes evident, however, within the first 24 hours of life and almost exclusively occurs in newborns with blood type A or B whose mother's blood type is O. Since this newborn's blood type is O, his erythrocytes do not express AB antigens that could be bound by maternal antibodies. In addition, his normal hemoglobin and low reticulocyte count make hemolysis unlikely.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician after his adoptive mother observed jerking movements of his arms and legs earlier that morning. He was adopted from an orphanage in Albania at 4 months of age. He has a history of intellectual disability. Examination shows pale skin and light blue eyes. There is a dry, eczematous, scaly rash on the extensor surfaces of the extremities. This patient is most likely deficient in which of the following enzymes?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician after his adoptive mother observed jerking movements of his arms and legs earlier that morning. He was adopted from an orphanage in Albania at 4 months of age. He has a history of intellectual disability. Examination shows pale skin and light blue eyes. There is a dry, eczematous, scaly rash on the extensor surfaces of the extremities. This patient is most likely deficient in which of the following enzymes?
hint: This boy has an autosomal recessive condition that, in addition to the symptoms above, also causes a characteristic mousy or musty odor of the body and urine.
learning_objective: Recognize phenylketonuria, and recall the deficient enzyme.

answers.explanation_why: Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase results in failure to convert phenylalanine to tyrosine and is the underlying cause of phenylketonuria (PKU). Symptoms usually develop after the neonatal period and include developmental delay and seizures (due to phenylalanine accumulation in the CNS), hypopigmentation (due to a lack of melanin production from low levels of tyrosine), and eczema, all of which are present in this case. In addition, PKU manifests with a characteristic mousy or musty odor due to excretion of phenylalanine metabolites in the urine and sweat. PKU is typically detected by newborn screening for metabolic disorders.

Branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase deficiency results in the accumulation of branched-chain amino acids (i.e., valine, leucine, isoleucine) and causes maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). This condition manifests in the early neonatal period with vomiting, lethargy, dystonia, hypoglycemia (which can lead to seizures), and a characteristic maple syrup odor to the urine which eventually lead to severe central nervous system defects and intellectual disability.

Cystathionine synthase deficiency leads to homocystinuria, which can cause intellectual disability and seizures. However, this condition also causes ectopia lentis, marfanoid habitus, and increased risk of thrombosis.

Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency can cause intellectual disability and seizures. However, this condition typically manifests shortly after birth, not in early childhood. In addition, OTC deficiency causes symptoms of hyperammonemia (e.g., asterixis, slurred speech, nausea, vomiting, irritability).

Tyrosinase deficiency leads to oculocutaneous albinism due to defective melanin production and causes pale skin and light-colored eyes. However, this condition also typically manifests with visual abnormalities.

Homogentisate oxidase deficiency causes alkaptonuria. This condition results in the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which leads to ochronosis, valvular calcification, and nephrolithiasis. The urine of patients with alkaptonuria turns dark brown/black when left standing or alkalinized. Unlike this patient, affected individuals are typically asymptomatic in childhood.

question_text: A 4-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of vomiting, irritability, and poor feeding. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Physical examination shows increased muscle tone in all extremities. He appears lethargic. His diapers emit a caramel-like odor. Urine studies are positive for ketone bodies. Supplementation of which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 4-day-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of vomiting, irritability, and poor feeding. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. Physical examination shows increased muscle tone in all extremities. He appears lethargic. His diapers emit a caramel-like odor. Urine studies are positive for ketone bodies. Supplementation of which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's condition?
hint: This boy has maple syrup urine disease, which typically manifests in the early neonatal period with vomiting, irritability, poor feeding, dystonia, lethargy, urine that has a sweet-smelling odor, and ketonuria.
learning_objective: Recognize maple syrup urine disease, and recall the treatment for thiamine-responsive MSUD.

answers.explanation_why: Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is caused by decreased activity of branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKDH). Supplementation of thiamine (vitamin B_1), which is a cofactor for several dehydrogenases, can increase the activity of BCKDH in some patients with MSUD (thiamine-responsive MSUD). In addition to thiamine supplementation, patients should avoid intake of branched-chain amino acids (i.e., isoleucine, leucine, and valine).

Cysteine supplementation is indicated for patients with homocystinuria due to cystathionine synthase deficiency or decreased affinity of cystathionine synthase for pyridoxal phosphate. Patients with homocystinuria are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period but can develop osteoporosis, marfanoid habitus, lens subluxation, cardiovascular disease, and/or intellectual disability as they grow older. Urinalysis of patients with homocystinuria shows increased homocysteine levels, not ketone bodies. Cysteine supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

Increased intake of ketogenic amino acids (e.g., leucine, lysine) is indicated for patients with pyruvate dehydrogenase complex deficiency (PDCD), which can manifest in the neonatal period with vomiting, irritability, dystonia, and lethargy. However, this condition does not cause a caramel-like odor to the urine or ketonuria. In addition, PDCD results in decreased acetyl-CoA production and thus decreased ketone body synthesis. This patient with maple syrup urine disease should avoid intake of leucine, which is a branched-chain amino acid.

Methionine supplementation is indicated for patients with homocystinuria due to methionine synthase deficiency. Patients with homocystinuria are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period but can develop osteoporosis, marfanoid habitus, lens subluxation, cardiovascular disease, and/or intellectual disability as they grow older. Urinalysis of patients with homocystinuria shows increased homocysteine levels, not ketone bodies. Methionine supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

Tyrosine supplementation is indicated for patients with phenylketonuria (PKU), which can manifest with poor feeding, lethargy, spasticity due to CNS damage, and ketonuria. However, patients with PKU are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period. In addition, the urine of patients with PKU typically has a musty odor, not a caramel-like odor. Tyrosine supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

images.title: Classic phenylketonuria vs. tetrahydrobiopterin deficiency (malignant PKU)

answers.explanation_why: Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH_4) supplementation is indicated for patients with phenylketonuria (PKU), which can manifest with poor feeding, lethargy, spasticity due to CNS damage, and ketonuria. However, patients with PKU are typically asymptomatic in the neonatal period. In addition, the urine of patients with PKU typically has a musty odor, not a caramel-like odor. BH_4 supplementation is not used to treat maple syrup urine disease.

question_text: A 3629-g (8-lb) newborn is examined shortly after spontaneous vaginal delivery. She was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother is concerned because she is not moving her left arm as much as her right arm. Physical examination shows her left arm to be adducted and internally rotated, with the forearm extended and pronated, and the wrist flexed. The Moro reflex is present on the right side but absent on the left side. Which of the following brachial plexus structures is most likely injured in this infant?
content_preview: A 3629-g (8-lb) newborn is examined shortly after spontaneous vaginal delivery. She was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation and pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother is concerned because she is not moving her left arm as much as her right arm. Physical examination shows her left arm to be adducted and internally rotated, with the forearm extended and pronated, and the wrist flexed. The Moro reflex is present on the right side but absent on the left side. Which of the following brachial plexus structures is most likely injured in this infant?
hint: This infant's left arm is in a “waiter's tip” position, which suggests impaired shoulder abduction and lateral rotation, as well as impaired elbow flexion and forearm supination. This injury is common in neonates who require lateral neck traction during vaginal delivery and is associated with shoulder dystocia.
learning_objective: Recognize Erb palsy presentation, and recall the affected brachial plexus structure.

answers.explanation_why: Erb palsy is due to injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, which contributes to the motor and sensory function of the suprascapular nerve, musculocutaneous nerve, and axillary nerve. Erb palsy most commonly occurs secondary to shoulder dystocia or other birth trauma but can arise in adults as a result of neck and/or upper arm trauma.

images.title: Brachial plexus injuries: Erb palsy and Klumpke palsy

answers.explanation_why: Injury to the long thoracic nerve, which receives nerve fibers from the C5–C7 nerve roots, classically manifests with impaired abduction of the arm above 90° and winging of the scapula (due to innervation of the serratus anterior muscle). An isolated long thoracic nerve injury due to birth trauma would be very unusual. This patient's examination findings are consistent with injury to a different structure.

Injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus results in Klumpke palsy. Klumpke palsy commonly occurs secondary to birth trauma. It typically manifests as paralysis of the intrinsic hand muscles and forearm flexors, resulting in the characteristic “claw hand” and absent grasp reflex. Horner syndrome may also be present. This patient's “waiter's tip” position is not consistent with a lower trunk injury.
Injury to the axillary nerve would result in the inability to externally rotate and abduct the arm above 15°. An isolated axillary nerve injury would not explain this patient's other findings.

images.title: Clinical features of axillary nerve injury

answers.explanation_why: Injury to the posterior cord classically results in wrist drop (loss of radial nerve innervation of forearm extensors) and inability to externally rotate or abduct the arm (loss of axillary nerve innervation of deltoid muscle). Isolated damage to the posterior cord during birth is extremely rare and would not be consistent with the examination findings in this patient.

images.title: Radial nerve neuropathy
images.description:
Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP jointsSensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2^nd and 3^rd fingers. The 1^st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumbProximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function
