question_text: A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of irritability and poor feeding that began 2 days ago. He was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation and his birth weight was 3280 g (7 lb 4 oz). His 8-year-old sister and his father are healthy. During both pregnancies, his mother had severe polyuria. Today, he weighs 2900 g (6 lb 6 oz). Physical examination shows dry skin and mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, and a sunken anterior fontanelle. During the examination, he cries without tears. Laboratory studies show a serum osmolality of 305 mOsmol/kg H_2O and a urine osmolality of 45 mOsmol/kg H_2O. After the administration of a vasopressin analog, urine osmolality remains decreased. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this newborn's condition?
content_preview: A 5-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his parents for evaluation of irritability and poor feeding that began 2 days ago. He was delivered at 40 weeks' gestation and his birth weight was 3280 g (7 lb 4 oz). His 8-year-old sister and his father are healthy. During both pregnancies, his mother had severe polyuria. Today, he weighs 2900 g (6 lb 6 oz). Physical examination shows dry skin and mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, and a sunken anterior fontanelle. During the examination, he cries without tears. Laboratory studies show a serum osmolality of 305 mOsmol/kg H2O and a urine osmolality of 45 mOsmol/kg H2O. After the administration of a vasopressin analog, urine osmolality remains decreased. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this newborn's condition?
hint: Features of severe dehydration (e.g., weight loss > 9%, irritability, poor feeding, dry skin and mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, sunken anterior fontanelle, increased serum osmolality) and very low urine osmolality that does not correct with the administration of a vasopressin analog indicate nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate treatment for nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

answers.explanation_why: A high-protein diet is contraindicated in patients with DI because it increases renal urea excretion, which causes solute diuresis and worsens polyuria. Rather, protein restriction (< 1 g/day) is often advised for patients with DI.

Excessive sodium intake (e.g., a high-sodium diet) is contraindicated in patients with DI because it causes natriuresis and worsens polyuria (i.e., solute diuresis). Rather, sodium restriction (≤ 100 mEq/day) is often advised for patients with DI.

Demeclocycline acts as a vasopressin (ADH) antagonist that induces nephrogenic DI, worsens diuresis, and is, therefore, contraindicated in this patient with DI. Instead, demeclocycline can be used to treat syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion, a disorder that, contrary to this patient's presentation, manifests with decreased serum osmolality (due to free water retention) and increased urine osmolality.

Desmopressin, a vasopressin (ADH) analog, is used to treat central DI, which can manifest with weight loss, features of dehydration, and decreased urine osmolality. However, in central DI, urine osmolality would increase following the administration of a vasopressin analog. Instead, this patient has nephrogenic DI (renal resistance to vasopressin), as evidenced by the failed desmopressin trial (i.e., failure of urine osmolality to increase following the administration of desmopressin). Desmopressin has, therefore, already been proven ineffective.

Indomethacin is used to treat nephrogenic DI because of its ability to inhibit renal prostaglandin synthesis, which promotes the action of ADH on the collecting ducts, resulting in decreased diuresis. This male newborn has hereditary nephrogenic DI, most commonly caused by an X-linked mutation in the vasopressin V_2 receptor gene (AVPR2), which results in the failure of principal cells to respond to vasopressin (ADH). Females with a heterozygous mutation are typically asymptomatic because of the presence of a functional gene and lyonization of the mutated gene. However, they may develop polyuria during pregnancy, as seen in this neonate's mother, because of increased clearance of vasopressin by placental vasopressinase. In contrast, males with the mutation present with severe symptoms soon after birth.

Other therapeutic measures to treat nephrogenic DI are adequate hydration, dietary salt and protein restriction (to prevent solute diuresis), and hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) therapy. Although HCTZ is a diuretic, in patients with nephrogenic DI it paradoxically decreases urine volume by an incompletely understood mechanism.

question_text: A 26-year-old primigravid woman at 22 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of vaginal bleeding and suprapubic pain for the last 2 hours. She has no history of medical illness. She takes folic acid and a multivitamin supplement. The patient works as a physician in a local clinic. She has no history of recent travel. Her husband works as a flight attendant for an international airline and frequently travels to South America and Southeast Asia. Ultrasonography shows absent fetal cardiac activity and detachment of the placenta from the uterus. Examination of the stillborn fetus shows microcephaly. A reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction test of placental tissue confirms infection with a flavivirus. Which of the following measures during pregnancy is most likely to have prevented this fetus's condition?

Her husband works as a flight attendant for an international airline and frequently travels to South America and Southeast Asia. Ultrasonography shows absent fetal cardiac activity and detachment of the placenta from the uterus. Examination of the stillborn fetus shows microcephaly. A reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction test of placental tissue confirms infection with a flavivirus. Which of the following measures during pregnancy is most likely to have prevented this fetus's condition?
hint: The family of flaviviruses includes arboviruses such as yellow fever virus, Dengue virus, St. Louis encephalitis virus, West Nile virus, and Zika virus.
learning_objective: Recognize Zika virus infection and its transmission, and choose the appropriate preventive measure during pregnancy.

answers.content: Avoiding consumption of unpasteurized dairy products
answers.explanation_why: Avoiding the consumption of unpasteurized dairy products reduces the risk of contracting Listeria monocytogenes, which can be transmitted to the fetus during pregnancy and increase the risk of stillbirth. However, L. monocytogenes infection in the fetus would typically cause abscess and granulomas of multiple organs including the skin (granulomatosis infantiseptica), which has not been reported here. Moreover, L. monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus, not a virus. Infection with the virus that caused this fetus's condition could not have been prevented by avoiding unpasteurized dairy products.

Zika virus is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito in endemic regions (e.g., South America, Southeast Asia). Unlike other arboviruses that are only transmitted by an arthropod vector, the Zika virus can also be sexually transmitted. The patient's husband most likely acquired the infection during his travel to an endemic region and subsequently transmitted it to the patient via sexual intercourse. Most patients with Zika virus infection remain asymptomatic. However, in pregnant women, Zika virus can be transmitted transplacentally to the fetus and cause microcephaly and/or stillbirth, as seen here. Individuals who have traveled to endemic regions should use barrier contraception or abstain from sex for at least 2 months for women and 3 months for men (the virus persists in semen for a longer period of time). In the case of pregnancy, both partners should use contraception or abstain from sex for the entire pregnancy.

Combined antiretroviral treatment is indicated in pregnant women with HIV infection and a high viral load (≥ 50 copies/mL) in order to prevent the risk of vertical transmission from mother to fetus. HIV-1 infection has also been reported to cause stillbirth and microcephaly. However, HIV is a retrovirus, not a flavivirus. Infection with the flavivirus that caused this fetus's condition could not have been prevented with antiretroviral therapy.

Avoiding the consumption of undercooked meat reduces the risk of contracting toxoplasmosis, which can be transmitted to the fetus during pregnancy and increases the risk of spontaneous abortion and microcephaly, which is seen here. However, toxoplasmosis is caused by the protozoa Toxoplasma gondii, not by a virus. Infection with the virus that caused this fetus's condition could not have been prevented by avoiding undercooked meat.

There is currently no vaccination against the flavivirus that caused this fetus's condition. Yellow fever virus, which is a mosquito-borne flavivirus endemic to South America, can be prevented by vaccination but yellow fever manifests with hemorrhagic fever, and vertical transmission to the fetus is rare. Moreover, yellow fever can only be contracted by traveling to the endemic region; the patient's husband, not the patient, traveled to an endemic region. Congenital rubella, a TORCH infection that can cause stillbirth and microcephaly, can be prevented with MMR vaccination but the rubella virus is a togavirus, not a flavivirus. Furthermore, live attenuated vaccines such as yellow fever vaccine and MMR vaccine cannot be administered during pregnancy.

question_text: A 22-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding, lethargy, and an abdominal protrusion. The child was delivered at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother has not had routine prenatal care. The patient is at the 25^th percentile for height, 50^th percentile for weight, and 95^th percentile for head circumference. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, pale facies, and an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is distended and there is a protruding mass at the abdominal midline. The skin covering the protrusion appears normal. When the newborn cries during the examination, the mass enlarges but is easily reducible. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the abdominal protrusion?
content_preview: A 22-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because of poor feeding, lethargy, and an abdominal protrusion. The child was delivered at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother has not had routine prenatal care. The patient is at the 25th percentile for height, 50th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, pale facies, and an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is distended and there is a protruding mass at the abdominal midline. The skin covering the protrusion appears normal. When the newborn cries during the examination, the mass enlarges but is easily reducible. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the abdominal protrusion?
hint: This patient has features consistent with congenital hypothyroidism (poor feeding, lethargy, prolonged newborn jaundice, pale facies, increased head circumference, abdominal distention, and macroglossia). His midline abdominal protrusion is a congenital umbilical hernia, a common feature of congenital hypothyroidism.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital hypothyroidism, and recall the cause of congenital umbilical hernia.

answers.content: Failed convergence of the lateral embryologic folds
answers.explanation_why: Failed convergence of the lateral embryologic folds leads to abdominal wall defects such as gastroschisis or omphalocele, which can manifest as a protruding abdominal mass near or in the midline, as seen here. However, in gastroschisis, the intestines herniate uncovered by skin or peritoneum and in omphalocele, the intestines herniate through the umbilical ring covered only by peritoneum. This patient's skin-covered abdominal protrusion has a different cause.

images.title: Congenital malformations of the anterior abdominal wall
images.description: Omphalocele: herniation of intraabdominal contents through an anterior abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord caused by the failure of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity after its physiological herniation through the umbilical ring. Accordingly, the hernial sac is formed by the amniotic membrane and peritoneum, and the umbilical cord lies at the apex of the hernia.Gastroschisis: a developmental defect of the anterior abdominal wall in the paraumbilical region through which intraabdominal contents prolapse. As it is the anterior abdominal wall that fails to develop correctly, there is no outer peritoneal or membranous covering.Congenital umbilical hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through a patent umbilical orifice, which typically closes by 2 years of age. The sac of a paraumbilical hernia is the peritoneum.Diastasis recti: an abnormally wide separation of the right and left rectus abdominis muscles. The abdominal fascia are intact. There is therefore no herniation, but a midline bulge is visible on straining (e.g., when trying to sit up).

answers.content: Failed obliteration of the vitelline duct
answers.explanation_why: Complete failure of the vitelline duct to obliterate during the 7^th week of development causes a vitelline fistula; partial failure results in Meckel diverticulum. A vitelline fistula causes meconium discharge through the umbilicus. A Meckel diverticulum is asymptomatic in most cases and sometimes manifests with diverticulitis or painless lower gastrointestinal bleeding. Neither of these conditions would manifest with an abdominal protrusion.

images.title: Meckel diverticulum
images.description: The Meckel diverticulum is a remnant of the omphalomesenteric duct. The omphalomesenteric duct connects the yolk sac to the alimentary tract in the embryo (left image). The duct is normally obliterated by the 6^th week of intrauterine life. However, incomplete obliteration leads to the development of a diverticulum located approx. 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal valve (right image). The Meckel diverticulum is often connected to the navel via a fibrous cord, which is the obliterated part of the omphalomesenteric duct (middle image).

answers.content: Congenital weakness of the linea alba
answers.explanation_why: Congenital weakness of the linea alba is the cause of an epigastric hernia, which occurs in the abdominal midline (between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus) and can manifest with an abdominal protrusion that enlarges with an increase in abdominal pressure (e.g., during crying), as seen here. However, epigastric hernias typically manifest during adulthood, not during the neonatal period. The abdominal protrusion in this patient has a different cause.

images.title: Epigastric hernia
images.description: Herniation of intraabdominal contents through the linea alba, between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus.

answers.content: Persistence of a patent processus vaginalis
answers.explanation_why: The persistence of a patent processus vaginalis is the cause of an indirect inguinal hernia, which manifests as a mass that enlarges with increases in abdominal pressure (e.g., during crying), as seen here. However, an indirect inguinal hernia would manifest in the groin, not the abdominal midline.

images.title: Direct and indirect inguinal hernias
images.description: Normally, the only contents of the inguinal canal are the spermatic cord (or round ligament in females) and the ilioinguinal nerve.Direct inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, medial to the inferior epigastric vessels. The hernial sac lies posteromedial to and outside the spermatic cordIndirect inguinal hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through the deep inguinal ring into the inguinal canal, and, in the case of large inguinal hernia, also through the superficial inguinal ring. The hernial sac lies within the spermatic cord and is therefore covered by the same tissue layers as the spermatic cord.

answers.content: Failed spontaneous closure of the umbilical ring
answers.explanation_why: Failure of the umbilical ring to close during fetal development causes congenital umbilical hernia. The midgut develops outside the abdominal cavity until the second trimester, when it physiologically herniates back into the abdomen. If the umbilical ring fails to close or the fascia in this region is underdeveloped, abdominal content may bulge through the umbilicus. Umbilical hernias are more common in children with chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., Down syndrome, Edwards syndrome) or congenital hypothyroidism, as seen here. Most congenital umbilical hernias resolve spontaneously by 5 years of age.

images.title: Congenital umbilical hernia
images.description: Anterior abdominal wall of a newbornThere is a mass ∼2 cm in diameter protruding through the umbilical orifice.This is the typical appearance of a congenital umbilical hernia, which characteristically increases in size on crying or coughing.

question_text: A 14-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a rash on his face for the past 5 days. His mother says that the rash became more prominent after sun exposure. The mother did not receive prenatal care and the newborn was delivered at home. She has had episodes of arthralgia and a rash on her face and neck that often worsened during summer, but she has never been to a physician. The newborn is at the 50^th percentile for length and 25^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 79/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mm Hg. Examination shows erythematous, annular lesions with raised margins in the periorbital area and the scalp. An ECG shows a P-wave rate of 130/min and an R-wave rate of 75/min with no apparent relation between the two. Which of the following laboratory studies for the newborn is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 14-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a rash on his face for the past 5 days. His mother says that the rash became more prominent after sun exposure. The mother did not receive prenatal care and the newborn was delivered at home. She has had episodes of arthralgia and a rash on her face and neck that often worsened during summer, but she has never been to a physician. The newborn is at the 50th percentile for length and 25th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 79/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 82/51 mm Hg. Examination shows erythematous, annular lesions with raised margins in the periorbital area and the scalp. An ECG shows a P-wave rate of 130/min and an R-wave rate of 75/min with no apparent relation between the two. Which of the following laboratory studies for the newborn is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: This newborn's mother reports episodes of arthralgia and a photosensitive rash, both of which indicate systemic lupus erythematosus. The newborn's third-degree atrioventricular block along with a characteristic periorbital rash (erythematous, annular lesions with raised margins) should raise concern for neonatal lupus syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal lupus syndrome, and choose the most appropriate laboratory study.

answers.explanation_why: The finding of anti-Ro/SSA antibodies in a newborn is specific for neonatal lupus syndrome, which is a passively acquired autoimmune disease caused by the transfer of maternal anti-Ro/SSA or anti-La/SSB antibodies across the placenta and is the most common cause of complete heart block in a fetus or newborn. As well as manifesting with heart block or a characteristic rash, neonatal lupus syndrome can also affect the hepatic (e.g., hepatosplenomegaly, hepatitis) and hematologic systems (e.g., anemia, neutropenia, thrombocytopenia). The combination of positive antibodies (in mothers or newborns) and either congenital heart block, rash, or hepatic and hematologic findings is required for a diagnosis of neonatal lupus syndrome.

images.title: Neonatal lupus syndrome
images.description: Face of a newborn with erythematous rashMultiple ring-shaped erythematous patches can be seen around the lips, eyelids, and on the forehead. Neither nose or cheeks are affected by the rash.These findings are typical of neonatal lupus syndrome.

answers.content: Polymerase chain reaction for parvovirus DNA
answers.explanation_why: Congenital parvovirus B19 infection is associated with severe aplastic anemia and possibly fetal hydrops, neither of which are seen in this newborn. Furthermore, a congenital atrioventricular block and a periorbital, erythematous, and photosensitive rash would not be explained by this condition.

Antitreponemal antibodies are used to aid in the diagnosis of congenital syphilis, which can cause a rash in newborns. Furthermore, arthralgias and rashes, as reported in the patient's mother, may be seen in secondary syphilis. However, congenital syphilis is not associated with atrioventricular blocks and photosensitivity. Additionally, the rash in congenital syphilis is maculopapular and typically affects palms and soles rather than the face and neck. Moreover, early-onset congenital syphilis commonly manifests with hepatomegaly, jaundice, and rhinorrhea.

The presence of anti-dsDNA antibodies is specific for systemic lupus erythematosus, a condition that commonly manifests with a malar rash, arthralgias, and photosensitivity; the mother's arthralgias and rash are consistent with this diagnosis. However, anti-dsDNA antibodies do not cross the placenta; therefore, they would not be seen in a newborn with suspected neonatal lupus syndrome.

answers.content: Polymerase chain reaction for rubella virus RNA
answers.explanation_why: Congenital rubella commonly manifests with cardiac defects and dermatologic findings. However, this condition is associated with petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash) on the entire body rather than a photosensitive, erythematous, annular rash affecting the face and neck. Furthermore, cardiac defects in congenital rubella infection are typically structural defects (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus) rather than conduction blocks like the atrioventricular block seen here. Moreover, congenital rubella is commonly associated with cataracts and bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

images.title: Congenital rubella infection TORCH fact sheet

question_text: A 4-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of nasal discharge and cough. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 23-year-old woman gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated delivery. Two weeks ago, his mother noticed a “thick yellow-green discharge” from his left eye that was treated at home with teabag compressions. The mother has no medical insurance and did not receive prenatal care. The patient appears irritable. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Physical examination shows short, repetitive episodes of cough with brief inspirations between each cough. Bilateral, diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. There is mild swelling of the left eyelid. Polymerase chain reaction tests of nasopharyngeal and ocular secretions are positive for the same pathogen. Which of the following is the most likely causal microorganism?
content_preview: A 4-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of nasal discharge and cough. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 23-year-old woman gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated delivery. Two weeks ago, his mother noticed a “thick yellow-green discharge” from his left eye that was treated at home with teabag compressions. The mother has no medical insurance and did not receive prenatal care. The patient appears irritable. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 65/min, and blood pressure is 80/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Physical examination shows short, repetitive episodes of cough with brief inspirations between each cough. Bilateral, diffuse crackles are heard on auscultation of the chest. There is mild swelling of the left eyelid. Polymerase chain reaction tests of nasopharyngeal and ocular secretions are positive for the same pathogen. Which of the following is the most likely causal microorganism?
hint: This patient developed neonatal conjunctivitis and now presents with nasal congestion and features of pneumonia (tachypnea, hypoxemia, cough, and crackles on auscultation). Eosinophilia on a complete blood count is a relatively specific diagnostic clue for this newborn's condition, which could most likely have been prevented with adequate prenatal care.
learning_objective: Recognize Chlamydia trachomatis infection in neonates, and recall its clinical manifestations.

answers.explanation_why: Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which can cause neonatal conjunctivitis with thick, purulent ocular discharge and pronounced eyelid swelling, is transmitted perinatally during vaginal delivery and can be screened for during prenatal care (prenatal gonorrhea screening). However, gonococcal conjunctivitis typically manifests in newborns 2–7 days after delivery, whereas this patient's presentation began after 2 weeks. In addition to neonatal conjunctivitis, N. gonorrhea infection can cause disseminated gonococcal infection and septic arthritis, but not pneumonia.

images.title: Infant with gonococcal ophthalmic disease
images.description: The eyelids are swollen, with purulent exudate forming crusts around them. Below the crusts there may be a large reservoir of pus. Special care should be taken and safety goggles should be worn when examining the eyes.

answers.explanation_why: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection can cause rhinorrhea, bronchiolitis, and, occasionally, afebrile pneumonia during infancy or the late neonatal period. Both bronchiolitis and pneumonia cause cough, hypoxemia, and crackles on auscultation. Conjunctival injection may be present in patients with RSV infection, as seen here. However, RSV does not cause purulent conjunctivitis.

Parainfluenza virus type 1 typically causes croup, which can manifest with nasal congestion, a cough (classically a “barking seal” cough), and features of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, hypoxemia). Patients may be afebrile or only have a low-grade fever during the prodromal phase. However, croup is characterized by hoarseness and inspiratory stridor, rather than crackles, and it more commonly affects children 6 months to 3 years of age. Moreover, this patient's history of purulent conjunctivitis suggests a different diagnosis.

Streptococcus pneumoniae can cause pneumonia during infancy and the late neonatal period. However, pneumococcal pneumonia typically has a more severe presentation with high fever, whereas this neonate has afebrile pneumonia. Moreover, S. pneumoniae is a common cause of conjunctivitis in older children and young adults (pneumococcal conjunctivitis), but not in neonates.

Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococcus; GBS) infection in neonates can manifest as pneumonia, and this patient's mother most likely did not receive prenatal screening for GBS colonization. However, neonatal pneumonia due to GBS would manifest within the first 6 days of life (early-onset GBS infection), whereas the pneumonia in this newborn manifested at 4 weeks of life. Late-onset GBS infection, which occurs 1–12 weeks after birth, usually manifests with neonatal meningitis or neonatal sepsis, but not pneumonia. Moreover, GBS is a rare cause of neonatal conjunctivitis.

This newborn has Chlamydia trachomatis infection that likely was transmitted during delivery and is manifesting as neonatal conjunctivitis and afebrile pneumonia syndrome. Neonatal conjunctivitis due to C. trachomatis typically manifests 5–14 days after birth and likely explains this patient's mucopurulent eye discharge and swelling. Chlamydial pneumonia, which usually manifests 4–12 weeks after birth can be accompanied by neonatal conjunctivitis and is characterized by a staccato cough with or without low-grade fever and features of interstitial pneumonia on chest x-ray. C. trachomatis infection is treated with macrolide antibiotics (e.g., erythromycin). Prenatal screening for C. trachomatis infection is indicated for pregnant women < 25 years of age.

Herpes simplex virus 2 (HSV-2), which can be transmitted during vaginal delivery (if the mother has active genital herpes), would cause neonatal keratoconjunctivitis and, in the case of disseminated disease, pneumonia. However, HSV-induced keratoconjunctivitis is associated with vesicles and nonpurulent watery discharge, not purulent discharge. Moreover, disseminated HSV infection usually occurs within a few days of the onset of mucocutaneous or ophthalmological disease; pulmonary involvement 2 weeks after the onset of ophthalmological disease indicates a different diagnosis.

Bordetella pertussis infection (pertussis) can result in nasal discharge and cough without fever during the catarrhal stage, which may be brief in young infants. The catarrhal stage would be followed by paroxysms of a staccato cough with hypoxemia, as seen here (paroxysmal stage). Young infants are also at higher risk of developing complications of pertussis, such as pneumonia, and a lack of prenatal care (e.g., third trimester Tdap immunization) increases the risk of pertussis. However, B. pertussis does not cause neonatal conjunctivitis, so it is not the most likely causal organism.

question_text: A 1-hour-old female newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. She was born at 41 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The mother has no history of sexually transmitted infections, and her immunizations are up-to-date. The patient's Apgar scores were 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She is at the 75^th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the trunk shows the findings in the photograph. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 1-hour-old female newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. She was born at 41 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The mother has no history of sexually transmitted infections, and her immunizations are up-to-date. The patient's Apgar scores were 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She is at the 75th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the trunk shows the findings in the photograph. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The photograph shows pustules on a nonerythematous base and erythematous macules with fine collarettes of scale. These findings are characteristic of transient neonatal pustular melanosis (TNPM).
learning_objective: Recognize transient neonatal pustular melanosis, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Oral propranolol is used to treat complicated infantile hemangioma (i.e., one that grows rapidly, ulcerates, and/or is present in problematic areas, such as the periorbital region or airway). However, infantile hemangiomas appear as discrete, red-purple macules or papules. In addition, most infantile hemangiomas manifest days to weeks after birth, not at birth. Oral propranolol is not used to treat TNPM.

images.title: Infantile superficial hemangioma
images.description: The scalp has a solitary, ovoid, bright red nodule with irregular texture.This finding is suggestive of superficial hemangioma.

answers.explanation_why: Topical benzoyl peroxide is used to treat infantile acne, which can manifest with pustules. However, the pustules of infantile acne are typically inflamed (erythematous) and larger than those seen here. In addition, this condition does not result in the fine scaling seen in the photograph. Moreover, infantile acne most commonly manifests 3–4 months after birth. Benzoyl peroxide is not used to treat TNPM.

Intravenous acyclovir is used to treat neonatal herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, which can manifest with localized skin, eye, and/or mouth lesions at birth as a result of perinatal transmission. However, the cutaneous manifestations of HSV infection are clusters of fluid-filled vesicles on an erythematous base. The history of uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery and the absence of sexually transmitted infections in the mother also make this diagnosis unlikely. Acyclovir is not used to treat TNPM.

images.title: Neonatal herpes simplex
images.description: Scalp of a 9-day-old newbornMultiple partially confluent vesicles on an erythematous base are visible on the right frontotemporal aspect of the scalp. Further erythematous patches can be seen over the right temple and forehead.

answers.explanation_why: Reassurance is all that is required for TNPM, a benign, self-limited condition that manifests with pustules that can be present at birth. These pustules develop as solitary lesions or in clusters on any part of the body, including the palms and soles. When they rupture, they leave behind erythematous macules with collarettes of scale. Lesions in different stages may be present concurrently, even at birth. The diagnosis of TNPM is typically made based on the characteristic clinical appearance.

Topical mupirocin is used to treat mild localized staphylococcal pustulosis, which can manifest in neonates. However, the pustules of this condition are typically inflamed (erythematous) and develop in moist areas susceptible to skin trauma (e.g., diaper region, axillae). This condition can occur in early infancy but is unlikely to develop as early as 1 hour after birth. Mupirocin is not used to treat TNPM.

Surgical excision or laser ablation is indicated for large congenital melanocytic nevi (CMN) because of the risk of malignant degeneration. CMN are present at birth but appear as pigmented macules, patches, and/or plaques. Surgical excision is not used to treat TNPM.

images.title: Congenital melanocytic nevi
images.description: Extensive congenital melanocytic nevi in an infant, showing the characteristic variable coloration.

images.title: Transient neonatal pustular melanosis
images.description: Multiple pustules and erosions are visible on this neonate's trunk.

question_text:
A 1-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother has not had routine prenatal care. She reports having a self-limiting reddish rash that started on her face and spread to her trunk and limbs as well as joint pain in her hands, wrists, and ankles 2 weeks into the pregnancy. Cardiac examination of the newborn is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Video
content_preview: A 1-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. The mother has not had routine prenatal care. She reports having a self-limiting reddish rash that started on her face and spread to her trunk and limbs as well as joint pain in her hands, wrists, and ankles 2 weeks into the pregnancy. Cardiac examination of the newborn is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? Video
hint: Auscultation shows a continuous murmur that is best heard at the left upper sternal border (i.e., near the left infraclavicular region) and has a machine-like quality.
learning_objective: Recognize patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASD) manifest with a pulmonary flow murmur (systolic ejection murmur) heard best at the left upper sternal border and are often associated with fixed splitting of S2. ASDs are often low-velocity shunts that produce insufficient flow to be audible. Larger shunts may cause diastolic flow murmurs across the tricuspid valve owing to a large left-to-right shunt. However, the continuous machinery murmur would not be seen in patients with an ASD.

Persistent truncus arteriosus (PTA) results in a single conduit providing mixed venous and arterial blood to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic circulations. Cardiac exam findings of PTA would include a single loud S2 and the presence of an ejection click at the cardiac apex or left sternal border. Accentuated and bounding peripheral pulses might also be present. However, patients with an unrepaired defect present with harsh systolic murmurs at the left sternal border, unlike the continuous machinery murmur heard in this patient.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is associated with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo murmur best heard along the left mid- to upper-sternal border. The murmur can decrease in intensity as the degree of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction worsens because of increased right-to-left shunting of blood. The examination findings of a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, such as that observed in this patient, would not be seen in patients with TOF.

The murmur of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is generated as blood continuously shunts from the high-pressure aorta through the ductus arteriosus into the low-pressure pulmonary artery. It may envelop the S_2 and is not usually affected by positional changes. Patients with moderate-sized PDAs may present with bounding pulses, widened pulse pressure, and symptoms of heart failure.

This condition affects infants who are born prematurely and/or have congenital rubella infection (CRI). CRI is likely in this newborn given that the mother had features of rubella infection (e.g., an erythematous exanthem that began on the face, polyarthritis). The most common congenital heart defects associated with CRI are PDA and pulmonary stenosis. Pulmonary stenosis causes a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border.

Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is associated with a late systolic crescendo murmur with a midsystolic click heard best at the apex. The examination findings of a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, such as that observed in this patient, would not be seen in patients with MVP.

Ventricular septal defects (VSDs) manifest with holosystolic, harsh-sounding murmurs, best heard in the left lower sternal border. These murmurs often obliterate the S2 and are associated with a palpable thrill. The examination findings in this patient reveal a continuous machinery murmur in the left upper sternal border, which is not suggestive of a VSD.

question_text: One hour after delivery, a 3200-g (7-lb 1-oz) male newborn starts to cough and choke while being breastfed. He was delivered at 35 weeks' gestation because of premature rupture of membranes. Apgar scores were 8 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His parents refused prenatal screening. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 146/min, respirations are 51/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg. Examination shows cyanosis of the lips and oral mucosa. Crackles are heard throughout both lung bases. There is a harsh 3/6 systolic murmur along the left sternal border. Insertion of a nasogastric tube is attempted but the tube cannot be passed beyond 6 cm from the gums. An x-ray with contrast shows a blind-ended esophageal pouch; there is abundant gas in the stomach. Screening for which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: One hour after delivery, a 3200-g (7-lb 1-oz) male newborn starts to cough and choke while being breastfed. He was delivered at 35 weeks' gestation because of premature rupture of membranes. Apgar scores were 8 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His parents refused prenatal screening. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 146/min, respirations are 51/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg. Examination shows cyanosis of the lips and oral mucosa. Crackles are heard throughout both lung bases. There is a harsh 3/6 systolic murmur along the left sternal border. Insertion of a nasogastric tube is attempted but the tube cannot be passed beyond 6 cm from the gums. An x-ray with contrast shows a blind-ended esophageal pouch; there is abundant gas in the stomach. Screening for which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Coughing and choking spells when feeding, in conjunction with cyanosis, crackles on lung auscultation, and the inability to pass a feeding tube, suggest esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF). This diagnosis is confirmed by the x-ray findings. The harsh systolic murmur on cardiac auscultation suggests a cardiac structural anomaly.
learning_objective: Recognize esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula, and recall its associated complications.

answers.explanation_why:
Esophageal atresia with TEF is caused by a defect in mesodermal differentiation. About 50% of esophageal atresia cases are associated with other mesodermal defects, known as the VACTERL association: Vertebral anomaly, Anal atresia, Cardiac anomaly, Tracheoesophageal fistula, Esophageal atresia, Renal anomaly (including agenesis), and Limb malformation. Newborns with esophageal atresia should, therefore, undergo screening for other VACTERL anomalies. Screening typically includes echocardiography and renal ultrasonography.

Esophageal atresia with TEF to the distal esophageal segment is the most common type of esophageal atresia, accounting for > 75% of cases. A fetus with esophageal atresia is unable to swallow amniotic fluid, resulting in polyhydramnios, which can lead to premature rupture of membranes and premature labor, as seen here.

images.title: Newborn with type C esophageal atresia
images.description: X-ray (AP view with contrast): contrast agent filling a blind-ended esophageal pouch (green overlay) that ends at the level of the third thoracic vertebra. Inside the pouch, a nasogastric tube can be seen (dashed lines). There is abundant gas in the gastrointestinal tract, indicating patent tracheoesophageal fistula.

answers.explanation_why: Thymic aplasia may be seen in neonates with DiGeorge syndrome. This syndrome is associated with cardiac anomalies, which this patient most likely has. However, this newborn does not have other characteristic features of DiGeorge syndrome, such as an anomalous face (micrognathia, dysplastic ears, prominent nasal bridge) and a cleft palate. Common anomalies associated with esophageal atresia do not include thymic aplasia.

images.title: DiGeorge syndrome (22q11.2 deletion syndrome) fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Cerebellar hypoplasia can be seen in children with PHACE syndrome. This syndrome is associated with cardiac anomalies, which this patient most likely has. However, this newborn does not have other characteristic features of PHACE syndrome, such as infantile hemangiomas and eye anomalies. Common anomalies associated with esophageal atresia do not include cerebellar hypoplasia.

Iris coloboma may be seen in neonates with CHARGE syndrome. This syndrome is associated with cardiac anomalies and bilateral choanal atresia, which can manifest immediately after birth with cyanosis associated with feeding, similar to what is seen in this newborn. However, choanal atresia does not typically manifest with coughing and choking spells. Moreover, this newborn does not have other characteristic features of CHARGE syndrome, such as genital and ear abnormalities. Common anomalies associated with esophageal atresia do not include iris coloboma.

Esophageal atresia, which this newborn has, may be associated with gastrointestinal abnormalities, such as anal atresia and intestinal malrotation. Biliary atresia, however, is not a common association. Furthermore, biliary atresia typically manifests at birth with jaundice, which is not seen in this newborn.

question_text: Three days after delivery, a male newborn suddenly has a high-grade fever, seizures, and hypotonia. He was delivered at 35 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman following a pregnancy complicated by maternal fever and chorioamnionitis during the third trimester. Apgar scores were 6 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His mother received no prenatal care. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 80/min, and blood pressure is 70/45 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination discloses grunting breath sounds. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. There is hepatomegaly. Cerebral ultrasound shows diffuse hyperechogenicity. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this newborn's condition?
content_preview: Three days after delivery, a male newborn suddenly has a high-grade fever, seizures, and hypotonia. He was delivered at 35 weeks' gestation to a 26-year-old woman following a pregnancy complicated by maternal fever and chorioamnionitis during the third trimester. Apgar scores were 6 and 6 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. His mother received no prenatal care. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 180/min, respirations are 80/min, and blood pressure is 70/45 mm Hg. Pulmonary examination discloses grunting breath sounds. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. There is hepatomegaly. Cerebral ultrasound shows diffuse hyperechogenicity. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this newborn's condition?
hint: This newborn has a high-grade fever, respiratory distress, and hepatomegaly, indicating neonatal sepsis. In addition, the seizures, hypotonia, and abnormal cerebral ultrasound suggest meningoencephalitis. Maternal infection, as evidenced by chorioamnionitis and premature rupture of membranes (PPROM), is a typical source of early-onset disease (before 5 days of life) in preterm infants.
learning_objective: Recognize early-onset neonatal listeriosis, and recall its maternal risk factors.

answers.content: Transvaginal transmission of herpes simplex virus
answers.explanation_why: Congenital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection can manifest with signs of CNS disease (e.g., fever, seizures, hypotonia, abnormal brain ultrasound) and sepsis-like disseminated disease (e.g., hepatomegaly, pneumonitis). However, transvaginal transmission mostly occurs in mothers with genital herpes; chorioamnionitis and PPROM are not typical of maternal HSV infection. Infected infants usually also have characteristic diffuse vesicular skin lesions and may develop keratoconjunctivitis. Finally, CNS disease generally manifests in the second or third week of life rather than 3 days after birth.

answers.content: Maternal contact with cat feces during pregnancy
answers.explanation_why: Maternal contact with cat feces during pregnancy is a risk factor for toxoplasmosis. Congenital toxoplasmosis may cause premature birth and manifest with fever, seizures, pneumonitis, and hepatomegaly. However, infected mothers are usually asymptomatic or develop a mononucleosis-like disease during pregnancy; chorioamnionitis and PPROM are not typical. The severity of congenital disease decreases with gestational age: while first-trimester infection usually results in a classic triad (chorioretinitis, diffuse intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus) and other nonspecific features (e.g., blueberry muffin rash, jaundice, macrocephaly), second- or third-trimester infections are mostly subclinical or mild. This patient's severe neonatal sepsis with meningoencephalitis is better explained by a different condition.

answers.content: Maternal consumption of unpasteurized cheese during pregnancy
answers.explanation_why: Consumption of unpasteurized milk products is a risk factor for listeriosis, which typically manifests with self-limiting gastroenteritis in healthy adults. In pregnant women, however, listeriosis can cause complications (e.g., fever, chorioamnionitis, PPROM) and result in preterm birth or spontaneous abortion. Transmission from an infected mother to the fetus can either occur transplacentally or via direct contact with infected vaginal secretions and/or blood during delivery. This patient likely has early-onset neonatal listeriosis (granulomatosis infantiseptica), manifesting with severe systemic infection and disseminated organ involvement (i.e., of the liver and lungs). Signs of meningitis (e.g., fever, seizures, hypotonia, abnormal cerebral ultrasound) may develop as early as seen here, especially in preterm neonates, or have a delayed onset in the 3 weeks after birth, typically in full-term neonates with perinatal infection. Both mother and newborn should be treated with IV ampicillin and gentamicin.

Transplacental transmission of Treponema pallidum causes congenital syphilis, which may manifest with hepatomegaly and, in rare cases, neurological symptoms (e.g., seizures, hypotonia), fever, and sepsis. However, this patient's mother reports no features of present or past syphilis. Moreover, while fetal syphilis may result in miscarriage, stillbirth, or hydrops fetalis, chorioamnionitis or PPROM are not typical. The majority of newborns with congenital syphilis are asymptomatic at birth; symptoms of early congenital syphilis (e.g., jaundice, rhinorrhea, maculopapular rash on the palms and soles, skeletal abnormalities, lymphadenopathy) and, rarely, syphilitic leptomeningitis develop over several months. This newborn's acute septic meningoencephalitis is better explained by a different condition.

Preterm newborns like this patient are particularly susceptible to postnatal transmission of cytomegalovirus (CMV; e.g., through breast milk from an infected mother), and neonatal CMV infection can manifest with fever, seizures, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, pneumonitis, and sepsis. However, CMV infection during pregnancy generally manifests with nonspecific flu-like symptoms rather than chorioamnionitis and PPROM, and transmission is primarily transplacental. At birth, 90% of infected infants are asymptomatic, and those that develop symptoms often also present with a blueberry muffin rash, jaundice, small size for gestational age, microcephaly, and sensorineural hearing loss. Neuroimaging characteristically shows periventricular calcifications and hydrocephalus rather than diffuse hyperechogenicity.

question_text: A 2-day-old male newborn is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit because of irritability and feeding difficulty. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman following an uncomplicated delivery. He is awake and alert. He is at the 4^th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Cardiac examination discloses a 3/6 continuous murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular region. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
content_preview: A 2-day-old male newborn is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit because of irritability and feeding difficulty. He was born at 35 weeks' gestation to a 30-year-old woman following an uncomplicated delivery. He is awake and alert. He is at the 4th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 85/55 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Cardiac examination discloses a 3/6 continuous murmur best heard in the left infraclavicular region. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities. Echocardiography shows blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
hint: Features of heart failure (e.g., irritability, poor feeding, failure to thrive) with a continuous murmur in the left infraclavicular region are highly suggestive of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), for which premature birth is a risk factor. The echocardiography findings confirm the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize patent ductus arteriosus, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitors such as ibuprofen and indomethacin are the mainstay of treatment for symptomatic PDA in premature infants. Prostaglandins keep the ductus arteriosus patent, and by inhibiting cyclooxygenase, NSAIDs decrease prostaglandin production and thus promote ductal closure. NSAIDs are only effective in preterm infants.

Transcatheter or surgical closure is the treatment of choice for infants ≥ 6 kg, children, and adults. In preterm infants, procedural closure is generally only used if pharmacological treatment is unsuccessful.

Digoxin can be used for symptomatic management of heart failure in full-term infants with a large PDA who weigh < 5 kg. However, it would not correct the underlying cause of this patient's heart failure (PDA). In addition, this infant is preterm, and thus requires a different therapeutic approach.

Hydrochlorothiazide can be used in preterm infants with a large PDA for symptomatic management. Although it can provide symptomatic relief, it would not address the underlying cause of heart failure in this patient (PDA).

Prostaglandin E_1 (PGE_1) is indicated in patients with ductal-dependent congenital heart diseases (CHDs) in order to maintain ductus arteriosus patency before surgery can be performed. However, ductal-dependent CHDs typically manifest at birth with pronounced cyanosis. This patient's murmur and normal pulse oximetry reading are suggestive of an isolated PDA, which means that prostaglandins are contraindicated.

Furosemide is the preferred treatment for the management of heart failure in full-term infants with PDA who weigh < 5 kg. However, it would not address the underlying cause of heart failure in this patient (PDA). In addition, this infant is preterm and thus requires a different therapeutic approach.

question_text: A female newborn delivered at 37 weeks’ gestation develops respiratory distress immediately after birth. She was delivered vaginally to a 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus treated with insulin during the third trimester. The newborn's pulse is 136/min, respirations are 57/min, and blood pressure is 60/35 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91% when the newborn is crying and a saturation of 85% at rest. Examination shows grunting breath sounds and perioral blue discoloration that improves when the patient cries. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a split S_2 during inspiration but no murmurs are heard. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. A suction catheter cannot be passed through the nares. In addition to establishing an oral airway, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A female newborn delivered at 37 weeks’ gestation develops respiratory distress immediately after birth. She was delivered vaginally to a 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1. Pregnancy was complicated by gestational diabetes mellitus treated with insulin during the third trimester. The newborn's pulse is 136/min, respirations are 57/min, and blood pressure is 60/35 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91% when the newborn is crying and a saturation of 85% at rest. Examination shows grunting breath sounds and perioral blue discoloration that improves when the patient cries. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows a split S2 during inspiration but no murmurs are heard. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. A suction catheter cannot be passed through the nares. In addition to establishing an oral airway, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's condition is associated with central cyanosis that worsens both at rest and while feeding.
learning_objective: Recognize bilateral choanal atresia, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Arterial switch procedure is indicated in patients with transposition of the great vessels (TGV). TGV is associated with maternal diabetes and manifests with respiratory distress and cyanosis in the newborn immediately after birth, both of which are seen here. In patients with TGV, however, oxygenation is not affected by crying. Furthermore, this condition manifests with extreme cyanosis, progressive hypoxemia, and a loud, single second heart sound on cardiac auscultation.

answers.content: Endoscopic resection of the posterior nasal septum
answers.explanation_why:
Bilateral choanal atresia, a congenital condition characterized by complete blockage of the nasal cavity, typically manifests immediately after birth with respiratory distress, grunting breath sounds, and central cyanosis which improves with crying and worsens with feeding and at rest. The best initial test is the passage of a catheter through the nares, which is not possible in bilateral choanal atresia. Contrast rhinography in the supine position or CT scan of the facial bones confirms the diagnosis. After establishing an oropharyngeal airway, transnasal endoscopic resection of the posterior nasal septum is the most appropriate treatment to provide a permanent nasal airway. These procedures help prevent life-threatening cyanotic attacks and aspiration when the newborn's mouth is blocked during feeding. Finally, the newborn should be examined for other congenital anomalies since choanal atresia is often associated with CHARGE syndrome.

Splitting of the second heart sound, as seen in this newborn, occurs physiologically during inspiration, which leads to delayed closure of the pulmonary valve (P_2) due to increased right ventricular ejection time.

images.title: Choanal atresia
images.description: Retropalatal endoscopic viewUnilateral choanal atresia can be seen.

answers.content: Reconnection of the upper esophageal pouch with the lower esophagus
answers.explanation_why: Reconnection of the upper esophageal pouch with the lower esophagus is indicated in patients with esophageal atresia (EA). This condition may manifest immediately after birth with respiratory distress and cyanotic attacks, similar to what is seen in this patient. Since newborns with EA are unable to swallow properly, excessive foamy secretions at the mouth would also be expected. Moreover, in EA, a gastric catheter can be inserted through the nares but would be blocked at the level of the esophagus.

answers.content: Anastomosis between subclavian and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: Anastomosis between the subclavian and pulmonary artery is performed in newborns with ductal-dependent congenital heart diseases, such as tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), when early heart surgery is not possible. Symptoms of TOF depend on the severity of the right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) and may fluctuate, similar to the fluctuating cyanosis seen in this infant. However, infants with TOF and episodic cyanosis (i.e., tet spells) typically have mild RVOTO and only become symptomatic at 2–4 months of age. In contrast, newborns with TOF and cyanosis immediately after birth usually have severe RVOTO with symptoms that do not fluctuate or improve with crying. Finally, cardiac examination would show a harsh systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a single second heart sound.

Endotracheal administration of artificial surfactant is indicated in patients with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), a condition caused by surfactant deficiency in preterm infants. NRDS leads to diffuse atelectasis with respiratory distress and cyanosis after birth, both of which do not improve with crying. Furthermore, NRDS typically manifests with decreased breath sounds on auscultation. This infant was born at term with mature lungs; surfactant would not improve her symptoms.

question_text: A 3200-g (7-lb 1-oz) female newborn develops respiratory distress 10 minutes after delivery. She was born at 42 weeks' gestation via lower segment cesarean section. Apgar scores were 4 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Pregnancy and delivery were complicated by oligohydramnios and green amniotic fluid. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 175/min, and respirations are 65/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Physical examination shows nasal flaring, abdominal breathing, and substernal retractions. On pulmonary examination, diffuse crackles are heard bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows increased lung volumes and asymmetric, coarse opacities with bilateral effusions. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 3200-g (7-lb 1-oz) female newborn develops respiratory distress 10 minutes after delivery. She was born at 42 weeks' gestation via lower segment cesarean section. Apgar scores were 4 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Pregnancy and delivery were complicated by oligohydramnios and green amniotic fluid. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 175/min, and respirations are 65/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Physical examination shows nasal flaring, abdominal breathing, and substernal retractions. On pulmonary examination, diffuse crackles are heard bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows increased lung volumes and asymmetric, coarse opacities with bilateral effusions. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Meconium-stained amniotic fluid and respiratory distress immediately after birth suggest meconium aspiration syndrome (MAS). Postterm delivery, oligohydramnios, and cesarean delivery are risk factors for this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize meconium aspiration syndrome, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.content: Administration of surfactant via an endotracheal tube
answers.explanation_why: Surfactant therapy is routinely administered in patients with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS), which can manifest with signs of increased breathing effort (e.g., nasal flaring, substernal retractions, tachypnea) and hypoxia immediately after birth. However, chest x-ray findings would show diffuse, fine, reticulogranular opacities and decreased rather than increased lung volumes. Moreover, the major risk factor for NRDS is premature birth, while this patient was born at 42 weeks' gestation. This patient most likely has MAS, in which surfactant therapy might be indicated in mechanically ventilated patients but is not part of the initial management.

Indomethacin therapy is used to induce closure of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Although large PDAs can manifest with symptoms of respiratory distress (due to heart failure), these symptoms are not seen immediately after birth. Furthermore, PDA would manifest with a characteristic machine-like, loud continuous murmur on auscultation. This newborn most likely has MAS, in which indomethacin is not indicated.

answers.content: Administration of intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin
answers.explanation_why: Combination therapy with intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin therapy is used in the treatment of early-onset neonatal pneumonia (i.e., within 6 days of birth), which manifests with features of respiratory distress (e.g., tachypnea, increased breathing effort, hypoxia) and asymmetrical, patchy infiltrates on chest x-ray, similar to what is seen here. Empiric antibiotic therapy with ampicillin and gentamicin might also be indicated in newborns with MAS, as it is usually not possible to definitively rule out bacterial pneumonia. However, other steps in management (e.g., obtaining blood cultures) should be performed prior to initiating antibiotic therapy.

Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is used in the diagnosis of various infectious, inflammatory, and immunologic conditions. BAL is being investigated as a potential treatment for severe MAS but is not currently standard. A different step is more appropriate.

answers.content: Administration of supplemental oxygen via an oxygen hood
answers.explanation_why: The most appropriate step in the management of a newborn with MAS is to provide supportive care, which includes the administration of supplemental oxygen. Aspirated meconium in the tracheobronchial system leads to airway obstruction, chemical irritation, inflammation, and surfactant inactivation, culminating in alveolar collapse. Alveolar collapse results in areas of atelectasis and consequently a right-to-left pulmonary shunt, leading to areas of ventilation/perfusion mismatch with hypoxia and consequent hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction. This can, in turn, lead to persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN). The administration of supplemental oxygen counters pulmonary vasoconstriction, helping to prevent or reverse PPHN. The management of severe cases should follow the standard steps of neonatal resuscitation.

question_text: A 27-year-old primigravid woman at 38 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department in active labor. She has attempted to deliver at home but “has been pushing in vain” for the past 3 hours. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated and she received all routine prenatal care. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/81 mm Hg. Contractions occur every 3–5 minutes. The cervix is 10 cm dilated and 100% effaced; the vertex is at +1 station. The fetal heart rate is 155/min. A pudendal block with mepivacaine is given for analgesia. Three hours later, the vertex is still at +1 station; fetal monitoring shows contractions every 4 minutes and a reassuring heart rate. A forceps-assisted delivery is performed. This procedure places the newborn at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
content_preview: A 27-year-old primigravid woman at 38 weeks' gestation is brought to the emergency department in active labor. She has attempted to deliver at home but “has been pushing in vain” for the past 3 hours. Her pregnancy has been uncomplicated and she received all routine prenatal care. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 125/81 mm Hg. Contractions occur every 3–5 minutes. The cervix is 10 cm dilated and 100% effaced; the vertex is at +1 station. The fetal heart rate is 155/min. A pudendal block with mepivacaine is given for analgesia. Three hours later, the vertex is still at +1 station; fetal monitoring shows contractions every 4 minutes and a reassuring heart rate. A forceps-assisted delivery is performed. This procedure places the newborn at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
learning_objective: Recall complications of forceps-assisted delivery.

answers.explanation_why: Forceps-assisted delivery increases the risk of shoulder dystocia, which can lead to brachial plexus injury, not cervical plexus injury. Congenital brachial plexus injury may manifest as Erb palsy or Klumpke palsy.

Forceps-assisted delivery increases the risk of developing peripheral facial nerve palsy as the forceps compress the facial nerve against the mandible or parts of the skull. Facial nerve palsy caused by forceps delivery usually resolves spontaneously after a few weeks, in which case it does not require further diagnostic workup. Treatment is symptomatic (e.g., artificial tears). Other neonatal complications of assisted vaginal delivery (forceps or vacuum delivery) include injuries to the skin and subcutaneous tissue (e.g., ecchymosis, lacerations), skull (e.g., fractures), and eye (e.g., retinal hemorrhage), as well as subgaleal or intracranial hemorrhage, and, in rare cases, fetal death. External ear trauma (e.g., abrasions, lacerations) is more common in forceps delivery, and cephalohematomas and brachial plexus injuries are more common in vacuum delivery.

Maternal complications of assisted vaginal delivery include injuries to the genital tract (e.g., lacerations, hematomas), urinary tract (e.g., bladder or urethral injury), or anal sphincter (e.g., lacerations).

Cerebral palsy can develop as a complication of perinatal asphyxia and decreased oxygen supply to the brain. A prolonged second stage of labor, which this pregnant woman has, can lead to impaired blood flow to the fetus and subsequent perinatal asphyxia. However, there were no signs suggestive of perinatal asphyxia (e.g., fetal bradycardia) and forceps-assisted delivery alone does not increase the risk of cerebral palsy.

Neonatal epidural hematoma is an extremely rare complication of forceps-assisted delivery. Symptoms of epidural hematoma in a newborn include lethargy, seizures, and signs of elevated intracranial pressure (e.g., bulging fontanelle, papilledema), all of which may develop only several days after the delivery. A different complication of forceps delivery is more likely.

Forceps-assisted delivery increases the risk of birth trauma, including trauma to the sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM), which can result in congenital torticollis, not acquired torticollis. Causes of acquired torticollis include cervical muscle spasm and ocular problems, not forceps-assisted delivery.

question_text: Six hours after hospital admission, a 15-year-old primigravid girl delivers a 3006-g (6-lb 10-oz) full-term, male newborn via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. She only received prenatal care during the third trimester as she was unaware of her pregnancy until 30 weeks' gestation. Her medical history is unremarkable. She occasionally smokes cigarettes and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Physical examination of the newborn shows no abnormalities. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 152/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 55/36 mm Hg. Apgar scores were 7 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. This newborn is at increased risk of developing which of the following?
content_preview: Six hours after hospital admission, a 15-year-old primigravid girl delivers a 3006-g (6-lb 10-oz) full-term, male newborn via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. She only received prenatal care during the third trimester as she was unaware of her pregnancy until 30 weeks' gestation. Her medical history is unremarkable. She occasionally smokes cigarettes and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. Physical examination of the newborn shows no abnormalities. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 152/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 55/36 mm Hg. Apgar scores were 7 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. This newborn is at increased risk of developing which of the following?
hint: Maternal age < 20 years and maternal smoking are both risk factors for the newborn developing this condition.
learning_objective: Recall risk factors for sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

answers.explanation_why: Risk factors for hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy can be divided into fetal (e.g., cardiovascular abnormalities, pulmonary pathology), antepartum (e.g., intrauterine infection), intrapartum (e.g., traumatic delivery), and maternal (e.g., substance abuse or illness) risk factors, none of which are present here.
Risk factors for neonatal respiratory distress syndrome include prematurity, cesarean delivery, maternal diabetes mellitus, hydrops fetalis, and multiple pregnancies, none of which are present here.

Hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (HDFN) may occur in infants of mothers who have received inadequate prenatal care, as is the case here. However, HDFN only occurs in infants born from the 2^nd or later pregnancies because mothers must be sensitized to the ABO or Rh incompatibility during a prior pregnancy. Moreover, HDFN is commonly associated with maternal exposure to fetal blood (e.g., during amniocentesis, cesarean delivery, termination of pregnancy, placental abruption, trauma), which is not present in this scenario.

Healthy infants born to mothers < 20 years of age are at increased risk for sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS). Besides maternal age, maternal smoking and late or no prenatal care are the two other most important maternal risk factors associated with SIDS. Maternal drug use and alcohol use also increase the risk of SIDS. Risk factors can also be infant-related (e.g., prematurity, low birth weight, twins, history of apnea, history of sibling loss due to SIDS), pregnancy-related (e.g., placenta previa, placental abruption, premature rupture of membranes), or environmental (e.g., prone sleeping position, overheating, soft toys or blankets in the crib).

Infants born to mothers with inadequate prenatal care are at increased risk for neonatal infection and sepsis. This mother's prenatal care began at 30 weeks, so the infant is not at increased risk due to inadequate care. Other risk factors for neonatal sepsis include preterm labor, maternal infection (e.g., chorioamnionitis, UTI), and premature rupture of membranes, none of which are seen here.
