question_text:
A 1-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of poor feeding. Since birth, he has had 8 to 10 wet diapers per day and passes stools 3 to 4 times per week. His mother says that he passed stool for the first time 2 days after birth. He was born at term via a spontaneous vaginal delivery at home. He is exclusively breast fed and has not yet received any routine vaccinations. His mother recently immigrated to the USA from Mongolia and has not been to a physician in 10 years. There is no family history of serious illness. He appears lethargic. He is at the 5^th percentile for length and the 20^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 34.8°C (94.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 38/min, and blood pressure is 96/58 mm Hg. Examination shows jaundice and decreased muscle tone in the extremities. The abdomen is distended. The perianal area appears normal and rectal examination discloses inspissated stool. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
9.1 g/dL

Mean corpuscular volume
110 μm^3

Leukocyte count
12,800/mm^3 with a normal differential (N = 8000–16,000)

Reticulocyte count
1%

Serum

Na^+

137 mEq/L

K^+

3.7 mEq/L

Cl^-

102 mEq/L

Ca^2+

8.7 mg/dL

Glucose
95 mg/dL

Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL

Total bilirubin
8.5 mg/dL

Direct
0.9 mg/dL

Alkaline phosphatase
70 U/L

Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT)
35 U/L

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT)
30 U/L

C-reactive protein
0.20 mg/L

A peripheral blood smear shows macrocytes. Urinalysis and ultrasonography of the abdomen show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 1-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of poor feeding. Since birth, he has had 8 to 10 wet diapers per day and passes stools 3 to 4 times per week. His mother says that he passed stool for the first time 2 days after birth. He was born at term via a spontaneous vaginal delivery at home. He is exclusively breast fed and has not yet received any routine vaccinations. His mother recently immigrated to the USA from Mongolia and has not been to a physician in 10 years. There is no family history of serious illness. He appears lethargic. He is at the 5th percentile for length and the 20th percentile for weight. His temperature is 34.8°C (94.6°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 38/min, and blood pressure is 96/58 mm Hg. Examination shows jaundice and decreased muscle tone in the extremities. The abdomen is distended. The perianal area appears normal and rectal examination discloses inspissated stool. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 9.1 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume 110 μm3 Leukocyte count 12,800/mm3 with a normal differential (N = 8000–16,000) Reticulocyte count 1% Serum Na+ 137 mEq/L K+ 3.7 mEq/L Cl- 102 mEq/L Ca2+ 8.7 mg/dL Glucose 95 mg/dL Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL Total bilirubin 8.5 mg/dL Direct 0.9 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 70 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT) 35 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT) 30 U/L C-reactive protein 0.20 mg/L A peripheral blood smear shows macrocytes. Urinalysis and ultrasonography of the abdomen show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: Constipation, lethargy, poor feeding, hypotonia, failure to thrive (with length affected more than weight), abdominal distention, prolonged neonatal jaundice, hypothermia, bradycardia (heart rate < 100/minute in neonates), and macrocytic nonmegaloblastic anemia are features of a condition for which screening is routinely performed 1–2 days after term births.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital hypothyroidism, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Lower gastrointestinal series (barium enema) is used in the workup of patients with suspected Hirschsprung disease (HD), which typically affects male individuals and can manifest in the neonatal period with delayed passage of meconium, constipation, growth faltering, abdominal distention, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (due to increased enterohepatic circulation). However, rectal examination of patients with HD usually shows a tight anal sphincter, an empty rectal vault, and/or explosive expulsion of the feces after rectal examination (squirt sign). Moreover, HD would not cause macrocytic anemia, bradycardia, or hypothermia.

This neonate most likely has congenital hypothyroidism. If the mother has hypothyroidism, the manifestations of this condition can be apparent at birth, but they most commonly develop a few weeks to months insidiously after birth in the setting of maternal euthyroidism (because maternal T_4 can cross the placenta). Thyroid function tests (serum TSH and free T_4) are used to diagnose hypothyroidism and distinguish between primary and secondary hypothyroidism. The most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism is iodine deficiency worldwide and thyroid dysgenesis in iodine-sufficient regions. Iodine deficiency is a common cause among patients from certain regions (e.g., Central Asia) but is extremely rare in the US due to the iodization of salt. Other causes of congenital hypothyroidism include transplacental transmission of maternal antithyroid antibodies and genetic defects in thyroid hormone synthesis or thyroid hormone receptors. If congenital hypothyroidism is left untreated, organomegaly (e.g., macroglossia, hepatomegaly), impaired skeletal maturation (e.g., delayed fontanelle closure), myxedema, intellectual disability, and/or heart failure can occur.
answers.explanation_but: For neonates with hypothermia, hemodynamic instability, and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, the initial workup would also include screening for neonatal sepsis, TORCH infections, and certain metabolic diseases (e.g., Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1). If there is evidence of hemolysis (e.g., reticulocytosis), tests should be performed for Rh incompatibility, hemoglobinopathies, and erythrocyte membrane defects or enzyme defects.

answers.explanation_why: A liver biopsy is indicated for neonates with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia (cholestatic jaundice) if the initial abdominal ultrasound and blood workup are inconclusive. The liver biopsy can diagnose certain cholestatic diseases that cannot be diagnosed by ultrasonography (e.g., idiopathic neonatal hepatitis). This neonate has unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, for which a liver biopsy is typically not indicated.

A sweat chloride test is used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, which can manifest in the neonatal period with growth faltering, prolonged neonatal jaundice, delayed meconium passage, constipation, abdominal distention, and occasionally, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (due to increased enterohepatic circulation). However, anemia due to cystic fibrosis is uncommon during the neonatal period (typically manifests later in life as microcytic or normochromic anemia due to iron deficiency or anemia of chronic disease). Moreover, cystic fibrosis would not cause hypothermia and bradycardia.

In neonates, stool analysis for fecal fat or reducing substances is performed when a malabsorption syndrome is suspected. Stool analysis for occult blood is performed when cow milk allergy is suspected (e.g., in neonates fed with formula). The constellation of features in this patient indicates a different underlying condition, for which stool analysis is not indicated.

question_text: A previously healthy 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a rash for the past day. She has had no fever, runny nose, vomiting, or diarrhea. Her parents say they have not used any new laundry detergents or cosmetics and that she has not been in contact with any animals. Two days ago, the family arrived in Miami to introduce the girl to her grandparents during the summer vacation. The parents report that they dressed her in several layers of clothing to protect her from direct sun exposure. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery and is exclusively breastfed. Family history is unremarkable. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 55^th percentile for length and weight and at the 65^th percentile for head circumference. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple erythematous papules measuring 2–4 mm in diameter with background erythema in the axillae and on the neck and trunk. The oral mucosa appears normal. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 1-month-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a rash for the past day. She has had no fever, runny nose, vomiting, or diarrhea. Her parents say they have not used any new laundry detergents or cosmetics and that she has not been in contact with any animals. Two days ago, the family arrived in Miami to introduce the girl to her grandparents during the summer vacation. The parents report that they dressed her in several layers of clothing to protect her from direct sun exposure. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery and is exclusively breastfed. Family history is unremarkable. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 55th percentile for length and weight and at the 65th percentile for head circumference. She appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows multiple erythematous papules measuring 2–4 mm in diameter with background erythema in the axillae and on the neck and trunk. The oral mucosa appears normal. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient developed an erythematous, papular rash after arriving in a hot and humid climate, which is characteristic of miliaria rubra.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for miliaria rubra.

answers.explanation_why: Antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine) can be used to treat type I hypersensitivity reactions, which result in histamine release and can manifest with a pruritic, erythematous, papular rash. However, miliaria rubra is not histamine-mediated, so an antihistamine would not be appropriate.

Reassurance alone is appropriate for self-limited, asymptomatic rashes. However, this patient's rash is making her uncomfortable, and she would benefit from intervention to encourage resolution of the rash and prevention of its recurrence.

Oral acetaminophen can be used to treat fever or pain. This patient has not had any fever, and her discomfort is likely due to pruritus from miliaria rubra, which does not respond to treatment with acetaminophen.

Topical nystatin can be used to treat cutaneous candidiasis, which can manifest with an erythematous rash in the diaper or intertriginous areas after prolonged exposure to moisture. However, candidal intertrigo typically manifests with maceration, vesicles and pustules that easily rupture, and satellite lesions. Miliaria rubra does not have a fungal origin, so antifungal therapy is not indicated.

Miliaria is often seen in hot and humid climates (e.g., Miami) and can occur in all ages but commonly affects children and infants. Miliaria rubra is the most prevalent form of miliaria and manifests with a pruritic, papulovesicular, erythematous rash, typically on the intertriginous areas of the groin, axillae, and neck. Management of miliaria rubra consists of measures to reduce sweating and occlusion of eccrine glands, such as keeping the patient in a cool environment, wearing breathable clothing (e.g., cotton), lightly scrubbing the skin to remove debris that can clog sweat glands, and, if nonpharmacologic measures fail to reduce the rash, administering topical steroids to decrease inflammation.

images.title: Miliaria rubra
images.description: Multiple, partially confluent papules on erythematous skin are visible.

question_text: Three days after birth, a female newborn has the onset of recurrent episodes of apnea. The episodes last 20–30 seconds and are accompanied by desaturation on pulse oximetry and bradycardia. She starts breathing again when the sole of her foot is tapped. She was delivered at 29 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman and weighed 1100 g (2 lb 7 oz). Apgar scores were 6 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The patient was taken to a tertiary-level neonatal intensive care unit immediately after delivery, where she has been monitored since in an incubator with free-flow oxygen. The newborn's skin appears pink. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 56/29 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Capillary refill time is less than 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary examination and a chest x-ray show no abnormalities. The results of a complete blood count and serum studies are within normal limits. Blood culture and lumbar puncture results are pending. In addition to nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: Three days after birth, a female newborn has the onset of recurrent episodes of apnea. The episodes last 20–30 seconds and are accompanied by desaturation on pulse oximetry and bradycardia. She starts breathing again when the sole of her foot is tapped. She was delivered at 29 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old woman and weighed 1100 g (2 lb 7 oz). Apgar scores were 6 and 7 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The patient was taken to a tertiary-level neonatal intensive care unit immediately after delivery, where she has been monitored since in an incubator with free-flow oxygen. The newborn's skin appears pink. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 124/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 56/29 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Capillary refill time is less than 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary examination and a chest x-ray show no abnormalities. The results of a complete blood count and serum studies are within normal limits. Blood culture and lumbar puncture results are pending. In addition to nasal continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: Episodes of apnea that last > 20 seconds or that are accompanied by bradycardia and/or oxygen desaturation in an otherwise healthy premature neonate indicate apnea of prematurity (AOP). This condition occurs as a result of a combination of airflow obstruction at the nasopharyngeal level (obstructive apnea) and decreased respiratory drive (central apnea).
learning_objective: Recognize apnea of prematurity, and choose the most appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.content: No further treatment is indicated at this time
answers.explanation_why: Few nonsevere episodes of AOP can be managed with supportive measures (e.g., maintaining a physiological neck position and appropriate incubator temperature, avoiding excessive nasal suctioning) as well as nasal CPAP to keep the upper airways open and improve oxygenation. This patient has had multiple episodes accompanied by desaturation and requires tactile stimulation to trigger spontaneous breathing. Therefore, additional therapy is indicated.

AOP reflects immature respiratory control and is commonly seen in preterm neonates or neonates with very low birth weight, with the incidence inversely proportional to the gestational age. AOP typically manifests during the first few days after birth and is diagnosed clinically. Management includes supportive measures such as maintaining a physiological neck position, appropriate incubator temperature, and avoidance of excessive nasal suctioning. Other causes of apnea (e.g., sepsis) should also be ruled out. Additionally, nasal CPAP is indicated in all infants with AOP to keep the upper airways open and to improve oxygenation by improving the ventilation-perfusion ratio. Methylxanthines, such as caffeine, are the mainstay of pharmacological treatment and stimulate respiration, presumably by blocking adenosine receptors. Caffeine therapy is the preferred drug and is indicated in patients with recurrent episodes who require tactile stimulation (e.g., tapping the sole of the foot) to trigger spontaneous breathing, or if ventilatory support is necessary.

Given the high likelihood of developing AOP, caffeine can be administered prophylactically to neonates who are extremely preterm (< 28 weeks' gestation) or have an extremely low birth weight (< 1000 g).

Surfactant therapy is indicated in preterm neonates with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) for whom an initial trial of nasal CPAP has been unsuccessful. Although premature neonates have a high risk of NRDS, this patient does not have features that suggest this condition, such as tachypnea, grunting, or nasal flaring. Furthermore, typical findings of NRDS include diffuse ground-glass densities and air bronchograms seen on chest x-ray as well as diminished breath sounds on auscultation. Surfactant therapy has no role in the treatment of AOP.

Corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone) may be used in the treatment of severe bronchopulmonary dysplasia (BPD), which can manifest with episodes of desaturation. However, this patient has no other features (e.g., tachypnea, grunting, nasal flaring) that suggest BPD. Moreover, abnormal chest x-ray findings (e.g., fine granular densities, areas of atelectasis interspersed with areas of hyperinflation) and abnormal lung auscultation (e.g., rales or decreased breath sounds) are expected in BPD.

Acid suppression therapy may be used with caution in the treatment of severe gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in neonates. All neonates have GERD to some extent because of transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxation. The gastric fluid stimulates the laryngeal chemoreflex response, which is overactive in preterm neonates, resulting in apnea. Although apnea and desaturation may be symptoms of GERD, poor weight gain and feeding intolerance are also expected findings.

question_text:
A 2-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother's first pregnancy ended in stillbirth with hydrops fetalis at 35 weeks' gestation. She did not receive prenatal care during either pregnancy and refused postnatal screening after the first pregnancy. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She lives in Pennsylvania and there is no history of international travel. The newborn appears pale and lethargic. He is at the 10th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. He does not move his extremities spontaneously. Examination shows pallor of the mucosal membranes and jaundice. His spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. The remainder of the examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
9.8 g/dL

Hematocrit
26%

Reticulocyte count
21%

Serum

 Bilirubin, total

15.3 mg/dL

 Direct

1.1 mg/dL

 Aspartate aminotransferase
22 U/L

 Alanine aminotransferase
17 U/L

 Lactate dehydrogenase

820 U/L

A direct antiglobulin test is negative. A peripheral blood smear shows a few echinocytes and polychromasia consistent with reticulocytosis. Hemoglobin electrophoresis and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase assay show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 2-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother's first pregnancy ended in stillbirth with hydrops fetalis at 35 weeks' gestation. She did not receive prenatal care during either pregnancy and refused postnatal screening after the first pregnancy. She is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. She lives in Pennsylvania and there is no history of international travel. The newborn appears pale and lethargic. He is at the 10th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. He does not move his extremities spontaneously. Examination shows pallor of the mucosal membranes and jaundice. His spleen is palpable 3 cm below the left costal margin. The remainder of the examination and fundoscopy show no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL Hematocrit 26% Reticulocyte count 21% Serum Bilirubin, total 15.3 mg/dL Direct 1.1 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase 22 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 17 U/L Lactate dehydrogenase 820 U/L A direct antiglobulin test is negative. A peripheral blood smear shows a few echinocytes and polychromasia consistent with reticulocytosis. Hemoglobin electrophoresis and glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase assay show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Low hemoglobin with an increased reticulocyte count, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, increased LDH, and a negative Coombs test indicate nonimmune hemolytic anemia. The mother's history of stillbirth due to hydrops fetalis suggests a hereditary disorder.
learning_objective: Recognize pyruvate kinase deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Pyruvate kinase deficiency (PKD) is an autosomal recessive enzyme defect of the glycolytic pathway that results in extravascular hemolytic anemia. It is the second most prevalent erythrocyte enzyme disorder (after glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency). A higher incidence has been observed within Pennsylvania Amish communities, most likely as a result of the founder effect. The severity of the disease is highly variable; PKD can manifest with fetal demise due to hydrops fetalis, symptomatic anemia from birth that requires lifelong transfusions, or chronic compensated hemolysis. A peripheral blood smear typically shows normal erythrocyte morphology, but echinocytes are sometimes seen. Diagnosis is confirmed by measuring pyruvate kinase enzyme activity.

Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection can manifest with jaundice, splenomegaly, lethargy, and hypotonia. While congenital CMV infection also occasionally causes hemolytic anemia, this patient lacks other characteristic features of this condition, such as chorioretinitis, hearing loss, and hepatomegaly with transaminitis.

images.title: Congenital CMV infection TORCH fact sheet

answers.explanation_why: Fanconi anemia (FA) has a wide variety of clinical manifestations, which include neonatal anemia. However, FA typically causes aplastic anemia with a decreased reticulocyte count rather than hemolytic anemia. Moreover, most newborns with FA present with congenital anomalies such as café-au-lait spots, microcephaly, thumb and forearm malformations, and eye and ear abnormalities. Finally, although FA is a hereditary disorder that can affect multiple children with the same biological parents, stillbirth due to FA is unlikely.

Congenital parvovirus B19 infection can cause severe neonatal anemia and hydrops fetalis. However, it typically causes aplastic anemia with a decreased reticulocyte count rather than hemolytic anemia, and vertical transmission of parvovirus B19 cannot occur in multiple pregnancies since infection during one pregnancy confers maternal immunity against subsequent infection. The anemia in this newborn and the hydrops fetalis of the stillborn sibling have a different underlying cause.

Classic galactosemia can manifest with jaundice, lethargy, hypotonia, and hemolytic anemia in a newborn. However, patients only become symptomatic after being fed several times with breast milk and/or routine formula. Moreover, the initial presentation typically includes vomiting and hepatomegaly. Finally, although classic galactosemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that can affect multiple children of asymptomatic parents, it does not cause stillbirth.

question_text: A 3-week-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She has been well, but her mother is concerned about a rash that appeared on her cheeks 6 days ago. She has not had any other symptoms. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery and is exclusively breastfed. There is no family history of serious illness. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 75^th percentile for length and weight and at the 60^th percentile for head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's rash is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding this newborn's rash?
content_preview: A 3-week-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She has been well, but her mother is concerned about a rash that appeared on her cheeks 6 days ago. She has not had any other symptoms. She was born at term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery and is exclusively breastfed. There is no family history of serious illness. Immunizations are up-to-date. She is at the 75th percentile for length and weight and at the 60th percentile for head circumference. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's rash is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding this newborn's rash?
hint: This patient has neonatal cephalic pustulosis, which most commonly manifests in the first few weeks of life on the face and/or scalp with an erythematous, papulopustular rash without comedones.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal cephalic pustulosis, and choose the most appropriate recommendation regarding care.

answers.content: Breathable fabrics and avoidance of heat
answers.explanation_why: Breathable fabrics and avoidance of heat are measures used to avoid and treat miliaria rubra. Although miliaria rubra also manifests with an erythematous, papulopustular rash, it more commonly develops in areas that are prone to sweating and occlusion (e.g., intertriginous skin folds of the neck, axilla, and groin). Breathable fabrics and avoidance of heat are unlikely to improve neonatal cephalic pustulosis.

images.title: Miliaria rubra
images.description: Multiple, partially confluent papules on erythematous skin are visible.

answers.explanation_why: Topical mupirocin is used to treat impetigo, which can manifest with erythematous papules and pustules. However, these lesions typically rupture and leave shallow erosions covered in honey-colored crust. Moreover, children between the ages of 2 and 4 are most commonly affected. Topical mupirocin is not used to treat neonatal cephalic pustulosis.

images.title: Nonbullous impetigo
images.description: Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

answers.explanation_why: Topical tacrolimus is used to treat atopic dermatitis, often in conjunction with topical corticosteroids. Atopic dermatitis can manifest in infancy with an erythematous rash on the face but more commonly results in scaly, eczematous plaques without pustules. In addition, these lesions are often intensely pruritic and cause discomfort and irritability. Topical tacrolimus is not used to treat neonatal cephalic pustulosis.

images.title: Atopic dermatitis
images.description: Erythematous and scaly papules coalescing into plaques can be seen on the face of this infant.

answers.explanation_why: Oral isotretinoin can be used to treat severe infantile acne. Although this condition usually manifests with erythematous papules and pustules, the presentation is usually much more severe than that of neonatal cephalic pustulosis and also includes comedones (and sometimes nodules). Moreover, infantile acne most commonly manifests around 3 months of age. Oral isotretinoin is not used to treat neonatal cephalic pustulosis.

answers.content: Daily cleansing with water and soap
answers.explanation_why: Neonatal cephalic pustulosis is a benign, self-limited condition that typically resolves within a few months and does not leave scars. Management includes daily cleansing with water and soap and avoidance of oils and lotions, which can occlude the skin and exacerbate this condition. More severe cases can be treated with topical antifungals (e.g., ketoconazole cream) and mild topical corticosteroids (e.g., hydrocortisone cream).

images.title: Neonatal cephalic pustulosis
images.description: Papulopustular lesions are distributed across the left cheek, temple, retroauricular area, and parts of the scalp and forehead.The absence of comedones differentiates this condition from one of infantile acne.

question_text: A 2-hour-old female newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. She was born at 40 weeks' gestation to a 38-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. Apgar scores were 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She is 51 cm (20 in) in length and weighs 3445 g (7 lb 10 oz). Vital signs are within normal limits. Skin color is rosy, the auricular cartilage is well-formed, and the newborn's eyes are open. Examination of the skin shows a 2-cm, darkly pigmented, well-circumscribed macule with irregular margins and mild hypertrichosis on the child's abdomen. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely clinical course of this patient's skin finding?
content_preview: A 2-hour-old female newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. She was born at 40 weeks' gestation to a 38-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. Apgar scores were 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. She is 51 cm (20 in) in length and weighs 3445 g (7 lb 10 oz). Vital signs are within normal limits. Skin color is rosy, the auricular cartilage is well-formed, and the newborn's eyes are open. Examination of the skin shows a 2-cm, darkly pigmented, well-circumscribed macule with irregular margins and mild hypertrichosis on the child's abdomen. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely clinical course of this patient's skin finding?
hint: A hyperpigmented, well-circumscribed macule with irregular margins and hair growth that is present at birth is consistent with congenital melanocytic nevus (CMN).
learning_objective: Recall the clinical course of congenital melanocytic nevus.

answers.explanation_why: Progression to malignant melanoma is a potential complication of CMN. Approximately 2–5% of individuals with a large or giant CMN develop malignant melanoma over their lifetime. The risk of malignant melanoma arising from a small or medium-sized CMN is exceedingly rare (< 1%). This patient has a medium-sized CMN, for which a different clinical course is much more likely.

Progression to a nodular lesion is a potential clinical course of CMN. The nodular lesions are benign and most often develop within a large or giant CMN. This patient has a medium-sized CMN, for which a different clinical course is much more likely.

answers.content: Rapid growth followed by spontaneous resolution by the age of 5 years
answers.explanation_why: Rapid growth followed by spontaneous resolution by the age of 5 years is typical for infantile hemangioma, a skin condition characterized by a rapid proliferation of endothelial cells. While infantile hemangioma may appear as a solitary lesion at birth, it manifests as a red, painless papule or macule that is commonly located on the head or neck.

images.title: Infantile superficial hemangioma
images.description: The scalp has a solitary, ovoid, bright red nodule with irregular texture.This finding is suggestive of superficial hemangioma.

answers.content: Slowly fading discoloration that resolves by adolescence
answers.explanation_why: Slowly fading discoloration of macules that resolve by the age of 10 is a typical course of congenital dermal melanocytosis. This skin condition manifests as a blue-gray macule with indistinct borders. Moreover, the macule is most commonly located on the back, buttocks, flanks, or shoulders, not the abdomen.

images.title: Congenital dermal melanocytosis (Mongolian spot)
images.description: An approx. 5 cm, blue-gray macule with irregular borders is visible on the back. The macule has no evidence of hypertrichosis.

answers.content: Enlargement proportional to the child's growth
answers.explanation_why: CMN is a congenital skin lesion caused by the proliferation of melanocytes. This skin lesion grows in proportion to the child's growth, with the fastest growth occurring in the first few months of infancy. CMN typically manifests as a light to darkly pigmented, smooth, well-circumscribed macule or patch that gradually becomes elevated with a rough surface and irregular pigmentation as the patient gets older. Hair growth on the lesion may be present at birth or develop later as the nevus grows. Because CMN, especially large nevi, are at risk of progressing to malignancy, all patients should be monitored regularly. Surgical excision or laser ablation (depending on the type and size of the lesion) may be performed, particularly for large or giant lesions.

images.title: Congenital nevus in the intergluteal region
images.description: Large congenital nevus: Additional malignancy criteria are the diverse coloration and the slightly irregular margin of the nevus.

question_text: A 2-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician by her parents because she has not urinated since delivery. She was born at home at 39 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother reports having occasional headaches during pregnancy. The parents had refused prenatal care. The patient is 43.2 cm (17 in) in length and weighs 2180 g (4 lb 13 oz). Her blood pressure is 44/26 mmHg. Examination shows a large and soft anterior fontanel. The parietal bones are palpable only over the lateral surface of the cranium. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows bilateral renal hypoplasia. Which of the following medications did the mother most likely take during pregnancy?
content_preview: A 2-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician by her parents because she has not urinated since delivery. She was born at home at 39 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother reports having occasional headaches during pregnancy. The parents had refused prenatal care. The patient is 43.2 cm (17 in) in length and weighs 2180 g (4 lb 13 oz). Her blood pressure is 44/26 mmHg. Examination shows a large and soft anterior fontanel. The parietal bones are palpable only over the lateral surface of the cranium. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows bilateral renal hypoplasia. Which of the following medications did the mother most likely take during pregnancy?
hint: The large fontanel and incompletely formed skull bones suggest hypocalvaria.
learning_objective: Recognize fetal renal hypoplasia due to in utero exposure, and recall the teratogenic effects of ACE inhibitors.

answers.explanation_why: Although the use of tetracyclines during pregnancy is associated with the inhibition of bone growth, malformation, and discoloration of the primary teeth, it does not cause fetal renal malformations.

Carbamazepine intake during pregnancy can cause maternal folate deficiency, which is associated with intrauterine growth restriction, microcephaly, fingernail hypoplasia, and neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida). Carbamazepine use does not cause fetal renal malformations or hypocalvaria.

NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) can be used during the first trimester of pregnancy but should be avoided during the second and third trimesters, especially after 30 weeks' gestation. Intake of NSAIDs during this period is associated with premature closure of the ductus arteriosus, persistent pulmonary hypertension, and inhibition of uterine contractility. Ibuprofen intake does not cause fetal renal malformations or hypocalvaria.

Isotretinoin intake during pregnancy is associated with congenital malformations, such as cardiac abnormalities and facial cleft. Although isotretinoin use can cause craniofacial dysmorphism, hypocalvaria and renal hypoplasia are not expected.

Warfarin intake during pregnancy is associated with intrauterine growth restriction, bone deformities (e.g., nasal hypoplasia), ophthalmic abnormalities, and cerebral hemorrhage. Warfarin use does not cause renal hypoplasia or hypocalvaria.

In utero exposure to ACE inhibitors (e.g., captopril) or angiotensin receptor blockers can cause fetal renal hypoplasia. Other harmful side effects of ACE inhibitors, when taken after the first trimester, include oligohydramnios and its complications (e.g., intrauterine growth restriction, Potter sequence), poor cranial ossification (e.g., hypocalvaria), and fetal death. ACE inhibitors are also associated with cardiovascular and CNS malformations when taken during the first trimester. Therefore, ACE inhibitors should be avoided during pregnancy. Pregnant patients with new or existing hypertension should be treated with an antihypertensive that is safe for use during pregnancy (e.g. methyldopa). Renal hypoplasia, oligohydramnios, and IUGR can already be detected during prenatal ultrasonography.

A healthy newborn must pass urine within 24 hours of birth. Other causes of fetal renal hypoplasia include environmental factors (e.g., maternal nutritional deficiencies, maternal diabetes).

question_text: A 7-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents 30 minutes after she stopped breathing and “turned blue” during her nap. Her father mentions that she felt “floppy” when he tried to wake her. Thirty seconds later, the patient spontaneously started crying, and her skin color returned to normal. She was born at 35 weeks following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. She was exclusively breastfed and has recently been introduced to solid foods. She has no history of similar episodes and is otherwise healthy. Vaccinations are up-to-date. She is at the 50^th percentile for length and weight and at the 75^th percentile for head circumference. Development is appropriate for age. She is alert and appears well. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 38/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
content_preview: A 7-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents 30 minutes after she stopped breathing and “turned blue” during her nap. Her father mentions that she felt “floppy” when he tried to wake her. Thirty seconds later, the patient spontaneously started crying, and her skin color returned to normal. She was born at 35 weeks following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. She was exclusively breastfed and has recently been introduced to solid foods. She has no history of similar episodes and is otherwise healthy. Vaccinations are up-to-date. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight and at the 75th percentile for head circumference. Development is appropriate for age. She is alert and appears well. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 38/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
hint: A sudden, brief (< 1 minute), and resolved episode involving cyanosis and hypotonia without apparent cause in a child < 1 year is consistent with a brief resolved unexplained event (BRUE)
learning_objective: Recognize a low-risk brief resolved unexplained event (BRUE), and choose the most appropriate next step in evaluation.

answers.explanation_why: Pulse oximetry measures oxygen saturation and should be used to evaluate hypoxemia in infants with cyanosis. Although brief monitoring (i.e., 1–4 hours) with pulse oximetry is optional for low-risk BRUE, inpatient monitoring for 24 hours is not recommended.

Nocturnal polysomnography is used to diagnose obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea, and other forms of sleep-disordered breathing. Although this infant presents with an apneic episode, her symptoms fulfill the diagnostic criteria for low-risk BRUE, for which nocturnal polysomnography is not recommended.

A BRUE is considered low risk when all of the following criteria are met: age > 60 days, gestational age at birth ≥ 32 weeks or corrected gestational age ≥ 45 weeks, the event lasts < 1 minute, first BRUE, CPR by a trained medical provider was not required, no concerning signs on physical examination (e.g., bruising, choking, coughing), and no concerning history (e.g., apneas, feeding problems). No further evaluation is warranted for patients with a low-risk BRUE. Caregivers should be provided with reassurance, education, and CPR training. BRUE is a diagnosis of exclusion; an underlying condition is the actual cause of the episode in about half of infants who present with features of BRUE. Patients who do not meet all of the criteria for low-risk BRUE are considered high risk and should be evaluated for underlying causes. When no cause can be established, prolonged hospital admission for monitoring may be required.

Echocardiography is used to evaluate for congenital heart disease, which is a potential cause of cyanosis in patients with a right-to-left shunt. This patient's cardiovascular examination is normal, and echocardiography is not recommended for the workup of low-risk BRUE. Electrocardiogram is optional to screen for channelopathies (e.g., long QT syndrome) in individuals with BRUE.

Blood gas analysis is performed in infants to screen for inborn errors of metabolism, which can manifest with lethargy. Inborn errors of metabolism typically appear with additional signs, such as vomiting and developmental delays, which are not found here. Blood gas analysis is not required for low-risk BRUE.

question_text: A 2-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old mother, gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The patient's Apgar scores were 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively. Family history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and open-angle glaucoma in his father. He appears well. He is at the 80^th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 150/min, and respirations are 44/min. Genitourinary examination shows abnormal foreskin and two meatal openings. Examination of the eyes shows partial absence of the iris. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
content_preview: A 2-hour-old male newborn is examined in the hospital nursery. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation to a 27-year-old mother, gravida 1, para 1, after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. The patient's Apgar scores were 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively. Family history is remarkable for type 2 diabetes mellitus and open-angle glaucoma in his father. He appears well. He is at the 80th percentile for length, weight, and head circumference. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 150/min, and respirations are 44/min. Genitourinary examination shows abnormal foreskin and two meatal openings. Examination of the eyes shows partial absence of the iris. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
hint: This patient's aniridia and genitourinary anomaly (hypospadias) suggest WAGR syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize WAGR syndrome, and choose the appropriate screening method for associated malignancies.

answers.explanation_why: MRI of the brain may be used to screen for neuroblastoma, which occurs in several genetic syndromes (e.g., Turner syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, neurofibromatosis, Hirschsprung disease). This patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk for another condition.

Nephroblastoma (Wilms tumor) is associated with WAGR syndrome. Approximately 50% of children with WAGR syndrome develop nephroblastoma; therefore, screening ultrasound should be obtained quarterly until at least five years of age. Treatment typically consists of surgical resection and chemotherapy; radiation therapy is possible in advanced stages. Nephroblastoma has a good prognosis with survival rates > 90%.

Measurement of metanephrines (via serum or 24-hour urine collection) is used to screen for pheochromocytoma in patients with von Hippel-Lindau syndrome. Screening for pheochromocytoma is not recommended until 11 years of age, and this patient is a newborn. Moreover, this patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk of a different condition.

Urinalysis is used in the workup of Denys-Drash syndrome, which manifests with genitourinary abnormalities (e.g., undescended testis), early-onset nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria, and nephroblastoma. This patient's presentation is consistent with WAGR syndrome, for which screening urinalysis is not recommended.

Alpha-fetoprotein measurements can be used to screen for hepatoblastoma, which is associated with several genetic syndromes (e.g., Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome, Trisomy 18, Trisomy 21), and yolk sac tumors. This patient has WAGR syndrome, which increases the risk of another condition.

hint: Increased TSH levels in a newborn indicate congenital hypothyroidism.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital hypothyroidism, and choose the most appropriate management for a newborn.

answers.explanation_why: In newborns of mothers with a history of thyroid disorders (most commonly Graves disease), transplacental transmission of maternal TSH-receptor antibodies (TRAbs) can block the TSH receptor, resulting in transient hypothyroidism. This patient's mother has no history of thyroid disease. Additionally, maternal TRAbs usually have a stimulating effect on receptors, resulting in neonatal autoimmune hyperthyroidism. A different next step in management is more appropriate for preventing complications of congenital hypothyroidism.

answers.content: Repeat thyroid function testing in 2 weeks
answers.explanation_why: Thyroid function monitoring is recommended in patients with congenital hypothyroidism, but a different step in management is more appropriate for preventing complications of congenital hypothyroidism.

Thyroid imaging may be indicated in patients with congenital hypothyroidism if structural abnormalities are suspected (e.g., hypoplasia, aplasia). However, thyroid imaging results usually do not change the management of congenital hypothyroidism. A different next step in management is more appropriate for preventing complications of congenital hypothyroidism.

Thyroid hormone replacement therapy is indicated for all patients with congenital hypothyroidism to prevent brain damage and developmental disorders. Most children with congenital hypothyroidism do not have symptoms at the time of birth because the placenta supplies the fetus with maternal thyroid hormone; therefore, neonatal screening is vital even if children are asymptomatic. Neonatal screening is required by law 24–48 hours after birth.

Recommended therapeutic goals are to normalize T4 levels within 2 weeks of birth and TSH levels within 4 weeks. Patients require lifetime thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

Thyroid imaging may be indicated in patients with congenital hypothyroidism if structural abnormalities are suspected (e.g., hypoplasia, aplasia). However, thyroid imaging results usually do not change the management of congenital hypothyroidism. Furthermore, nuclear thyroid scan exposes the newborn to radiation. A different next step in management is more appropriate for preventing complications of congenital hypothyroidism.

hint: This newborn's condition is most likely due to decreased activity of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase.
learning_objective: Recognize physiological neonatal jaundice.

answers.explanation_why: Biliary atresia leads to neonatal jaundice by blocking the excretion of bile into the intestines and causing direct bilirubin to be returned to circulation. This condition manifests with direct hyperbilirubinemia rather than the indirect hyperbilirubinemia seen in this newborn.

Breastfeeding jaundice is caused by insufficient breast milk intake and manifests with indirect hyperbilirubinemia in the first week of life. However, newborns with breastfeeding jaundice usually also have a history of oliguria (e.g., few wet diapers) and weight loss. This newborn has already surpassed her birth weight and the mother reports breastfeeding her frequently without difficulty, making insufficient breastfeeding an unlikely cause of her jaundice. In this newborn, breast milk jaundice rather than breastfeeding jaundice is likely a contributing factor.

Although patients with Dubin-Johnson syndrome can develop hyperbilirubinemia and jaundice, the onset of symptoms usually occurs during adolescence. In addition, laboratory studies in patients with Dubin-Johnson syndrome show direct hyperbilirubinemia caused by defective excretion of conjugated bilirubin, not the indirect hyperbilirubinemia seen in this newborn.

Physiological neonatal jaundice is a common condition that manifests between the second and the eighth day of life with jaundice and mild indirect hyperbilirubinemia in an otherwise healthy newborn. This condition is caused by several components of bilirubin metabolism in newborns, including immaturity of the pathways for hepatic conjugation and elimination (due to decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase), the short life span of erythrocytes in newborns, and increased enterohepatic circulation of bilirubin (due to low bacteria in the gastrointestinal tract and certain breast milk components). Exclusively breastfed newborns are more likely to develop physiological neonatal jaundice. Treatment of neonatal jaundice by phototherapy is indicated if bilirubin levels increase above a defined threshold.

Rhesus incompatibility leading to immune-mediated hemolysis (also known as hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn; HDFN) most often causes severe indirect hyperbilirubinemia that appears within the first 24 hours of life. Although this newborn's incompatibility with her mother's Rhesus type puts her at risk for HDFN, her normal hemoglobin and low reticulocyte count make hemolysis unlikely.

Congenital hypothyroidism is associated with decreased bilirubin clearance, which can lead to indirect hyperbilirubinemia and neonatal jaundice. However, the typical manifestations of congenital hypothyroidism such as poor feeding, decreased activity, hypotonia, failure to thrive, abdominal distention, large fontanelles, dry skin, and hypothermia are absent in this newborn.

answers.content: ABO hemolytic disease of the newborn
answers.explanation_why: ABO hemolytic disease of the newborn due to ABO incompatibility leads to immune-mediated hemolysis. This disease typically results in mild indirect hyperbilirubinemia and neonatal jaundice. ABO hemolytic disease of the newborn usually becomes evident, however, within the first 24 hours of life and almost exclusively occurs in newborns with blood type A or B whose mother's blood type is O. Since this newborn's blood type is O, her erythrocytes do not express AB antigens that could be bound by maternal antibodies. In addition, her normal hemoglobin and low reticulocyte count make hemolysis unlikely.

hint: Infants born with this pregnancy-related complication have a high risk of developing periventricular leukomalacia.
learning_objective: Recall risk factors for preterm delivery.

answers.explanation_why: Risk factors for postpartum endometritis emerge shortly before and during birth and include multiple vaginal examinations, cesarean delivery, prolonged labor, and meconium in the amniotic fluid. Although low socioeconomic status is a risk factor for postpartum endometritis, its impact becomes more significant as birth approaches.

Antepartum hemorrhage has various causes, the most common being placental abruption, placenta previa, trauma, and stillbirth. Common risk factors for these conditions include gestational hypertension, multiparity, smoking, substance use, maternal age > 35 years, and a previous history of these conditions, none of which are seen here.

This individual's age (< 18 years), low prepregnancy weight, shortened cervix, and race/ethnicity (Black individual of non-Hispanic origin) are risk factors for preterm labor and delivery. Other important risk factors include maternal age above 35 years, infections (e.g., urinary tract infections, sexually transmitted infections, or vaginal infections), multiparity, smoking, substance use, and a history of preterm labor or preterm birth, which is the strongest risk factor.

For individuals with a short cervix (< 25 mm) on transvaginal ultrasound at less than 24 weeks' gestation and no history of preterm birth, intravaginal progesterone supplementation is generally recommended in addition to regular prenatal monitoring to reduce the risk of preterm birth. Strict bed rest is not recommended.

Maternal risk factors for intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) include systemic conditions resulting in uteroplacental insufficiency (e.g., gestational hypertension, diabetes mellitus with vasculopathy), maternal phenylketonuria, and substance use (e.g., cocaine, tobacco), none of which are seen here. Low prepregnancy weight is a risk factor for a constitutionally small fetus, not for IUGR.

answers.content: No increased risk of pregnancy-related complications
answers.explanation_why: This patient is under 18 years of age, has a low prepregnancy weight, a cervical length < 25 mm before 24 weeks' gestation, and race/ethnicity is Black of non-Hispanic origin, all of which are risk factors for a certain pregnancy-related complication.

Risk factors for obstructed labor include fetal macrosomia, fetal malpresentation or malposition at the time of labor, uterine abnormalities, and placenta previa. This patient has no risk factors for fetal macrosomia (e.g., diabetes mellitus, obesity, excessive weight gain during pregnancy, advanced maternal age). Furthermore, the fetus size, amniotic fluid index, and placental position are all normal.

question_text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 6-month history of progressive difficulty walking and speaking. Her parents also report that she has recently started having trouble feeding herself and appears to be losing interest in playing. She was born at full term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery, and her early development was within normal limits. Family history is notable for a paternal aunt who had a progressive neurological disorder and died in her early 20s. On examination, the girl is listless and has difficulty following commands. She has poor head control and generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished in all four extremities. Funduscopic examination reveals bilateral optic atrophy. Nerve conduction studies show symmetrically decreased conduction velocities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents because of a 6-month history of progressive difficulty walking and speaking. Her parents also report that she has recently started having trouble feeding herself and appears to be losing interest in playing. She was born at full term following an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery, and her early development was within normal limits. Family history is notable for a paternal aunt who had a progressive neurological disorder and died in her early 20s. On examination, the girl is listless and has difficulty following commands. She has poor head control and generalized hypotonia. Deep tendon reflexes are diminished in all four extremities. Funduscopic examination reveals bilateral optic atrophy. Nerve conduction studies show symmetrically decreased conduction velocities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Deficient enzyme activity in leukocytes helps establish the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features and diagnosis of metachromatic leukodystrophy.

answers.explanation_why: Tay-Sachs disease (TSD) is caused by hexosaminidase A deficiency, leading to GM2 ganglioside accumulation and progressive neurodegeneration. Symptoms typically appear at 3–6 months of age and include developmental delay, hypotonia, and characteristic ophthalmological findings. In TSD, however, the hallmark ocular feature is a cherry-red spot on the macula, not optic nerve atrophy, and patients have hyperreflexia rather than hyporeflexia. Peripheral neuropathy and decreased nerve conduction velocity are not features of TSD. Additionally, this patient does not have other expected manifestations of TSD, such as hyperacusis and seizures.

Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder caused by arylsulfatase A (ARSA) deficiency, resulting in the accumulation of sulfatides that are toxic to oligodendrocytes and Schwann cells. This leads to progressive demyelination in both the central and peripheral nervous systems. Childhood onset is characterized by psychomotor regression, impaired memory, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, ataxia, and optic nerve atrophy that can lead to vision loss. Nerve conduction studies reveal decreased velocities due to demyelination. Metachromatic leukodystrophy is diagnosed by finding deficient ARSA enzyme activity in peripheral blood leukocytes or dried blood spots, and/or by identifying pathogenic mutations in the ARSA gene. A positive family history of progressive neurological decline supports the diagnosis of genetic leukodystrophy.

Krabbe disease is caused by galactocerebrosidase deficiency, which leads to progressive demyelination. In childhood, this condition typically manifests with significant mental and motor deficits, including developmental delay, peripheral neuropathy, and optic nerve atrophy that can lead to vision loss. However, Krabbe disease commonly manifests within the first year of life, and affected infants initially have limb stiffness rather than hypotonia.

Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the MECP2 gene. This condition almost exclusively affects girls and manifests with neurodevelopmental regression, including loss of motor skills, intellectual and verbal disability, and ataxia. Peripheral neuropathy, decreased nerve conduction velocity, hypotonia, and optic atrophy are not features of Rett syndrome. Additionally, this patient does not present with typical symptoms of the condition, such as scoliosis, hyperventilation, microcephaly, and characteristic hand wringing.

Niemann-Pick disease (NPD) is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by sphingomyelinase deficiency that leads to sphingomyelin accumulation and progressive neurodegeneration. NPD typically manifests with psychomotor regression, hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and characteristic ophthalmological findings. However, the hallmark ocular finding in NPD is a cherry-red spot on the macula, not optic nerve atrophy. Peripheral neuropathy and decreased nerve conduction velocity are not features of NPD. In addition, this patient does not have common systemic findings of NPD, such as hepatosplenomegaly.
